HEADLINE: New York's Jobless Rate Falls

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
''And those who didn't get jobs left the labor market.''
Mr. Ehrenhalt also discounted an increase of 16,000 in the number of people employed in New York City in August, saying the gain was too small to be significant, given the limited size of the survey sample. The employment figures are based on a survey of 2,200 households in the city.
''I don't see any signs of particular strength, looking through the array of labor market indicators for the city,'' he added.
But in a statement released at City Hall, Mayor David N. Dinkins expressed optimism about the drop in the unemployment rate, saying that it suggested ''that the decline in our economy that began nearly three years ago may be nearing bottom.''
Informed of Mr. Ehrenhalt's comments, a spokesman for the Mayor, Leland T. Jones, said the city still regarded the drop as ''cause for optimism,'' especially when compared to the rise in the national unemployment rate.
''It appears as though we did not have quite as troubled a month as the rest of the economy did,'' he said.
The New York State unemployment rate also dropped, to 5.0 percent in August from 5.3 percent in July. A year ago, it was 5.1 percent.
Unemployment in New Jersey was 4.8 percent in August, the same rate as in the three prior months. It was 4.4 percent a year ago.

HEADLINE: Split on How to Save Spotted Owl Is Reported in Bush's Study Group

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Sept. 7

 BODY:

 
No Announcement of Consensus
The Federal study group was to have delivered its recommendation by Sept. 1, but Federal officials said today that the panel had not reached a consensus and that nothing was expected until next week at the earliest.
Jim Mosely, the Agriculture Department's assistant secretary for natural resources and the environment, today called reports that a decision had been reached ''inaccurate and misleading.'' He said the study group, which includes the Secretaries of Agriculture and Interior, and the heads of the Office of Management and Budget, the Environmental Protection Agency and the Council of Economic Advisors, have yet to reach an agreement. 
White House officials and congressional aides say the panel is torn between two positions.
One side, led by the Interior Secretary, Manuel Lujan Jr., wants to continue the Government's logging program at a relatively high level; if that causes legal problems by further threatening the owl, then changes to the Endangered Species Act should be considered. Mr. Lujan offered an indication of his thinking during a tour of Oregon two weeks ago when he was quoted as saying ''environmentalists are not going to like'' the panel's proposal.
The other side, dominated by people from the Forest Service, which is a branch of the Agriculture Department, favors adopting most of the recommendations of a Government scientific panel, which said the owl could only be saved by reducing the volume of logging by 50 percent or more.
No matter what the task force ultimately recommends, Congress is moving ahead on its own plan to reduce logging in the Northwest. In August, the House subcommittee that oversees the Forest Service voted on a plan to reduce the Northwest timber harvest by about 25 percent for next year, a proposal that would protect major forest areas where the owls live and follow the main guidelines of the Government scientific panel.
To allow more cutting than the House has proposed - as Senator Slade Gorton, a Republican of Washington, has advocated - could bring on more of the kind of lawsuits that have held up the timber sale program on Forest Service lands for the last three years, say some members of Congress.
In the late 1980's, nearly 5 billion board feet of timber was cut annually from Federal lands in the Northwest.
While environmentalists want to see the cut reduced by 50 percent, Congress is moving toward a level of 3.1 billion.
A White House official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the task force would likely reach a consensus on a recommendation to cut between 3 billion and 3.5 billion board feet.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr., who has said he wants to continue the Government's logging program and change the Endangered Species Act if the northern spotted owl is still threatened. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Deputy Defies Dukakis on Budget Plan

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Sept. 7

 BODY:
But Edward L. Lashman, the Secretary of Administration and Finance, struck a conciliatory note, calling Ms. Murphy's plan ''a very serious effort,'' even if it fell short of making the necessary budget reductions.
 
Intrigue at the Top
Ms. Murphy's plan, announced in a packed news conference at the gold-domed Statehouse, was the latest twist in a palace intrigue that began earlier this week when Mr. Dukakis learned she intended to take advantage of his absence while he was on a trade mission to Europe to issue what his aides termed a ''secret plan'' to revise the state's finances. Under Massachusetts law, the Lieutenant Governor assumes the Governor's powers when the chief executive is out of the state.
Mr. Dukakis, the Democratic Presidential nominee who was defeated by George Bush two years ago, had postponed his departure and derided her actions as a pathetic effort to achieve ''personal political gain.'' 
Ms. Murphy is a candidate for the Democratic nomination for governor, and polls show her trailing badly in the three-way race. The primary will be held on Sept. 18.
The Governor, who is not seeking re-election, finally left for Berlin on Thursday evening, although he warned that he would cut short his trip if she acted ''irresponsibly.''
With Mr. Dukakis gone Ms. Murphy proclaimed today, ''I won't be a do-nothing Lieutenant Governor.'' But she insisted at the news conference that her plan was ''nothing radical, nothing irresponsible.'' She did not move to dismiss any Dukakis cabinet member, as some of the Governor's aides had predicted.
 
Some Cuts and Changes
Instead, Ms. Murphy, who holds a doctorate in economics, announced a package of budget cuts and accounting changes. Among these were orders that 1,000 of the state's 4,000 department managers be laid off, that the state's 64,000 employees be reduced by 10 percent, that funds for all overtime pay be frozen and that the salaries of all officials earning more than $40,000 a year be temporarly cut. That would include her and Governor Dukakis.
Ms. Murphy estimated that her proposals would save the state $150 million this year. Coincidentally or not, that is about the same amount as the cuts Mr. Dukakis ordered on Tuesday, when he learned that tax revenue in August had again fallen short of projections despite the passage in July of the biggest tax increase in the state's history.
Massachusetts has been running a deficit since the Presidential campaign year of 1988, when the state's economy began to slow and revenue plummeted. Although Mr. Dukakakis has raised taxes and cut nearly $1 billion from the $13 billion budget over the last two years, the deficit has continued as the economy has continued to slow.
At the news conference Ms. Murphy said, ''This is a different way to achieve the same thing'' as the Governor's plan. But she added that her plan was superior because Mr. Dukakis had ordered across-the-board cuts that would have a severe impact on services like health care and education.
''We must not make across-the-board cuts that treat schoolchildren and political appointees as equals simply because we refuse to set priorities,'' she said.
 
Amount of Savings Disputed
But she was immediately disputed by Mr. Lashman, the state finance official, who said her proposals would only save about $15 million, not $150 million.
Philip Johnston, the Secretary of Human Services, said he did not intend to put Ms. Murphy's plan into effect, noting that it would force him to make deep cuts in programs for the mentally ill, the blind and abused children.
Steven Crawford, Mr. Dukakis's press secretary, said that the Governor had already cut the number of state employees by 8,500 since 1988 and that the current total of 64,000 employees was down to the 1983 level. Finding further cuts is not simple, he added.
Mr. Crawford also said the Lieutenant Governor's executive order did not involve a time frame, and therefore Mr. Dukakis's officials could easily stall until his return next week.
Ms. Murphy said another important change was her plan to make each department of the state government open its books, publish a montly report of its spending and balance its books each month.
She denied that her action was a ploy to get coverage in the press to help her in the Democratic contest for governor, where she is opposed by Francis X. Bellotti, a former State Attorney General, and John R. Silber, the president of Boston University.
Ms. Murphy insisted that her reason for acting after Mr. Dukakis left was simply that she was concerned by the state's continued fiscal troubles, especially after she learned that tax revenue had fallen again last month.
Mr. Bellotti said today that her actions were ''sad'' and the uproar she caused had further hurt the Democratic Party here, which has already been heavily criticized by the public for the fiscal crisis.
Mr. Silber discounted Ms. Murphy's budget plan as ''stupid,'' and said, ''She's not doing anything but having a little coffeehouse coup d'etat.''

HEADLINE: Budget Negotiators Go Into Seclusion

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7

 BODY:
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, who is heading the Democratic delegation at the talks, agreed with Mr. Bush that the events of August did not make a budget compromise less necessary.
''If we needed a budget agreement five weeks ago,'' he said at a news conference today, ''we need one more today in terms of the ability of our economy to grow, to avoid a recession and in order to support economic progress. And now with the military challenge we have in the Middle East, I think it's even more important.''
 
Plans for $50 Billion Cut
At the outset today, both sides maintained that they had plans to cut the deficit by at least $50 billion in the 1991 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1, and by $500 billion cumulatively over the next five years. 
With no changes in spending or taxes, the deficit in the $1.2 trillion Federal budget is expected to be more than $170 billion in the new fiscal year, not counting the savings and loan bailout, and about $250 billion counting the bailout money.
Reporters are not allowed near the officers' club at Andrews where the talks are taking place, and only sketchy information slipped out about what was discussed.
Mr. Bush stayed for only 25 minutes this morning and left the session in the hands of Richard G. Darman, his budget director, and about two dozen lawmakers from both parties.
 
Negotiators Are Far Apart
The two sides' opening offers were said to be sharply at odds.
The Administration's plan would limit the amount of state and local tax payments that taxpayers could deduct on their Federal income tax returns. It would also lower the capital gains tax, raise taxes on alcoholic beverages and cut spending sharply on many domestic programs, including Medicare and pension benefits for retired Federal employees and military personnel.
The Democratic plan includes higher income taxes on the wealthy, a new tax on gasoline and other fuel to encourage oil conservation and large cuts in Pentagon spending.
 
Neither Side Moves
''Big differences remain,'' Mr. Bush said before returning to the capital. ''It's going to take compromise.'' But despite the stated willingness of both sides to try to reach agreement, neither seemed willing to budge.
For example, two Republican negotiators, Senator Gramm and Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, said they would not ''tolerate'' an income tax increase. Central to the Democratic plan is an increase to 35 percent from 28 percent in the tax rate paid by the wealthiest Americans.
Democrats also favor higher taxes to encourage fuel conservation, while Republicans support tax breaks to stimulate domestic oil production.
The Democrats would impose a 2 percent tax on all forms of energy, with the rate rising to 4 percent in 1992, and would also impose a tax on oil that would take effect if the price of crude oil dropped below $20 a barrel. The price closed today at $30.04.
Whatever else they do this weekend, two steps seem inescapable.
First, the annual deficit ceilings set by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law will have to be raised. The limit for the next fiscal year is now $64 billion, and both sides agree that the economy would collapse under tax increases or spending cuts large enough to meet that figure. They also agree that the across-the-board spending reductions that would be required if the original target is missed would be more than the economy could stand.
Second, money for the savings and loan rescue operation will have to be excluded from the budget law's targets. Most negotiators believe this makes sense, since much of the money spent next year will be repaid in subsequent fiscal years when assets of the failed savings institutions are sold.

Darman, budget director; Brent Scowcroft, national security adviser, and John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
India Insists on Gulf Refugee Aid While Supporting Embargo

BYLINE: By SANJOY HAZARIKA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Sept. 7

 BODY:
Mr. Seth accused the West of insensitivity to the desperate condition of scores of thousands of third world refugees trapped in Jordan, Iraq and Kuwait.
''Our people cannot afford to stay in five-star hotels,'' he said. ''We cannot afford to charter flights to get that number of people out.'' 
''Western Governments were quick to impose sanctions but not quick enough to deal with the consequences,'' he said, referring to the exodus from Iraq and Kuwait and the unsanitiary conditions and lack of food and water at the refugee camps in Jordan and elsewhere.
 
Air-and-Sea Evacuation Plan
Mr. Seth also said that India wanted to send several ships to Dubai and if possible to Kuwait to evacuate more than 100,000 Indians still trapped in the region. One plan is to fly refugees who have reached Jordan to Dubai, and then take them home by ship. India also hopes to augment refugee flights from Amman to New Delhi with direct flights to Baghdad, Indian television reported tonight.
Indian officials have suggested in the last few days that the Iraqi Government is saying that any Indian vessels would be allowed to go to Kuwait only if they take food and medicine.
Mr. Seth would not confirm that that was the situation but hinted that it was. He said ships enforcing the embargo against Iraq might also block Indian ships.
India cites Article 661 of the United Nations Charter, which allows humanitarian assistance to people suffering the effects of a blockade. It has instructed its representatives at the United Nations to lobby for such aid to be made available to people of all nationalities in Iraq and Kuwait.
Mr. Seth said that food and medicines should be distributed under the supervision of the International Red Cross and the Red Crescent Society of Iraq.
 
Economy Also Suffers
Mr. Seth said that India was getting support from other underdeveloped nations on another issue, the harsh economic jolt that their economies are suffering as a result of the sanctions.
''For every dollar increase in the price of oil, our foreign exchange outgo is 222 million dollars,'' he said.
He said that India and other third world countries were pressing the United Nations Security Council to consider ways to ease the burden of the blockade on poor nations. ''The Philippines, Bangladesh, Pakistan - all of us are in the same boat,'' he said.
About 170,000 Indians were in Kuwait and another 9,000 in Iraq when Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. An Indian airlift has brought about 20,000 people back while another 30,000 have fled Kuwait and are in Iraq, Jordan, Turkey and Saudi Arabia.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 6, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1169 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Opponents to U.S. Move Have Poverty in Common

BYLINE: By ANDREW H. MALCOLM

 BODY:
As they have historically in similar foreign crises, virtually every poll shows overwhelming initial support for the Administration's movement of troops into Saudi Arabia. The New York Times/CBS News Poll of 1,422 Americans conducted by telephone Aug. 16 to 19 found that 77 percent supported the action.
But who are those who oppose the policy? According to political scientists and polling experts, opposition in this crisis closely follows classic public opinion patterns in conflicts in Korea, Vietnam and even the unsuccessful invasion of Cuba at the Bay of Pigs.
 
'It's a Class Thing'
''Quite simply, it's a class thing,'' said George C. Edwards, professor of political science at Texas A&M University and author of ''The Public Presidency: The Pursuit of Popular Support'' (St. Martin's Press). ''And what determines your economic class is your education.'' 
Of those in the Times/CBS News Poll who did not graduate from high school, 22 percent opposed the troop deployment; 12 percent of college graduates opposed it. Of those earning less than $15,000, 27 percent were opposed; of those earning more than $50,000, 8 percent were opposed. The trends reflected in the Times/CBS News Poll continue to be picked up in polls by other organizations, including a Gallup Poll over the weekend.
To some degree, a division along class lines also means a division along racial lines: 35 percent of blacks in the Times/CBS News Poll oppose the sending of United States troops to Saudi Arabia, as against 15 percent of whites.
Professor Edwards and others did not rule out the lingering influence of social alienation among blacks, who made up a large portion of military draftees and casualties in Vietnam and whose leaders, including the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., blamed that war for draining resources from domestic social programs.
The experts also noted that blacks tend to be Democrats and are thus predisposed to opposing Republican military policy.
Although the polling data indicate that poor, uneducated blacks oppose the military deployment in greater proportion than do poor, uneducated whites, the experts nonetheless said the split was really one along class lines.
 
Following News Was Key
Because blacks are disproportionately represented among the less educated and the less affluent, a larger percentage appears to oppose such military moves.
Samuel Kernell, professor of political science at the University of California, San Diego, said, ''The uneducated, who by and large do not follow current events closely, are simply not responsive to the same positive stimuli as the better-educated and more affluent, who do tend to follow the news.''
He added: ''At the moment, Republican and Democratic leaders, the nation's cue-givers, are in agreement and supportive. And informed citizens have no independent flow of contradictory information.''
John E. Mueller, a political scientist at the University of Rochester and author of ''War, Presidents and Public Opinion'' (Wiley & Sons), said: ''This is a new incident, but an old phenomenon. It's the follower phenomenon. The well-educated support the President at first, whatever he's doing. When President Johnson stopped bombing North Vietnam, his support went up. When he started bombing again, his support went up. The decline tends to come later.''
Professor Kernell said he expected support to dip by Thanksgiving as political leaders began dividing along party lines and individuals accumulated their own evidence. ''Gas prices may hit them hard,'' he said. ''A relative or friend may be killed or wounded. They'll see the costs, but not the benefits. The erosion will set in.''
Those new opponents will swell the existing minority, who do not seem susceptible to persuasion, in part, because they are not listening. The 63-year-old Miss Birdsong, for example, estimates that she watches 10 hours of television a day in her Troy, Ohio, apartment. But like many opponents in the Times/ CBS News Poll in follow-up interviews, she will not watch the news. ''When that Iraq news comes on, I switch, unless it's interrupting a soap opera,'' she said.
The poll, which had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points, found that of those following the news closely, 85 percent supported the deployment of troops to Saudi Arabia, while among those who did not follow the news closely, 59 percent supported it.
Eugene Patrick, a 52-year-old school bus mechanic in Florence, Miss., who has a sixth-grade education and who does not read, said that he voted for Mr. Bush and that he still believed Mr. Bush was a good president. ''That Iraq guy doesn't need to be there,'' said Mr. Patrick. ''But we have no business there either.''
Mr. Patrick, who is black, was unaware of the involvement in the Iraq crisis of prominent blacks, including the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who helped arrange the release of some hostages from Iraq, or Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. But he said he thought there was a racial motive to American military involvement.
''I believe a lot of people are worried the blacks are going to take over, and sending them is some slick way of thinning the blacks out,'' he said.
According to the Department of Defense, as of June 30, the United States military, excluding the Coast Guard, had 421,211 blacks (20.6 percent) among its 2,040,676 troops.
Kenneth Garnsey of Denison, Tex., a 51-year-old unemployed handyman who did not attend high school, sees the Iraqi confrontation as ridiculous for another reason. ''We're going to blow them up,'' said Mr. Garnsey, who is white. ''And then we're going to pay to rebuild them. That's what we always do. We should just bomb Iraq a little bit, like we did with Libya a few years ago. You don't hear any more about them making trouble.''
Sandra Robertson, a Florence, Colo., housewife, agrees with Miss Birdsong's opposition. ''We're always more interested in helping people in other countries when we have poor and homeless here at home,'' she said.
Professor Edwards sees the confrontation's duration as the key factor in any opinion shift this fall. ''The U.S. position may be the right one,'' he said. ''But it's difficult to defend over time. A war for cheap gasoline? The reasons must resonate with the American public. Americans do not have a history of making military sacrifices for economic gain. To fight, it has always been a question of 'morality.' A Soviet attack on Western Europe? Yes. An invasion of Cambodia? No. An invasion of Kuwait? I don't know.''

SECTION: Section 1; Page 4, Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 678 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
EUROPEAN NATIONS PROPOSE GULF AID

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, Sept. 7

 BODY:
Mr. De Michelis, who was chairman of the meeting today because Italy holds the rotating presidency of the community, said the 12 would share the costs of the crisis and, in that way, would relieve the United States.
''The money we give to Egypt, Jordan and Turkey is money that the United States will not have to give,'' he said. [A spokesman for the State Department in Washington had no comment on the community's decision.] 'Ready to Tighten Embargo' 
A decision on the exact size of the community's contribution to the planned aid package was postponed until Sept. 17, pending talks with Saudi Arabia and some gulf states. Community officials said it would probably total around $2 billion for 1990 and 1991.
The Community foreign ministers also stressed the need to close all loopholes in the trade embargo against Iraq, noting that sanctions should be effective in blocking the movement of goods by land and air as well as by sea. ''We are ready to tighten the embargo,'' Mr. De Michelis said.
Although the foreign ministers made no reference to the meeting in Helsinki on Sunday planned by President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, officials said they were eager to show a united community position in anticipation of the meeting.
Further, they accepted a Soviet proposal for a joint Soviet-European Community statement on the gulf crisis to be issued at the United Nations on Sept. 27. A senior British official said it was not clear why Moscow wanted the statement, but he added: ''Why not do it, if Moscow wants it?''
 
Three Communiques Issued
The foreign ministers issued three formal communiques today, one urging the United Nations Secretary-General to send a mission to reach Western diplomats trapped in Kuwait, a second reiterating the community's desire for close ties with the Arab world and the third dealing with the aid package.
They noted that, along with the so-called front-linestates of Egypt, Jordan and Turkey, efforts should be made to help other Middle East nations as well as the countries of Eastern Europe, whose efforts to build market-oriented economies have been complicated by the rise in world oil prices.
The European Commission, which is the community's executive branch, has estimated that Egypt, Jordan and Turkey alone stand to lose $2.8 billion this year and $6.5 billion next year from lost trade and higher oil prices. It has proposed that the community cover 15 percent of that cost, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates 65 percent and Japan and South Korea the remaining 20 percent.
 
Donations but No Control
Community officials said the members were eager to be seen by Washington as taking part in the ''burden sharing'' effort, with Britain and France stressing the considerable costs involved in their own military buildups in the gulf region. Britain, Italy and Portugal have also offered aircraft and ships to transport American troops and equipment.
But it is also apparent that President Bush's call for donations to help pay for the American military presence has caused discomfort in several European capitals, not least because such contributions would not give community governments any control over the use of United States forces.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 4, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 506 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
U.S. Insists Individual Nations Can't Break Blockade of Iraq

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 7

 BODY:
''That is the work of the Sanctions Committee of the Security Council,'' he said.
The committee, made up of all Security Council members, will resume hearing arguments on what constitutes humanitarian aid when it continues the debate adjourned on Thursday.
 
A Conflict of Views
On Thursday, China and Iran indicated that they might ignore the sanctions and send food and medicine to Iraq. Tunisia, Yugoslavia, Romania and India said they wanted to send emergency supplies to their citizens trapped in Kuwait. They said they believed that the shipments would be permitted as humanitarian aid under the United Nations sanctions. 
The American officials noted that Iraq itself has stated that it has many months of food in reserve. They said, too, that in the event a need on humanitarian grounds is determined, the United States would like to see food shipped and distributed through humanitarian agencies, not commercial or government sources. They insisted that it was important to insure that such supplies not become a way to breach the sanctions or divert food.
Here at the United Nations, the Military Staff Committee, which has figured prominently in recent Security Council over the crisis in the Persian Gulf, held its regular semimonthly meeting Thursday. Created by the United Nations Charter, it is charged with advising the Security Council on military matters, including the long-abandoned proposal for a standing United Nations military force. For more than 40 years, it has had virtually nothing to do.
Originally at the insistence of the Soviet Union and more recently of the United States as well, the Security Council has been re-examining the role of the committee with an eye to giving it a more powerful role in coordinating the activities of the multinational forces currently in the Persian Gulf under United Nations auspices.
At first, the committee was comprised of the chiefs of staff of the five permanent memebers of the Security Council, the United States, the Soviet Union, China, Britain and France.
As time went on, the chiefs of staff delegated committee duties to junior officers, usually the military attaches of the permanent five members' missions. Chairmanship of the meetings rotates on a monthly basis, and a more senior officer often appears when his country had the chair, according to a diplomat familiar with the committee.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher But Falls Against the Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar firmed slightly in reaction to a Government report showing that the nation's jobless rate rose to 5.6 percent in August from 5.5 percent the month before, traders said.
''I think people were anticipating a far worse figure,'' said Harlan Matusow, an assistant vice president in currency trading at the New York office of Bank Julius Baer & Company. Analysts said a bad unemployment report could have persuaded the Federal Reserve to ease credit. Lower interest rates tend to weaken the dollar. 
Much of the dollar's advance the rest of the day appeared to stem from investors covering short positions by buying dollars, he said.
Traders who had anticipated a worse unemployment report and had been selling dollars decided to cover their positions, he said.
In addition, since the start of the Iraqi crisis, investors have been afraid to hold short positions over weekends for fear the dollar's value could be adversely affected by events before the market reopens Monday, he said.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 140.25 Japanese yen from 141.65 yen at Thursday's close. Later in London, it fell to 140.15 yen. In New York, the dollar was quoted at 140.05 yen at late afternoon, down from 140.65 late Thursday.
The dollar rose against the British pound. The pound cost $1.8933 in London, cheaper than $1.9075 late Thursday. In New York, the pound was quoted at $1.8930 at late afternoon, down from $1.9125 late Thursday.
The British Chancellor of the Exchequer, John Major, said sterling will not join the exchange rate mechanism of the European Monetary System during a weekend meeting of European finance officials. Rumors that the pound would join the mechanism have recently suppported the currency.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.5680 German marks, up from 1.5560; 1.3055 Swiss francs, up from 1.2975; 5.2530 French francs, up from 5.2135; 1,170.50 Italian lire, up from 1,161.50, and 1.1634 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1563.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $386.75 an ounce, from $389.50 late Thursday. In Zurich, gold fell to $387.00 an ounce, from $388.80 late Thursday.
Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose 64 cents to close at $388.23 an ounce.
Silver bullion closed at $4.800 an ounce on the Comex, up from $4.770 late Thursday. Silver was unchanged in London at a late bid of $4.80 an ounce.

HEADLINE: Fed Did Not Act on Dollar

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
''This does not mean that we are out of the intervention business,'' said Sam Cross, executive vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and manager of the Fed's foreign operations.
Asked during a news briefing whether the Fed had failed to intervene because it was satisfied with the direction of the dollar or because it felt intervention would be futile, Mr. Cross responded, ''It doesn't necessarily mean either one of those things.'' 
He said conditions did not call for intervention.
During the three months that ended July 31, the dollar declined 8 percent against the Japanese yen, 12 percent against the British pound and 5.5 percent against the German mark. The dollar sank further in August, reaching an all-time low of 1.5375 marks.
Mr. Cross said decisions to intervene were not made purely on the basis of the value of the dollar, but also took into account fundamental economic positions of the United States and other countries.
While the Fed did not intervene to increase the value of the dollar, it did sell marks and buy dollars in open market transactions and directly from another bank, which was not identified.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 23.26 Points; Week's Rise Is 5.19

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 23.26, to 2,619.55. But with oil prices rising most of the week, the Dow gained just 5.19 for the week. In another slow day, volume slumped to 123.8 million shares, from 125.6 million on Thursday. But 922 stocks rose and 10 hit new highs, while 560 fell and 62 reached new lows. 
''The market's not focusing on developing evidence of a recession,'' said David B. Bostian Jr., chief economist of Jesup, Josephthal & Company, ''but on the potentially positive aspect of the Bush and Gorbachev meeting.''
Traders here said unfounded rumors from ''somewhere in Asia'' that President Saddam Hussein had fled Iraq caused traders to take profits on crude oil, and prices fell abroad. Crude prices in the United States opened lower and remained lower, ending at $30.04, down $1.39.
Traders said the drop in oil prices touched off buying of S.& P. 500-stock index futures in Chicago, which caused heavy program trading in New York, with program traders working on the thin price differences between the futures and the stocks.
Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, said the effect of five buying waves and one selling wave was to tack 34 points on the Dow. Since the Dow rose only 23.26 points, the implication was that program buying was the main source of the rise.
 
Rumors Lift UAL by 8
UAL rose 8, to 100 1/4, on rumors that a union buyout group had obtained financing and on speculation that Marvin Davis, the oilman who had bid before, might bid again.
Toys ''R'' Us led the Big Board active list, falling 5/8, to 23 1/8, after Robert J. Schweich of Wertheim Schroder cut his earnings estimate. I.B.M. rose 3 1/8, to 105 1/2, after favorable comments by Shearson; Merrill Lynch; Smith Barney; Morgan Stanley and Sanford C. Bernstein.
Oracle, the software maker, headed the Nasdaq active list, falling 1 3/4 to close at 8 1/8, after hitting a new low of 6 3/4. It said it would report a loss, its first, in the quarter ended Aug. 31.
With crude oil down, the Dow transportation index rose 16.08, to 908.28. UAL accounted for most of that, but Delta Air Lines rose 3/4, to 55; CSX was up 7/8, to 30 3/8, and Conrail rose 7/8, to 38 3/4.

HEADLINE: Ford Chief's Views on Oil

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 7 (Reuter)

 BODY:
The auto industry is better prepared now to withstand the effects of an oil crisis and meet consumer demand for fuel-efficient vehicles than it was during the Middle East oil crisis of the 1970's, Harold Poling, chairman of the Ford Motor Company, said today.
 
Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on
Aug. 2 has led to concerns about oil supplies and is ''the most immediate challenge confronting us,'' Mr. Poling said in a speech at Wake Forest University in Winston-Salem, N.C.
''The industry is much better prepared today than in the 1970's to maneuver through an oil crisis, and the same is true of the U.S. economy as a whole,'' he said.
Mr. Poling said American industry was ''honing its competitive abilities - renewing its factories, accelerating productivity, focusing on quality and making employee involvement a way of life - improvements that pave the way for an enhanced competitive position in the years ahead.'' HEADLINE: Aid to Airbus Called Unfair In U.S. Study

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7

 BODY:
The report, which was prepared by a private consulting firm, Gellman Research Associates of suburban Philadelphia, found that the government backers of the consortium -France, West Germany, Britain and Spain - had already committed or disbursed $13.5 billion into Airbus Industrie programs since the late 1960's. With the addition of commercial interest rates, the total value of the aid was put at $25.9 billion.
Yet none of the programs are commercially viable, or are likely to be, the study said. Instead, the report added, Airbus sold aircraft below cost to increase market share, a process that deprived American makers of revenues to invest in new aircraft. 
The subsidies ''provide an unfair advantage over United States manufacturers and could injure the industry's future competitiveness,'' said J. Michael Farren, Under Secretary of Commerce for international trade. Against an overall trade deficit last year topping $100 billion, he noted, this industry generated a $12 billion surplus.
Europeans respond that the United States Government distorts free and fair trade in aerospace at least as much as the Europeans through Pentagon and National Aeronautics and Space Administration contracts and ''Buy American'' policies. According to Henri Martre, chairman of Aerospatiale, a French aerospace organization, the American industry receives at least three times as much overall support as the European.
Europeans also say that the American industry is now being helped by the low dollar exchange rate, which makes American planes more competitive. Bonn has just agreed to provide Daimler-Benz guarantees of more than $2 billion to cover the currency exchange risk from Airbus programs until 1999.
Daimler-Benz, Germany's largest industrial corporation, recently acquired Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm, the German partner in the Airbus consortium. The other partners are Aerospatiale of France, British Aerospace and Construcciones Aeronauticas of Spain.
 
Program Strongly Criticized
Washington has strongly criticized the currency guaranty program and threatened to file charges against Bonn under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world's free-trade charter. Exchange loss reimbursement undermines free trade by forestalling a normal redressment of deficits, American officials argue.
The Administration has warned that it will be forced to take legal action against the consortium if the issue is not resolved by Oct. 1.
A European Community spokesman, Peter Doyle, said that the publication of the report came in the middle of the negotiations and was therefore ''untimely and unhelpful.'' He added that the release was ''even more surprising'' in that it came a day after ministers from the Airbus countries had met with a member of the community's Executive Commission, Frans Andriessen, in London and concluded that there was common ground for the continuation of talks with the United States.
 
Report 'Was Ready'
Asked why the report was issued at this time, Commerce Under Secretary Farren said only that ''it was ready.'' He added that he did not expect it to affect the negotiations.
The United States for at least the last five years has been highly critical of Airbus subsidies for the reasons cited in the report. But officials said this was the first time a detailed objective analysis of the subsidies had been placed within a single complete package. Entitled ''An Economic and Financial Review of Airbus Industrie,'' the report is expected to figure prominently in internal Administration discussions about what action to take on Oct. 1.
The Commerce Department paid Gellman Associates $50,000 for the study. The same firm did a similar paper for the department in 1986, but it was never published. The earler work cost the department $150,000.
Asked whether the Europeans provided any data for the report, Aaron J. Gellman, the president of the consulting firm, said: ''We sought assistance from them. We were promised much and virtually nothing was delivered.''

HEADLINE: Anxiety Under That Fabled Cypress

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Sept. 7

 BODY:
The Pebble Beach Company has been sold to Ben Hogan Properties, a Fort Worth company controlled by Minoru Isutani, who owns an empire of golf clubs and sporting goods manufacturers in Japan and abroad. Most of his companies do business under the name Cosmo World Corporation.
The price, which was not announced, is believed to have been in the range of $800 million to $1 billion.
The property was sold by a partnership, Miller, Klutznick Davis & Gray, whose most widely known partner is Marvin Davis, the Denver oilman. Mr. Davis acquired the Pebble Beach Company as part of his $800 million purchase of 20th Century Fox, the film company, in 1981. The partnership bought Pebble Beach in two stages, in 1983 and 1985, for an undisclosed price, from Fox, which had paid $70 million for it in 1978. 
Real estate executives said there had been other bidders and that the Davis partnership had made a sizable profit on the sale. Some press reports said, however, that the Davis partnership had been losing money on its operations because of heavy debt payments.
The most famous part of the property is the Pebble Beach Golf Links, where the annual Bing Crosby National Pro-Am, now the A.T.&T. Pro-Am, seems to attract as many movie stars as professional golfers and where the 1992 United States Open Championship is to be held. But the property also includes three other golf courses, two hotels, hundreds of acres of real estate and the scenic 17-Mile Drive, where tourists pay $5.75 to wend their way past ocean cliffs, lush Spanish-style estates nestled in deep woods and a lone cypress tree on a craggy cliff made famous by the photographs of Ansel Adams and Edward Weston. Now the company claims trademark protection for the tree and is trying to bar photographers from making commercial use of it.
 
'A Piece of Americana'
Seeking to allay fears, the Pebble Beach Company's president, Tom Oliver, said at a news conference Thursday that the new management would continue to run things the same way. Mr. Oliver, however, was not available for an interview today.
Others involved in the transaction also maintained their silence. Several calls to Cosmo's American headquarters in Los Angeles were answered by someone saying that anyone who could talk was busy or out of the office.
Pebble Beach is only the latest prime American property bought by Japanese interests and ranks in size with Mitsubishi Estate Comapany's 1989 purchase of a controlling stake in Rockefeller Center for $846 million.
''When you're buying Pebble Beach it's like you're buying Yellowstone Park,'' said Daniel S. Levitan, director of real estate consulting in the Los Angeles office of Price Waterhouse. ''It's a piece of Americana.'' But Mr. Levitan said that the Pebble Beach purchase might be one of the last of its kind, given the decline of the Japanese stock market and uncertainties about the health of the American real estate market.
Mr. Levitan said, however, that if the estimates of the price were right, it indicated that ''this was not an economic decision to buy this in my opinion,'' adding, ''It was an ego purchase.''
It is also part of a broadening of Japanese interest from buying primarily downtown office buildings to buying resorts and golf clubs. Other Japanese companies have purchased the La Costa resort near San Diego and the Riviera Country Club in Los Angeles.
Part of this interest stems from the booming popularity of golf in Japan, a tiny nation without the land to build many golf courses. On any given weekend, the courses at Pebble Beach and elsewhere in California are filled with Japanese golfers. In can be far less expensive to fly here from Japan for a week of golf than to pay the dues in a Japanese golf club, where memberships can cost more than $1 million. And Japanese owners can deliver customers to their American golf courses, allowing them to pay more for a course than an American company, real estate analysts say.
Mr. Isutani, who controls Cosmo World, has attracted his share of controversy. In Japan, some members of his golf clubs have accused his company of selling far more memberships than had been agreed, making it difficult to get reservations, The Los Angeles Times reported earlier this week. His name has also been in the Japanese media for his relationship with Hisashi Shinto, the former chairman of the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Company who is being tried for his involvement in the political bribery scandal involving the Recruit Company, the newspaper added.
In July, The Las Vegas Sun reported that the Nevada gaming authorities were planning to reject Mr. Isutani's application to run a casino there. The newspaper cited Mr. Isutani's possible involvement in the Recruit scandal, though such a link has never been proved.
Cosmo World is developing a huge hotel and resort complex near Las Vegas and has signed up Caesars World Inc. to manage the non-casino hotel. The company is developing the Los Angeles International Golf Club and is co-developing a resort in Hawaii. It purchased the Ben Hogan Company, a maker of golf clubs and sportswear, in 1988.
Despite Pebble Beach's prominence and the questions about Mr. Isutani, many people here seem to accept the purchase as a fact of life.
To some extent, the controversy was blunted because reports of the sale began to circulate in June, giving people time to adjust. However, the initial reports were that Cosmo was going to buy only 49 percent of the property.
It is not clear why it changed to a full buyout, although some real estate specialists say that when the property was originally put on the market, a 100 percent stake was offered for sale. The minority investment might have been floated to diffuse controversy.
''The 49 percent was one way to try to keep a lot of people happy in the area,'' said Brad Blackman of Blackman, Flynn & Company, a San Francisco real easte firm. ''Everybody's been attempting to try to keep transactions less controversial,'' he said. However, after it appeared that controversy was not developing, he said, the deal was changed to a complete purchase.
 
Varied Reactions by Golfers
Golfers here expressed a range of reactions.
''I think it's part of our heritage,'' said Charles Kirby of Fort Myers, Fla., who is vacationing here. ''I hate to see it go into the hands of foreigners.''
But Dennis Schwary, a Southern California financial consultant, said he was not worried. ''Until they find a way to unbolt it and take it home, it will still be in America.''
Some expressed hope that as in their purchases of failing American factories and companies, the Japanese would infuse new capital in the operation. Despite its reputation and stiff greens fees, the course has a problem with weeds, and the greens are brown in patches from the continuing California drought.
''All I want them to do is put some water on it,'' said Tom Testman, from Orange County, who golfs here two or three times a year.

The Economy
The job market deteriorated markedly for the second straight month in August as the nation's unemployment rate edged up one-tenth of a point, to 5.6 percent, the highest in two years, the Labor Department reported. The report, the first broad gauge of economic performance for the month and the first job report since Iraq overran Kuwait on Aug. 2, showed that non-government job growth, which had been slowing since early 1989, has now halted. [1.] 
 
 
 
Companies
 Manville agreed to provide up to $520 million in new funds over seven years to the trust set up to compensate victims of its asbestos products. The new funding, however, is contingent on changes being negotiated in the way the trust operates. [29.] Big U.S. airlines were caught by the sharp rise in jet fuel prices and weakening passenger traffic just as they were adding routes and planes in record numbers. But most carriers say they are sticking to their ambitious expansion plans. HEADLINE: A Symphony in Search of a Home (or Cash)

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
No symphony orchestra has ever picked up and moved to another city, and the 82 members of the Buffalo Philharmonic, who passed the hat to pay for the $360 classified ad, regarded it as highly unlikely that some prosperous town looking for culture would make them an offer.
But, as hoped, the ad quickly drew the attention of news organizations, and spokesmen for Buffalo's Local 92 of the American Federation of Musicians, which represents the orchestra members, were ready with tongue-in-cheek comments.
''We're going to entertain any offers that come as a result of the ad,'' said Frances Morgante, a violinist and union representative. ''But, obviously, to move around the country is not what we would like to do. We want management to keep what they have here. We will go to any extent to maintain our status as a major symphony orchestra.'' 
''Who knows?'' Susie Myers, an English horn player, said in another telephone interview. ''We might get a good offer. We might be the Green Bay Packerettes.''
But there was a serious side to the attention-getting gesture as well, said Richard Myers, the orchestra's principal trombonist and a spokesman for the union. He said that every member of the orchestra had received a letter of dismissal from the management last month in an apparent move to scrap and renegotiate a three-year contract signed a year ago.
Mr. Myers said the orchestra's management had demanded a wage freeze to cancel wage increases of 5 percent scheduled for the second and third years of the contract. He said the orchestra also wanted to cut seven weeks from its 46-week schedule, due to start Sept. 22, and to permanently eliminate five vacant musicians' chairs.
He said the orchestra musicians, whose minimum wage is $32,016 a year, would lose $10,000 to $12,000 if salaries were frozen and the season cut to 39 weeks. The musicians would lose seven weeks' pay as well as the increases scheduled in the contract that the management wants to scrap, he said. He also said the orchestra was already understaffed by nearly 20 members.
 
'The Minor Leagues'
''If we take the cuts they're demanding, we'll be reduced from a major American orchestra to the minor leagues,'' Mr. Myers said. ''It's tragic that this orchestra, with a history of distinguished conductors, great soloists and major tours, has arrived at a point where musicians are constantly being asked to subsidize their own existence.''
In a review for The New York Times in 1986, Tim Page said of a concert by the Buffalo Philarhonic in Carnegie Hall: ''The Buffalo sound is full, rich and well-blended; the playing disciplined but never mechanical, with only an occasional muddy passage or tentative attack.''
Steve Paschang, a spokesman for the orchestra, acknowledged that the management was seeking a wage freeze, a shortened season and a smaller orchestra. He said the measures would ''come close to'' making up the $2.2 million deficit in a 1990-91 budget that he estimated at $6.5 million.
Mr. Paschang noted that the orchestra had signed a three-year contract last September in the expectation of substantial subsidies from state, county and city governments. He could not say how much the orchestra had sought, and obtained, from government sources.
 
'Support Should Be There'
''Yes, we got some help, but not as much as we wanted,'' he said. ''The Philharmonic is in trouble. The city is coming back. This is a world-class orchestra - many music critics say it's one of the seven or eight best in the country - and the support should be there. We don't know why it isn't.''
Asked about the musicians' advertisement offering to move en masse to another city, Mr. Paschang said: ''It's an attention-getter. We take it about as seriously as they do.''
The musicians' union attributed the budget problems to ''mismanagement and fiscal irresponsibility'' by the orchestra and its board, Mr. Myers said. ''The members of the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra are facing the most serious threat to the survival of their organization since the beginning of its troubled history.''
 
Distinguished Conductors
Since its inception in the 1930's as a Works Progress Administration orchestra, the Buffalo Philharmonic has had distinguished conductors, including William Steinberg, Josef Krips, Lukas Foss, Michael Tilson Thomas, Julius Rudel and Semyon Bychkov. The present musical director is Max Imiano Valdes.
Several orchestra members said they did not want to leave Buffalo, but warned that a move was not out of the question.
''We're serious,'' said Ms. Myers, whose husband is a spokesman for the union. ''We want them to know we want to remain a major symphony orchestra, and we're willing to relocate. We're a superb orchestra, and everybody admits that, but we constantly have to justify our existence, and we're tired of it.''
The tactic of threatening a move to another city is commonly used by sports teams, like the National Hockey League's Buffalo Sabres, who recently warned of a move if the city did not build a new arena in five years. Buffalo is considering the arena and a new football stadium for the Bills. With the biggest attendance in the minors for its Bisons (a Pittsburgh Pirates farm club), Buffalo wants a major league baseball franchise, too.
As for offers to move the Philharmonic, Mr. Myers said, ''We're not holding our breath.''

HEADLINE: About New York;
Making Struggle More Bearable For AIDS Cases

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
There were also a couple of dozen people, mainly minorities and poor, who have chosen to give their time to those struggling with AIDS. Along with about 60 others, they are members of the Bronx AIDS Volunteer Organization, known as Project Bravo. Bravo is a joint effort of four Bronx hospitals and is financed by the United Hospital Fund and the city and Federal governments. Some volunteers are middle class, but many teeter on the economic edge.
''These are people who have been kicked around by the system,'' said the coordinator, Bridget Lee Poust, who says most are so poor they could not participate if Bravo didn't pay for transportation. 
The mission of Bravo, which was begun in 1986 by clients of Montefiore's methadone clinic, is to help those with AIDS in the city's poorest borough. It hopes to provide some measure of the magnificent support that the Gay Men's Health Crisis has given people with AIDS, mainly in Manhattan. As the cruel scourge falls ever harder on the poor, minorities and drug users, Bravo is on the front line.
The stakes - and the outlook - are disheartening. A study postulates that one in five men in the Bronx now carry the virus that causes AIDS.
''It could destroy this borough,'' Ms. Poust said softly. ''You could look around one day and say, 'Where did everybody go?' ''
Why does anyone volunteer for unpaid work with a guaranteed sad ending?
Some do it as a memorial to someone who has died of AIDS, perhaps a child. Some have the AIDS virus themselves. Some are moved by the plight of homeless people with AIDS. Some believe in an afterlife and the certainty of perfect peace. Some couldn't put any of it in words.
 
Ms. Poust said poor
Bronxites are often distrustful at first, even of this clearly humanitarian effort, reflecting lifetimes of being disappointed by those in authority.
Some, she said, believe the C.I.A. started AIDS. Some even think white doctors devised it to eliminate blacks.
Volunteers do a little of everything. They go with a frantic mother to pick up a welfare check. They intercede with a landlord trying to evict someone in the hospital. When that fails, they will scour the Bronx for another apartment. They'll play checkers for hours, take people out for Chinese food, buy Christmas gifts with their own money. One found herself wheeling a man with the disease to another ward for dates with his sick wife.
The newest Bravo initiative is called the Legacy Project. It involves people with AIDS making videos in which they discuss things like their childhood, what it is like to have AIDS and what they think about whatever. The idea, Ms. Poust says, is to combat ''this feeling that nobody will ever know I was here.''
A philosopher once wrote that if nothingness awaits us, let us not live in a way that makes this an act of justice.
Lizabeth Kahn is an unemployed hairdresser whose brother and a couple of good friends died of AIDS. She herself carries the virus that causes the disease. She told of convincing one patient to go to the dentist. ''You'll look at yourself in the mirror and smile, and at least you've got your teeth,'' she said.
Clydette Niles, a former addict, told of teaching arts and crafts, things like making ashtrays and key chains. ''But some of them don't want to do nothing,'' she said. ''The ones that don't want to do nothing, I'll just stay and talk to.''
William Ramos said he volunteered because he has AIDS himself. His message: ''It's not as bad as you think it is.'' So why has he twice tried to commit suicide?
Edna Honeyghan, a retired nurse, attributes her devotion to the AIDS work to maternal instinct. She lost her only child in a miscarriage. ''I don't expect to get anything out of it,'' she said.
Mary Leonard, a Roman Catholic nun, comes to listen for an inner peace that descends when people finally lie back and rest in God's arms. Never ever does she mention the word AIDS.
Bravo.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Bush and Gorbachev, in Helsinki, Face the Gulf Crisis

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HELSINKI, Sept. 8

 BODY:
''Here in Helsinki, President Gorbachev and I meet, hopefully to strengthen our common approach to this unjustifiable act of aggression,'' he said after alighting from his new Presidential jumbo jet at the Helsinki Airport this morning, The two leaders were meeting for the third time as heads of state; they met in Malta in December and in Washington at the end of May.
''If the nations of the world, acting together, continue as they have been to isolate Iraq and deny Saddam the fruits of aggression, we will set in place the cornerstone of an international order more stable and secure than any we have known,'' Mr. Bush said.
 
Personal Contact 'Essential'
Mr. Gorbachev, flying into Helsinki about seven hours later, said:
''I hope this will be an important meeting. We have things to discuss, although we are constantly exchanging views, maintaining contact by telephone and letter and through our representatives. But at such a time personal contact is essential. 
''I think we will discuss the acute crisis in the Persian Gulf and many other questions, current questions of world politics.''
President Bush told reporters on the way to Helsinki that he had no plans to ask Moscow to send ground troops to the multinational force assembled in Saudi Arabia - a proposal that Mr. Gorbachev would almost certainly reject because of strong popular opposition at home.
The Soviets fear a military conflict a few hundred miles from their southern border would arouse the painful memories of their war in Afghanistan and might also increase tensions between Russians and the country's large Islamic minority.
 
A Sensitive Issue
John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, said in an interview with CNN today that the President ''sensed a sensitivity on that issue by the Soviets, and felt it was an inappropriate request to make at that time.''
But Mr. Bush said he would propose ''a wide array'' of cooperative measures against Iraq.
Soviet journalists said that Mr. Gorbachev might be willing to integrate Soviet warships into an international armada policing the economic embargo against Iraq if Mr. Bush would agree to put the force under the authority of the United Nations.
Although the United States has resisted subjecting its armed forces to United Nations control, a senior American official said it was ''not excluded'' that some United Nations role could be found that would elicit a measure of Soviet military cooperation.
Soviet analysts also predicted that Mr. Gorbachev would agree to American requests that Moscow withdraw its military trainers and technicians from Iraq, although the Soviet leader may seek to do this without fanfare.
The Soviets have said they were reluctant to remove the 193 military personnel and other, civilian weapon specialists for fear that this would precipitate the taking of Soviet hostages.
 
'Impossible to Justify'
But Moscow seems more willing to withdraw its military specialists now that Soviet women and children have been evacuated from the region.
''Many Soviet analysts feel that we've got to get them out of Iraq because morally it is impossible to justify their presence,'' said Stanislav N. Kondrashev, the well-connected political commentator for the Government daily Izvestia.
Mr. Gorbachev was almost certain to make a strong appeal for expanded American help in rescuing his economy. The Soviet leader arrives in Helsinki at a time when his popularity at home is at the lowest ebb since he came to power five years ago, and he would welcome any new American commitment of assistance.
President Bush also seemed sympathetic to Mr. Gorbachev's needs, telling reporters that he was ''all for'' expanding technical aid in areas like the development of Soviet oilfields.
One serious rift between the two superpowers has emerged over Moscow's call for a peace conference that would consider the gulf crisis and then move on to discuss the Israeli occupation of Arab lands and the conflict in Lebanon.
 
Idea of Meeting Revived
The United States has never been enthusiastic about Moscow's longstanding notion of an international conference that might try to impose a settlement on Israel.
Western diplomats were startled early this week when the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, revived the idea and suggested adding Iraq to the agenda.
In a statement issued before he left for the summit meeting in Helsinki, Mr. Shevardnadze again raised the idea of a conference, suggesting that it would deal with the Iraq crisis in a first phase and then move on to deal with issues of Israeli-occupied Arab lands and the conflict in Lebanon in later phases.
Mr. Shevardnadze also offered to travel to Iraq and ''to work with Israel at the ministerial level'' in an attempt to organize such a gathering.
He acknowledged that the United States ''has not yet shown great enthusiasm for this plan.''
''But I believe we should not be frightened by this idea,'' he said.
 
Issue Linked, Arab Says
The Soviets and some Arabs contend the promise of such a conference could strengthen the resolve of Arab nations in facing down Iraq and give President Hussein a face-saving way to retreat.
''I don't think the Soviets mean to postpone the resolution of this most urgent problem until we can solve the problems of the Palestinians and Lebanon,'' said an Arab diplomat in Moscow. ''Clearly you do not want linkage in the sense of a concession to Saddam Hussein. But the issues are linked in that these problems are all symptoms of the same larger cancer in the Middle East.''
Western diplomats said there was great unease among the allies that the Soviet push for a diplomatic initiative would seem to give ground before Mr. Hussein has indicated any willingness to withdraw his forces from Kuwait.
''Bush cannot afford to send any signal that encourages Saddam to think we are offering a deal,'' a Western diplomat said. ''Saddam has to make the first move. Until he does, we are not in the business of looking for face-savers. If you make an offer, Saddam will just pocket it and think you are losing your resolve.''
 
A Division of Labor
At the same time, Mr. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, seemed to hint that Mr. Bush would welcome a more active Soviet diplomatic role.
In his interview with CNN, Mr. Sununu said that ''because of past relationships, the Soviet Union may have some capacity to influence Saddam Hussein, and maybe the President will be encouraging them to at least discuss the situation with them.''
A Western diplomat in Moscow said, ''I'm sure that when they compare notes, the two Presidents will agree there can be a useful division of diplomatic labor here.''
In their discussion of the Soviet economy, Mr. Gorbachev is likely to outline his plans for phasing out central state controls on the economy and to seek some commitment that as the Soviet Union moves toward free markets the United States will step in with aid and investment.
White House officials said the United States was eager to bolster Mr. Gorbachev's domestic position, especially given his cooperation during the gulf crisis. But American investors have increasingly shied away from the Soviet Union because of the uncertainty over the Kremlin's control of its economy and disputes over major issues like the ownership of natural resources.
Secretary of Commerce Robert A. Mosbacher is scheduled to arrive in Moscow next week with a group of high-powered corporate executives to investigate the prospects for increased American investment.
But Mr. Sununu noted today that ''there is still some uncertainty on the part of U.S. investors, U.S. businesses.''
''For example,'' he said, ''they don't know whether they should sign a contract with the central Government, or the republic or the municipality, or some new entity.
''For the Soviet Union's own sake in being able to attract that investment, they really ought to clear the ambiguity so that private investors in the United States and around the world can feel comfortable about the kind of relationships that have been established.''

HEADLINE: Larger Costs of the Crisis

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:

 
Some Less-Obvious Costs
The indirect costs to Americans are harder to pin down because they depend in large part on the way businesses, consumers and the Federal Reserve respond to the surge in oil prices. But by almost every reckoning these costs will far exceed the extra spending on energy and military firepower.
Edward Gramlich, an economist at the University of Michigan, points out that the initial effect of higher oil prices is much like that of a tax increase. An extra $10 a barrel adds about $5 billion a month to oil bills. And because consumers have less to spend, demand falls for everything from houses to hamburgers. As sales decline, businesses cut back investments in new equipment and reduce their inventories, spreading the decline through the economy.
But even as the demand contracts, the prices of goods and services are likely to rise. Higher costs for energy and for ubiquitous petroleum-based chemicals are passed through to consumers. And the inflationary impact is magnified as workers try to offset their reduced spending power by pressing for higher wages. Stephen Roach, an economist at Morgan Stanley & Company, estimates that if oil settles at $25 a barrel, pushed down by additional production from Saudi Arabia and other countries to offset the loss of output from Iraq and Kuwait, the general price level would rise within a year by about an extra 1 percent. 
 
Choices Are Few
How might Washington respond? Changes in taxes and spending, once the fastest-working and most accurate weapons in the Government's policy arsenal, have been rendered inoperative by chronic budget deficits. While budget negotiators may yet manage to fashion a deficit-reduction package, no one is suggesting that the Government will again be in a position to use fiscal policy to deal with inflation and recession. That leaves the Federal Reserve, the agency that controls the supply of money and credit.
Benjamin Friedman, an economist at Harvard, notes that before the gulf crisis the Federal Reserve presided over an economy experiencing wobbly annual growth of 1 percent, but ominously strong inflation of 5 percent. Rather than risk adding to inflationary pressures, the Federal Reserve had been holding firm to the credit tiller.
The tax-like oil shock has almost certainly further weakened demand and induced businesses to postpone investments. Fred Bergsten, an economist at the Institute for International Economics, says, ''It's hard to find anybody outside the Government who doesn't think we're already in a recession.'' But at the same time, the inflation rate is almost certainly up: Stephen Roach at Morgan Stanley estimates that the Consumer Price Index will rise by 6.6 percent for 1990.
''That puts the Fed in a box,'' Mr. Friedman says. If the Federal Reserve loosens credit to offset the contractionary effect of higher oil prices, it risks embedding the new, higher inflation rate in the expectations of businesses and workers. And once the new inflation has taken hold, the Harvard economist warns, it would be extremely costly to root out.
Extrapolating from the experience of the 1970's, he estimates that Americans would have to sacrifice 6 percent of their income for one year - more than $300 billion - to rid the economy of a one percentage point increase in the ''core'' inflation rate. On the other hand, if the Federal Reserve does not ease credit to accommodate higher oil prices, it risks a longer, deeper recession.
 
Differences in Timing
Robert Gordon, an economist at Northwestern University, points out, moreover, that the problem of offsetting the oil shock is further complicated by lags in the impact of monetary changes. Higher oil prices hit business and consumers overnight. But monetary policy works by changing the costs of borrowing money, and the effects take at least six months to ricochet through the economy.
Richard Cooper, an economist at Harvard, says the Federal Reserve's least risky option is to buffer the oil shock, expanding credit by enough to offset the fall in demand. Mr. Gramlich of the University of Michigan agrees, contending that the prospects of avoiding a rise in core inflation are now much better than in the 1970's. Both businesses and workers, he says, are savvy enough to treat the impact of an oil price increase as a one-time event rather than a self-fulfilling prophecy of inflation to come.
But relatively few economists share their confidence. ''I get nervous with more than 5 percent inflation,'' concedes Robert Z. Lawrence at the Brookings Institution. And in any case, it is hard to find an analyst who predicts that the Federal Reserve will go out on an expansionary limb by fully accommodating the oil shock.
Robert Hall, a fellow at the Hoover Institution of Stanford University, guesses that the Federal Reserve will compromise. Judging from its past behavior, he thinks the central bank will aim at influencing the growth rate of G.N.P. in dollar terms, rather than focusing on the growth of output or the rate of inflation. Thus, if the oil shock increases the overall price level by 1 percent, Mr. Hall expects the Federal Reserve will not try to offset a 1 percent fall in output.
 
Figuring the Damage
A 1 percent cut for one year would mean that about $55 billion in output would be lost. If the Federal Reeserve were to take a hard line on prices, attempting to smash any change in the expected rate of inflation in the first few months of the crisis, the damage could be much greater. Robert Gordon points out that in the early 1980's the Federal Reserve was willing to accept a cumulative $1.3 trillion loss in output as the price of reducing the inflation rate by six percentage points.
If Iraq fails in its bid to dominate the Persian Gulf and oil producers restore exports to their previous levels, oil prices will presumably slip back to the pre-crisis level of about $21 a barrel. If prices remain high, however, the Congressional Budget Office believes the economy will suffer chronic losses from lagging productivity. And while their estimates, derived from computer simulations, are just educated guesses, they do suggest that the long-term impact could be staggering.
 
Effect on Productivity
A permanent increase in the price of oil would induce businesses to choose production methods that use more capital and labor, and less energy. It would also reduce the profitability of investments outside the oil industry, slowing purchases of new plants and equipment. Thus if the oil price were to remain $10 a barrel higher than before the invasion, the budget office estimates that the United States would experience a once-and-for-all drop in productivity of 2 percent.
The resulting 2 percent loss of gross national product would run to about $120 billion a year by the mid-90's, when the drag on productivity would be fully absorbed. A calculation of the cumulative damage is not possible without making assumptions about the rate of growth of the economy and the ''discount rate'' used to equate the value of current income with income in the future. But Warwick McKibbin, an economist at the Brookings Institution and a creator of the computer simulation model used by the budget office, points out that even a very conservative set of assumptions would lead to estimates of more than $2 trillion.

HEADLINE: As One Grocery Boycott Ends, One Drags On

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

 BODY:
Mayor Dinkins said at the rally that his office was continuing to work toward a settlement in Flatbush, but added that details of that boycott, and of the negotiations, were ''too complicated'' to discuss. ''We're confident we will achieve a resolution,'' he said.
 
Accused of Stealing Cherries
The Brownsville boycott arose from an incident on Aug. 4 in which two sisters, Doretha and April Whitt, charged that the owners of the store had accused them of stealing cherries and insulted their mother, Dorothy. The owners at the time, Heejin Lee, and his wife, Inga, told the police that when Mrs. Lee confronted the two women about eating cherries from the bin, they pushed her down to the ground. 
Blacks and Korean-Americans in New York City's poorer neighborhoods have shared a testy relationship for some time. Some blacks resent the relative economic success of Korean-Americans and feel they do not have the same opportunities.
The main reason the boycott ended so quickly in the Brownsville section was that the store changed ownership, and officials were able to convince the protesters that the new owners, Brian Ju, was unrelated to the Lees. Yesterday, Doretha Whitt joined the Mayor on the speaker's platform, hugging him and thanking him.
Mr. Ju, a bit overwhelmed by the swarm of television cameras and supporters at his bountiful market, at the corner of Watkins Street, said he would earn the respect of the community simply by selling ''best quality produce at the best prices.'' He also has agreed with city officials to hire black and Hispanic workers.
 
Resident 'Glad It's Over'
Residents seemed relieved that the boycott had ended. Marjerie Pittman, a 40-year-old receptionist for the New York State Health Department, said the boycott had hurt the already deflated reputation of Brownsville, a poor neighborhood often in the news because of drug use and crime there.
''We do not need this,'' Mrs. Pittman said. ''Why should we keep on bickering and nagging when it's over? These people have a business, and I'm going to shop in their store because it's the closest one to my home. The majority of the community is glad it's over.''
The swift resolution of the Brownsville boycott represented a victory for Mayor Dinkins, who took office last fall at a time of pitched racial and ethnic tension. Despite his frequent and impassioned calls for conciliation and respect, those tensions have not abated. In recent weeks, the Mayor has come under fire for not taking a tougher stand against violent crime.
 
Dinkins Approach Disputed
Yesterday, the Mayor said that the two families, the Whitts and the Jus, and the two communities ''demonstrated that we can work together, that we can share it together, and most importantly that we can build communities - together. ''
Earlier in the day, however, the owner of Family Red Apple store in Flatbush, Bong Jaejang, called the Mayor's scheduled appearance in Brownsville ''phony'' and said Mr. Dinkins had only ''paid lip service'' to his own situation. ''He's done nothing for us,'' he said. ''He has said the boycott is wrong, but he hasn't come to the store to buy food.'' Mr. Jaejang said his electric bills were being paid by private supporters.
Michael Kharsen, the director of the Mayor's community assistance unit, said that the Mayor's aides had been to the Flatbush store but that the Mayor himself believed a personal visit would not be fruitful during the negotiations. Mr. Dinkins has said he does not believe the Flatbush boycott is primarily a racial one.
