LENGTH: 580 words

HEADLINE: Academy of Engineers Says U.S. Should Welcome Foreign Investors

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
The report comes at a time of uncertainty about what the Bush Administration will do to help American companies compete. Officials have said they want to avoid having the Government set industrial policy, through measures like incentives to encourage production of certain products. But President Bush recently suggested that he would offer Federal support for work on ''generic technologies'' that industries may use in their own way. The report calls for much stronger Federal action. 
 
Expert Testimony
The panel, which studied the issue over the last year and a half, comprises 14 prominent academic and industrial officials, who took testimony and written comments from more than 150 industrial and academic experts.
Dr. Thomas H. Lee of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who headed the panel, said that if a company moved design and manufacturing plants to the United States, the money it would contribute to the economy would be more than 10 times the amount taken to its home country in profits.
''Is ownership the most important thing, or is the corporation's activities in our country the more important criterion?'' he asked. ''We believe the most important thing to do is create an environment that is attractive for people to come in and do research, and do development, and do production. Instead of looking at protection measures to protect our corporations' interests, a better way to address the problem is to ask ourselves: How can we make this country an attractive place for all countries to work?''
 
Benefits for Suppliers
For example, he said, if an electronics company carries on research and engineering here, the employees will be American and will ''carry the ideas in their heads'' as they participate in the advances. In addition, many suppliers will be American.
Dr. Robert M. White, president of the National Academy of Engineering, which is affiliated with the National Academy of Sciences, said two arguments against keeping the country open to foreign companies are that companies will take their profits home and that American politics may be affected through political contributions by foreign owners. But the report said these considerations are outweighed by the need to participate in the growth of transnational industries.
The report also recommends that the Government help reduce barriers to the spread of technology and invest significant amounts of money for research in generic technologies like semiconductors. ''Current Federal science and technology policies are targeted primarily on basic research and 'mission-oriented' technology related to national defense,'' it said.
John Howard, director of international finance at the United States Chamber of Commerce, said the chamber agreed that the country should remain open to foreign investment. But the chamber has not formed its policy on what the Government should do to strengthen American companies. ''We are grappling with that right now,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
Compromise, and Seats, At Budget Negotiations

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANDREWS AIR FORCE BASE, Md., Sept. 8

 BODY:
Under the hard-won compromise, the tables are now arranged in a long rectangle, with top-ranking Democratic and Republican leaders at one end, Administration officials at the other.
 
 A Varied Cuisine
 The talks are being held in a large, carpeted room that normally serves as the officers club bar and doubles as the site for special buffets featuring ethnic cuisine. The budget negotiators missed Thursday's Taco Party, but if negotiations drag on, they may have a chance to enjoy next week's Mongolian Bar B'Q.
Elaborate security arrangements have been made to keep reporters and lobbyists away from the talks, although much of the secrecy appears to have been designed to make sure that Republicans and Democrats do not get wind of each other's bargaining positions before proposals are laid on the table. 
The officers club and its adjacent buildings have been transformed into a sort of mini-Capitol, guarded by Capitol police officers and complete with Democratic and Republican cloakrooms, staff caucus areas, computers, facsimile machines and telephone banks. The ever-efficient Air Force staff has supplied each caucus room with care packages of Alka-Seltzer, Tums, Tylenol and Halls cough drops.
Congressional and Administration aides here to advise their bosses have been issued special credentials (embossed with the United States seal and bearing identification numbers) that are required for entering the restricted area. While the initial plan had called for color-coded identification tags - yellow for Democrats, green for Republicans and red for the Administration - organizers decided at the last moment that neutral peach-colored tags for all staff members would better foster a sense of harmony.
 
A Budget Slumber Party
 Some lawmakers brought their pajamas and toothbrushes in anticipation of what had promised to be round-the-clock negotiating sessions. But most have declined the no-frills sleeping accommodations provided at the Andrews ''distinguished visitors quarters'' and chosen instead to return home each night.
As the lawmakers arrived this morning, Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the House Ways and Means Committee, was overheard discussing the merits of the budget slumber party approach with Senator Jim Sasser, the Tennessee Democrat who heads the Senate Budget Committee.
''Why don't you stay?'' Mr. Rostenkowski suggested. ''If I got to know you better, maybe I'd get to like you.''
 
Top Democrats Absent
 Democrats have their own worries about the wisdom of making deals with Mr. Darman that may not pass muster at the White House. Although the Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, and the House Republican leader, Robert H. Michel of Illinois, are attending the sessions, the two top Democratic leaders in Congress are not.
The House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, and the Senate Democratic leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, have decided they will be present only when President Bush attends. Aides see this as a tactical advantage, intended to insure that the Democratic leadership has the same opportunity as the President to exercise veto power over any compromise the negotiators may produce.
Mr. Bush, who is meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Helsinki, is expected to drop in on the budget negotiators when his plane lands at Andrews late Sunday night.
 
Bargaining Moves Slowly
 Bargaining on the deficit package is moving slowly, each side now having rejected the first two offers presented by the other. But there was said to be some decision on how to divide spending cuts between military and domestic programs. They have been invited to the White House at 10 A.M. on Monday and this may provide the deadline they need to reach a final agreement.
Democrats would achieve their $50 billion in deficit cuts for 1991 largely through higher taxes, including a new 2 percent energy tax, and reductions in military spending. Republicans, also aiming for $50 billion, would limit the Federal deduction for state and local income taxes, but would cut the capital gains tax rate and make deep reductions in spending for benefits programs like Medicare, Medicaid and Federal retirement.
Both parties are recommending higher taxes on alcoholic beverages, with beer and wine bearing the biggest burden since Federal taxes on those beverages have not been raised since 1951. Republicans have been especially scornful of a Democratic proposal to find $2.5 billion in new revenue by improving collection of debts owed the Federal Government.
Such estimates are among the legendary devices that Republicans and Democrats employ each year to reach deficit-reduction goals. Senator Phil Gramm, a Texas Republican who serves on the Senate Budget Committee, suggested to his colleagues this morning that the only way to insure that the Government really got the $2.5 billion would be to hire unemployed K.G.B. agents to do the collecting.
The talks broke up this evening at about 10 P.M. when a fire alarm interrupted a sharp argument and forced the negotiators to evacuate the officers club.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Neutral States of Europe Start Shedding Their Postwar Shell

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HELSINKI, Finland

 BODY:
Asked if he could foresee any circumstances that might lead Finland to abandon its military neutrality and join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Mr. Suominen shook his head, laughed and said, ''We certainly wouldn't want to be an adversary if the Soviet Union joined NATO.''
 
Edging Toward Involvement
The neutral states in the new, post-cold war Europe are edging cautiously toward greater involvement in collective security arrangements that they have shunned for decades.
Officials from all of them say they have been encouraged by the recent revival of the Western European Union, a political and military council established after World War II as the basis of a European Defense Community that never came to pass because of objections from France. It was the Western European Union, not NATO, that the allies used as the European forum to approve military enforcement of the United Nations sanctions against Iraq early last month. 
A declaration made in Helsinki this week by conservative European political parties, including some from neutral countries, reflected some of the changing thinking about military involvements. All parties, including the neutral states, said they supported the military actions taken by the United States in the Persian Gulf and urged countries that had not yet done so either to send forces there or to ''give financial support for their operation or assistance to those states suffering as a result of the sanctions.''
 
'Far More Room to Move'
The Social Democratic-led Government in Stockholm under Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson has been under pressure from the conservative opposition to take a more active role in the Persian Gulf crisis, Swedish politicians and journalists say. Asked here if he wanted the Government to send more weapons, the Swedish conservative leader Carl Bildt, chairman of the Moderate Coalition Party, said, 'We have no forces to send - no oceangoing ships - and our aircraft don't use the same kind of fuel as American, Saudi or British planes.''
So far, the new neutrality is long on words and short on deeds, a fact criticized by Britain's Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher, in a speech here Thursday. She seemed to fear that the attitude could become general, even in countries that belong to NATO, unless she brought them up short.
Who infects whom remains to be seen, but the greatest change seems to be taking place among the neutrals.
Mr. Suominen said in an interview, ''If there is more cooperation than confrontation between the United States and the Soviet Union, we have far more room to move than we did when confrontation was at its height.''
 
Expanding Trade Markets
Economic and political change in the Soviet Union is also having an effect on trade and business patterns in neutral Finland, which before 1985 conducted 20 to 25 percent of its foreign trade with Moscow, Mr. Suominen said.
Now, it conducts 65 percent of its trade with the European Community and other free-market European countries. In the first half of this year, only about 10 percent was with the Soviet Union.
Finnish imports from its Communist neighbors - $4 billion last year -could rise sharply in the rest of 1990 because Finland obtains almost all its oil from the Soviet Union. But because it pays for imports under barter arrangements, Finnish exports to Moscow will rise, too.
Mr. Suominen, Finland's Trade Minister, said that would probably change soon. ''We will be going into normal hard-currency trade with the Soviets, and that may reduce the volume of trade further,'' he said.
Teuvo Tikkanen of the industry-supported Finnfacts Institute said that with the country's unemployment now down to about 3.5 percent, inflation was expected to rise to 6 percent this year as the economy overheated. ''I think that in the changing Europe, we can't be the last ones to join the E.C.,'' he said.
The Community, based in Brussels, has said that it would not consider applications until after the completion of its 340 million-member single European market by the end of 1992.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
In Europe, Faint Support Seen for a Military Strike

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
Mrs. Thatcher has given vigorous support to President Bush during the crisis and has sent a 2,000-strong force of British ships and planes and ground support personnel to Saudi Arabia and neighboring Gulf states. Now she may send up to 4,000 more, according to British officials, possibly including two British armored infantry brigades with tanks and artillery. ''We'll send whatever the people in Washington tell us they'd most like to have,'' one of her advisers said Friday.
The next step, according to British officials, might be to tighten the embargo by extending it to the airways, to keep Iraq's allies in the crisis - particularly Libya - from running the blockade with aircraft. It is unclear, however, whether the United Nations or public opinion here would tolerate shooting down Libyan or Yemeni cargo planes to keep them from bringing military supplies or food into Iraq. 
 
Force Remains an Option
Few here, inside or outside the government, foresee large-scale offensive military operations against Iraq by the United States or the forces allied with it before the end of this year, unless President Hussein provokes them. The expectation that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will reaffirm Soviet support for the embargo in his talks with President Bush in Helsinki on Sunday strengthens British hopes that the embargo will lead to a peaceful resolution of the crisis after all.
But Mrs. Thatcher, like Mr. Bush, is keeping the option of force open, and her aides say the government would not hesitate to use it if it became necessary.
''There could be a severe retaliatory strike if Saddam went for the Saudi oil fields, or moved forces into Jordan, or sent a gunboat out to confront the blockade, or started shooting hostages,'' said David Bolton, a former Royal Air Force officer with extensive service in the Middle East who is now director of the Royal United Services Institute for Defense Studies. ''Otherwise I see no possibility of severe military action this year,'' he said.
A two-day emergency debate in the House of Commons produced a 437-to-35 majority Friday, reflecting a broad consensus of all major parties in support of Mrs. Thatcher's steps in the crisis so far.
Military offensive options - whether a full scale frontal assault on Iraqi forces in and around Kuwait or something more limited, like commando raids in support of Kuwaiti resistance forces inside the annexed country -would be costly and produce human suffering and horror on a scale few in Europe have much stomach for, either in Britain or France.
 
Defensive Posture
''The success of the embargo will produce a settlement of this matter without a war,'' President Francois Mitterrand said in Paris on Friday.
What to do if it fails is a question that has not yet been fully faced, according to British officials. ''The whole posture of the military forces in the gulf is still a defensive one,'' one aide to Mrs. Thatcher said. ''We're a long way from seriously considering a large-scale military operation.''
When they do think about it, many politicians in Europe fear the United States could drag them unwillingly into a war by launching a solo attack against President Hussein's forces in Kuwait or Iraq from aircraft carriers and amphibious attack ships in the gulf. The French Minister of Defense, Jean-Pierre Chevenement, said earlier this week that a war would leave 100,000 dead on both sides.
British officials say the most likely scenario until the full complement of American equipment arrives in and around Saudi Arabia in mid-October is a progressive tightening of the embargo, giving Iraqis not terrorized by President Hussein time to think about whether they would be better off without him.
''I believe an air blockade will be the next step,'' Mr. Bolton said. ''Nations in the area will be strengthened in their right to refuse overflight rights to aircraft running the blockade into Iraq, and then the possibility of international agreement on forcing down or shooting down violators can be considered.''
 
Effects of Human Suffering
But if the blockade is so effective that Iraqi and Kuwaiti civilians or foreign hostages begin to suffer starvation, even some normally hawkish people here wonder how long public support for the embargo would continue.
''I think the United States has handled this extremely well,'' said Dr. John Gilbert, a Labor Party Member of Parliament who has served in high Ministry of Defense posts. But in the House of Commons on Friday he said, ''I am not sure public opinion is going to endorse a situation in which we in the West were trying to starve innocent people.''
Others wonder how long a huge, fully equipped, highly trained military force can remain idle. Dominique Moisi, deputy director of the French Institute on International Relations, said: ''I don't see a continuation of the embargo without some resort to military force. The result would be a Pyrrhic victory for us, which means we would win, but at what cost?''
An undertone in the House of Commons debate was the idea that the danger of conflict will lead the Americans and everybody else to see the necessity of negotiations with President Hussein, though Mrs. Thatcher rejected any suggestion of compromise on the fundamental issues of Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait and restoration of the government there.
 
Two Islands and an Oil Field
''The West really cannot afford to let Saddam Hussein go smiling home with two islands and an oil field in his pocket,'' the British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, said Friday, referring to suggested inducements to get him to withdraw short of war.
But whether the world can tolerate President Hussein in power in Baghdad, in control of chemical weapons he has already used and potentially in possession of nuclear weapons as well, is not a question that is eagerly tackled in Europe.
In the best scenario, if Iraq goes home and President Hussein disappears from the political scene, many wonder whether even that would mean American and British forces would simply go home.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Hussein's Summit Message: Gulf Crisis Is an Arab Issue

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 8

 BODY:
Instead, he demanded that the Persian Gulf crisis be settled along lines he put forward on Aug. 12.
In essence, that proposal would have allowed Iraq to retain Kuwait and its oil fields while the crisis was left to the Arab nations to resolve, and it would also have tied the withdrawal of Iraqi troop from Kuwait to Israel's withdrawal from occupied Arab lands.
''Both of you will not be able to produce the right answer to an Arab issue,'' Mr. Hussein said.
But the message appeared to have been crafted as much with the intention of goading Mr. Gorbachev into rejecting the American hope for a still tougher Soviet stand against Iraq. 
The 53-year-old Mr. Hussein, whose Government signed a friendship treaty with the Kremlin in the 1970's and whose army fights mainly with Soviet weapons, said the Helsinki meeting would demonstrate to the world whether Moscow was finished as a superpower, or was prepared now to make a show of strength and stop playing second fiddle to the United States.
 
Raising Doubts About Moscow
''He who represents the Soviet Union should remember that doubts about the place of the Soviet Union as a superpower have gotten into the mind of every politician in the world for some time now, especially as the U.S. began to assume to be the sole power in the world and when it became arrogant with no one in sight to show it a more balanced course.''
Mr. Hussein added, ''Those concerned should choose this crucial time, through this decisive issue, to restore to the Soviet Union its role by adopting a stand that is in harmony with justice and fairness.'' He defined this as meaning that Moscow should break with the United States and other Western powers, and with the United Nations Security Council, in their demands for an immediate and unconditional Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait.
As for President Bush, Mr. Hussein, who has previously called Mr. Bush ''a liar'' and compared him to Hitler, adopted a somewhat softer line and said that the American leader should abandon his effort to force Iraq from Kuwait for the sake of his own prestige and that of the United States.
While offering no hint that he was prepared to bow before the pressures mounting against him, Mr. Hussein acknowledged in the message that the outcome of the Helsinki meeting could be portentous - for Iraq and the world. The close attention that Baghdad is giving the summit meeting was underscored by the newscast precceding Mr. Hussein's message, which included interviews with Iraqi soldiers in Kuwait. Several of the soldiers denounced the idea of Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev joining to impose a settlement in the gulf crisis.
After opening the message with the standard Muslim greeting to the two leaders, ''peace be upon you,'' Mr. Hussein said that they were ''in a position to decide whatever relates to the future of good or evil for humanity.''
He also spoke of the responsibility of Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev ''to save our region the evil of war, and the ensuing evils,'' and appealed to God to infuse ''the light of faith into your hard hearts so that they will see the paths of righteousness.''
In this, and in many other passages of the message, the Iraqi leader presented himself as a faithful believer and, in his confrontation with the West, as the champion of the world's Muslims. The posture contrasts with Baghdad's harsh suppression of Muslim leaders earlier during Mr. Hussein's 12-year tenure as the ruler of Iraq.
The message also included hints of the shrewd, mocking figure who rose from a motorcycle-borne gunman in the streets of Baghdad to become one of the most powerful and feared leaders in the modern Arab history.
At one point, he referred to Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev as ''masters of the White House and the Kremlin,'' a blunt, even crude break with normal diplomatic usage for communications between heads of state.
 
'Backward and Corrupt Rulers'
The message also spoke of ''the backward and corrupt rulers'' of oil-producing Kuwait and accused them of having ''conspired'' against Iraq, apparently by refusing economic and territorial demands from Baghdad in the period before the invasion.
But as much as anything, the message appeared to be a fresh effort by Mr. Hussein to foment trouble for the majority of Arab leaders who have aligned themselves with the United States and other nations in condemning Iraq. Again, he accused the United States of defiling Muslim holy places in Saudi Arabia by sending troops.
He spoke of those who would ''try to trespass in God's house and in the prophet Mohammed's tomb,'' declaring, ''Whatever cover those trespassers may come under, whatever their justifications are, God will not forgive them.''
Before the message was broadcast, Baghdad television announced a new decree by Mr. Hussein intended to increase Iraq's food production in the face of the United Nations economic sanctions.

HEADLINE: SOUND;
New Audio Equipment In Time for Autumn Nights

BYLINE: By Hans Fantel

 BODY:
To what extent DAT will supplant the immensely popular analog audio cassettes, currently in universal use, won't, of course, be known for years. Immediate prospects for the new medium seem limited by its initial cost and the short supply of equipment.
Even so, this fall's introduction of DAT marks a turning point in home audio. By bringing digital technology to home recording, DAT is bound to delight serious audiophiles, who can now match the sonic quality of CD's with their own homemade tapes. 
The first DAT recorder specifically designed for amateur use to arrive in the United States is Sony's DTC-700, tagged at $900. This price, like the cost of top-rank cassette recorders of the ordinary type, confines its appeal to affluent audiophiles, eager to be the first on the block with the very latest thing. However, as other companies enter the field, prices may drop under competitive pressure, perhaps even before the year's end. As is often the case with new sound equipment, delivery delays may be encountered, and a plentiful supply of DAT recorders may not be available for a few months.
Apropos of dropping prices, the current slump in the economy has prompted the audio industry to pay more attention to budget models. This fall, in an effort to offer good value in low-priced equipment, the industry is putting emphasis on what is known as compact systems.
These are prepackaged, single-brand stereo rigs - usually small enough to fit on a shelf or sideboard - that include everything: a CD player, a tape deck, radio tuner, amplifier and speakers. Nothing further needs be added. Just plug it in and play.
Nobody pretends that these prepackaged mini-components sound like full-size systems. But the best of them come surprisingly close to the performance of their larger counterparts and are well suited for rooms of modest size.
A fine example is Denon's new Cellena System, Model G-05. It combines a CD player, a dual cassette deck (for convenient copying), an AM/FM tuner, a frequency equalizer, two compact speakers with special bass reinforcement devices, and an amplifier rated at 28 watts per channel with no more than 0.005 percent distortion. The Cellena takes up less than 2 cubic feet of space and costs $800.
Similar in concept and general configuration is Yamaha's new Unity System (Model YST-C10), selling for $799. It features a patented circuit that bolsters the bass projection of its bantam speakers.
By far the most elaborate and versatile among the prepackaged mini-systems being introduced is Optonica's CD-U10, priced at $1,300. In addition to all the usual facilities (CD player, radio tuner, tape deck, amplifier and speakers) this system has a built-in ambience synthesizer that can create the impression of large acoustic spaces even in small rooms.
With a single touch, the listener can choose among seven different simulated acoustical environments. Depending on the type of music to be played, these settings can suggest a large hall, a medium-sized hall, an intimate stage, such as might be encountered in a small theater or nightclub, a cathedral, or a front-row seat in a small auditorium.
Trend watchers in audio have noticed that among this fall's new entries the proportion of separate tuners and amplifiers is on the rise. The shift is slight and does not seriously challenge the predominance of receivers, which are a combination of both tuner and amplifier. Such receivers are still the preferred choice in budget systems, mainly because it is cheaper to combine a tuner and an amplifier in a single unit.
Yet for all its economy, the receiver has certain drawbacks. The more powerful it is, the bulkier it becomes. Moreover, at higher power levels, stray electric or magnetic fields from the amplifier may interfere with the function of the tuner. That is why in high-performance systems it is advisable to have tuner and amplifier in separate components.
Now that digital disks place greater demands on the amplifier than was the norm in the LP era, these considerations, relating to higher power levels in amplifiers, are coming to the fore and may explain the gradual trend toward separate amplifiers and tuners.
Among the latest entries of this kind, Proton's 400 system is a clear standout. These distinctively styled components offer advanced technology formerly available only in more expensive models. For example, Proton's proprietary way of supplying reserve power for loudness peaks in the music - such as a sudden fortissimo - permits the AM-455 ($250) amplifier to exceed its nominal 50-watt rating and deliver up to 72 watts per channel.
The matching AT-470 AM/FM tuner ($220) features patented circuitry designed by the renowned radio engineer Larry Schotz. This permits the tuner to perform equally well in rural fringe locations remote from the FM station and in urban environments where signals bouncing off tall buildings often prevent clear reception.
Other interesting newcomers in this group include Onkyo's Integra A-8500, rated at 80 watts and priced at $420. Its matching T-4700 tuner ($450) automatically analyzes the incoming signal. Depending on the strength of a particular station, this tuner then automatically adjusts several internal variables to optimize reception.
Harman-Kardon's exclusive Active Tracking Circuitry will be available this fall in a new digital tuner, the Model TU-9600, priced at $449. This particular circuit helps a listener separate stations that interfere with each other on the FM dial. In the past, this could be done only by compromising a tuner's sensitivity and its sound quality. The Active Tracking Circuitry overcomes these problems.
A whole passel of new loudspeakers are sounding off this fall, but hardly any of them embody basic innovations. A possible exception is MB Quart's new design with its patented new air vent for the woofer enclosure, which helps to keep the motion of the woofer cone under tight control. In this way, speakers achieve uncommon clarity and accuracy of timbre in the lower range. Among the first models of this type to arrive this fall will be MB Quart's 490 MCS, priced at $799 a pair.
It is hard to imagine customers lining up for loudspeakers costing $3,500 a pair. But KEF's new Model 105/3, making its debut this season, is being eagerly awaited. This is because this speaker is the not-so-little brother of KEF's renowned Model 107, which is even more expensive ($4,800 a pair) but has been widely hailed as one of the best speakers ever made. There is a close family resemblance between the two, which makes the new Model 105/3 seem something of a bargain to prosperous perfectionists.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 21, Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1757 words

HEADLINE: DANCE;
Canada's Dance Packs Its Cultural Luggage

BYLINE: By WILLIAM LITTLER; William Littler is dance and music critic of The Toronto Star.

 BODY:
Dance Theater Workshop will also be playing host, beginning Friday, to the phenomenon of ''talking dance'' through ''Affamee,'' by Jo Lechay and Eugene Lion, and in the new year, return visits to New York are in the works for Edouard Lock's La La La Human Steps and the Desrosiers Dance Theater. What has long been called the Unguarded Border is becoming, for Canadian dance, the welcome opportunity.
The opportunity comes at a moment when some doubt attaches to the very future of Canada as a nation. Recent political events, surrounding attempts to respond to the demand of the Province of Quebec for recognition as a ''distinct society,'' have exacerbated regional tensions.
But is it accidental that at the very time these tensions are heightened, Canadian dance appears to be moving into a brigher spotlight? Not, perhaps, if Northrop Frye's description of the regionality of culture is correct and we stop thinking of Canadian dance in national terms. 
In a speech some years ago, Stuart Keate, then publisher of The Vancouver Sun, described Canada as ''the vichyssoise of nations - cold, half-French and difficult to stir.'' It is that, but it is also a nation paradoxically united by its sense of separateness. Canadians have, and like to have, space between them. As sparse inhabitants of the third largest country on earth, they cluster in a few population centers, divided in some cases by distances greater than those associated with the dimensions of other countries.
While this condition has weakened their sense of togetherness, it has strengthened their sense of rootedness to the place in which they live, and no more so than in the Province of Quebec and its cultural metropolis, Montreal. The title the Brooklyn Academy of Music has given its Canadian program is more than geographically correct, it bespeaks spiritual self-sufficiency. When Eduoard Lock was once asked why he, a native Moroccan with artistic debts to American post-modernism and German Expressionism, thought of himself as a representative of the extraordinary kinetic vitality of 1980's and 90's Montreal, he responded simply that he lives and works there. ''There'' matters critically, as a filter through which all imported ideas somehow change in passing.
One of his colleagues, Paul-Andre Fortier, goes even further in attributing the special excitement current in Montreal dance to the limited availability of imported ideas, especially ideas from the English-speaking nation to the south, during the formative years of many of the choreographers now associated with the excitement. With a language barrier to cross, the New York studios of Martha Graham or Merce Cunningham represented elusive destinations for some of these choreographers. And with a limited exposure to techniques from elsewhere, developing their own became the natural thing to do.
Besides, as Mr. Fortier points out, some of the most important of these movers and shakers to be came to dance as adults, too late in their physical development to master some of the established techniques. He himself came from literature (''I finished my literary studies before I did my first plie''), Mr. Lock came from film and Ginette Laurin of O Vertigo Danse from gymnastics. And virtually all of them came spiritually from Quebec.
''Our identity as Quebeckers is a subtext,'' says Mr. Fortier. ''It is the same in film, in theater, in all the arts. The necessity of expressing ourselves as a French group of people gave us wings to create. It is something you can't escape from.'' Not everyone subscribes to the hermetic theory of Quebec creativity. Iro Tembeck, a historian who teaches at the University of Quebec at Montreal and is the author of a forthcoming book on Quebec dance, points to the close contacts that influential teachers of the present generation had with Paris and New York. But even Miss Tembeck acknowledges the current preference for work that is driven by original ideas rather than established techniques; Quebec's choreographers have become shoppers in the supermarket of movement options.
Which is not to say that their work is easy to perform. Indeed, much of it cultivates physical risk. As Dena Davida, artistic director of the Montreal dance space Tangente: Danse Actuelle, puts it: ''These are dangerous times, and the physical risk-taking becomes an emblem in the work of someone like Edouard Lock.''
Miss Davida, in common with other observers of the local scene, sees Mr. Lock and his choreographic contemporaries as essentially apolitical despite their tapping the Zeitgeist. Their inspiration tends to be personal and emotional, ''electrified emotion'' as she describes it.
The emotion is nonetheless fueled by the Zeitgeist in Quebec, which Miss Tembeck believes is an inheritance of a 1948 protest manifesto and the rule-breaking spirit it proclaimed among artists opposed to a society dominated by the Catholic Church.
While Quebec society has become much more open in the intervening years, the rule-breaking spirit, the contempt for tradition and the desire to shock have remained characteristic features of its leading dance artists.
How different this attitude is, save in the work of a Robert Desrosiers, from those shared by leading dance artists in much of the rest of Canada. But then, Mr. Desrosiers, a transplanted Quebecker based in Toronto, represents something of a special case: His imagery confronts viewers with the shock of eccentricity, the product of a bizarre personal imagination rather than a reaction to a societal condition.
Toronto itself has yielded to Montreal the distinction of being ''where the action is.'' As Canada's largest, richest city, it continues to play host to a greater number of performers, but the creative edge cuts deeper in Montreal.
Is it that Toronto's commercial-mindedness has inclined artists there to play safer? Or is it that such Toronto-based choreographers as David Earle (of the Graham-inspired Toronto Dance Theater) and Danny Grossman (formerly of the Paul Taylor Dance Company) address themselves to more traditionally humanistic issues, to content, rather than to the pursuit of stylistic innovation characteristic of Montrealers?
Whatever the case, Toronto, like Montreal, is a center of dance activity rather than the center. There is no counterpart in Canada to New York and the benign tyranny it has imposed on American dance. The energies that activate the movement arts in Montreal differ considerably from those operating in Toronto, which are different again from those in Winnipeg or Vancouver.
When Karen Jamieson of Vancouver turned up at this summer's Canada Dance Festival in Ottawa with a work commissioned to celebrate the National Gallery's landmark exhibition of the paintings and sketches of the British Columbia artist Emily Carr, she did so with a piece of choreography that took possession of the building and entered into dialogue with it, speaking a language of mystery, softness and contemplation, imaginatively as well as geographically thousands of miles distant from the high-impact dance coming out of Montreal.
Traveling so far east represented a relatively rare experience for Ms. Jamieson. The high cost of moving between Canada's major urban centers has only reinforced their particularity. Economics and geography have thus conspired to deprive Canadians of real ownership of their dance heritage. Most of what they see is locally produced.
Northrop Frye might not call this a bad thing. Roots that are local have a chance to grow deep. But this situation does lead to a certain amount of reinventing of the wheel. When critics pointed out a debt to Alwin Nikolais in the design-conscious work of Anna Wyman of Vancouver, for example, she had to point out that at the time she had choreographed the work in question she had yet to see anything by Mr. Nikolais.
Relative isolation is becoming less of a factor in Canadian dance, even in Quebec, with its proudly permanent language barrier. But if geographical distances are shrinking, psychological distance remains. For this reason, as much as for reasons of the country's increasing political Balkanization, the notion of a national dance identity - or a national cultural identity, for that matter - has to be dismissed as so much wishful waving of the Maple Leaf.
This development may come as bad news to cultural institutions such as the Canada Council, which helps support about 30 of the country's 50 or so professional dance companies and tends to view the country as a whole. To the artists themselves, it is a simple fact of life that each, in his or her own way, is a separatist.
''Separatism is not something you can put words to,'' says Paul-Andre Fortier. ''It is not something you think of before doing a work. It is there in the air we breathe.''
Mr. Fortier has recently been breathing the air of Mexico, and, to his surprise, he found people in his audiences understanding some aspects of his work at a deeper level than at home. Audiences, he concludes, are where you find them: ''I'm jumping off a building and either the audience catches you or they don't.''
Canadian choreographers are jumping off many buildings these days. They just aren't waving a flag about it.

PUB-DATE: September 9, 1990

SECTION: Section 2; Page 35, Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 3464 words

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
Why Mozart Has Become an Icon for Today

BYLINE: By RICHARD TARUSKIN; Richard Taruskin is a professor of music at the University of California at Berkeley.

 BODY:
Mozart is so familiar that some performers have been going out of their way to defamiliarize him, whether by updating him or by embalming him in ''historical'' timbres. Those supremely provocative opera productions of Peter Sellars try to have it both ways. The works are updated on the stage, embalmed in the pit - a perfect paradigm of post-modernism, perhaps, and yet another unmasking of the pseudohistoricism of ''Early Music.''
But that sort of approach will probably not be much in evidence in the orgy of veneration at Lincoln Center. Sentimental adoration has been the order of the day for Mozart since time immemorial. Dissenting voices have now and then been raised. ''There are ways to hate Mozart,'' John Cage amiably announced one day (though, disappointingly, he failed to list them). Frederick Delius grumbled, ''If a man tells me he likes Mozart, I know in advance he's a bad musician.'' But such talk is probably just talk, revealing a greater distaste for the cult than for its object. 
For Mozart is our foundation stone, our icon and our pedigree. Celebrating him means celebrating ourselves. In him we see our species transcendent, effortlessly bringing forth what Bernard Shaw called ''the only music yet written that would not sound out of place in the mouth of God.'' From there to actual deification is just a step. ''I love Mozart as the musical Christ,'' wrote Tchaikovsky. ''I do not think this comparison is blasphemous. Mozart was as pure as an angel, and his music is full of divine beauty . . . the culminating point of all beauty in the sphere of music.''
The sheer harmonious perfection of Mozart has given us our notion of musical Eden, sometimes called the ''Classical'' period, an 18th-century fairyland invented by the tortured and hard-working artists of the 19th century, who looked upon Mozart's mythically prodigal powers of spontaneous invention (a myth that has been somewhat debunked by recent scholarship) with a reverence bordering on terror. They invented ''Salieri'' to punish the careless god-child for shaming them but aspired, withal, to his exalted station. The dying Mahler's last word, according to his widow - uttered when he was past hearing surrounding voices, and possibly enjoying the heavenly reception many accounts of borderline death-experience relate - was ''Mozart!''
Until recently, when interest in Mozart suddenly exploded as a result of commercial theatrical and cinematic exploitation, a taste for Mozart was a connoisseur's taste - ''a mark of caste,'' to quote Shaw again. For many, Mozart was and is problematic. Within his lifetime, Mozart's music was thought brash, overspiced and too complicated for the average listener. (''Too many notes, my dear Mozart,'' said the Emperor.) In the 19th century, a cult of Mozart sprang up among the literary - not, for the most part, among musicians - that emphasized his violence, his sensuality and his power to subvert.
 
Deeper Meanings:
Disintegration And Malaise?
In his celebrated book ''The Classical Style,'' Charles Rosen has revived this strain of Romantic Mozart worship, insisting eloquently that Mozart's music ''cannot be fully appreciated . . . without re-creating in our own minds the conditions in which it could still seem dangerous.'' Some readers may also recall Virgil Thomson's once famous piece ''Mozart's Leftism,'' in which Mozart's true liberalism (understated, between-the-lines, to be discerned by the discerning) was contrasted with the overtly proclaimed populism of Beethoven, ''an old fraud who just talked about human rights and dignity but who was really an irascible, intolerant, and scheming careerist.''
More recently, radical critics like Rose Rosengard Subotnik and Susan McClary have suggested that some of Mozart's later music carries the seeds of disintegration - stylistic, psychological, even social. This shocking message can be found, they argue, not just in the operas that inspired Romantic thinkers like E. T. A. Hoffmann or Soren Kierkegaard with their idea of Mozart's ''demon,'' but in instrumental works as well. And what shocked Mozart's more sensitive contemporaries may shock us, too, if we're still sensitive.
In the last three symphonies, Ms. Subotnik discerns (for the first time in music) evidence of a ''critical world view,'' meaning a sense of reality that is no longer fully supported by social norms, but must be personally constructed and defended. The high level of unsettling chromaticism in these works (traditionally symbolic of the irrational), their tendency to unify movements by means of shared forms or melodic motives (deliberately shoring up coherence in a way that implies a threat to it) and the calculated disruptions in the musical continuity, she argues, add up to an unprecedented portrayal of a mind under stress. Mozart, for her, is the first composer who suffers as we do from the malaise of modernity.
Ms. McClary, concentrating on the concertos, finds evidence of social alienation in the relationship between the soloist and the accompanying group. In a close technical reading of the slow movement of the G-major Piano Concerto (K. 453), she finds the orchestra to be no simple accompanist but an antagonist that dominates and ultimately crushes the individual (soloist), whose personal needs are ''blatantly sacrificed to the overpowering requirements of social convention.'' She finds a special bitterness in the movement's ''harmonious closure,'' for the harmony masks repression.
To continue to uphold Mozart as the embodiment of ''pure order,'' Ms. McClary concludes, is really to uphold ''an icon of the old cultural order for purposes of warding off - or at least institutionally marginalizing - the increasingly successful encroachments of new, previously disenfranchised producers (ethnic minorities, members of the working class, women) and forms of culture.'' Ms. McClary invites us to identify with Mozart as their representative.
There can be no denying the relevance of such a view to the sorry life Mozart ended up leading in the real world. (The life he was privileged to lead in his creative imagination is of course a closed book to us, though we sometimes like to pretend his manuscripts and sketches give us access to it.) Ms. McClary's characterization of her pianist-protagonist - self-dramatizing, exhibitionistic, maladjusted - chimes with, and may well be influenced by, the unvarnished (or devarnished) Mozart portrait that has emerged of late from revisionist biographies like that of Wolfgang Hildesheimer, now a dozen years old. (Since Hildesheimer, demystification has progressed apace; medical historians now confidently pronounce the idyllic god-child to have been an obsessional, anal-fixated, paranoiac personality - in a word, infantile, meaning anything but childlike.) It is always a question how far we are justified in reading an artist's work in terms of his life; and Ms. McClary's work carries the further burden, insofar as the musical and academic establishments are concerned, of an explicit political agenda. Still, her voice, and Ms. Subotnik's, have been heard.
Neal Zaslaw, adviser and scholar-in-residence to Lincoln Center's bicentennial festivities, and nobody's idea of a scholarly maverick, ends his just-published, grandly conceived and executed survey, ''Mozart's Symphonies: Context, Performance Practice, Reception'' (Oxford University Press), with a searching consideration along similar lines of the ''Jupiter'' Symphony finale, concluding that it ''perhaps gives us a glimpse of Mozart's dreaming of escaping his oppressive past and giving utterance to his fondest hopes and highest aspirations of the future'' - by which we are to understand everyone's past and everyone's future. There seems to be an increasing awareness - though it is definitely a minority awareness - that at its highest and best, Mozart's music embodies not only beautiful sounds but profound and sometimes terrible meanings.
 
Music for Use: Contexts Lost And Changed
 So maybe it was not just out of laziness or incomprehension that audiences used to have a very selective relationship with Mozart's vast output. Maybe they had a notion of what was highest and best in it, and what kind of messages they wished to derive from it. Three operas, a half-dozen symphonies, a few concertos and a handful of chamber and keyboard works - with greatly disproportionate emphasis on the works in minor keys, of which Mozart actually wrote very few: these used to constitute the active Mozart repertory, with the rest relegated to secondary categories of ''historical interest,'' if not oblivion.
As early as 1799, a reviewer, after acknowledging Mozart's supreme genius, remarked of a quartet of early Mozart symphonies, just published for the first time, ''it does not follow that everything of the sort that Mozart wrote is worth preserving, nor does it follow that after his death people should without exception collect and publish everything he wrote, especially in his younger years.''
Wrong, says Mr. Zaslaw, who in his recent book is quick to turn around (inconsistently, it could seem, in light of his remarks on the ''Jupiter'' finale) and warn that such strictures are founded on a fundamental error. The reviewer, he alleges, was guilty of ''confusing the general change in symphonic style between c. 1774 and 1799 with Mozart's personal development as a composer.'' It's not Mozart's fault, in other words, if his earlier works seem superficial to listeners who know his later ones - and it's not fair of us to entertain a preference.
Moreover, Mr. Zaslaw argues, modern notions of what art is all about are anachronistic to most of Mozart's work, and irrelevant to its evaluation. The ''fundamental thesis'' of his book is that ''Mozart's symphonies, far from being 'art for art's sake,' were Gebrauchsmusik - music for use, functional music - which, when divorced from its original setting, loses some of its meaning.'' His mission, carried out with gusto and erudition, has been to restore a sense of the original context to Mozart's work, thereby to recover the lost meaning - and thereby, too, willy-nilly to inhibit contemporary judgment.
Laudable as it is from the standpoint of ''disinterested'' scholarship, the enterprise is open to question as criticism. It rests on the implicit assumption, still regnant in the musical academy, that the meaning of an artwork is complete at the time of creation, and that the passage of time entails nothing but loss of meaning. Tradition, in this view, is only noise and distortion, a cosmic game of ''telephone.''
Another view is possible. Contexts, it may be argued, are not simply lost but changed. The venues and social milieus in which Mozart symphonies are now ''used'' - the concert hall, the stereo-equipped home or automobile - are inescapably different from those the works inhabited when new (theaters, churches, aristocratic soirees). Change of context adds as much meaning as it may take away.
This applies to apprehension as well as to consumption. For us today, ''Don Giovanni,'' say, is not just the opera Mozart and da Ponte knew, bearing only the meanings it had for them and for the audience that greeted it in Prague two centuries ago. ''Don Giovanni'' is also something E. T. A. Hoffmann has known and construed, and Kierkegaard, and Charles Rosen, and Peter Sellars. Its meaning for us is mediated by all that has been thought and said about it since opening night, and is therefore incomparably richer than it was in 1787. Reconstruction of the original meaning, assuming it could be recaptured pure, should add its valuable mite to the pile, but cannot replace it. For that, were it possible, would be an impoverishment.
Such a position, alas, is not fashionable in our age of Authenticity. Judge Bork, rejected by the United States Senate, seems to have found a haven in the musical-intellectual community. Approach things for what they are (that is, were), we are enjoined, and judge them not. Enjoy. Uncritical acceptance of the past (coupled - it could scarcely be by coincidence - with an ultracritical reception of the present) is now the rule.
We tend to despise those who have been picky in the face of Mozart's cornucopia. It is with no little self-congratulation that some critics have celebrated the indiscriminateness of what is now considered enlightened taste, and in particular the abandonment of any ethical dimension to artistic judgment. (See what happens now if you voice any principled objection to the cruel and cynical ''Cosi Fan Tutte.'') Yet respect it or not, the Romantics, who - mindlessly, we are told - valued in Mozart only their own reflection, definitely had a criterion. Do we? Intransigence, which (when coupled with passion) is what lends all authority to criticism, is on the wane. The recent revised edition of Joseph Kerman's classically crusty ''Opera as Drama'' now makes room for Mozart's ''Idomeneo.'' Not that there is anything wrong with ''Idomeneo'' (that is, with its inspired music), but including it considerably softens the book's curmudgeonly old thesis (advanced pointedly against a ''flabby relativism'' that holds everything to be ''all right on its own terms'') that opera lost its dramatic way after Purcell and did not recover it till Mozart met up with da Ponte. Now we read, ''most of us would rather have notes by Mozart than drama by any one else,'' and ''what gives 'Idomeneo' a certain haunting power as drama,'' despite its problems, ''is its basic subject matter.''
So, flabby or firm, relativism is on the rise, and musicology, always a great omnivore, has been its accomplice.
 
The 80's Ideal: Attention K. Mart Shoppers
 But there is something else, too, behind our plan to put the Kochel catalogue on parade, something 80's-ish and ugly. The demystification of Mozart, which began in earnest, and in honest if somewhat reckless fashion with Mr. Hildesheimer's biography, turned dishonest and trivializing and vastly remystifying with ''Amadoose'' (which is how you must pronounce it at the video store). The careless god-child of Romantic legend has become the braying ass of ours, glorified in the popular imagination as a boorish bumpkin who was ''good at what he does,'' a cynical Gladstone Gander, gifted and successful far beyond his moral deserts - and to be loved for it. That, it gives pain to acknowledge, is our current Mozartean self-reflection. Our musical Christ has turned yuppie. Accordingly, it is as the object - the symbol, even - of conspicuous musical consumption that he has at last become popular in the decade now ending. There is something dismally authentic about this, to be sure. The ideal (if that is the word) of conspicuous consumption was what motivated 18th-century aristocratic patronage of the arts. Some economic historians, for whom it symbolizes decadence, call it ''quantitative luxury,'' and it is to be thanked or blamed for all the reams of faceless ''Gebrauchsmusik'' that have come down to us from Mozart's time.
Mozart consumption today, far more than at any time past including his own, is undeniably a matter of quantitative luxury, and his masterworks have indeed begun to recede into the faceless mass (or haven't you tuned in lately to FM?). More records of Mozart are now issued and bought than of any other composer, as a glance at the bimonthly listings in Fanfare magazine will quickly confirm. Philips Records, like Lincoln Center, has announced a complete Mozart for sale. Record clubs now offer him as their primary (if still relatively infinitesimal) ''classical'' inducement. As little as 10 years ago, it was not so.
This last bit of intelligence comes from an editorial in the latest issue of 19th-Century Music, the toniest of all academic music journals. The editors go on to ruminate that Mozart is ''the 1980's' not-so-secret code word - as in 'Mostly Mozart' - for user-friendly classical music, their paradigm of Old-Age-New-Age music if not their very metonymy for nonthreatening sound tout court.'' Take that, Mr. Rosen, Ms. Subotnik.
But it's hard to disagree with the diagnosis. And in that light, it's hard not to see in Lincoln Center's bicentennial gourmandizing a musical Trump Tower, less a Mozart-fest than a K. Mart (as in Kochel, the numbers man). Somehow it doesn't seem much of a celebration anymore.
 
The Prognosis: Greater Fluency, Less Commitment?
 On the brighter side, there have lately been some solid strides in Mozartean performance practice. Admirable research continues, the latest notable contributions being those of Mr. Zaslaw on matters of orchestral execution, William Malloch on minuets (play them faster!), Jean-Pierre Marty on tempos (standardize them!), Hugh Macdonald on repeats (observe them!), Will Crutchfield on appoggiaturas (add them!), David Grayson on instrumental embellishment (go to town!).
Predictably, ''historical'' performers have been quickest to adopt the recommendations that entail the least creativity (Mr. Crutchfield and Mr. Grayson in particular have been getting a lot of backtalk), though the pianist Robert Levin's astonishing yeoman work in the concertos (yes, he improvises his cadenzas) will no doubt inspire rivalry ere long, much to everyone's benefit.
On the more ordinary level of scrupulous text-rendition, Mozart performance on period instruments becomes more mellifluent and convincing year by year. The viability of the fortepiano is no longer at issue, thanks to the work of Malcolm Bilson, Melvyn Tan, Steven Lubin, Penelope Crawford and others. Mr. Lubin's chamber group, the Mozartean Players, is setting a high standard in the very difficult medium of keyboard plus strings.
And then there are the period orchestras, permanently established by now in Boston, New York, Washington, San Francisco, Ann Arbor, Toronto and other North American cities (if we may parochially ignore England and the European continent for the moment). Because of all this specialist activity, everyone, it seems, is playing Mozart with a new fluency these days, whatever the make or model of their instruments.
But (to end this jeremiad with a proper caveat) if we no longer care what we play, does it matter how we play it? Is the coolness that is so essential a part of our enlightened ''historical'' performance style a true reflection of history, or is it, like the wholesale consumption of the Kochel catalogue, a mark of lessened commitment?
Laurence Dreyfus, a Bach scholar and viola da gambist who is at the forefront of historical performance today, is troubled by the latter possibility. Why, he asked aloud at the recent Berkeley Festival and Exhibition ''Music in History,'' must one ''continue to turn to the remastered recordings from 60 years ago in order to experience the passionate rapture that accompanies a musician engaged wholly with the artwork?'' What is missing, he contends, ''is the insight that the giants of our pantheon are great to the extent that they learn to represent the depths of melancholy, and melancholy, as Kant recognized, was a kind of secret key to the sublime.''
This comes very close to the Subotnik-McClary position on what made Mozart Kant's greatest musical contemporary. It's not something we are likely to recapture by turning him back into a purveyor of ''functional music.''

SECTION: Section 3; Page 12, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1160 words

HEADLINE: The Executive Computer;
Can Invaders Be Stopped but Civil Liberties Upheld?

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
For example, is a company vulnerable to legal action, or the seizure of its computer equipment and data, if a single employee is accused of using a home computer to capture or store unauthorized data? Do private messages sent on an electronic mail system have the same protection as messages sent through the Postal Service? Is the concept of property valid in a world where data can be copied and replicated without limits and without disturbing the original data?
To stimulate discussion of such questions, a group called the Electronic Frontier Foundation has been formed by several prominent computer industry figures, including Mitchell D. Kapor, the founder of the Lotus Development Corporation and On Technology Inc., and Stephen Wozniak, a founder of Apple Computer Inc. It plans to lobby for laws that clarify computer and telecommunications issues and to help pay the legal costs of some computer users caught up in the crackdown.
Mr. Wozniak, Mr. Kapor and a Silicon Valley entrepreneur who preferred to remain anonymous also recently gave a $275,000 grant to another organization, Computer Professionals for Social Responsibility, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif. Gary Chapman, the group's executive director, said the money would be used to expand its public advocacy efforts on behalf of civil liberties in the world of computing. 
One of first places the Electronic Frontier Foundation decided to help out was the case of Steve Jackson Games of Austin, Tex., a company that designs and publishes role-playing games. It is not a computer or software company; its games are published in book form and are played by rolling dice.
On March 1, Secret Service agents armed with a search warrant raided the company's offices and confiscated three computer systems, two laser printers, miscellaneous hardware and papers. They took the data in the computers, including backup disks.
Steve Jackson, the founder of the company, said the agents refused to say why they were there, what they were looking for or when the seized equipment and data might be returned. No charges have been filed in the case, and no official explanations have been offered. William J. Cook, an assistant United States attorney who coordinated the search, said in response to a journalist's question last month, ''There is no indication that Steve Jackson Games is a target of the operation,'' but he and the Secret Service declined to say what officials were searching for.
Yet, for months, Steve Jackson Games could not ship new products and had to lay off 8 of its 17 employees, Mr. Jackson said. The company, which had annual revenues of about $1.4 million, nearly failed, he said. Most of the hardware has been returned, Mr. Jackson said, although some of it was damaged beyond repair. The Electronic Frontier Foundation has hired a lawyer for him to seek the return of the rest of the equipment and documents, as well as an explanation for the seizure.
Hours before the raid on the company, Secret Service agents visited the home office of Loyd Blankenship, a 25-year-old writer who works for Steve Jackson Games, and confiscated computer hardware, software and data. Mr. Blankenship has not been charged with a crime, but his equipment and data have not been returned. Mr. Blankenship did not respond to a request for an interview for this article.
Mr. Jackson said Mr. Blankenship had been using his computer as a word processor to write a role-playing game called ''Gurps Cyberpunk.'' In the game, players can adopt hundreds of identities, including those of hackers. As part of the manual for players, Mr. Blankenship gave a brief but realistic description of computer networks and security systems. ''Adventurers may want to break into a computer system,'' Mr. Blankenship wrote, ''usually to steal, alter or destroy information, although they will occasionally just want to have a look around (or to prove they can do it in the first place).''
Mr. Jackson acknowledged that he knew Mr. Blankenship was a skilled computer user who had been in touch with a group of hackers called ''the Legion of Doom.'' Other members of the legion have been targets of Secret Service raids coordinated under the name ''Operation Sun Devil.'' Federal officials said the raid on Steve Jackson Games was not part of Operation Sun Devil.
''Any employer who heard this tale will think hard before he hires a computer cracker,'' said John Perry Barlow, another principal in the Electronic Frontier Foundation, ''which may be, of course, among the effects the Secret Service desires.''
Operation Sun Devil, conducted by Federal agents in more than a dozen cities, has resulted in the seizures of at least 40 computers and immeasurable amounts of data. Some suspects said their doors were broken down with sledgehammers, their wives and children held at gunpoint. Officials involved in the operations have declined to comment on such accusations other than to say the investigations are continuing.
Operation Sun Devil is ''seriously misdirected,'' said Mr. Chapman of Computer Professionals for Social Responsibility. ''Most computer crime is carried out by insiders within large companies. White-collar crime accounts for most of the economic loss, not teen-agers with personal computers. And yet society has developed such an intense fear of new technologies beyond its understanding that it is willing to suspend the rights of any computer user who might be caught up in a wholesale sweep.''
Mr. Cook also brought an indictment against Craig Neidorf, a 20-year-old college student who published an electronic newsletter. It included a document, from a contributor, that had been stolen from a Bellsouth Corporation computer. It described the 911 emergency phone system in Bellsouth's region. Bellsouth said the eight-page document was valued at $79,449. Mr. Neidorf, who said he did not know it was stolen, was charged with wire fraud and transporting stolen documents over state lines.
The charges were subsequently dismissed when it was pointed out that Bellsouth included the same document in a booklet that was sold to the public for $13.
