HEADLINE: Inside the Nation's Best-Run S.&L.

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif.

 BODY:
''Golden West is one of the best financial firms in the country, period,'' said Peter Treadway, an analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.
There has not been much good news from the savings and loan industry for the past five years. Hundreds of institutions have collapsed and hundreds more are in danger of failure, victims of regional economic downturns, poor management and outright fraud. The cost to taxpayers will reach into the hundreds of billions of dollars. Industry executives are widely viewed as incompetent or criminal, and all too often the stereotype is true.
But a significant portion of the industry has always remained profitable and honest. The Sandlers, for example, are conservative, methodical, penny-pinching and risk-averse in the extreme - and they have spent nearly three decades shaping Golden West, now the nation's sixth-largest savings and loan, in their image. The antithesis of the high-rollers attracted to the industry by deregulation, they remain downright boring - and proudly so. 
 
An Appetite for Calm
 ''Perhaps we can best characterize Golden West's attitude toward lending by simply saying that your management likes to sleep undisturbed by worries and nightmares,'' the Sandlers wrote in a letter to shareholders in their most recent annual report.
The Sandlers use all the techniques of modern financial management, paying especially close attention to cost control. But the core of their business is decidedly - some might say refreshingly - old-fashioned: The company lends out Federally insured deposits almost exclusively in the form of home mortgage loans, forgoing potentially more lucrative but far riskier loans and direct investments in shopping centers, office buildings and other commercial real estate. Of the 27,436 loans it made last year, 93 percent went to single-family homes and virtually all of the rest to multi-unit residential housing.
It does this through a network that seems almost anachronistic in this age of one-stop financial shopping. It has 205 branches in California and five other states and operates 65 loan offices in 16 states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
For the most part, the branches accept only savings deposits, eschewing the business of offering checking and other ''transaction'' accounts that might attract more customers but are far more expensive to maintain. To keep costs low, the company does not even have automated teller machines, almost certainly making it the largest financial institution in the nation not to offer that service. Most of its customers are old-fashioned savers, who patiently deposit their funds in return for competitive interest rates. ''They've identified their customer and the services the customer wants, and they don't provide anything else,'' Mr. Treadway said. ''They have tremendous control of expenses.'' As archaic as the strategy might seem, it has worked. Golden West's earnings have been consistently strong at a time when the industry as a whole has been running up huge losses. The company's shares are worth 10 times what they were at the beginning of the 1980's. It has almost no bad loans.
Even as most other institutions scramble to raise more capital to meet the Government's tougher new standards for financial strength, Golden West is in the enviable position of having far more capital than regulations require. Unlike most savings and loans, Golden West has also been able to raise new capital in the financial markets in recent months, completing two subordinated debt offerings totaling $215 million.
As a result, it is one of the few institutions with the capability of expanding, either by acquisition or internal growth. In May, for example, the company acquired from the Government the $725 million in deposits held by a failed savings institution in Colorado, already its second-largest market after California. And just last week, the company completed the acquisition of Community Federal Savings and Loan in Ramsey, N.J. Community Federal, with six branches and assets of $460 million, gives Golden West its first deposit-taking offices in the Northeast.
 
The Partnership
 The Sandlers have been running Golden West together since acquiring it for $4.1 million in 1963, when it had $34 million in assets. They took it public in 1968, and today, assets have grown to $20 billion.
Mr. Sandler, 58 years old, is a former New York lawyer who serves as chairman and co-chief executive and, in his three-piece suit, looks very much the old-fashioned banker. Mrs. Sandler, 59, learned about the industry as a securities analyst on Wall Street. She holds the titles of co-chief executive and president. The two finish each others' sentences, prompt each other to tell favorite stories and appear to have long since worked out whatever problems might have cropped up in the marriage of their personal and business lives.
''You know that old saying about it being lonely at the top?'' asked Mr. Sandler. ''Well, it's not here.''
Moreover, they are clearly enjoying the vindication of their cautious approach after having been roundly criticized by Wall Street for not being aggressive enough and disparaged by competitors for running something of a dinosaur. ''Over 20 years, running the institution in our fashion, through all the turmoil that's taken place, our compound annual rate of growth and earnings is 20 percent,'' said Mr. Sandler, ticking off the kind of statistic that has turned Golden West into a current favorite among stock analysts. ''To my knowledge, no bank or thrift has done that.''
Yet the Sandlers still face questions about whether their approach can continue to work in an age of full-service banking. Most of Golden West's major competitors - including its two biggest rivals, H. F. Ahmanson & Company of Los Angeles and the Great Western Financial Company of Beverly Hills - are positioning themselves to compete directly with commercial banks.
Believing that the distinctions between banks and savings and loans will continue to disappear in coming years, both Ahmanson and Great Western are pushing to get more transaction accounts from customers. Great Western offers consumer loans and other services that were once the exclusive province of banks.
''Golden West is very strong for what it attempts to do, but that's not the only route to success as the banking and thrift worlds come together,'' said Bert Ely, an industry consultant in Alexandria, Va. ''The thing I worry about is that while their strategy certainly works today, it may not work five years from now.''
 
Looking at Change
 The Sandlers say they have nothing against change. After Congress and the state legislatures deregulated the industry during the early 1980's, ''We researched discount brokerage,'' said Mr. Sandler. ''We just couldn't figure out how to make money in it. Everyone else got into it, and a few years later they were all getting out.''
Now, Mr. Sandler said, the company is studying the possibility of offering traditional checking and other transaction accounts. ''We're going to analyze it, and if there's a role for it, we'll go ahead with it,'' he said.
Still, the Sandlers freely admit that they see no advantage to plunging into new businesses just to be trendy or to match the competition.
Golden West's most clearly visible advantage is its low operating costs. The company's general and administrative expenses last year - the cost of running the company - were $181.8 million, or 0.97 percent of total assets, down from 1.14 percent the year before. That compares to 1.57 percent of assets on average last year for the 10 other largest savings and loan companies in California.
If the company's expense ratio had been the same as that of its competitors, its earnings last year would have been $86.5 million, or $1.37 a share, instead of its actual profits of $157.9 million, or $2.51 a share. In this year's second quarter, Golden West earned $49 million, or 78 cents a share, a 22 percent increase over the same period in 1989.
The greater profit margin gives the company more flexibility in deciding how many new loans to make - and therefore it may say no to riskier loans that other institutions might consider as they try to generate higher earnings.
''Because we're such a profitable company, we can operate well with a lower volume,'' Mrs. Sandler said. ''We don't have a high-fixed-overhead loan machine that we have to feed continually.''
The company's cost advantage comes from many things, large and small. It does not have the expense of installing and maintaining automated teller machines nor the costs involved in traditional checking accounts, which require expensive check-processing equipment, data bases and manpower. Cost-consciousness is so ingrained that branch managers charge executives visiting from headquarters for the phone calls they make from the branch.
The company also studies the work load in its branches and has an hour-by-hour and day-by-day model for each staffing requirement. Of the 1,050 employees who work in its branches, more than 500 are on permanent part-time status, keeping payroll costs low. The company has something of a reputation for stinginess and has never invested much in the appearance of its branches.
 
A Modest Look
''Their branches are - I wouldn't call them low rent, because that would be unfair,'' said Eric I. Hemel, an analyst at the First Boston Corporation. ''They're streamlined. They're smaller and more Spartan. They're a visual metaphor for the entire company.'' Just as important to Golden West's success as cost-cutting is the high quality of its loan portfolio, a result, to some extent, of its almost total concentration on home mortgage lending. Borrowers, after all, are less likely to default on their mortgages than on any other type of loan.
And even within the field of mortgage lending, Golden West stands out. Last year, an impressive 93 percent of its residential loans were made with downpayments of 20 percent or more, considerably higher than the industry average. The result has been to keep the number of bad loans to a minuscule five-tenths of 1 percent of total loans last year.
 
Just Say No
 How do they do this? The Sandlers point to a deeply ingrained corporate culture, which holds that there is no shame for a loan officer to say no. Indeed, when in two periods in the last decade economic conditions or intense competition suggested that they would have to lower credit standards to attract borrowers, they instead virtually swore off making new loans, even at the cost of not growing for a year or two.
''We were damned by Wall Street,'' Mrs. Sandler said. ''When you have zero loan growth for two years, you really feel the heat.''
But by retaining earnings at a time when it was not growing in asset size, Golden West improved its underlying financial strength.
The strategy paid off when Congress, in legislation passed last year to bail out and reform the industry, substantially increased capital requirements.
Today, as one of the few institutions whose capital levels greatly exceed all three of the Government's new minimum tests for financial strength, Golden West has options closed to most institutions. Chief among them is the ability to grow.
Many analysts think the company's next big move will be in Florida, where it holds an option to acquire Beach Federal Savings, a failed institution in Boynton Beach owned by the Government.
But whatever Golden West does - and however it chooses to adapt to growing competition from banks and to the always changing regulatory climate - as long as the Sandlers stay in charge, it is certain to remain conservative, even dull. ''We have a jewel of a company,'' Mrs. Sandler said, ''and we're not about to do anything to jeopardize it.''
 
THE SANDLERS, SIDE BY SIDE
OAKLAND, Calif.
It is not always easy for Herb and Marion Sandler to be husband and wife as well as co-chief executives. They will occasionally be at a dinner party or business gathering when the men and women drift into separate groups. ''The wives gather here and the gentlemen gather there, and I want to be over there where Herb is talking about business,'' Mrs. Sandler said. ''It can be a little awkward.''
But aside from that type of situation, the Sandlers say they have almost no problems working alongside each other. ''If we came at things differently all the time, it would be impossible, but that's true for any executives working closely together, not just husbands and wives,'' Mrs. Sandler said. After graduating from City College of New York and Columbia University Law School, Mr. Sandler became a lawyer and represented a number of savings institutions. Mrs. Sandler, after graduating from Harvard and New York University's business school, worked as a securities analyst, following the stocks of savings and loan companies. After their marriage, in 1961, they talked constantly about how they were unimpressed by the quality of the management running most savings institutions. Finally, deciding to see if they could do better, they moved to the West Coast from New York to scout small savings institutions that might be takeover candidates. In 1963, they made a deal for Golden West.
Today, they work in adjacent offices and are in and out of meetings together all day. And although it's clear that they run the company, they stress repeatedly how much they rely on the two other members of their office of the chairman - James T. Judd, 51 years old, and Russell W. Kettell, 46, both senior executive vice presidents. ''This isn't the Herb and Marion show,'' Mr. Sandler said. Although they are not planning on retiring any time soon, the Sandlers have a succession plan in place, in case of the unexpected. Mr. Judd and Mr. Kettell are at the top of the list. ''We call it the Mack Truck question,'' Mr. Sandler said. ''We all have backups ready to go in case something happens. The idea of somebody being indispensable is anathema to corporate governance.''
 
THE SEATTLE STAR
When listing the nation's best-managed savings institutions, analysts usually mention a handful of other large California-based companies in addition to Golden West, including the Great Western Financial Corporation of Beverly Hills and H. F. Ahmanson & Company of Los Angeles.
But there are also small, little-known institutions like the Washington Federal Savings and Loan Association of Seattle - ''arguably the stellar performer - pound for pound, inch for inch - of the nation's savings institution industry,'' according to Eric I. Hemel, an analyst at the First Boston Corporation.
Washington Federal has $2.6 billion in assets and 65 branches in Washington, Oregon and Idaho. It is perhaps the strongest company in the industry as measured by its capital reserves.
Unlike most other institutions, Washington Federal continues to make mostly fixed-rate instead of adjustable-rate mortgages. Fixed-rate mortgages can be riskier than adjustables for savings institutions because they become less profitable if interest rates rise.
Elliot Knutson, Washington Federal's chairman, said he has never been worried. ''We've been profitable every month for 30 years,'' he said. ''If you keep your costs low enough and your people are good enough and your capitalization is strong enough, you can keep the risks low.''

HEADLINE: Trading Safety for Better Car Mileage

 BODY:
He didn't even mention the adverse effects of such standards on automobile safety. The fact is, tougher Federal fuel economy standards mean trading lives for oil. 
Given present technology, auto manufacturers would have to make smaller cars to meet tougher fuel standards. Why? Because most other approaches to saving energy - front-wheel drive, using lighter materials - have been taken; so downsizing is one of the few options left. The problem is that smaller cars mean more occupant deaths and injuries. For every 10,000 registered cars one to three years old in 1989, 3.0 deaths occurred in the smallest cars on the road compared with 1.3 in the largest.
This is not to say we should ignore America's dangerous dependence on foreign oil. It's not to say we don't need fuel economy standards, either. But instead of enacting laws that encourage smaller cars, why not think about auto safety and oil conservation together and work toward safety-compatible fuel economy alternatives? For example, why not limit cars' top speeds? Because of engine improvements, newer cars achieve much more power per unit of engine displacement. But this advancement isn't being used entirely for improving fuel economy. A large part is being used for improving acceleration and, in some cases, for increasing top speeds. Current technology does allow for electronic speed controls without any adverse effect on acceleration at slower speeds.
 
BRIAN O'NEILL,
President
Insurance Institute for Highway Safety
Arlington, Va., Aug. 28

HEADLINE: Austria's Clandestine Workers

BYLINE: By BRENDA FOWLER

DATELINE: VIENNA

 BODY:
The street-corner black market for workers here is another sign of the economic upheaval in Eastern Europe and its spillover effects on the region's Western neighbors. Tens of thousands of East Europeans have streamed into Austria recently to work illegally, according to police statistics, Government officials and economists. Most are temporary employees, who work in Austria for a few months for the comparatively high wages and then return home, much as illegal Mexican workers in the United States do. At home, even low-paying jobs are dwindling as Eastern nations making the rocky transition to market-driven systems experience higher unemployment and more business failures.
In Austria, the so-called clandestine workers from Eastern Europe have been both welcomed and shunned. For companies in industries like construction and tourism, the illegal workers have been a low-cost source of badly needed labor. 
Yet the growing number of Eastern Europeans who work and live in Austria illegally is a source of mounting political concern and social conflict in a small nation that borders the East and whose unemployment rate, though low at 5.2 percent, is rising. Estimates of the number of clandestine workers in Austria are necessarily imprecise, ranging from 40,000 to 140,000. But in a country with a population of seven-and-a-half million and a labor force of only three million, the strain is starting to show. Spurred by reports of rising crime and worries about foreigners taking jobs from Austrians, the Socialist-led Government imposed last week a visa requirement for Poles, who it says make up the majority of new illegal workers. At the same time it decided to send soldiers to patrol part of the border with Hungary, across which as many as 200 Eastern Europeans - mostly Romanians - have been crossing illegally each day.
The strict measures brought cries of outrage from some in Austria who said the country was trying to reconstruct the Iron Curtain. But what worries officials and politicians, who face elections next month, are recent statistics. While the number of people employed in August was 2.3 percent higher than in August 1989, unemployment has nevertheless increased slightly, to 5.2 percent, considered high in Austria. This may be a sign that employers are passing over native workers for the cheaper foreign labor, said Jan Stankowsky, an economist at the Austrian Institute for Economic Research.
Ingrid Nowotny, head of the foreign labor department at the Ministry for Social Affairs and Labor, observed, ''Compared to other countries, the problem of clandestine labor hardly existed here two years ago.''
Austria, to be sure, is not the only country absorbing a wave of Eastern Europeans eager for work in the West. Hungarians, Romanians and Poles are also pouring into Berlin in anticipation of German reunification, said Guy Standing, coordinator of labor market research at the International Labor Organization in Geneva. Officials from Norway told Mr. Standing that as many as 35,000 Poles entered their country - most illegally - this summer to work.
But tiny Austria, which has borders with Yugoslavia, Hungary and Czechoslovakia, is an easy first stop for many East Europeans whose home economies are getting worse. Czechs, Slovaks, Yugoslavs, Hungarians and, until last week, Poles, may enter Austria without visas. Once in the country, many easily find work.
''If you're here, then you're going to get work,'' said Anna Stefaniak, a Pole who has worked illegally in a variety of positions since arriving in Austria six months ago.
They do have to put up with long hours and pay which, while many times higher than in the former socialist countries, is poor by Austrian standards. Miss Stefaniak, who comes from eastern Poland, said most people earn from $4.50 to $7.25 an hour, a fortune compared with Polish wages. With such incomes, many Poles work for a few months in Austria and then return home.
''Austria's system encourages the use of migrational workers since these sorts of workers are likely to receive low wages and no official benefits, and in Austria the benefits are a big percentage of labor costs,'' Mr. Standing said.
Some officials here said recent policies that restricted the number of work permits given to foreign workers in a time of fairly robust economic growth only made the problem of clandestine workers worse.
''So many firms were pressed into illegality because they couldn't get official permits for the employment of foreigners,'' said Martin Mayr, director of the social policy department at the federal Chamber of Commerce.
Still, according to Gudrun Biffl, a labor expert at the Austrian Institute for Economic Research, there are now signs that the increase in the number of foreign workers - both legal and illegal - is starting to have an effect on the weakest members of Austria's labor force: the elderly and single women with children.
''How can you rationalize letting in foreign workers to the extent that your own people are getting sacked?'' she asked.
Though employment of foreigners who don't have a work permit is illegal, it has been tolerated.
''For an employer to be found out and punished? The probability is probably one in a million,'' said Karl Dirschmied, head of the department for labor market affairs at the Chamber of Workers and Employees in Vienna.
In an attempt to bring some of those working illegally here into the legitimate work force, Austria passed a law this summer granting a work permit to all those foreigners who were registered in Austria before April 1. Before the new statute, foreigners could declare their presence in Austria, but still work illegally. Previously it was the employers who applied for permits to hire foreign workers, who weren't allowed to be in the country during the application process.
Yet, so far, only a few thousand people have applied for the amnesty, which lasts until Oct. 1. While the law is good for workers because it brings them under Austria's social security umbrella, there is little incentive for the employer to keep the worker since costs will be higher, especially if the supply of clandestine workers is still available, economists and officials here note. To try to prod illegal workers to join the amnesty program, the Austrian Government will authorize labor officials to enter businesses to check for illegal workers, starting in October.
How these measures and the imposition of the visa requirement for Poles will affect the clandestine labor market is uncertain. What is sure is that the number of unemployed in Eastern Europe can only increase as the socialist economies switch over to a capitalist system.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY/September 2-7

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:

 
Another Landmark Is Sold
 
The Pebble Beach Golf Links - lone cypress and all - has been bought by a Japanese company. The Cosmo World Corporation of Tokyo paid an estimated $1 billion to a partnership that included Marvin Davis. So much for the Japanese Government's efforts to keep companies from snapping up American landmarks. Maybe the new owners will quit trying to scare off professional photographers who want to take pictures of the famous tree.
 
A Taste for Crude Oil
 
For the latest on whether Western nations will have to shiver through the winter with severe energy shortages, call the petroleum connoisseurs. Much of the extra oil pumped by Saudia Arabia and other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting countries is too heavy and sour (or high in sulfur) for Western tastes, some experts say. And with Kuwait's refineries under an embargo, the United States and its allies are short on the capacity to cook this product into something their cars, jets and boilers can readily consume. ''Heavy crude produces a much lower volume of finished products,'' said Alfred O. Munk, a consultant who was manager of foreign affairs at the Amoco Corporation. Analysts said that the failure so far of diplomacy in the Middle East and prospect of rising energy demand in winter pushed oil prices up $2.72 last week to $30.04 a barrel. 
 
Mexico's Revival
 
Mexico has regained admission into the global credit markets. State-owned enterprises have floated about $1 billion in bond issues, the first in nearly a decade. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's austerity and privatization drive appear to be paying off, giving the Government enough money to pay debts old and new. More borrowing does raise the prospect that Mexico will once again fall behind on its payments, but officials promise a much more conservative, project-by-project approach.
 
The Mainframe Market Fills Up
 
The International Business Machines Corporation is finding the mainframe computer market more crowded. A day before I.B.M. announced its first new generation of mainframes in five years, Fujitsu Ltd. of Japan introduced its own new line. Fujitsu became the world's second-largest computer company last month with its acquisition of Britain's ICL P.L.C. Whose computers are faster, or the better value, depends on which company you ask. Japanese performance figures might not reflect the real speeds most users can expect, said Joseph Payne, an analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. He says Fujitsu's new machines, with a proprietary operating sytem, will challenge I.B.M.'s only in Japan. Mr. Payne said I.B.M. has gained the advantage of ''a stunning roll-out.''
 
COMPANIES
 
Confessions of a Best Seller
 
Did Alan Neuharth help propel his autobiography, ''Confessions of an S.O.B.,'' onto the best-seller lists by having the Gannett Foundation spend about $40,000 to buy 2,000 copies? Or is Benjamin C. Bradlee, The Washington Post's executive editor, taking revenge for some nasty comments in Mr. Neuharth's book, where he called The Post the ''Palace of Malice,'' and ''the most overrated newspaper in the country''? Mr. Neuharth, the former chief executive of the Gannett Company, is chairman of the foundation, which supports journalism education. The Post reported that a foundation executive asked editors at several Gannett newspapers to buy stacks of Mr. Neuharth's books at local bookstores, paying full retail instead of the bulk discount available to the author. Why? The best-seller lists only count retail sales. Mr. Neuharth says he had no such motive, and dismissed the story as a Bradlee vendetta.
 
ABC's Unfair Advantage
 
The Federal Trade Commission has charged Capital Cities-ABC Inc. and the College Football Association with an illegal formation. Their exclusive five-year, $300 million contract is altogether too effective in fending off competitors who might like to broadcast other college games, the F.T.C. says.
 
USX Without Steel?
 
All the USX Corporation needed to put its steel business up for sale was for Carl C. Icahn, the corporate raider, to let the company get up off the wrestling mat. Three months ago, USX was beating back a proxy proposal by Mr. Icahn to have the company spin off its steel operations. Charles A. Corry, the USX chairman, has concentrated on enhancing the USX energy business. Hard to imagine the company formerly known as United States Steel being without an I-beam to stand on? Yes, but a few years ago, the Greyhound Corporation sold off its buses.
 
It's All in Mack's Name
 
In some industries, the best-known brand doesn't count for much. Mack Trucks Inc. agreed last week to be purchased by Renault, the French auto and truck maker, for only $103 million. Mack, which lost $185 million last year, has slipped to fifth-largest among the nation's manufacturers of heavy trucks.
 
Turning Chefs Into Celebrities
 
Quick quiz: Name three French chefs. Now, name three active French politicians. If the first answer was easier, thank Yanou Collart's avid promotion of French chefs in the United States. Last week, for Craig Claiborne's 70th birthday, she arranged for more than 60 chefs and restaurateurs to celebrate in Monte Carlo.
 
THE ECONOMY
 
Fear of Recession
 
Manufacturers are becoming so cautious in preparation for a recession that they might make it inevitable. August unemployment rose one-tenth of 1 percent to 5.6 percent, the highest figure in two years. Manufacturers cut 45,000 jobs, for a total of 455,000 since January 1989. Stephen S. Roach, the senior economist at Morgan Stanley, said the cutbacks, which usually follow a decline in output, come as industrial production is still expanding. ''The business community is scared to death,'' he said. ''By cutting costs with a vengeance, they may be sowing the seeds of their own demise.''
 
In Brief
 
The Manville Corporation agreed on Friday to add as much as $520 million over seven years to a fund for asbestos victims.
 
A Federal judge ordered Government regulators on Wednesday to return the $9 billion Franklin Savings Association, seized in February, to its owners. The action was temporarily delayed by a higher court.
 
About 80 percent of television and radio stations illegally charge more for political than for commercial advertising, the Federal Communications Commission reported on Friday.

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Politics and the Gulf

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
On his recent campaign swing, Mr. Bush sensibly and properly refrained from openly seeking Republican votes as a reward for his military response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. That, nonetheless, was the net effect of his remarks.
Similarly, the President made no mention of votes at a news conference this week, when he reported ''clear signs of progress'' in his Administration's effort to curb drug abuse. The evidence for such progress is skimpy, but the President's reminder that he was conducting a ''war on drugs'' was a political plus. 
His Helsinki conference with Mikhail Gorbachev is all but certain to reinforce his poll standing. The Soviet Union is no longer a superpower; but ever since Winston Churchill coined the phrase, meetings ''at the summit'' have provided plenty of photo ops and political pizazz for home consumption.
Not that opposing international aggression, protecting energy supplies, dealing with the drug menace and negotiating with foreign leaders are merely exercises in domestic politics. It's a fact that out-parties have to live with, however, that Presidents reap political hay from such legitimate activities.
In fact, U.S. troops in the gulf may be making the strongest bid for support for Mr. Bush and his party in the November elections. The rally-round-the-flag effect and public approval of the troop deployment probably can be maintained at least until then, with significant effect at the polls.
The Republicans may well need such help. Before Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait and Mr. Bush responded so strongly, 1990 was beginning to look like something of a Democratic year - for one reason, of course, because the President's party more often than not has lost support in mid-term elections.
This year, in addition, the public has shown itself greatly concerned with the threat of recession, which a growing number of economists think is real, and which residents of the Northeast know to be not just a threat. Rising oil prices could make recession a reality across the country, while at the same time boosting inflation - the worst possible political news for Mr. Bush and the Republicans.
The President already is under fire within his own party for abandoning his pledge not to raise taxes. He and the Democrats who control Congress have yet to agree on a budget package, which reflects on both parties. If they finally settle on a tax increase to reduce the Federal deficit, Mr. Bush could suffer two ways: from agreeing to an unpopular step he had pledged to oppose and because rising taxes would make recession all the more likely.
To an unsettled economy the horrendous savings and loan scandal must be added as a Republican liability. It's true that Congressional Democrats bear much responsibility, and that some of them are likely to go down in flames on the S.& L. issue. But the larger facts are that the S.& L. collapse started during the Reagan-Bush Administration, and the cleanup under the Bush Administration looks more and more like a mismanaged mess.
It doesn't help, either, that the involvement of the President's son, Neil Bush, as a director of the failed Silverado S.& L. symbolizes the scandal for many Americans. The President himself was the beneficiary of $300,000 raised for his campaign in November 1987 at a dinner organized by Michael Wise, then the chairman of Silverado.
The emotional abortion issue also seems to work against the Republicans, who are more closely identified with anti-abortion efforts than are the Democrats. Since the Supreme Court made it possible for states to restrict a woman's right to abortion, the Republican position seems to threaten that right, alienating even some who personally oppose abortion.
So it's no wonder Mr. Bush wants to talk about standing tall in the desert. Despite the risk, that's his best political bet.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 5, Column 4; Week in Review Desk

HEADLINE: The Region;
What Real Estate Developers Make of New York's Future

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Because this market is such an accurate barometer of the whole regional economy, the views of these hardened veterans may be as good a crystal ball as one could expect in turbulent times.
''We've been through this before,'' said Andrew J. Singer, a mortgage broker who is president of Ackman Brothers and Singer.
After nearly a decade of unsurpassed and largely unexpected growth, the real estate market has gone into a decline. The value of apartments and houses has fallen. There is a glut of new office space. Many new luxury apartments are empty or renting at lower rates than had been projected. Some of the city's pre-eminent developers are attempting to renegotiate the debt on buildings. 
In the face of all this, developers have been tirelessly retelling the saga of Olympia & York, the Canadian real estate company that came to New York at the height of the fiscal crisis of 1970's and bought up so much property - at bargain prices - that it became the city's largest commercial landlord within a decade.
Few economists anticipated the economic resurgence of the 1980's, and few New Yorkers demonstrated Olympia & York's confidence in the city. But the story underscores for many developers the value of persevering during difficult times.
''I think the real professionals in our business are not doing as well as four or five years ago, but they are holding their own,'' said Lewis Rudin, president of Rudin Management, a large owner of commercial and residential buildings. ''It's a very competitive business and you have to be able to stay the course.''
Many developers and economists base their optimism on both the strength of the rebound from the economic crisis of the 1970's and the belief that the current malaise seems mild compared to the problems of two decades ago. Between 1969 and 1976 New York lost more than 500,000 manufacturing jobs, and the city had to obtain Federal loans to stave off bankruptcy.
Developers and economists argue that the current slump, in comparison, is fueled largely by the loss of about 25,000 jobs in one area, Wall Street. They see future prosperity in the city's high proportion of jobs in finance, information and law, industries that are considered likely to grow.
''Even though I know the shorter term is bleak, I'm certainly a believer in the city and its long-term economic health,'' said Mortimer Zuckerman, chairman of Boston Properties. ''I don't think this is a fundamental change. I think this is a cycle. The basic ingredients that make this city so attractive are still here, the particular energy and talent of the people of New York.''
A substantial financial commitment backs up Mr. Zuckerman's sentiments. Boston Properties plans to redevelop the site of the New York Coliseum at Columbus Circle with a cluster of towers containing offices, apartments and stores. Mr. Zuckerman has agreed to pay $337 million for the site, now owned jointly by the city and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
Other developers are also investing in New York's future, although it is unclear whether many foreign investers are joining in. A number of significant development plans, including two huge housing complexes proposed in Queens, were approved by city officials last month.
Some real estate executives question whether the developers will be able to obtain financing for such large projects - 7,500 apartments in the Arverne section of the Rockaways and 6,000 in Long Island City - when the sale and rental of new market-rate housing is soft. But many people, including city and state officials, believe the projects will eventually be built.
City planners say that several big new projects are coming up for review soon. Included are high-rise apartments proposed by Donald J. Trump for his property along the Hudson River on Manhattan's Upper West Side and a plan for a large complex in the Melrose section of the Bronx, to be developed by the New York City Housing Partnership, a nonprofit group that promotes middle-income dwellings.
Some developers contend that their industry is inherently self-correcting and that any decline in new construction will allow the market time to absorb recently completed buildings. But the corrections can be extremely painful. Even some of the most experienced developers, like the Milstein and LeFrak families, have run into trouble on individual properties.
In July the Milsteins defaulted on the mortgage of the Normandie Court, an apartment complex on East 96th Street. Federal regulators say they are keeping a close watch on the mortgage of the LeFraks' four large rental apartment buildings at the Newport complex in Jersey City.
These real-estate empires, however, are not endangered, and developers say that other new commercial and residential buildings are prospering. Many repeat an old adage: the market is never as good as it looks in an upswing, nor as bad as it feels in decline.
Mr. Rudin has been reminding people about Olympia & York's foresight in the 1970's, when, he said, ''New Yorkers could not see beyond their noses.''
He suggested that today's pessimists may be guilty of a similar myopia. ''Foreigners will come in again, you'll see, and they will see things that some of us cannot,'' he said.

(Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

LENGTH: 955 words

HEADLINE: The World;
Increasingly Isolated, North Korea Starts Talking

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN

DATELINE: SEOUL

 BODY:
A significant opening occurred last week when, after a year of sputtering delays, Prime Minister Yon Hyung Muk of North Korea led the highest-level delegation to South Korea since the end of World War II. The two sides failed to narrow their differences but agreed to continue efforts to reduce tensions, meeting next in North Korea. More important was the fact that a dialogue had begun. Clearly part of what compelled the North to visit the South was the changing global environment brought about by the collapse of the cold war. But there were also signs of extraordinary internal and external pressures on the ossified regime of the 78-year-old self-proclaimed Great Leader, Mr. Kim.
Decades ago, North Korea impressed many in the West as a Socialist dynamo, investing in heavy industry and making gains that outstripped its war-ravaged southern neighbor. Today the country is limping along at an official annual growth rate of 3 percent, while South Korean growth has been about 9 percent a year. While the North shunned trade as an engine for economic growth, choosing instead to be completely self reliant, South Korea surged ahead by investing in industries that could export automobiles, machinery and consumer goods to the West. There are signs that North Korea suffers from mounting debts, a huge military burden and declines in production, exports and currency exchange. 
This year, moreover, the Soviet Union, North Korea's most important ally and benefactor, served notice that it would soon demand hard currency for its oil and high technology. Former allies in Eastern Europe are no longer available as partners, and China has too many problems of its own to bail out North Korea. Pyongyang is reportedly encouraging a few joint business ventures with foreigners and copying a few of China's capitalist-style economic incentives, but there is no evidence they are having a major impact.
By most accounts, North Korean officials watched with mounting alarm and jealousy while South Korea transformed its economic miracle into political clout, holding the Olympics two years ago and forging new ties with Moscow and Beijing. Pyongyang seems to have been stunned when President Mikhail S. Gorbachev abruptly met with President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea in San Francisco last June on his way home from a chat at the White House.
As recently as last weekend, when Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze stopped off in Pyongyang on his way to Tokyo, Soviet officials have been effectively advising North Korea to clean up its act. So there is hope that heavy-handed examples of terrorism against South Korea, like the 1983 bombing in Burma that killed seven high-ranking South Korean officials, or the 1987 explosion on a South Korean airliner in which 115 people died, are a thing of the past. North Korea has even acknowledged the existence of two nuclear reactors and promised to open them eventually to international safeguards.
Another sign of change is North Korea's contacts with Tokyo and the United States. American officials have held about a dozen meetings with North Korean diplomats in Beijing. The United States has also opened its door to visiting scholars, athletes and performers. A payoff came last May, when North Korea returned the remains of five soldiers missing in action since the Korean War.
The major question mark relates to what happens after the death of Mr. Kim. Diplomats view the elder dictator's son and chosen successor, Kim Jong Il - the Dear Leader, as he is known - as corrupt, erratic and unlikely to hold power for long. More probably, many say, the army will turn against him and try to take control in conjunction with a new generation of technocrats seen as increasingly moving into positions of power.
The army and technocrats, these specialists believe, would moderate North Korea's political positions and eliminate the personality cult that has stunted the country for two generations.
North Korea remains one of the most closed societies in the world, with an eerily immaculate capital reminiscent of a movie set. But there are signs of dissatisfaction underneath the tranquil surface. Chay Pyung Gil, a political scientist at Yonsei University and author of several books about North Korea, has spent years tracking down North Korean diplomats, students, athletes, businessmen and technicians stationed abroad in Communist countries - and he has found considerable grumbling. ''Even Kim Il Sung has had to pay attention to dissident groups,'' said Mr. Chay.
But it would be naive to expect Communism to vanish overnight as it has in Eastern Europe. After all, Mr. Kim came to power after World War II as a homegrown revolutionary patriot admired in many parts of the Korean peninsula for throwing off decades of colonial Japanese rule and founding an army, national bureaucracy and other major institutions. North Korea is considered more likely to adjust his legacy than abandon it, which means that no matter what happens, the road to rapprochement with South Korea and indeed the West may be long and hard.

LENGTH: 397 words

HEADLINE: Hostage Situations Demand Forthright Action;
Democracy in Jordan

 BODY:
United States aid has been meager: about $50 million a year. This is a pittance for the friendship, patience and loyalty King Hussein has shown over the years. Since 1973, he has maintained de facto peace and tacit cooperation with Israel, and issued a number of peace proposals.
More important, he has implemented political reforms at home, making Jordan the most democratic of the Arab states. ''Jordan: Human Rights Protection After the State of Emergency,'' an Amnesty International report of last June, documents the brutal political repression that once characterized life in Jordan. Recent changes, while not revolutionary, are unprecedented.
Scores of political prisoners and detainees have been released, instruments of repression reined in, and freedom of expression restored. Last November, the country elected its first free parliament in 22 years. In the coming months, if security is not threatened by external conflict, martial law will be completely abolished and political parties legalized.
Israel's supporters often say it is the only democracy in the Middle East and chastise the Arab states for human rights abuses. President Bush has also made help for ''emerging democracies'' a priority. If both place such importance on democratic development, then increased foreign aid should be immediate.
This is especially true if the United States insists on making its blockade of Iraq absolute. It is unlikely that President Bush will grant Jordan even partial exemption, despite its economic situation and highly politicized Palestinian population. At the least, Jordan should be compensated for losses; otherwise, its nascent democratic experiment and King will flounder.
 
OLIVER WILCOX
 Washington, Aug. 23, 1990
 
The writer is a researcher on Jordan for Physicians for Human Rights

HEADLINE: Energy Tax: Still on the Table

BYLINE: By LEON PANETTA; Leon Panetta, Democrat of California, is the chairman of the House Budget Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The Middle East crisis has made our already worrisome economic and fiscal problems worse. But perhaps the threat of war, stagflation and the prospect of $300 billion budget deficits will shock us into action, as political business as usual during the late 1980's did not.
The new demonstration of our energy vulnerability, after a decade of wasted opportunity, at least makes clear the direction in which policy should move. The American people are economic hostages to Middle East dictators, who produce oil shocks, and to Government budget deficits, which produce high interest rates. 
We desperately need both a fiscal policy of assured long-term deficit reduction and an energy policy of assured incentives for conservation. A phased-in energy tax should be the centerpiece of a five-year deficit reduction plan, which would also include other savings and revenues.
The tax should begin at low levels, and increase over several years. In anticipation of increased energy prices, businesses and families will begin to conserve energy now. Similarly, the certainty of lower future deficits will lead to lower long-term interest rates now, reducing the likelihood or severity of recession and stimulating investment, economic growth and job creation.
A phased-in energy tax also fits our fiscal dilemma. The weakness of the economy means that deficit reduction may have to be ''back-loaded'' - adjusted from the contemplated $50 billion in fiscal year 1991, but increased enough in later years to keep a five-year total of at least $500 billion.
We should not play Russian roulette with the economy in an attempt to reach an arbitrary figure for 1991. It is just as obvious, however, that we must not back away from our responsibility to reduce deficits now. Nothing could be more damaging to our Government's credibility, and more likely to raise interest rates and destabilize financial markets, than a collapse of U.S. economic policy at a time of crisis.
Obviously, an energy tax alone will not solve the budget crisis. The Middle East confrontation has not resurrected the cold war, so we should still pursue long-term defense reductions, particularly in European-based forces and in defense weaponry dedicated to a Soviet threat that has largely disappeared - while enhancing our capacity to deal with the Saddam Husseins of the world.
We must also pursue restraint in the growth of entitlement programs and low-priority discretionary spending, while recognizing that new funding is required in a number of areas, such as education, health and research, for an efficient economy and just society.
And we must adjust any fiscal package to make sure it is equitable - a problem that energy taxes bring sharply into focus. If we enact an energy tax, it must be accompanied by tax and other measures to ease the impact on those least able to pay. We should avoid the kinds of policies that led in the 1980's to a shift of income from lower- and middle-income families to the wealthy.
The President has set the right guideposts. His biggest problem has been not with Democrats but with some Republicans, who have consistently undermined him by criticizing his decisions, leaking his budget proposals to the press and threatening to oppose a final budget agreement.
At this time of crisis, the nation cannot afford delay or partisanship. And it cannot afford avoidance of responsibility by our political leaders. In the long run, the deficit and our dependence on oil pose a greater threat to our economy than Saddam Hussein. They, too, must be confronted head on.

HEADLINE: The Golden Door, Re-opened

 BODY:
Yet their splendid work is not quite finished. For there is another part of the island, south of the main building and separated by a ferry slip, that the restorers haven't touched. It contains two dozen contagious disease wards, a morgue and many dark and forbidding rooms. 
Only a small percentage of the 12 million immigrants went there, and, because the buildings are collapsing in a tangle of rust and vines, no visitors will be allowed. But this Ellis Island deserves better; it, too, is wondrously evocative.
The average immigrant spent three to five hours on the island. In far shorter time, visitors will be able to follow the path through the heart of the building the immigrants originally took: from the ferry slip to the vaulted registry room, where they were examined and interrogated by an army of doctors and inspectors. On any given day, 5,000 people would move through this room. Most received a joyous stamp of approval; a few - 2 percent of all cases - a crushing ''no.'' The sick and lame wound up in the hospital and the wards at the south end of the island. It was this part of the island that caused the one nasty dispute during the restoration process.
Lee Iacocca, who was largely responsible for raising $345 million to refurbish the Statue of Liberty and reclaim Ellis Island, wanted to build an immigration theme park that critics promptly labeled an ''ethnic Disneyland.'' Tne National Park Service, which manages the island, decided instead to lease the buildings to a developer who would raze some of them and turn the hospital into a plush international conference center.
But while the developer continues to seek financing in an uncertain economic climate, the old buildings, and the history they contain, rot away. Dust swirls in the morgue, which holds a tiny amphitheater for autopsies, with eight holes in the wall where corpses were refrigerated. Weeds sprout through the concrete floor of a room containing a half-dozen autoclaves - huge containers where mattresses and bed linen were sterilized by superheated steam. One building holds a giant coal-fired boiler; another has a massive Dickensian contraption for pressing sheets.
A Park Service guide recently told a visitor that these abandoned structures held special meaning. ''The Museum recaptures history,'' he said. ''These buildings are history.'' He said he hoped enough public and private money could be found to ''stabilize'' them by preventing further rot until a permanent plan can be devised.
That's a modest idea and a good one. These poor, huddled structures speak of anxiety and hope - and tug us forcibly into the past.

On Vacation In a Windmill
Travelers looking for somewhere different to stay in England, Wales or France might find their needs met by an outfit called Distinctly Different. Its rental offerings include converted windmills, water mills, chapels and schools, narrow boats, oast houses and a former train station.
A 14th-century forge in Totnes, Devon, preserves its links with the past as a smithy goes about his work. The converted stone building set in a walled garden comprises four double bedrooms and four family rooms. Prices range from $27 to $40 a person a night. 
One of the windmills is Cley Mill at Cley-next-the Sea, Norfolk. Dating from 1713, the mill has a five-story brick tower with timber gallery, fantail and sails and two bedrooms. Other accommodations, next to the mill, are a family bedroom (a double room with beds for more than two people) and a single room. Prices: $30 to $35 a person a night. In Wales, a tiny Quaker chapel that overlooks the mountains of the Radnor Forest at Llandrindod Wells, Powys, has one family bedroom, one double and one single room from $20. The rates for properties in England include breakfast; breakfast is not included in France.
Among properties in France, Distinctly Different offers Le Moulin des Chezeaux, an 18th-century water mill on the edge of the village of Rivarennes near St.-Gaultier in the valley of the Creuse River in central France; its three double bedrooms all have private bath. Room rates are about $56 a day.
Brochures covering the properties, none of which have cooking facilities, are available for $2 from Distinctly Different, Masons Lane, Bradford-on-Avon, Wiltshire BA15 1QN, England; phone: 2216 6842.
 
California Taxing Tourist Import
Beginning Oct. 1, the California State Board of Equalization will begin a new program to enforce a little-known tax law requiring state residents to pay a use tax on items purchased abroad. The law, which was enacted in 1935, is aimed at protecting California businesses from tax-free competition.
California residents returning from trips abroad with merchandise purchased in foreign countries for their own use or as gifts used within the state will be assessed a tax equivalent to state and county sales taxes, which range from 6.25 to 7.25 percent.
The tax board, in cooperation with the Customs Service, plans to send out about 30,000 tax bills this year based on the value of goods listed on customs declaration forms filled out when travelers return to this country. Officials estimate that the program will boost revenue by $6.3 million annually.
According to a spokeswoman for the board, all but four states have a use tax law and until now have relied on voluntary compliance. Other states are keeping close watch on California's program with the idea of adopting it.
Not every traveler will receive a tax bill under the new program. The board has established a threshold dollar amount, which officials decline to reveal, below which the process would not be cost effective. Travelers returning with only a few bottles of perfume or a tweed cap are expected to comply voluntarily with the law by contacting the tax board's office in their county. A tax form will then be mailed to them, which they are to fill out and return with a check for the tax.
A bill pending before the State Legislature would exempt from the tax the first $400 of merchandise purchased abroad and hand carried into the state, making the tax law conform to Federal regulations allowing travelers to bring in that amount of goods duty free.
 
Nudists Protest Florida Rules
A recent ban on skimpy swimwear in Florida's 120 state parks has angered nudists and puzzled some vacationers. The restrictions, state officials say, are targeted at such barely-there styles as the thong (G-string) bikini, but nudists complain of a violation of First Amendment rights. They also say the ban will hurt Florida's tourism industry, which relies in part on vacationers from overseas, many of whom are used to sunbathing topless.
Raphael Marcucci of the Florida Department of Commerce said that of the 38.7 million tourists who visited the state last year, fewer than 5 million were foreigners.
Although a ban on indecent exposure in state parks has existed for several years, the new restrictions, a result of revisions of the Florida Administrative Code, are more specific as to which parts of the body must be covered.
Randy Lewis of the Florida Department of Natural Resources said that if the wearer of a close-to-nude swimsuit in a park refused to cover up or leave he or she could be cited and given an administrative - not criminal - fine of about $35. Park rangers are responsible for enforcing the stricter code.
 
Faster Service To Greek Isles
Twin-hulled Hovercraft ferries cruising at 50 miles an hour have sharply reduced the time it takes to get from Piraeus, Greece, to three outlying islands.
Introduced this summer, the 330-passenger Golden Olympic Supercat makes the trip from Piraeus to Mykonos in two hours and 15 minutes compared with about six and a half hours for the regular ferry. The Golden Olympic leaves the Flisvos Marina at 9 A.M. and 4 P.M. daily except Tuesday; the one-way fare is about $40. The price of the regular ferry is $16.75. For reservations in Greece call 360-9911 or 360-3960. Another Supercat ferry leaves at 8 A.M. and 4:30 P.M. for Poros and Spetses. The craft takes just under an hour to reach Poros and about two and a half hours to get to Spetses. The fare is $10 to Poros and about $14 to Spetses. The regular ferry takes three hours and 40 minutes to Poros and costs $5.25. The trip to Spetses takes five hours and 35 minutes and costs $5.75.
The Supercats Marine Company, which operates the Hovercraft, also offers one-day tours to Poros and Spetses. The price, including lunch, is $32 for Poros and about $43 for Spetses.
For reservations in Greece, call 325-3640.
 
Future Shock For Air Travel
Asked what they would like in airlines, participants in a recent survey had some glorious fantasies: ''Get rid of the peanuts,'' ''individual VCR's instead of crummy movies'' and ''no-frills middle-of-the-night flights'' were a few responses. But other suggestions showed that frequent travel causes riders to yearn for some basics - faster check-in procedures, cheaper fares and better service.
The question on improving air travel was included with the Zagat hotel survey for 1990. The Zagats, Tim and Nina, began publishing their surveys on restaurants and in 1988 added hotels and resorts. This spring their second hotel survey, which was filled out by 5,400 unpaid participants who were on the road at least 47 days a year, included brief sections on airlines and car rentals. The airline section was returned by 4,400 participants of whom 61 percent were men and 39 percent women. Here are some airline ideas, realistic and otherwise: Contour head rests; telescopes for window viewing; quiet zones - no movies, seat-belted study; limo-taxi pickup at the plane for passengers with no luggage; a good sandwich instead of mush, a la carte dining, vegetarian meals available without prior notice; discounts for frequent fliers, no bogus trips; automatic discounts for frequent-flier miles if planes are late; showers in first class.
The survey will be published in December.
 
MYSTIC SEAPORT BY LANTERN LIGHT
Lantern-light tours of Mystic Seaport are scheduled for Dec. 5 to 21, from 5 to 9 nightly except Tuesday. Tickets go on sale Oct. 1.
In these one-hour tours, costumed guides lead groups of 16 people through the reconstructed 19th-century museum village in eastern Connecticut, visiting shops and vessels. Unlike the daylight Christmastime tours, curators and interpreters on the evening tours take 19th-century roles, enacting scenes showing the evolution of Christmas observances from the Puritan days of the early 19th century to the Victorian period when the Christmas tree became well established. Twenty tours go out each evening, and 150 people are used in the presentations. Mystic Seaport, on Exit 90 off Interstate 95, is also reachable by Amtrak.
Tickets for the evening tours are $12, $6.50 for children 2 to 12; it is not necessary to pay museum admission. Reservations are acepted by phone only, and tickets are mailed on receipt of a check or money order. The seaport number is 203-572-0711.

HEADLINE: Cruising by Moonlight Along the Tiber

BYLINE: By Frances D'Emilio; Frances D'Emilio, who lives in Rome, is the author of a guidebook about the city to be published next year by Hippocrene.

 BODY:
The Tiber's abandonment over the last few decades is a relatively recent event in Rome's nearly 3,000-year existence. As legend tells it, the twins Romulus and Remus founded the settlement that would grow into Rome on the spot on the left bank where they were rescued from their drifting in a basket down the Tiber. In reality, the hills of what was to become Rome probably attracted various tribes because nearby Tiber Island made it easy to cross the river.
Up to about about a century ago, Romans washed their clothes and themselves in the Tiber. Until the pollution of the postwar industrial boom, Romans escaped the broiling summer sun with a dip in the river, and private bathing clubs on pilings made the river banks look like a kind of Coney Island boardwalk.
But although the Tiber was the city's lifeline, it also brought destruction. Houses were built right down to the banks, with nothing to stop the flood waters, which rolled through Rome every couple of hundred years. After the city was seized from the Pope in 1870 and became the capital of newly united Italy, the Government made one of its first tasks the taming of the Tiber. Among those offering solutions was Giuseppe Garibaldi, the unification hero. Riverside dwellings were demolished and sidewalks and roads moved up to bridge-deck level. 
If walling off the river put the Tiber out of sight, so to speak, the ''miracle'' economic boom of the 1950's and 1960's put it out of mind. Sewage dumping was finally banned in 1976, but it was only in the last few years that the purification plants mandated by law began seriously reducing river pollution. Now, the return of many kinds of fish is an optimistic indicator, though industrial discharge beyond city limits remains a problem. Still, a swimmer today runs a high risk of contracting hepatitis, and it's possible to see the occasional river rat.
Until the launching of the Acquabus, exploring the Tiber required some daring and maybe even foolhardiness. Many stretches along the cemented-over banks are calf-high in weeds, and some of the less-visited stretches are littered with broken bottles and syringes discarded by addicts. Step aboard a river boat and you sidestep the problems and plunge into a world that's practically bucolic in places, and, on hot, breezeless nights, one of the coolest stretches in Rome. Only a few yards away from the frenzy of relentless traffic, the Tiber is a silent retreat from the noise pollution.
The service began in 1987 with one uncovered boat to test tourist interest. This year, four canopied boats each carry 35 to 45 passengers up and down from Tiber Island to Duca d'Aosta Bridge, near Olympic Stadium. On nights when World Cup soccer matches were played, fans from Europe and Latin America filled the boats with cheers and songs. They and Romans discovered the boats beat a sea of cars and buses caught in traffic on Lungotevere, the roadway that flanks both banks of the snaking Tiber.
The river trip takes 40 or 50 minutes each way, depending on current, and passengers can board along the right bank (the Vatican and Trastevere side), opposite the island or at Duca d'Aosta Bridge, or on the left bank, just past Cavour Bridge. For cost-conscious visitors, the ride is also something of a bargain; one-way tickets cost just under $1.
If you start near the stadium, take a few minutes before boarding to view Ponte Milvio, the first bridge just beyond the course of the boats. For a good vantage point, walk along the newly made, asphalted bicycle path that runs for about nine miles on the right bank (to your left as you face the dock and near the 55-foot-tall obelisk inscribed Mussolini Dux). Censor M. Aemilius Scaurus, who built the bridge - of bricks in 109 B.C. - gave it its name. Garibaldi had the bridge sabotaged in 1849 to stop the advance of French troops. It was ordered rebuilt by Pope Pius IX. Emperor Maxentius was thrown into the river from the bridge after his defeat by co-emperor Constantine in A.D. 312. It was at Ponte Milvio that Constantine is said to have seen a flaming cross in the sky and was moved to adopt Christianity.
Winding downriver, Acquabus glides by several private clubs with riverside pools and tennis courts as well as rowing clubs, one of them dating to 1872. Despite the high bacterial count of the river, early evening finds bare-chested men rowing or paddling canoes in this stretch and upriver. After two more bridges, the boat passes a fire station and, in the evening, the candlelit tables of diners at Isola del Sole, one of the restaurants on the Tiber. Nearby on the left bank is a particularly green stretch rented from the city by the World Wildlife Fund in an effort to keep the area from being cemented over. Willows and poplars lean out over the murky green water, making the bank look as if it should line Mark Twain's Mississippi.
By getting off and on the boat you can incorporate the river tour with other sightseeing. By disembarking at Ponte Cavour, for example, and climbing the stairs to street level, you can take in Ara Pacis, a glass-enclosed, reconstructed monumental marble altar dedicated to the victories of Augustus in Spain and Gaul.
Try to time a boat ride from Ponte Cavour downriver for just before sunset. The Acquabus veers west as it navigates a bend, and in front of you will be a silhouetted dome of St. Peter's, likely breaking a pinkish or orange sky if it's a typically scorching Rome summer day.
Take the same stretch after dark and ahead will lie the fortress Castel Sant'Angelo, bathed in the golden glow of artificial lighting. A little luck and a swollen, yellow moon will be hanging over the 12 marble angel statues spaced across the bridge to the castle.
To explore the castle, you'll have to come in morning, when the monument is open. (Don't be too distracted by the fake designer sunglasses and bags laid out on the bridge by ''vu' cumpra'' - North African peddlers. Gangs of dirty-faced, ragged kids periodically swoop through and relieve people of wallet, handbag or jewelry, designer or not.) The bridge was built by Hadrian as a majestic approach to his mausoleum, which he began constructing in A.D. 130 along the right bank. Archeologists believe the tomb was covered with earth, which in turn was studded with cypresses and statues. In the Middle Ages, the mausoleum was surrounded by ramparts and the citadel became a key defense point. Legend has it that St. Gregory the Great, while crossing the bridge, saw an angel on top of the fortress, and the vision was taken as a sign of an imminent end to a plague ravaging Rome.
On the right bank, just beyond the triple-arched Fascist-era Ponte Savoia, is a travertine block a few yards in from the river's edge and at the base of two symmetrical stone staircases. The slab is believed to have served as a marker in ancient times to show where public land ended and private property began. The barely decipherable inscription recalls one Tiberius Giulius Ferocious (A.D. 101-103), ''curator of the riverbed and banks of the Tiber and of the sewers of the city of Rome.''
The Acquabus is forced to stop by the rapids near Isola Tiberina, as the island is known in Italian. After stretching your sea legs - the boat-shaped island, of volcanic origin, can be covered on foot in about 10 minutes - contemplate another legend tied to the river.
When a deadly epidemic gripped the city in 293 B.C., the oracles were consulted and indicated that an emissary should go to the site of the cult of Asclepius, god of healing, and bring back a serpent. But the snake slithered away from the ship that was bringing it to Rome and ended up on Tiber Island, where a temple to the god was erected.
The temple is no more, but the island, with its hospital dating to 1548, still is dedicated to healing. Descend the steps and look for the block of travertine decorated with a serpent curled around a stick, like a single-snaked caduceus. (Hint: it's just above where the rubber police dinghy is parked.)
Set into the steps of the main altar of the island's St. Bartholomew's church is a medieval marble font carved out of an ancient column. The head of Rome's underwater archeology department, Claudio Mocchegiani Carpano, says the 40-foot-deep font probably marks the spot of the temple's sacred spring.
The island is a good place to look at Ponte Rotto (broken bridge), built 181-179 B.C. Only one arch remains.
To continue the archeological tour of the river, leave the island on the left bank side via Ponte Fabricio, better known as the ''bridge of four heads,'' after the four-headed sculptures decorating it. Keeping an eye out for gypsy gangs, which frequent the island, walk along Lungotevere until Ponte Sublicio, near Porta Portese, the gateway where Vittorio De Sica's suspected Bicycle Thief was spotted.
From there you can see the pride and joy of the archeologist's 12-year-old department, the excavation of a three-story storehouse, built in the first century A.D., for jars of wine, oil and fish sauce that were unloaded from barges at an ancient dock. In those days, it was strictly no deposit, no return, and the throwaway pottery grew into a 100-foot-high mountain of shards, which can be seen a 10-minute stroll away in Testaccio.
On the other side of Ponte Sublicio, Rome's shortest bridge, and on the right bank, once stood a lighthouse built by Pius VII in 1815. Barges towed by buffalo along the banks brought the heaviest cargo to be unloaded there. During the Middle Ages, pilgrims disembarked there for the final leg of their journey to see the tomb of St. Peter. If those medieval tourists had the convenience of the Acquabus, they might have been tempted to keep on going upriver for a little sightseeing.
 
CHARTING A COURSE FOR A RIVER TRIP IN ROME
 
River Boats
The Acquabus runs every day but Monday, May through September. Last year it also ran two weeks at Christmas time.
Schedules are posted near boarding points on the right and left banks of the river, but beware, runs depend on water conditions. This year, July and August saw morning trips canceled; the service began in mid to late afternoon, depending on when water was released upriver. The final runs end at midnight, except for the month of September, when service terminates at 8 P.M. During the summer the last two downriver trips from Ponte Duca d'Aosta end at Ponte Cavour, and not the island, to insure that the crew finishes at midnight. Boats leave about every 25 minutes. Fares are paid on board, so if the boat is about to leave, just hop on. City subsidy and commercial sponsorship make the fare a bargain: a one-way ticket (at 1,150 lire to the dollar) costs just under $1; a weekly ticket for unlimited rides is about $6 and monthly, about $22.
Acquabus officials say that they will decide in late September, based on water conditions, whether they will continue service through the Christmas holidays this year. But in any case service will be suspended for two weeks in October for cleaning and maintenance of the boat. For more information, telephone 686-9068.
The Tiber II is an excursion boat that normally makes one run daily except Monday, March through December, to the excavated city at Ostia Antica, the Tiber's ancient outlet to the sea; it departs from Ripa Grande (right bank) near Ponte Sublicio, in Trastevere. The trip takes about two and a half hours. Fare is about $36, round trip, and includes a one and a half hour tour of the ancient port city; an optional buffet lunch on board is about $21. This July and August, excursions were suspended for repairs to the boat. Because of the low level of the river, the boat's operators were uncertain at this writing when runs would resume this fall. For information: 446-3481.
 
Dining
Er Cucurucu, 10 Via Capoprati, near Ponte Duca d'Aosta, but not to be confused with the nondescript restaurant near the dock. Walk up the stairs from the boat and follow the bike path to your left. Dine on a terrace sheltered from sun and rain by a bower of vines and watch the Acquabus and rowers glide by. Service is excellent; so is the pasta, but it is a bit expensive. Lunch or dinner for two with house wine costs about $95 (a half-bottle is about $5, nearly twice the going rate). Closed Sunday in summer, Sunday evening and Monday in winter; reservations, 325-2571.
Isola del Sole, Lungotevere Arnaldo da Brescia, has a gangplank leading to a delightful patio filled with candlelit tables and sheltered from the elements by big white umbrellas. Strangely enough, fish is not served; but, a rarity in Rome, you can order light salads for lunch. A meal for two, with wine, is about $60 to $70.
Open for lunch and dinner daily except Monday, with indoor tables available in winter. The nearest Acquabus stop is Ponte Cavour. Parking is also available. To reserve a waterside table, 320-1400. Il Canto del Riso, Lungotevere Mellini, specializes in risotto. This restaurant on pilings in the river near Ponte Cavour features fish for a second course. A favorite dish is rice with shrimp. Dinner for two is about $80 to $100. Open for lunch and dinner daily except Monday. Patio space is limited, so call for reservations, 361-0430.
 
Other Diversions
Bicycles can be taken aboard the Acquabus, space permitting. The bicycle path passes right by the Ponte Duca d'Aosta landing. A convenient place to rent bikes is Piazza Sonnino, off Viale Trastevere, and near the Tiber Island departure point.
Although swimming in the Tiber is impossible, you can swim right near it at a riverside club. The pool at the Circolo dei Lavori Publici, 7-9 Lungotevere Thaon di Revel, 39-33-45, is open from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. There are showers and dressing rooms, and you can buy lunch at a poolside snack bar. Admission is about $11 for the day, about $7 from 2 P.M. on. The club is opposite the boat dock at Duca d'Aosta Bridge.
 
Guides
Determined tourists can sometimes obtain a map, with descriptions in Italian, of the Tiber from Castel Sant'Angelo to Testaccio by visiting the city's department of underwater archeology in the Central Restoration Institute along Via di San Michele, near the Sublicio Bridge. A guidebook to the Tiber's archeology will be published in early 1991. Dividing the river into mapped sections, the 32-page book will cost about $9 and cover the Tiber from Ponte Milvio to Ostia Antica.
The book will be available from the Tiber II boat office or the Nicolaci bookstore, which specializes in archeology, 23 Via Palermo, 46-39-67. F. D'E.
