HEADLINE: New York's Out-of-Town Reviews

BYLINE: By Claudia H. Deutsch; Claudia H. Deutsch is a reporter for the Business section of The Times.

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from what other cities' newspapers say about New York.
 
New Yorkers
''Try as they will - and some are very earnest contenders - New Yorkers just can't overtake Bostonians in the Three R's of driving: reckless, rude and rambunctious. Strange, in a city stacked with high achievers.'' And, in a cab: ''At 57th, a sudden field reversal worthy of Bo Jackson - or Jesse Helms joining the A.C.L.U. - took us from far right, abruptly, on a wondrous swing left to the squealing accompaniment of brakes, tires and perturbed folks who'd been cut off. 
'' 'Would you believe this is my first day driving in New York?' '' the driver asked. - The Boston Sunday Globe, ''A Love-Hate Relationship With Big Apple Travels,'' by Bud Collins, Jan. 28, 1990.
''Doing like the natives, I found it necessary to be hyperactive, to EXPRESS OPINIONS LOUDLY. . . .''
''More than ever, it seems, the rich and the poor rub against one another in New York in a way that rarely happens in the rest of America. Comfortable people cut big deals in tall buildings while legions of homeless people seek warmth in cardboard boxes on sidewalks below. . . . It is a tremendously jarring sight that can't help but force the visitor to question why this wealthy nation can allow these huddled masses to be cast out on the street.'' - The Detroit Free Press, ''Bites of the Apple,'' by Bill McGraw, March 25, 1990.
 
Neighborhoods
''As readers of Tom Wolfe's 'The Bonfire of the Vanities' are aware, in New York City there are neighborhoods and neighborhoods, and the wise resident and visitor know which is what and where. In some mid-city blocks, one can become deceased with relative ease; in others, spending large sums of money takes less effort than breathing.
''This part of town - Madison Avenue and the East 70's and 80's - definitely belongs in the latter category. But it's no mere crass enclave of glitz and glitter - it's got culture, too.'' - The San Francisco Examiner, ''Art Treasures of Upper East Side,'' by William A. Davis (reprinted from The Boston Globe), Aug. 6, 1989. ''To visit Harlem is to see tourists by the busloads, people of all races, pouring in by day, visiting the restaurants, museums and landmarks, and even taking Sunday-morning bus tours of the gospel churches.
''At night, the jazz and supper clubs draw them in, with swing and crooners and an atmosphere reminiscent of Harlem's great heyday during Prohibition . . . .'' - Des Moines Sunday Register, ''Harlem Beckons to Visitors With New Carefree Look,'' by Roy H. Campbell, March 20, 1988.
''. . . there are curious souls who have always wanted a peek at quaint Greenwich Village. Throughout the 20th century, the village has sustained its reputation as a separate, eccentric enclave for impassioned intellectuals and artists living in unfettered style. Blocks are short, streets are narrow enough to keep traffic to a reasonable pace. Three-story, 1820-ish Federal houses with eight-paneled doors and two-dormer windows on top establish a humane ambiance.'' - The Boston Sunday Globe, ''Greenwich Village, Still the City's Cultural and Artistic Pacesetter,'' by Leslie Gourse, March 25, 1990. ''Manhattanites are brilliant at inventing excuses for never leaving their gleaming, steel-and-glass canyons and overpriced roosts. For them, New York's four outer boroughs are largely terra incognita - not quite as reprehensible as 'Jersey,' but certainly unworthy of more than oblique consideration. It's not fair.'' - The Washington Post, ''New York, Boroughing Out: Reyond the Core of the Big Apple,'' by David Yeadon, April 22, 1990. ''In the past two decades, Queens has experienced an influx of immigrants from many South American countries. Unfortunately, the most prominent mention they get in the press is when drug dealers shoot at one another in the borough's streets. The fact is that they have brought some delicious cuisine to Anglos who aren't frightened by the grossly exaggerated reputation of Queens as Medellin North.
''Walking through areas of Elmhurst and Jackson Heights actually is fun for several reasons. It's almost like taking a mini-tour of Colombia, Peru, Argentina and Ecuador without having your passport stamped.'' - The Washington Post, ''Queens Cuisine: Ethnic Eateries Serving Up Sizzle, Spice and Soul,'' by Grace Lichtenstein, April 22, 1990.
 
Views
From the Brooklyn Bridge: ''We stepped onto the bridge from the Brooklyn side - and it was a walk into a new world. I had been seeing the city up close - on subways, in cabs and down shadowed streets of midtown - but suddenly I had distance, perspective and light. Manhattan was unveiled, with skyscrapers so packing the island's southern tip that if the city were on a seesaw, Harlem would be high in the air.'' - The Washington Post, ''The City From Afar: Stepping Out on the Brooklyn Bridge,'' by John Donnelly, April 22, 1990.
From the water: ''Seeing Manhattan offshore is witnessing the town at its most theatrical. During daylight hours the dramatic skyline rises from the harbor like dragon's teeth. At dusk, when the buildings' lights blink on, the city offers its own fantastic light show, the greatest on Earth.'' - The Boston Sunday Globe, ''Down to the Sea in Ships - New York Style,'' by Thomas O'Neill, July 1, 1990.
 
Bargains
''Vintage clothes are a good buy in New York City, where top dealers offer a wide range of styles for a fraction of the cost of contemporary clothing.'' - Los Angeles Times, ''New York and Old Clothes Make for Bargains,'' by Jennifer Merin, Feb. 4, 1990. ''Rack rates for double rooms start at $245 at the Plaza, for instance, and $295 at the Pierre. Yet the city also has a number of good hotels - attractive, convenient and in safe neighborhoods - that are moderately priced. That is, their rates are half or less those charged by top-tier properties.''
Among the recommendations: the Wales, Algonquin, Iroquois, Mansfield, Wentworth, Remington, Washington Square Hotel, Vanderbilt Y.M.C.A. and Leo House. - The Seattle Times, ''Mid-Priced Hotel Rooms Getting Easier to Find,'' by William A. Davis (reprinted from The Boston Globe), Jan. 1, 1990. ''Campus Holidays USA is offering to arrange clean, safe, economical accommodations in the New York City area for young travelers in the residences at Stevens University. The campus is in the suburb of Hoboken, just two stops by metro from Greenwich Village. . . .'' - Los Angeles Times, ''Youth Beat: Summer Options for New York City,'' by Lucy Izon, April 1, 1990.

HEADLINE: Living on the Edge of Conflict

BYLINE: Laura R. Blumenfeld; Laura R. Blumenfeld is a graduate student at Columbia University's School of International and Public Affairs.

 BODY:
''The Kuwaitis are thieves. Saddam is just claiming what is rightfully his.'' ''Saddam Hussein will save the Arabs as Mohammed and Saladdin did.'' ''Kuwaitis spent their money on jewels and cars instead of the Arab cause. They deserve it.''
''Why does the world yell? When Israel invaded Palestine, no one cared.''
Amman is abuzz with pejorative stories about Kuwaitis: In Kuwaiti emergency rooms, no other Arabs are treated until every splinter is removed from Kuwaiti fingers. Kuwaiti landlords expel Arab tenants for no reason. Kuwaiti men rape their maids. Kuwaitis are just like Jews. 
 
PUB-DATE: August 9, 1990
We got a call from the Prime Minister's office this morning, confirming that the Jordanian government would join United Nations economic sanctions against Iraq. None of the political officers were around, so I took the message, hand shaking. A lot of hands are shaking around here. At around noon air-raid sirens went off around the city. A friend who works next to civil defense headquarters told me that at the sound of the siren, crews pulled on white uniforms and started screeching down the driveway in ambulances. Then word got out - it was only a test. They rushed back into the building. An hour later sirens again rrrrrrrrr-ed through the air. Out tumbled the civil defense crews, yelling, ''Hurry, hurry! The Israelis are here!'' only to trudge back up the driveway a few minutes later.
There has been a rush of Americans registering with the embassy and phoning in to check on the security situation. One woman burst into tears when a consular officer told her she'd have to wait three days to pick up her renewed passport. ''By then,'' she sobbed, ''all the Americans will be evacuated and I'll be stranded!''
Arabs are coming to us for help, too. Jordanians with children born in the States are asking to be evacuated along with their ''Amcit'' (diplomatic jargon for American citizen) kids. Dispirited Kuwaitis are standing in our visa line and applying for refugee status. We had to call in a consular officer from Damascus to help us with the flood.
Among embassy staff, the theme is confusion. We'll have a meeting to discuss the crisis, and then another meeting to analyze the discussion of the crisis, and then yet one more meeting to review the analysis of the discussion of the meeting about the crisis. One diplomat, who had waited all night at the Iraq-Jordan border in case Amcits crossed over, said the poor crisis management was shocking. ''Everything's so disorganized and incoherent,'' the diplomat told me behind a closed door. ''When our time comes to evacuate, I'm going to run across the street to the Royal Jordanian airline office, book a flight, and go. I wouldn't depend on this embassy to get me out of here.''
The increased threat of a terrorist attack or a run on the compound has staff members altering their daily schedules. Some are leaving overnight bags in the embassy in case the building's surrounded. And our tightly coiled nerves are just being further jangled by the barrage of ''Oh my God Jordan was on TV are you still alive?'' calls from the States. Suddenly everyone back home is dialing Amman. My mom has been phoning for a daily ''voice check.'' Just to say hi, she says.
The other Columbia summer intern in Jordan - she was working for a nonprofit agency - decided to forget about her nonrefundable round-trip ticket and leave the country immediately, ''before something happens.'' All flights to New York are booked. So she flew out this morning to Germany and will improvise from there.
Some locals are leaving, too. A bunch of wealthier Palestinians and Jordanians I know are going to Europe to ''sit this one out.'' ''We can't stand it any more,'' one woman said. Today a young Lebanese woman who had moved to Amman after her brother was killed by a shell in Beirut said she was going back. She thinks, at this point, it's safer in Lebanon.
Jordanians who are staying put are preparing for war. People are buying flour, rice and sugar in bulk. They're filling jerrycans with water and kerosene. I met a young mother hauling a crate out of the local grocery. ''It is Pampers for my baby,'' the woman explained. ''One year's supply.'' At the curb, another shopper filled her entire trunk with eight-packs of toilet paper.
Mostly, people are doing a lot of sitting around and panicking. One woman tried to convey the mood to me, translating an Arabic saying. ''We are sitting in the palm of a monkey,'' she explained, holding out a cupped hand. ''We have no control,'' she said, flipping her hand over, spilling imaginary bodies onto the sidewalk.
My Arabic teacher has adopted a fatalistic attitude. ''What can we be doing?'' she said, stopping midsentence while translating a newspaper article. ''We don't have bombing shelters. And we only hold off the Israelis for 20 minutes anyway.'' She has gone from teaching me vocabulary words like ''peace process'' to those like ''warning'' and ''provoke.'' This past week we learned ''gas attack'' and ''total destruction.''
Meanwhile, from what I can gather, Israel is strangely calm. I don't know what's going on over there on a popular level, but Israel's TV news has virtually ignored the blowup. Two nights in a row, the 9 P.M. news spent most of the report covering the murder and funeral of two Israeli boys. Not that the deaths aren't important. But when at 9:22 they say, almost as an afterthought, ''And the U.S. deployed troops in Saudi Arabia today,'' you wonder, why the nonchalance?
O.K., to be fair: Tonight, finally, the anchorman did assure viewers that Iraqi rockets don't have enough power to lob chemical warheads into Israel. An Iraqi missile wouldn't reach far enough, the report said. That probably popped out a few eyeballs around this
 
PUB-DATE: August 10, 1990
1 P.M. I've been grounded. First I was supposed to go to Jerusalem this weekend, but that's off because the Allenby Bridge could be sealed off at any time and I'd be ''stranded'' in Israel. Then I was supposed to go to Wadi Rum, near Aqaba, where ''Lawrence of Arabia'' was filmed. But the embassy task force set up to handle the crisis said I shouldn't go. ''Because of the circumstances, we need to be able to reach you,'' I was told.
I'm worried about my friend Howard, who has been spending the summer as an intern in Baghdad. He was supposed to have arrived here already as part of an embassy drawdown; yesterday, a convoy of five U.S. embassy cars, with 10 ''nonessential staff and dependents,'' including Howard, among its passengers, plus five dogs and two cats, made its way to the Iraq-Jordan border. At the last minute, though, border officials refused to let the convoy pass. Late in the afternoon, one of our officers radioed the news in to the embassy from the border checkpoint. We all sat there in a stupor; I was picturing Howard, sitting in one of the convoy cars, driving again through the desert, seven relentless hours back to Baghdad.
Around Amman, groups are distributing leaflets calling for volunteers to fight America. For days, ads hailing Iraq, praising the King's support for Saddam and assailing America have dominated local papers. Most of them feature pictures of the King of Jordan and Saddam side by side. Sometimes a smiling Arafat or Qaddafi appears with them. But Egypt's president Mubarak is jerk of the week. ''Hang Mubarak,'' ''He is the worst traitor!'' and ''Mubarak is son of Sadat'' - people are saying these things on the street. A rumor that Mubarak had been assassinated brought Jordanians to their feet, cheering and applauding. Saudi Arabia is no favorite either. The latest local joke:
U.S.A. stands for United States of Arabia.
Tomorrow is a national holiday, celebrating the 38th anniversary of King Hussein's accession to the throne. Citizens are hoisting flags all over the city. Oddly, while the King is perceived here as vigorously pro-Iraqi, he has quietly announced that Jordan will join United Nations economic sanctions against Iraq. I keep wondering: What will happen when Jordanians realize the King is double-crossing Saddam?
 
7 P.M. A reporter friend just called and told me about an anti-U.S. demonstration at the university here. The Muslim Brotherhood and Palestinian groups organized it. Ten thousand people screamed, ''We will drink American blood!'' and ''Saudi has sinned asking non-Muslims to defend the holy places!'' The crowd cheered, waving Iraqi, Palestinian and Jordanian flags. On top of a mosque, American, British and Israeli flags shriveled up in flames. Demonstrators swarmed around foreign correspondents, demanding to know if they were Americans. An Egyptian cameraman was beaten bloody. My friend said he kept yelling: ''I am Italian! Italian! Spaghetti! Fettuccine!'' Just two weeks ago I'd been trotting around campus looking for ''University of Jordan'' T-shirts. Everyone I spoke with said friendly things like ''American, yes? Ahhh! Welcome!''
 
PUB-DATE: August 11, 1990
Howard's free!
Sitting around the ambassador's pool, I overheard a political officer tell someone: This time the Iraqis let the embassy convoy cross.
I scrambled over to the Regency Palace Hotel, where the embassy had prepared to receive the original 10 Americans (and their pets), plus Penelope Nabokov. She is a 10-year-old girl who had been traveling alone when her plane was stranded in Kuwait. Having been moved to Baghdad, she was allowed by the Iraqis to join the American convoy at the last minute.
I flashed my embassy ID at the security men in the lobby and bounded out of the elevator on the 11th floor. ''Are they here yet?'' I gulped, tripping on a port-a-pooch box with a little white poodle inside. Suitcases littered the hallway.
The Baghdad bunch were in a meeting. There was disagreement about travel plans. Embassy staff explained to me that they had to get out of Jordan quickly, before terrorists or journalists got to them. (I'm not sure which the embassy considered worse.) But some were refusing to fly out tonight, because the carrier couldn't take all five dogs and two cats. Finally they emerged. Howard picked me up in the air and twirled me around. I kept poking him and saying: ''You're O.K.! You're here!''
Two hours later, they were gone to Paris. I rode, under heavy security, with Howard and the others on the bus to the airport. TV crews lighted paths for us on leaving the hotel and arriving at Queen Alia International Airport. Reporters called out, ''How do you feel?'' But no one said a word. The only one who reacted to the flashing cameras was Penelope. ''They called out my name!'' she said, skipping inside the airport terminal. ''How do those strange people know me?''
It hurt, saying goodbye to Howard. After 10 agitated days, praying to see his face, it was hard to watch it vanish again so soon. As the airport elevator doors closed on the Baghdad refugees, one called out to me, ''You should be going with us!''
I wish I were.
 
August 12
Anti-American protests are everywhere. So many different groups are sponsoring them, the embassy has put together a demonstrations-and-rallies schedule, like a TV Guide. Jordanians are ordinarily careful to distinguish between their hatred of American policy and their admiration for Americans themselves, the American life style. ''It's nothing personal,'' they've been telling me all summer.
Now, however, it feels personal. No acts of violence yet, but it's just a matter of time, people say. The anti-American rhetoric is growing more intense, graphic, bloody. In the market this morning, three veiled Arab women, usually the epitome of reserve, screamed at an American friend of mine, ''America bad, bad, bad!'' Yesterday, Tareq Masarweh, a respected columnist in the Arabic Ar-Rai paper, wrote: ''Let the U.S., Britain, France and the other looters mass their troops and fleets to kill the Iraqi people. At the first shot, we will kill you on every Arab street and we will turn the earth red.''
Today, in an interview with a foreign journalist, Masarweh said: ''If America attacks Iraq, I will personally go out into the streets and kill Americans. So will many others.''
The International Lions Club of Jordan has called for ''popular committees to extend support for Iraq and to alleviate effects of the siege; special popular committees for mobilization of masses to confront the imperialist-Zionist onslaught; striking at U.S. and British interests and the interests of any country who supports them.''
All this talk about striking at ''American interests'' has set our local hires on edge. The intifada ''collaborator syndrome,'' where fear of being hacked up by compatriots keeps Palestinians from cooperating with Israel, soon may surface in Jordan as well.
Even the international telephone operators are getting into the anti-West spirit. Usually when I attempt overseas calls, the male operators flirt. Typically, they respond to my ''Call the United States, please'' with: ''Ahh, collect from Loora? That a very beoooootiful name! You are very very pretty O.K.?''
Now though, when I start speaking English, the operators promptly hang up on me. Click. Finally, I've caught on and try to muddle through in Arabic. Last night the guy placed my call but demanded first, ''Are you a Muslim or a foreigner?'' No more chitchat with the American ladies. And tonight, when I tried to call my dad, the operator said in chilly tones, ''We know you working embassy America.''
Still, hatred toward the United States is not without its inconsistencies. A small anti-American, flag-waving demonstration materialized next to the embassy today. Police broke it up before it really got going. A friend of mine ran to see it, but the crowd had just scattered. ''What happened?'' he asked a Jordanian soldier guarding the embassy. The soldier pointed his machine gun over to a Jordanian standing on the visa line for the States. ''Ask him, over there,'' the guard said. ''He participated.''
A few, very few, Jordanians acknowledge the downside to Saddam's Gulf War II. First of all, people are afraid it will disrupt the flow of remittances that Palestinian and Jordanian migrant laborers send back home. ''When my brother used to come visit us from Kuwait, he'd carry 10 suitcases,'' said a Palestinian girl. ''All the brothers and sisters got presents - one suitcaseful each.'' Now she worries her brother will lose his job.
Palestinians and Jordanians fear that Saudi Arabia will punish them for supporting Iraq and bar them from employment. Also, if Jordan ends up getting dragged into a war, plenty of suffering will follow. ''My friends say they are happy to starve for the Arab cause,'' a Jordanian woman told me. ''But for how long?''
Only one Arab among the dozens I've spoken to actually criticized Saddam. The man, a policeman, described Iraq's leader as ''a not good.'' ''Then why does everyone love him so much?'' I asked. The policeman said nothing. He just stood there, watching traffic, shifting his weight back and forth - right leg, left; right leg, left. I thought he didn't understand my question. Just as I began to drift down the sidewalk he said, ''People love to be slaves.''
 
PUB-DATE: August 14, 1990
6 P.M. My last day of work at the embassy was so frenetic, no one had time to say goodbye. Only one officer wandered into my office. ''You know, I read about you in Thomas Friedman's book 'From Beirut to Jerusalem,' '' he said. Gulp. All summer people have been saying things like, ''Hey, I heard you were in the Friedman book.'' But no one actually remembers the pages about me, which is good, considering I talk about my yeshiva education and the time terrorists shot my father while he was on vacation in Jerusalem. ''So you're pretty Jewish then, huh?'' the officer said. ''Uhhhh,'' I said, thinking ''Trust the guy.'' He'd always struck me as one of the more tolerant people in the embassy when it comes to Jews. He said he was appalled by the anti-Semitic rhetoric he's heard from American diplomats, who talk about rich New York Jews controlling the government, the media and the banks.
Perhaps, since it was the last day of my internship, it was time to divulge closely guarded secrets. I didn't want anyone to overhear us, so I took a piece of paper and wrote in pencil: ''Well, you know how I always say I'm vegetarian? I love meat. But I keep kosher.'' He looked very surprised, but I think he understood. I took another piece of paper and wrote, ''And my father isn't really a professor.'' No? his eyebrows asked. ''He's a rabbi. We're eight generations of rabbis,'' I scribbled. What a brief flash of freedom, to finally tell someone in Jordan who I really am and where I really come from! When I got home from work, I soaked the penciled notes in a sinkful of water and flushed them.
 
1 A.M. A friend and I just got back from night swimming in the Dead Sea. The salty water popped my body up into the black air. What a relief to get away from Amman and the news and the cable traffic from Washington.
I asked a waiter at the beachfront hotel about the lights on the opposite shore. ''Jerusalem,'' the waiter said.
''Really?'' I asked. ''Right there? I heard Jerusalem was far from here.'' I looked down, drawing toe spirals in the sand.
''No, that's Jerusalem.'' He sounded sure. ''It's all Jerusalem. Everything they took - for us is Jerusalem,'' he said, staring off at the pinkish lights.
I had always wondered, all those times standing on the Israeli side of the Dead Sea, what people thought across the border. Now I guess I know. Driving back to Amman, we saw a tank mounted on a truck. It rumbled down the road toward the Jordan Valley, toward Israel. One tank, no big deal.
I had just finished reassuring myself when we pulled around a bend, and there, as far as we could see, stretched a convoy of trucks, all carrying tanks. None of the trucks had headlights on, just dim red beams. ''Quick, turn on the radio!'' I said. We hadn't heard the news in several hours. These days, whole countries are conquered in that time.
There was nothing new on the news. What would Iraq want in Jordan anyway? It's not like it has any precious natural resources like oil to covet. Fertilizer is one of Jordan's top exports, along with phosphates.
True, Iraqis may just be passing through on their way to Israel. Saddam could attack Israel and Saudi Arabia and in one swoop liberate all three holy cities captive to Western implants. Which reminds me: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria has just been added to the imperialist-Zionist list. Jordanian-Syrian relations have always been tenuous. So Assad's signaled willingness to cooperate with the West has triggered a chorus of ''We told you he was a traitor!'' around Jordan. I heard one Jordanian refer to him today as ''the bought one.'' He insisted the deposed Kuwaiti Emir bought Assad with ''hundreds of billions of millions of dollars.'' It was clear to us all along, the man said, that Syria's leader was a Zionist.
Even before the invasion, conspiracy theories raged. Everyone from my doorman to ministry directors has confided to me at some point: ''You know, so-and-so is really backed by blah-di-blah.'' The C.I.A. funds the Muslim Brotherhood; Yitzhak Shamir supports the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine; King Hussein is an Iranian agent; Israel and the Palestinians are plotting to take over Saudi Arabia.
Today's conspiracy: The U.S. and Israel are secretly preparing to conquer Aqaba.
 
PUB-DATE: August 15, 1990
3 P.M. I'm on a Royal Jordanian flight to the States. No one at the embassy believed I'd actually make it. There's such a mad crush of people trying to fly out. At the airport, suitcases, travelers and security guards churned around like a storm. I had to use my rudest New Yorker's voice to get a seat. And I'm ashamed to say I even yelled at a nice Swedish man who ran over my toe with his luggage cart.
I'm choking in the last row of the smoking section, sitting in the middle of a Jordanian family of seven. The father says he is the royal dentist in Saudi Arabia for King Fahd's brother. The Saudi prince fled the country for England. So the dentist decided to leave too, for the States. ''I take a month vacation from Saudi Arabia,'' the dentist tells me, patting his screaming 2-year-old. ''And then what, you'll go back?'' I ask. ''If there is a back,'' he says with a strained smile.
A group of American students who studied Arabic at Yarmouk University in Jordan this summer are sitting in front of me. One just pulled out the Royal Jordanian flight route map. ''Hey guys, check it out, Kuwait's still on the map!'' he says, laughing. The students say they were treated great all summer. Jordanian students were superfriendly and constantly invited them home for weekends. ''But ever since this Iraq-Kuwait thing,'' one guy says unhappily, ''they really chilled out toward us.''
10 P.M. Eastern daylight time. My parents met me at the airport. As I walked out of customs into the surge of anxious families, I spotted my mother wearing a clown nose and a stars-and-stripes Uncle Sam hat. ''Now we can sleep at night,'' said my father. I'm home.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 3, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1469 words

HEADLINE: The Underside of the Stones

BYLINE: By JON PARELES; Jon Pareles is the chief pop music critic of The New York Times.

 BODY:
The Jones murder scenario makes a slender foundation for a book with the vast pretensions of ''Blown Away.'' Mr. Hotchner, the author of the memoir ''Papa Hemingway'' and biographies of Doris Day and Sophia Loren, professes to map the course of the 1960's against the ascent of the Rolling Stones. Jones, the son of an aeronautical engineer from Cheltenham, England, put an ad in a musicians' magazine that brought together some working-class kids who loved rhythm-and-blues; he named the group the Rolling Stones, and it worked its way from the back rooms of pubs to arenas full of screaming fans. The arc ends, for the book's purposes, with Jones's drowning in July 1969 and the Altamont, Calif., concert that December, at which three people died and many more were beaten by Hell's Angels who had been hired as a security force. 
With such convenient and well-worn symbols, the author tries to wrap the latest addition to the genre of nasty biography - exemplified by Albert Goldman's wildly slanted ''Lives of John Lennon'' - in portents of significance. ''More than any other rock group,'' Mr. Hotchner writes, ''the Stones were a product of their times.'' Not that the author appears to have done much research into the sociology, history, politics, economics or demographics that might illuminate the 60's. Mr. Hotchner does try to rename the generation that came of age in that decade as the Jagger Generation. But for insights into the culture of the 60's, look elsewhere; ''Blown Away'' is about digging up dirt.
The method echoes books like ''Edie: An American Biography,'' edited by Jean Stein and George Plimpton, and ''I, Tina'' by Tina Turner and Kurt Loder. Long quotes, from sources whose credibility the reader must determine, are held together by driblets of narrative. Mr. Hotchner's book includes interviews with the Stones' friends and lovers and assorted, sometimes irrelevant contemporaries, like the fashion designer Mary Quant. ''Blown Away'' reads like it was word-processed rather than edited, with frequent repetition and clunky transitions. Try this one: ''Rock music was also destined to become another great leveler but the Stones were finding it difficult to emerge from the bleak obscurity of the back room at the Wetherby Arms.''
The dirt on the Rolling Stones has been sifted and resifted, with far more style, in books like Philip Norman's ''Life and Good Times of the Rolling Stones,'' Stanley Booth's ''Dance With the Devil'' and Chet Flippo's tour diary ''It's Only Rock and Roll.'' With the Stones' help, researchers have long since tabulated who snorted what when and who bedded whom how. Although the current band members did not give interviews to Mr. Hotchner, they have been candid with other journalists, from whom ''Blown Away'' borrows generously. By now, anyone who cares about the Stones knows that Mick Jagger is ambitious, that Keith Richards became a heroin addict and that Brian Jones had a drug problem and a violent, unpredictable temper, including a tendency to beat his girlfriends that is well documented by ''Blown Away.''
What's not documented is the music. ''Blown Away'' tells the story of some unkempt, amateurish rhythm-and-blues fans who grew up to be nasty, selfish rock stars; how they were capable of stirring thousands of people remains a mystery. Mr. Hotchner's interviewees go on about Mr. Jagger's pansexual appeal. But no one points out that the Jagger-Richards team came up with brilliant songs about the nexus of sex and power and desire - songs that, far from being bound by the 60's, have dated hardly at all. Some are still misconstrued; Mr. Hotchner, eager to blast the Stones as Satanic, hasn't figured out that ''Sympathy for the Devil'' might just be ironic.
One endlessly repeated motif in ''Blown Away'' is that Mr. Jagger and Mr. Richards ousted Jones from the band in 1969 - something the author treats as a horrifying betrayal. According to ''Blown Away,'' Jones taught Mr. Jagger how to play harmonica and was the inspiration for the singer's dance moves. Again and again, the book insists that Mr. Jagger and Mr. Richards were conspiring to remove Jones and that they had illegitimately wrested the leadership of the band from him. At first, Jones may have been the most skilled musician among the Stones' founders. But rock has less to do with technique than with originality. Jones's eclipse began when the band started playing its own material; Mr. Jagger and Mr. Richards could write songs while Jones could not. As singer and lyricist, Mr. Jagger naturally became the focus of the band.
If Mr. Hotchner wants to indict the songwriters for their disloyalty, he almost inadvertently tells a different story. While he extols Jones's musicianship, his dirt-seeking leads him to reveal Jones as increasingly unstable and drug-addled, missing concerts and messing up recording sessions. In his most chilling chapter, ''The Persecution of the Stones,'' Mr. Hotchner details the repeated drug raids directed at the band members, raids that led an already paranoid Jones to have a nervous breakdown around the end of 1967. As the Stones became a world-class band with professional obligations, it seems amazing that they kept Jones in the band as long as they did; eventually, loyalty had to give way to the music. The last Stones album with Jones, ''Beggars Banquet,'' was one of their best, but so were three that followed it: ''Let It Bleed,'' ''Sticky Fingers'' and ''Exile on Main Street.''
Mr. Hotchner admits that the Stones became experts in the studio, but misunderstands what they did there: ''Their imaginative mastery of the very complicated process of taking a simple song once it was taped and enhancing it with all the electronic apparatus available in a high-tech studio has been the key to the success of their songs, although, of course, studio inventiveness is meaningless unless the song itself has strong ingredients.'' Actually, the Stones didn't save modest little ditties with studio sweetening; they made studio work inaudible, creating the sound of a lean, tough band playing together on an inspired night.
While Mr. Hotchner uses Jones's ouster to pillory the Stones, his heart seems to be elsewhere. ''Blown Away'' reveals an obsession with the class system. The author genuflects before titles; Prince Rupert Loewenstein, who became the Stones' accountant, ''is an authentic member of the House of Hapsburg'' who ''scintillates elegance from his Savile Row dark-blue suit to his custom-tailored shirt with his initials discreetly on the cuff.''
Despite the upheavals of the 60's, the class system wasn't overturned. And Mr. Hotchner is disgruntled. For him, the Stones' success was just a means to unseemly social climbing. Mr. Jagger, he writes, ''yearned for someone with class and good breeding who, by her association with him, could elevate him from the level of being a pop singer from a lower-middle-class family.'' But in the chapter called ''Requiem for the Jagger Generation'' - itemizing the ways the 60's didn't remake the world - his first item is ''The Class System,'' under which he writes, ''Rock stars are no longer referred to as 'new royalty.' '' Jones's death fulfills the author's obsession; it is the revenge of the brutish laboring classes on a proper middle-class lad.
It is, of course, absurd to blame the Stones for the death of the 60's; they never pretended to be anything but performers, and the band survived the decade much better than most of its contemporaries. The Stones made bad mistakes in public - like taking the advice of San Francisco bands, who should have known better, on whom to hire for the security force at the Altamont concert. But the Rolling Stones never pretended to be saints, and it seems that Mr. Hotchner's real complaint in ''Blown Away'' is that you can't always get what you want.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 11, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1418 words

HEADLINE: Something's Gone Terribly Wrong in New York

BYLINE: By J. ANTHONY LUKAS; J. Anthony Lukas is the author of ''Common Ground: A Turbulent Decade in the Lives of Three American Families,'' which won a Pulitzer Prize for general nonfiction in 1986.

 BODY:
With allowance for the hyperbole of a bedazzled visitor, this was the city of my youth, the enchanted island in which I grew up and to which I later returned on vacations from college, on furlough from the Army or simply because, in those heady years, it was the center of my universe.
It was the city of Fiorello La Guardia and Bill O'Dwyer, of Glenn Miller and Duke Ellington, of A. J. Liebling and Max Lerner, of King Kong Keller and Jackie Robinson, of Lionel Trilling and Mary McCarthy. It had its misery and its slums, its racial injustice and its social obtuseness, but somehow it had a rough and ready openness; a respect for excellence, whether in hitting high C or turning a double play; a willingness to give any kid on the playground his shot at the yawning basket of life.
This is the city that shadows Jim Sleeper's mournful and angry book. ''The Closest of Strangers'' is a moving elegy for that ''unique civic culture,'' a lost world whose ''irrepressible idea was that, even as each of us is raised in some ethnic, racial, or religious community, each of us can, as an American and especially as a New Yorker, decide to transcend anything in our pasts that has made us small and contribute to a unique urban experiment that E. B. White called 'cosmopolitan, mighty and unparalleled.' '' 
Now, in what he calls the ''depths of our civic night'' - in the wake of Bernhard Goetz, Howard Beach, Tawana Brawley, Bensonhurst and the Central Park jogger - Mr. Sleeper believes that this ethos has been pulverized by the collision of narrow self-interests, an insistence on viewing the world through the distorting lens of race, a refusal to accept basic standards of personal accountability and civil order.
And he asks with rising indignation, even despair, ''Who would want to remain in such a city?''
This cry may strike some as a trifle apocalyptic. After all, there have been other junctures in the city's history when there seemed ample grounds for despair. The draft riots of 1863, when rioters, most of them Irish, killed blacks by the score, and the Triangle Shirtwaist fire of 1911, when capitalist exploitation of immigrant labor aroused rage, are two that come to mind.
Nonetheless, the central thrust of Mr. Sleeper's question will resonate in many New Yorkers: that something has gone terribly wrong in our city - and, by extension, in many troubled communities across the land; that we have let our standards of civility and truth waste dangerously away; that we are awash in poisonous tides we seem powerless to beat back.
A savvy editorial writer for New York Newsday who in 1987 edited a splendid special issue of Dissent magazine on New York, Mr. Sleeper wishes to provoke us into a searching re-examination of our preconceptions on race and class. He calls his book a ''conversation with fellow New Yorkers.''
Unfortunately, it is frequently less a conversation than a shouting match. For, unlike his introduction to the Dissent issue, in which he evenhandedly distributed responsibility for the city's malaise, this book makes only passing reference to ''brutal, calculating'' real estate speculators and the ''self-absorbed'' middle class of the 1980's. Instead, he heaps a lion's share of the blame on certain ''black leaders and their left-liberal apologists.''
Page after page, we get numbing variations on this theme: ''activist lawyers and social engineers,'' ''left-leaning civil libertarians,'' ''militant black and Hispanic leaders,''
''black-nationalist educational reformers,'' ''white leftists and black militants,'' ''coldly hostile affirmative action elites.'' Or we get sentences like this: ''The confluence of radical spite, absurd legal extrapolations, and liberal disdain for white ethnics that led to forced busing, the bloating of welfare rolls, and the mau-mauing of white teachers broke the spine of New York's civic culture.''
It is not the ideological content of these phrases to which I object - for, appearances notwithstanding, Mr. Sleeper is by no means a neoconservative dogmatist - it is the empty clang of the language, the sheer banality of such labels, like graffiti scrawled on a brick wall.
In distinguishing himself from the neoconservatives, Mr. Sleeper shrewdly points out that ''they need to recall that the fallen have stories. Listening well to such stories is an acknowledgment of their bearers' dignity.'' But ''activist lawyers'' and ''social engineers'' have stories too. Their abstract positions grow from a rich humus of sentiment, perception and experience, which is sadly lacking in these pages.
This is too bad, because Jim Sleeper is usually a thoughtful man, who combines a streetwise feel for New York's neighborhoods with a solid grounding in political theory and a passion for the tough questions. Here he has boldly, if sometimes injudiciously, addressed the biggest issues in urban America. ''The Closest of Strangers'' offers a number of important insights that are not vitiated by the screech of his rhetoric.
In a searching critique of the legalistic bent of recent American liberalism, Mr. Sleeper argues that the great legal victories of recent years - Brown v. Board of Education and Roe v. Wade, to mention only two - have seduced liberals away from the mundane tasks of organizing, education and - yes - politics. As they grew ever more adept at addressing judges, they forgot how to persuade their fellow Americans. But liberals soon discovered ''the limits of the law's ability to untangle the pathologies of white racism in a capitalist economy.''
And here his argument about the limits of legalism joins with an even more important argument about the importance of class in American society. The reliance on the courts, he says, ''represents a fateful, typically American dodging of the reality of social class divisions, which are arguably more fundamental than racial divisions in perpetuating social injustice. . . . The law can address injustices based solely on race, but, because it protects private property and the freedom of capital to invest or disinvest as its owners see fit, the law cannot as easily address injustices rooted in economic class distinctions.''
In these pages, Mr. Sleeper sounds more like the social democrat or socialist I suspect he is than the crabbed Bourbon some of his less temperate language evokes. Yet there is a curious paradox in Mr. Sleeper's argument. In plumping - correctly, I think - for political action to address matters of class, he collides head-on with his elegiac pleas for a return to a civic culture rooted in ''old-fashioned notions of republican, even 'bourgeois,' virtue.''
Virtue - a word not heard much these days - is a time-honored notion rooted in Aristotelian and Platonic thought. Up through the centuries its emphasis on the commonality of citizens has been an antidote to interest-based politics, whether of class or race. In seeking to dissolve narrow racial thinking in a new civic virtue, therefore, Mr. Sleeper undercuts his plea for a politics that frankly confronts class, a divisive ''interest'' if ever there was one.
With all its failings, ''The Closest of Strangers'' is a valuable sifting of the shibboleths and pieties that often impede our most ambitious social programs. At a time when a White House official, after surveying the nation's antipoverty efforts, can conclude that the best option is to ''keep playing with the same toys. But let's paint them a little shinier,'' we need all the searching re-examinations we can get. But we can do without any more name-calling.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 10, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 918 words

HEADLINE: The English Revolution in America

BYLINE: By FORREST McDONALD; Forrest McDonald's most recent book is ''Requiem: Variations on Eighteenth-Century Themes.''

 BODY:
The sketches and essays are diverse. Mr. Bailyn's approaches to the three Thomases of the American Revolutionary epoch - Jefferson, Hutchinson and Paine - are as different from one another as the subjects were, but they are held together by a common theme: the influence of ideas on the politics of the period. More specifically, each is directed toward expanding, correcting, elaborating and illustrating the thesis Mr. Bailyn first advanced in his extremely influential 1967 book, ''The Ideological Origins of the American Revolution.''
That thesis runs roughly as follows: 18th-century Americans viewed political activity through an ideological prism that for the most part had been shaped by English thinkers involved in the effort to deny the throne to Charles II's Roman Catholic brother, James, in 1679-81. The successful outcome of the Glorious Revolution of 1688 pushed the essential concepts of these thinkers to the peripheries of English debate, but through the writings of the opposition there - mainly John Trenchard and Thomas Gordon (writing as Cato), Viscount Bolingbroke and James Burgh - they were absorbed into the mainstream in America. The oppositionist litany included: a fear of standing armies; a rigid insistence that power must be restrained by a mixed form of government with checks and balances; an obsession with corruption, luxury and vice; a belief that speculation in the public debt and other ''paper'' wealth was the root of most evil; a nostalgia for a simpler, pristine agrarian past; and, above all, an almost paranoid fear of conspiracies of wicked and designing men to deprive the people of their liberties. When, in the 1760's, Parliament ended the period of salutary neglect toward the colonies and began trying to tax Americans and regulate their trade, Americans far and wide perceived the efforts as being part of a studied design to reduce them to slavery.
Mr. Bailyn's thesis, based as it was upon a sampling of the pamphlet literature of the Revolution, mainly in New England, might not have made a major splash but for its timing. The historical profession was bored with constitutional explanations, and the long-prevailing economic interpretation associated with Carl Becker and Charles A. Beard had just received a series of fatal blows. The time was ripe for something fresh, and Mr. Bailyn supplied it. His impact was tremendous: in the two decades that followed, ideological interpretation of the whole sweep of American history from the 1760's to the 1840's expanded into a veritable cottage industry.
Rarely has a single book stimulated such a burst of productive scholarship, though the new works often presented alternative formulations of the argument. Mr. Bailyn has little patience with revisionist positions, and while in the present essays he corrects and enlarges his original thesis, he essentially adheres to it.
He is most convincing in three essays, two of which abundantly illustrate the pervasiveness of the oppositionist turn of mind. One is a sketch of an obscure Connecticut minister named Stephen Johnson, who late in 1765 published six newspaper articles and a pamphlet (originally a sermon) that, as Mr. Bailyn shows, anticipated ''almost the entire range of arguments that would be debated in the coming decade.'' Johnson's language and examples are mostly biblical, but his arguments could have been lifted directly from the writings of Bolingbroke or Burgh. The other is a sketch of an even more obscure man with the improbable name of Harbottle Dorr. Dorr, a Boston shopkeeper, apparently sensed that momentous events were in the offing, and early in 1765 he began collecting and copiously annotating local newspapers. When he stopped, 12 years later, he had gathered, bound and indexed 3,280 pages of papers. His running comments, one man's opinions about the great imperial crisis, could likewise have been taken directly from the writings of the opposition: his thoughts were their thoughts.
Another especially persuasive piece is the last in the book, an essay that moves Mr. Bailyn's thesis forward in time to cover the writing and ratification of the Constitution. Anti-Federalists, Mr. Bailyn shows, used the same language against ratification that earlier Americans had used against parliamentary excesses. That is not particularly surprising. What is surprising is the extent to which Federalists, who rejected the oppositionist viewpoint, were nonetheless influenced by it because its widespread acceptance forced them to take it into account. I would have been happier had Mr. Bailyn brought other British thinkers into his pantheon of people who helped shape American political ideas - David Hume, Adam Smith and Sir William Blackstone, for openers. But he has made an unassailable case that the English opposition was central to the thinking of American Revolutionary leaders, anti-Federalists and Jeffersonians.

LENGTH: 1082 words

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
The Next Step in Developing Stamford?

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
The city's Planning Board unanimously opposed the zoning change at a meeting on Aug.1. ''Although we don't object to a floating zone, we feel Mr. Malkin's project is too intense,'' said James Serafino, the chairman, ''and we are concerned about creating a second downtown in the South End, which is primarily residential.''
The Zoning Board will consider the Transportation Center Design District zone tomorrow night. ''So far, the members favor some change in zoning for that area,'' said Joseph Frattarolli, the chairman. ''The question is the amount of change and the amount of activity. We would want a reduced project; how much reduction will be a long conversation.'' 
Among the most outspoken critics of Metro Center II is Robert Rich, president of the F. D. Rich Company, Stamford's designated urban-renewal developer for almost 30 years and the owner of most downtown buildings.
''This is not the time for Metro Center II,'' said Mr. Rich. ''There are too many voids in the city that ought to be filled first.''
The current industrial-residential zoning of the area was intended to prevent office construction there from competing with the city's central business district north of the road and rail corridor.
Mr. Malkin said the $50 million Stewart McKinney Transportation Center, the railroad station completed in 1986, should be the hub of Stamford's next wave of development.
''The future of business will depend on mass transit because the roads can't take it any more,'' he said. ''Every city on the Eastern Seaboard has improved rail traffic, making depots the most important location for new development. It's the one place that can be developed in Stamford without creating additional congestion.''
The Stamford station is a stop for buses, Amtrak and the Metro-North Commuter Railroad. Automobile leasing is available, and south of the station is a 600-car municipal parking garage. The station is flanked by access ramps to Interstate 95. Last month the city announced plans to build food and service stores in the station.
But the area is dark and deserted off-hours and plagued by crime and vandalism, which Mayor Thom Serrani, a staunch supporter of Metro Center II, believes ''can be eliminated by having people working and living there.''
''It's a prime area that is not doing us any good as a wasteland,'' he said.
Current plans for Metro Center II are for 600,000 square feet of offices in two 250-foot-high towers, one at each end of the municipal garage; 400 units of housing in 400,000 square feet south of the garage; landscaped plazas, and 25,000 square feet of service shops such as a food market, a dry cleaner and a bank.
Should the zone be approved, the Chamber of Commerce fears future projects in which substantial retail activity could be introduced. ''It opens the way for more erosion of downtown businesses,'' said Terrance Walsh, the director of the chamber. The anxiety of small retail merchants overwhelmed by the Town Center mall has been sharpened by a recent increase in empty stores on Broad and Bedford Streets.
The Southwest Connecticut Area Commerce and Industry Association has favored development around railroad stations for five years, as does the Regional Plan Association in Manhattan. Both organizations view it as the next phase of development.
Station-area development is under way in White Plains, Newark, New Brunswick, N.J., and Norwalk, where a $100 million commercial-residential project at the South Norwalk station was approved last month. It is to be developed by the Starrett Housing Corporation of New York City.
Three of Rich's buildings in Stamford were recently acquired by Citicorp in an effort to resolve some of the developer's financial problems caused by overbuilding and vacancies.
''Developers, including ourselves,'' Mr. Rich said, ''mistakenly thought that this market had unlimited potential. We were wrong. The market is not that deep.'' He argues that the city's land-use boards allowed millions of square feet to be built in inappropriate places before steps were taken to stop sizable development outside the central business zone.
But there seems to be little interest in downtown Stamford among prospective tenants, who may prefer different locations, newer buildings and specific layouts and sizes.
''The feedback we get from companies interested in coming here is that the train station looks attractive,'' said Joseph Ercolano, vice president of the Southwest Connecticut Area Commerce and Industry Association.
Included in the Metro Center II plan is a commitment to subsidize 10 percent of its housing units for low-income tenants. In addition, Mr. Malkin, a founder of the Stamford Urban League, would donate up to $1.6 million to the South End Neighborhood Foundation as part of the zone change.
The foundation, a coalition of minority groups, intends to makes loans to bring local housing and businesses up to code and to pay for legal services in closing crack houses.
''The South End has been ignored for too many years,'' said Iona Thraen, a member of the foundation's board. ''We want to be part of the development picture.''
Stamford has frequently been chided as a city without an identity. There are those who remember the chaos of urban renewal and worry now about disturbing a completely rebuilt downtown.
''A lot of people who have lived here all their lives resent what's happened,'' said Mayor Serrani. ''But they are thinking of Stamford in a different time.''

PUB-DATE: September 9, 1990

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 1, Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1344 words

HEADLINE: Democrats Offer Contrasts, but Have the Voters Noticed?

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
With the state's economy slumping and the prospect of a huge state budget deficit waiting on the next governor's desk, both Democrats also argue that their talents are urgently needed.
Mr. Cibes, a six-term state legislator and the co-chairman of the General Assembly's Finance, Revenue and Bonding Committee, says the state must adopt a sweeping overhaul of its tax system. He has proposed cutting the sales tax from to 5 percent from 8 percent, reducing the corporate-profits tax to 10 percent from 13.8 percent, eliminating entirely the separate tax on dividends, interest and capital gains and making up the difference with a graduated personal-income tax that would peak at 8 percent for those with income above $100,000.
Mr. Morrison, 45 years old, has represented the Third Congressional District since 1983. He said he rejects the idea of an income tax entirely, unless it is first approved by voters in a statewide referendum, and he argues that Connecticut's economy is too fragile to withstand any new taxes except as a last resort. 
As governor, Mr. Morrison said, he would impose an immediate hiring freeze and concentrate on ''squeezing the dollars harder.''
The Democratic candidates have also proposed differing plans to bolster environmental protection. Mr. Morrison would raise permit fees, for example, to companies that discharge waste and use the money to enhance enforcement. Mr. Cibes would use revenues from the new tax structure for the same end.
 
Rising Above the Primary
Both candidates have also pledged to maintain or increase education grants to local school systems, although Mr. Morrison has not been specific on where he would find money for spending increases in the face of next year's deficit.
For the all the urgency of their rhetoric, the candidates' strategies have worked indirectly to keep the voter turnout low. Mr. Morrison, for example, has sought to rise above the primary by appearing to take on Mr. Weicker and Mr. Rowland now. His television commercials for the primary do not even mention Mr. Cibes until last week.
By contrast, Mr. Cibes, a 47-year-old professor of government at Connecticut College, in New London, has gone in the opposite direction.Instead of concentrating on broad appeals that would increase his name recognition, his campaign has focused on winning over what Mr. Cibes calls ''activist'' Democrats - that minority of the party that would already have been likely to vote in the primary.
Because Mr. Morrison is far better known, almost everyone, including Mr. Cibes, admits that a large turnout would increase Mr. Morrison's chances for victory. But no one knows what the magic voter-turnout number may be for either man.
In the last statewide Democratic primary, the 1982 race for secretary of the state nomination, only 16.7 percent of the party members voted. In the last gubernatorial primary, in 1978, between Gov. Ella T. Grasso and Robert K. Killian, her Lieutenant Governor, 33 percent of the voters came out for a race that raised widespread interest and enthusiasm inside the party.
 
37 Other Nominations
What also remains unknown is the extent to which the low-key gubernatorial primary race could affect turnout for the other races to be decided on Tuesday.
Across the state, 37 other Democratic and Republican nominations are to be decided, ranging from the Democratic nomination for sheriff of Litchfield County to the Democratic registrar of voters in Griswold.
Two State Senate nominations are also to be settled as well as 21 nominations in the State House of Representatives.
There is also one Republican Congressional primary, for the Third District seat in the New Haven area being vacated by Mr. Morrison. In that race, State Senator Thomas Scott, the party-endorsed candidate, faces former State Representative Gerard B. Patton. The winner will face the Democratic nominee, Rosa L. DeLauro on Nov. 6.
 
Final-Day Decisions
Polls throughout the state will be open on Tuesday from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m.
Only registered voters who are enrolled Democrats can vote in the party's gubernatorial primary, but unaffiliated registered voters may take part in the Third District Republican Congressional primary.
Democratic Party leaders also said that whatever calculations the candidates have made through the campaign so far, much of what happens on Tuesday could still be determined in the campaign's final days.
''You can make all the arguments you want prior to Labor Day,'' said the Democratic Party state chairman, John F. Droney Jr. ''But it all peaks this week.''
 
THE CANDIDATES ON THE ISSUES
Here are the views of the two Democratic candidates for governor, United States Representative Bruce A. Morrison and State Representative William J. Cibes Jr., on selected issues. STATE TAXES AND SPENDING MORRISON: Favors cutting corporation taxes as soon as possible but opposes any new taxes until spending controls can be imposed. Rules out an income tax unless a statewide referendum shows that a majority of state residents are behind it. Favors a 25 percent business tax credit for expenses of employer retraining to help diversity the economy.
CIBES: Would create a graduated income tax on wages that would range up to 8 percent for incomes above $100,000. Corporation taxeswould then be cut to 10 percent, from an effective rate of 13.8 percent; the sales tax would be cut to 5 percent, from 8 percent. Income on dividends, interest and capital gains, now taxed separately, would be treated as ordinary income.
 
THE ENVIRONMENT
MORRISON: Favors stricter rules on consumer-product packaging. Would increase allocations for the Department of Environmental protection by increasing permit fees for the discharge of waste.
CIBES: would use part of the revenue generated by his tax-reform plan to pay for environmental protection. Favors requiring businesses to conduct regular environmental audits of their waste-discharge operations.
 
SCHOOL FINANCING AND DESEGREGATION
MORRISON: Would raise the state contribution toward meeting the costs of local school districts to 50 percent, from the current rate of about 43 percent, as soon as possible, but has given no timetable. Favors a magnet-school system that would encourage voluntary desegregation of schools.
CIBES: Would use mony from tax reform to finance the state's school aid formula fully. Would help local school boards cut costs on insurance and purchasing, perhaps through the creation of regional consortiums. Favors tighter restrictions on segregated housing as a way to combat segregation in schools.

HEADLINE: Families Pursue Communal Housing

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

 BODY:
The idea has had an impact on living patterns in Denmark, its adherents here say. And, they add, there has been an enthusiastic response in several states, with at least 50 co-housing groups formed. Five groups, including three in California, have purchased sites and are currently in the final design stage.
Tomorrow at 7:30 P.M., the Westchester Co-Housing Project, which Mrs. Elie helped form nearly a year ago in Yorktown, will be the host for a presentation by the authors of ''CoHousing: A Contemporary Approach to Housing Ourselves.'' The book, published in the fall of 1988, introduced the co-housing concept to this country. 
The authors are Kathryn McCamant and Charles Durrett, a husband and wife from California. This will be their first presentation in the New York City area. The couple, a design and consulting team, have lived in different co-housing developments in Europe and will show slides of their experiences as well as discuss their book.
The meeting is being co-sponsored by Westchester Residential Opportunities, a nonprofit open-housing center and will be held at the Washington-Rochambeau Room at Mercy College, on Strang Boulevard in Yorktown Heights.
 
Change in Life Styles Cited
''The life of the average American has changed drastically in the last decades of this century, but housing hasn't caught up,'' Ms. McCamant said in a telephone interview. ''The large majority of women work outside the home but they are still supposed to provide all the accouterments for the single-family home. Women are being run ragged and it's kind of crazy.''
Co-housing, Ms. McCamant said, offers a focus for a new living pattern that many people have already been thinking about. ''The interest has been out there, but the builders haven't focused on it at all,'' she said. ''They keep building bigger homes with even more grandiose bathrooms, and who wants that?''
The co-housing concept, which clusters a number of living units on small plots, requires rezoning support from planning boards that often have been suspicious of clustered housing. But advocates said they believe the idea makes good environmental, economic and emotional sense.
 
'It's Up to Us'
''Its up to us to show there are ways for people to live closer together with more group space without being environmentally abusive,'' said Richard Mason, a leader of the Yonkers co-housing contingent, with which the one family from Hartsdale is linked.
Supporters said that the projects by their nature were particularly sensitive to the environment, with larger numbers of people sharing less space and more equipment, buying food cooperatively and recycling as a group.
Although co-housing projects differ, all share common characteristics. They are designed by the residents themselves after consulting with architects, and they are managed by their owners. Each project has a common area with a kitchen and other multi-purpose rooms, often including a tool shop, a music room for teen-agers and a laundry room. This area is surrounded by individual homes; although smaller than a typical condominium or co-op apartment, they have their own kitchens and living rooms.
The whole project is designed to encourage interaction, from the paths leading to cars parked on the periphery to the living units themselves, which are positioned so residents can see each other come and go.
 
Plans to Combine
In the audience tomorrow evening will be members of the two co-housing chapters that formed almost simultaneously last year in the northern and southern parts of the county. They are planning to combine in a new community in Westchester if they can find a site.
The Yorktown section has five families that have decided to co-house. The section was started last fall by Emily M. Sack, 46, an early-childhood specialist and homemaker who moved to Mahopac seven years ago with her husband, Robert Schloss, a research scientist at International Business Machines in Yorktown. Life in her pre-Revolutionary Colonial on two acres on East Lake Boulevard, she said, has not been her homeowner's dream.
There is no playground nearby for her 5-year-old son, Daniel, Ms. Sack said, no sidewalk to walk along and meet people, ''no downtown with little shops to visit.'' The suburbs, she said, ''are not great for kids,'' or for their parents.
''There's clean air here, maybe, but the suburbs separate everyone too much,'' she said. ''It's outrageous for me to make a zillion phone calls and then drive half an hour each way to make dates for my son.''
 
Sharing and Compromises
Ms. Sack began thinking about and even drawing pictures of what she called ''a way of living with more community feeling.'' It would be a place with common spaces, communal guest rooms and shared laundry, ''a compromise between everyone needing to have their own washing machine, their own lawn and their own playground equipment,'' she said.
Co-housing ''is a way to combat isolation,'' she said, and offers ''a place where you can take for granted that people care about each other.''
When her husband gave her the co-housing book for her birthday last October, Ms. Sack said, ''it was exactly what I had been saying, exactly what they have been doing in Denmark for the last 20 years.''
Her idea appealed to Mrs. Elie, 46, a school librarian at the Brookside Elementary School in Yorktown Heights, who has shared a house on Locust Avenue in Peekskill with two other women since her two children grew up.
 
A Different Daily Life
''In communities 100 years ago, there was a focal point where people walked to market and passed each other sitting on a porch,'' Mrs. Elie said. ''Now, you can order groceries by phone, go to an automatic bank teller and easily not have any contact with people at all.'' Co-housing, she said, can help re-establish that contact.
''The way you make friends is when you see them,'' Mrs. Elie said. ''Co-housing provides a rich social environment where if I have an idea or have read an interesting book, there will be other people around to share that with. I won't have to call a friend and say let's get together the fourth Tuesday of next month.''
The seven families in the co-housing group in Yonkers agree. ''For my particular life style, contact within the so-called nuclear family is not enough,'' said Mr. Mason, president of Varnett Robinson, a Manhattan-based wholesale jewelry concern. He lives in Yonkers with his wife, Wendy, and their two children.
''For most of us, so much time is spent earning a living, there's little time to pursue extra things like forming friendships,'' Mr. Mason said.
The members of the co-housing groups in the county may be considered pioneers, but Mr. Mason said: ''What we are advocating is not so radically different.
''We are simply changing the emphasis from individual acquisiton to community, while preserving those things which make the individual family important.''

SECTION: Section 3; Page 10, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1813 words

HEADLINE: Reluctantly, an Obscure Agency Gets Its Day in the Sun

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
''When you strip away all the rhetoric, the debate over McCarran-Ferguson has to do with how the insurance industry designs its coverage points and arrives at its prices,'' said Fred R. Marcon, I.S.O.'s president. ''I.S.O. is central to that discussion.'' The measure would make it illegal for insurers to engage in most of the pursuits they have undertaken through I.S.O. over the years, all but shuttering an organization that insurers have come to depend upon.
I.S.O.'s practice of projecting future claims from data on historical insurance payouts would no longer be permitted. It's the projection more than the historical data that the lawmakers found objectionable.
Nor would I.S.O. be permitted to publish so-called advisory rates -premiums that an average insurer should charge to generate a certain level of profit. The net result is that I.S.O. would be limited to generating common policy language and to serving as a central data base for information on past claims. 
There is little dispute that some of the best-known insurers in America have depended heavily on I.S.O. data in setting premiums when their own customer base is too small for an informed decision to be made. For instance, though the Kemper National Insurance Company has more than $6.6 billion in assets, the Long Grove, Ill.-based company now has only two automobile policies outstanding in South Dakota, three in Nevada, five in Montana and fifty in Oklahoma.
That is not enough business on which Kemper can base sound premium judgments. ''So we need to go to a much larger data base, such as the I.S.O.,'' said Gerald L. Maatman, Kemper's president and chief executive. At the Travelers Insurance Company, Howard Hardy, an actuary, said, ''From a rate standpoint, we use I.S.O. premiums extensively as a starting point. They are very much a benchmark for us.''
I.S.O. loss data and advisory rates are used mostly in business -as opposed to individual - insurance. In ''personal lines,'' the largest insurers in America, including Allstate and State Farm, have customer bases that are so large and pools of customers who are so alike that the insurers do not need I.S.O. data because they have enough of their own.
But there are many more types of risks to insure in business: protecting a small manufacturer against interruption of his operations, a giant chemical company against liability from pollution or a candy store against the liability of someone falling in the store.
Typical of the data I.S.O. provides insurers of these types of policies is the information that for every $1,000 an Alabama beauty salon takes in, $2.23 is paid out in liability claims.
Therein lies the rub. Consumer groups argue that in forecasting losses and advising on premiums, I.S.O. has basically acted the way a cartel would, driving up insurance premiums artificially and allowing inefficient insurers to gouge the public. Consumer activists say the issue is straightforward: Keep I.S.O. out of the business of projecting claims expense and advising on premiums, and premium rates will fall. Estimates of the possible reductions range from 10 percent to 30 percent depending on the type of insurance involved.
''When price leadership is achieved formally through an institutionalized organization such as the I.S.O., it harms the consumer interest,'' said Stephen Brobeck, the executive director of the Consumer Federation of America in Washington. ''You end up with a price based on the costs of the most inefficient producer rather than the lowest-cost producer.''
Robert Hunter, president of the National Insurance Consumer Organization, a watch-dog organization based in Alexandria, Va., that is leading the effort to repeal McCarran-Ferguson, said, ''There is ample evidence that breaking up systems like I.S.O. produces more competitive results.''
I.S.O. executives could not disagree more. They argue that premiums would actually go up and that insurance would become less available if McCarran-Ferguson were repealed and I.S.O. had to restrict its activities. Denied access to I.S.O. data, which is based on the experience of hundreds of insurance companies, many insurers, particularly smaller ones, would be forced to hire outside actuaries to duplicate the I.S.O.'s work at much greater expense, I.S.O. officials say. That would lead insurers to hike premiums, if not stop writing some types of insurance altogether.
Precisely what would happen, of course, no one knows. ''Would smaller insurers find life more difficult if they were not given expected-loss data?'' asked Victor Lincoln, an executive vice president of the New York Casualty Insurance Company of Watertown, N.Y. ''That's a given. But would they go out of business? That's an extreme position.''
Mavis A. Walters, an I.S.O. executive vice president, said, ''At a minimum, restricting our activities would mean much higher costs to the insurers and therefore to the consumers and businesses they serve.''
Although I.S.O. is only 19 years old, it was created from the merger of a number of similar organizations, called ''rate bureaus,'' in the early part of the century. Insurers had banded together and set up the bureaus, contending that they were needed to make certain that premiums charged were adequate. Because some of these state-supervised rate bureaus required their members to adhere strictly to the bureau's advisory premiums, they became known as legal cartels.
Today, I.S.O. retains some of the characteristics of its predecessors. Its 606 members are still insurers, including such well-known names as Kemper, Aetna and Travelers. I.S.O.'s 2,700 employees are still predominantly actuaries - professionals who compute premium rates based on past loss experiences.
But unlike in years past, rate bureau members are no longer required to subscribe to all of the bureau's services or to maintain its advisory rates. Smaller I.S.O. members pay less than $100 a year for maybe a report or two, while giants like Aetna and Traveler's pay millions of dollars a year for a broad range of services.
Sensing that consumer activists were becoming increasingly hostile, I.S.O. recently moved to appease critics. It placed three persons from outside the insurance industry on its 21-person board. It began excluding insurance company representatives from the process of generating reports on industrywide claims. And it no longer publishes advisory premiums for certain lines of insurance. Instead, it will publish information on historical data and expected losses, and insurers will be required to develop their own premium rates.
''Just about everyone connected with this industry - insurers, agents, regulators - view the move away from advisory rates as a fundamental change in the way property and casualty insurers arrive at prices,'' Mr. Marcon said.
But consumer groups have not been placated. They argue that it will still be possible for insurers to construct an I.S.O. rate from the information on projected claims that I.S.O. will continue to disseminate. Consumer groups argue that insurance premiums will be only slightly more competitive than they are now.
''The change is peanuts,'' said Mr. Hunter. ''It would take a monkey about 10 seconds to figure out an I.S.O. advisory rate based on information I.S.O. will now be giving you. It's literally one step of math.''
Mr. Hunter may be onto something. A number of years ago, I.S.O. phased out advisory rates in a number of states for personal lines of insurance such as homeowner's policies. The impact was basically nil.
''Companies kept on doing business pretty much at the level they had been,'' said Mr. Lincoln of New York Casualty.
The debate shows no signs of easing. Regardless of the outcome, one question is whether, if I.S.O.'s activities were curtailed, consumer activists would back off from their criticism of insurance. Mr. Marcon, I.S.O.'s president, is doubtful. ''Until we address the problem of rapidly rising insurers' costs, all the promises of consumer groups, governors and would-be governors about lower rates are just that - promises,'' Mr. Marcon said.
 
TAKING ON THE ACTUARIAL TABLES
Before Robert Hunter became president of the National Insurance Consumer Organization, the group challenging the insurance industry's exemption from antitrust laws, he worked for a rate bureau that helped set premium prices. Decades later he is one of the most outspoken critics against the practice.
The institution of the rate bureau is key to the problem, Mr. Hunter said - ''the focal point of the collusion.''
Mr. Hunter points out that the actuarial tables themselves, which are used to project how long people live or how many auto accidents a person will be in, are a necessary service. But the service should stop there.
''There is no question that insurers have to look at last year's data and speculate as to what will happen in the future,'' Mr. Hunter said. The problem occurs when a single group tells the entire industry what inflation will be, estimates future levels of unemployment and predicts whether there will be an oil embargo,'' he said.
''What we are saying is that historic data should be promulgated but it shouldn't be manipulated and projected into the future to produce the final price fixed rates,'' Mr. Hunter said.
According to Mr. Hunter, a government study two years ago showed that when a handful of states dispensed with rate bureaus to set workers' compensation premiums, the average rate fell by 30 percent. It would not be as dramatic with personal or auto insurance, but the rates would still fall, he said.
''I think if it goes to the floor it will pass by a significant margin,'' Mr. Hunter said. ''In part because it is an election year, no one wants to be on record as being against this.''
''We will paint it as a vote as to whether insurers will be able to fix prices,'' Mr. Hunter said. ''Because that's what it is.''
