LENGTH: 1406 words

HEADLINE: American Broadens Its Deployments

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
Last week United States officials acknowledged an increasingly apparent truth: in becoming involved in the defense of Saudi Arabia they were involving themselves in the entire Arab Middle East, with all its complexities.
Military officials made known the extent of their deployment, not just in Saudi Arabia and the waters nearby, but in air bases in four other states on the southern rim of the Persian Gulf. And Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d met with a succession of Arab leaders; one accomplishment was a commitment from Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates to collectively pay much of the bill for the American troop concentration.
The Arab countries caught up in the Persian Gulf crisis have varied political systems, resources, populations and roles. There are monarchies and dictatorships, radicals and conservatives, rich and poor. 
For some years before the invasion of Kuwait, the pro-American countries of the Arabian peninsula were loath to align themselves too tightly with the United States. Since Aug. 2 all have become host to elements of the American military, now numbering 100,000 people. But foreign influence and presence in these countries has long been a touchy subject because all, to varying degrees, have been influenced by non-Arab powers, notably the old Turkish empire and afterward the long arms of Britain and France.
LEBANON Population 3.3 million; per capita national product $690 (1985). Established as a republic with a parliament in the 1940's but since the 1970's has been bled and sundered by civil strife. The Government, headed by President Elias Hrawi, is dominated by Syria. A rival Maronite Catholic regime led byGen. MichelAoun has received weaponry from Iraq. Lebanon was one of the Arab League member nations that voted last month to send non-Saudi Arab troops to Saudi Arabia to help confront Iraq. But analysts say Lebanon could become an important base for smugglers trying to breach the blockade of Iraq. Lebanon was formerly controlled by France.
JORDAN Population 3 million; per capita national product $1,780 (1986). Monarchy with a weak parliament. Situated precariously between Israel and Iraq, and with a large Palestinian population that the ruler, King Hussein, must worry about. He is the Arab leader who has been closest to Saddam Hussein throughout the crisis, seeking desperately to mediate between Mr. Hussein and the dictator's antagonists. Jordan is in an uneasy alliance with Iraq, but has asserted that it would implement the anti-Iraq embargo. Jordan has also asked for more foreign aid to offset economic woes - including a horde of refugees. The King is a descendent of theSharif of the Hejaz whose tribesmen fought, withBritish support, for freedom from Turkey inWorld War I. The Sharif was ousted from his Arabian fief by Ibn Saud, who became king of what is now Saudi Arabia.
EGYPT Population 55 million; per capita national product $490 (1987). Parliamentary republic with a flaccid political opposition and a pro-Government press, President Hosni Mubarak has led efforts to organize the multination Arab military contingent now deployed in Saudi Arabia. The capital, Cairo, has long been a power center in the Arab world and a perennial rival of Baghdad. Was one of Iraq's main backers during the eight-year Iran-Iraq war. Since making peace with Israel in 19798, Egypt has been the Arab nation with closest ties to the United States, and gets $2 billion a year in American aid. Formerly controlled by Britain; a short-lived monarchy ended in 1952 with the ouster of King Farouk by a military cabal.
BAHRAIN Population 500,000; per capita national product $7,550 (1987). Emirate with a hereditary ruler, Sheik Isa bin Sulman al-Khalifa. Minor oil reserves. Firmly anti-Iraq in the present crisis, and member of Gulf Cooperation Council. Since long before the Iraqi invasion has been the site of an important United States naval base. Since Aug. 2, has allowed the United States and Britain to deploy combat aircraft, and Britain has sent naval vessels to the emirate. Formerly a British protectorate; independent for 19 years. YEMEN Population 7.4 million; per capita national product $690 in the north in 1987 and $480 in the south in 1986. State formed in May through merger of Northern Yemen, a republic with ties to the West, with Southern Yemen, a Marxist state whose territory was formerly controlled by Britain. Elections are tobe held under the aegis of a presidential council, now headed by President Ali Abdullah Saleh. Post-merger Yemen has oil reserves of 4 billion barrels and seems symphathetic toward Iraw. But under pressure Yemen has declared, under pressure, it will abide by the embargo against Iraq.
SAUDI ARABIA Population 16.1 million; per capita national product $5,480 (1988). Hereditary monarchy led by king Fahd; OPEC member with oil reserves of 255 billion barrels. Puritanical Islam prevails. In the past has played down links to the United States. Leader of Gulf Cooperation Council; is solidly against Iraq now but was a supporter in the Iran-Iraq war. Has permitted a vast deployment of United States forces on its terrain and pledged to pay for most of it. King Ibn Saud founder of modern Saudi state had British backing.
SYRIA Population 12 million; per capita national product $1,962 (1985). Dictatorship headed by Hafez al-Assad, who, like Mr. Hussein, is considered ruthless in his suppression of dissent. Has oil reserves of 2 billion barrles. Longtime rival of Iraq, each country has its own brand of secular, Arab-nationalist Baath Party politics. Despite decades of anti-Westernism, Syria received theBush Administration's thanks when it agreed to send a small military contingent to Saudi Arabia. Between the world wars, France was given a mandate over the area of modern Syria and Lebanon. In 1941 Syria was declared an independent republic.
IRAQ Population 18 million; per capita national product $1,950 (1988). Dictatorship whose leader, Saddam Hussein, is seen by many Arabs as a friend of the poor and a foe of oil-rich plutocrats; his political roots are in the secular Baath party but he has lately been affirming in the importance of Islam. OPEC member with reserves of 100 billion barrels. Has a vulnerable internal economy, now sapped by the embargo. Control of oil prices, dispute over an extensive oil field onthe border and more certain access to the sea appear to be major motives in overrunning Kuwait. Iraq claims it was formerly a part of Turkish provinces that became Iraq. British set up an Iraqi monarchy that was replaced by a military regime in a bloody 1958 coup.
KUWAIT Population 2 million, with a large Shiite Muslim minority; per capita national product $10,410 (1988). Emirate with mammoth oil reserves of 95 billion barrels and membership in OPEC. Supported Iraq in the Iran-Iraq war. Now in exile, the Government of the Emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmad al-Sabah, is passionately opposed to Iraq. The Emir's family, rulers since the mid-18th century, sought British protection from Turkish domination in the late 19th century; British protectorate ended in 1961.
QATAR Population 468,000; per capita national product $17,017 (1987). Hererditary emirate - the current Emir is Sheik Khalifa bin Hamad al-Thani - with a puritanical variety of Islam, oil reserves of 5 billion barrels and OPEC membership. Firmly aligned against Iraq, has agreed to deployment of American warplanes. Formerly linked to Britain; has been independent for 19 years.
United Arab Emirates Population 2.1 million; estimated per capita national product $11,900 (1987). A collection of seven feudal city-states in a loose federation with a ruling council headed by a President, Sheik Zayed bin Sultan an-Nahiyan, the ruler of Abu Dhabi. A member of OPEC. Strongly anti-Iraq in this crisis, the federation has accepted the deployment of United States warplanes.
OMAN Population 1.3 million (1989); estimated per capita national product $6,100 (1987). A hereditary sultanate formerly called Muscat and Oman, with oil reserves of 4 billion barrels. Staunchly anti-Iraq in the present crisis; has permitted deployment of American and British warplanes; Britain has also sent naval forces. Long influenced by Britain, which recognized its independence 29 years ago. The current Sultan, Qabus bin Said, deposed his father and predecessor in 1970; the dynasty was established int he 18th century.

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
A Crippled Apartment Developer's Offspring Thrive

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY J. TRAINOR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
 At least three Oxford subsidiaries were sold to former executives, and many other executives went on to head the multifamily interests of other developers and institutional investors.
"It is almost as if there is this entire fraternity of former Oxford people you run into all the time in this industry," said Jonathan Kemper, former general counsel at Oxford and now chairman of the National Housing Council, a trade association, based in Washington, of multifamily developers.
 One of those people is Thomas S. Bozzuto, a national partner in Oxford who headed its mid-Atlantic office, which was responsible for the area from New Hampshire to South Carolina. The region was consistently Oxford's most profitable from 1981 to 1987, when it built and managed more than 10,000 garden apartments and 500,000 square feet of office space valued at a total of $600 million. 
Mr. Bozzuto and three fellow Oxford executives, Richard Mostyn, the late Bernard Lubcher and John Slidell, bought the mid-Atlantic development group and formed Bozzuto and Associates. The partners of the privately held company have declined to disclose what they paid for it. It employs several other former Oxford staff members and has fared well in the Washington-Baltimore market by following an approach radically different from that of its predecessor.
Among the projects that Bozzuto contracted with Oxford to finish was the Heather Ridge development in Bowie, Md.
"Oxford's main business was to manufacture upscale garden apartments on a national basis," Mr. Bozzuto said. "We are concentrating on the Baltimore-Washington area. Part of the reason Oxford got into trouble was by expanding into markets that it didn't know anything about. We want to remain on top of our market right here."
Richard L. Boales, a former Oxford employee who manages projects for Bozzuto, noted other differences between the old and new companies.
 "Basically, we have a four-part approach to the business," he said. "To finance multifamily properties conservatively by acting under joint-venture agreements and avoiding syndication; to stay in a market we know; to build and own properties for the long term rather than be driven by short-term fee income, and to remain small and responsible to our market here.
"Basically we are still in the apartment business. We manage all our own properties but we have intentionally kept it a small hands-on operation."
Financing arrangements with such institutional lenders as Copley Real Estate Investment, an investment arm of the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company, have helped the company remain profitable in a volatile multifamily market, he said.
"Oxford was very good at what it did at that time and in that financing environment," Mr. Boales recalled. "But the financing markets have completely changed since then and they're changing today. The challenge for any developer is to adjust to the changes and operate in a way that will keep those financing channels open."
At its peak, Oxford's development partnerships turned out apartment complexes nationwide, operating under seven regional offices. The company, originally based in Indianapolis, became a multifamily housing giant under the direction of Leo E. Zickler, who joined the firm founded by his father-in-law, Leo A. Lippman, in 1961. In 1968, while president and owner, he took a leave to form Cambridge Builders, a Boston area development firm.
Mr. Zickler returned to Oxford in 1976, as president and owner, just before the national economy went into a steep recession. He immediately concentrated on developing federally subsidized housing and Oxford quickly gained a reputation in that field.
In 1983, Mr. Zickler moved the company to Bethesda, in part to be able to hire other experts in multifamily housing who were familiar with the complex rules of Government-assistance programs.
Throughout the 70's Oxford built an average of 2,000 apartments a year. That increased dramatically in the 1980's, peaking in 86, when the company began construction of 13,000 apartments. That year the National Housing Conference named Mr. Zickler "Man of the Year" for his work in developing low- and moderate-income housing.
But that year also proved disastrous for Oxford and many other large builders of multifamily dwellings who had embarked on ambitious expansion plans fueled by favorable tax treatment.
Despite intensive industry efforts, Congress eliminated Federal income tax deductions for investment losses in the development of multifamily housing, effectively wiping out the syndication business on which Oxford thrived. Investors could no longer invest in the limited ownership of an apartment project and deduct the losses they incurred during construction and lease-up.
Although Mr. Zickler and many in the industry foresaw the changes, they were not able to restructure the many development partnerships and reverse the company's overexpansion. With its major source of revenue cut off, Oxford soon faced large cash shortfalls, and investors and lenders began lining up to collect what they were owed.
Mr. Zickler and Oxford made several attempts to restructure and find other sources of funds, but each failed. In 1988, Mr. Zickler dismantled the company, selling off some assets and placing some Oxford-controlled partnerships under bankruptcy protection. It severed some ties to former consultants, made deep cuts in its development, construction and financing staffs and laid off hundreds of employees.
Now, its financial problems resolved, it is emerging with its assets and property-management operation intact. It is still among the country's top 10 apartment managers, overseeing 45,638 units for about 30,000 investors, and, according to Donald Boardman, executive vice president, is negotiating with several large developers to take over their property-management operations.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Companies Pool Effort on Irish Play

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:
Its opening on Thursday at Stamford Theater Works signaled what the theater's artistic director, Steve Karp, and the executive director of the Irish Arts Center in Manhattan, Nye Heron, agree is the producing wave of the future.
The Stamford engagement is an example of cost sharing by two theaters - and the chance for local theatergoers to preview a play that is scheduled to move on Sept. 28, with cast and scenery intact, to the Irish Arts Center, an Off Broadway theater on West 51st Street. The Center's artistic head is Jim Sheridan, who directed the film ''My Left Foot.''
 
Love From Mourning
Mr. Karp recalled his discovery of the play: ''I went to see 'Away Alone,' a hit at the Irish Arts, last spring and was so taken with it, I asked to meet its director, Terence Lamude, who said, 'I have another play I've been wanting to do.' And this was the one. I read it and loved it a lot. It's about how love comes out of mourning - and the families can't take it, like the Capulets and the Montagues.'' 
At the same time, the play came to the attention of Mr. Heron who did not love it a lot when he read it but changed his mind when he attended a staged reading, in which Malachy McCourt had the part of the widower, the role he is playing in the Stamford and Off Broadway productions.
''So we had two theaters that wanted to do the same play - separately and simultaneously,'' Mr. Heron said. ''Doing it this way makes it easier to do the plays you want to do - and more economical. Off Broadway costs keep going up, and we're saving one-third, which includes the set and the rehearsal period.''
''But the Stamford run is not a tryout,'' Mr. Heron added. ''No changes are being made. This is the play.''
Mr. Karp said: ''For the first time, we're originating a production in Stamford that we know is moving to New York. And for the first time, we have rehearsals in New York. But then, because we're so new, everything we're doing is for the first time.''
 
Taking Risks
In its second full professional season, the Stamford company may be rapidly achieving the cachet of New York visibility. ''Rumors in the Palace,'' a comedy by Enid Rudd that had its premiere in Stamford in February, has been announced for an Off Broadway production this season.
''We want provocative and entertaining plays,'' Mr. Karp said, ''that speak to our audiences and that we can do in our modest circumstances. But we're also interested in taking risks.'' And ''Remembrance'' - the title refers to ''the name of the day reserved in Ireland for commemorating the war dead, like Memorial Day here,'' Mr. Lamude explained - may be provocative indeed.
''Except for the animosity between the Catholics and the Protestants,'' he said, ''you don't have to know the specifics of the troubles in Belfast, a city of hate in economic collapse, with strict boundaries, to get the play. It's about how prejudice can tear love apart, and it mirrors other situations with universal themes.''
Mr. Lamude continued: ''After directing 'Taming of the Shrew,' I love to stage love scenes between older people. They're pure and tender and wise. And they revert to the youngish awkwardness common to all who fall in love.''
The roles of the elderly lovers are being played by Mr. McCourt and Aideen O'Kelly. Mr. McCourt, who grew up in Limerick, had a thriving saloon business for 20 years in Manhattan. ''I had the first singles bar here in America,'' he said. He was also the irreverent host of a radio show in the 1970's and its short-lived television counterpart.
About the play, Mr. McCourt said, ''I can go babbling about violence and chaos and bigotry and the possibility of love's survival, but 'Remembrance' shows us the way people work and eat and drink and talk and get up and go out amidst all that - and how the young disbelieve that people in their 60's are capable of romantic and sexual love.''
Ms. O'Kelly, who was born in Dalkey, Ireland, and has appeared in numerous regional theater productions in Connecticut, added, ''And their families use the crutch of patriotism and idealism to cover up their own weaknesses and bolster their tender egos.''
Remaining performances of ''Remembrance'' today and next Sunday at 2 and at 7 P.M., Tuesday through Friday at 8, and Saturday at 4 and 8. 359-4414. Center for the Arts of Sacred Heart Academy, 200 Strawberry Hill Avenue, Stamford.

SECTION: Section 12NJ; Page 1, Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1932 words

HEADLINE: Family Leave: Wide Effects Are Seen For Employers

BYLINE: By BARBARA STURKEN

 BODY:
The family leave law in New Jersey is separate from the state's liberal disability rules placing new mothers on paid disability if a doctor certifies they are physically unable to return to work. Family leave is separate from and does not affect disability benefits.
Some of New Jersey's largest employers have already felt the effects of the new law. At the Hackensack Medical Center, six people so far have taken leave in the four months since the hospital notified its 3,000 workers of the law's provisions. Andre Ferullo, the center's vice president for human resources, said that five of the requests were for maternity leave and one was for the care of a seriously ill parent.
''We're not troubled by this law,'' Mr. Ferullo said, adding that the hospital in each case handled the absences by juggling other staff members' shifts and bringing in temporary workers. 
The law was passed over the strenuous objections of most business organizations, including the New Jersey Chamber of Commerce, which argued that government should not dictate corporate policies. Marvin Goldstein, a Roseland lawyer who is advising corporate clients on the implications of the act, said many companies, especially small to medium-size businesses, felt they were already inundated with costly regulations.
The law's supporters say that since the Government already sets minimum wage levels and other business practices, family leave laws are not burdensome, and indeed are common in most other industrialized nations.
''Family leave is not a radical idea; it is just plain common sense,'' said Representative Marge S. Roukema, Republican of Ridgewood, a sponsor of the Federal bill. ''The arguments against it do not hold water.''
Many of the business community's objections were taken into account when the state and Federal bills were being considered, she said, noting that small businesses with fewer than 50 employees are exempt and that employers can deny leave to key employees if their absence would disrupt the business.
Cathy Johnson, a Congressional aide, said the bill was needed because many companies were not adopting family leave policies on their own. She cited a Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics survey showing that just 37 percent of employees nationwide are covered by written maternity policies and that few companies have policies granting leave for other purposes, like caring for an ailing parent.
Those on both sides of the issue agree that the law could have a lasting impact on the workplace. Since May, the measure has been in effect at the 5,000 or so companies in New Jersey that employ 100 or more people.
 
Wider Coverage Ahead
Next year it will extend to businesses with a staff of 75 and by May 1993 will apply to any company with at least 50 employees, which covers about 61 percent of the state's 3.7 million workers, according to the New Jersey Department of Labor.
Meanwhile, employers in New Jersey are awaiting final guidelines from the State Division on Civil Rights. Hearings are expected to begin on Wednesday. Proposed regulations were recently circulated for comment and are expected to become final this fall, said Jeffrey Burstein, a deputy state attorney general.
Under the draft regulations, employees taking leave for a newborn or adopted child must provide 30 days' notice, if possible, and can take 12 weeks' consecutive leave within 12 months of the birth or adoption; reduced or intermittent leave can be taken only if the employer agrees.
An employee who takes time off to care for a seriously ill family member must give 15 days' notice and can take 12 weeks over one year for one serious health episode, or stretch the leave over 24 months if more than one health condition is involved.
 
Some Companies Develop Policies
Some of the state's largest employers were developing new policies even before the law was passed, in part because of the demographic changes that created the momentum for the legislation in the first place. Women now make up about half of the nation's work force, with 80 percent of them in their childbearing years.
Also, as the country's population is living longer, it becomes more likely that an employee will have to care for a parent or spouse. An employee should not have to be forced to choose between keeping a job and caring for a family member, say family leave supporters.
Janet Grace, a research associate at the state's Commission on Sex Discrimination in the Statutes, which drafted the bill, said that even though many large companies had worked out family leave benefits, either through negotiation or in union contracts, others offered none.
''We used to have calls every other day from people who were threatened with job loss, or lost benefits and seniority in a particular job when they requested a leave,'' she said.
The growing number of working couples and single parents employed outside the home was a consideration, Ms. Grace said. ''We had cases of families with seriously ill children who could not get time off to get their child to the hospital,'' she said. ''It seems unfair that at a time of emotional stress, you should have to worry about job loss.''
 
Schoolteacher Sought Leave
In one case, Harrison Kornbau, a schoolteacher who lives in Stratford, near Camden, was denied time off by his employer when his daughter was seriously ill with leukemia, he said. ''Their attitude was, 'Why can't your wife deal with it?' '' he said. His wife was exhausted by dividing her time between caring for the couple's other children while spending 12 hours a day in the hospital with their daughter, he said, but he was not able to take time off even in the month before his daughter's death.
Later, Mr. Kornbau spoke out on behalf of family leave bills at the state and Federal level. Yet even now he is not covered: his school is across the Delaware River in Pennsylvania, where a family leave bill is still pending.
For some businesses, the law's most troubling passage is a provision that allows a worker to take an intermittent leave to care for an ill relative and to spread the leave over a 24-month period. That could lead to employees' fashioning their own part-time schedules, creating staffing shortages, business leaders say.
Gerald Hall, a spokesman for the New Jersey Chamber of Commerce, said that the act could open the way for abuse by employees who simply want to take time off from work. Critics also say the legislation is unclear on the subject of just what constitutes a serious health condition, leading some to suggest that an employee could request leave if a child has a cold.
 
Economic Pressures a Factor
When leave is unpaid, economic pressures deter most people from taking prolonged leaves of absence, said Gail Ruderman, head of human resources at Revere Travel in Trenton. ''I don't know too many people who can afford to take that kind of time off,'' Ms. Ruderman said.
The travel agency employs 185 people, almost all of them women, and has a policy granting three months' unpaid maternity leave. Ms. Ruderman said the company did not think the new state law would be onerous, pointing out that many of her employees had not even taken the full three months to which they were entitled, because of economic factors.
She also said that granting leave had helped boost morale and thus improved productivity. In one recent case, Ms. Ruderman gave an indefinite leave to an employee whose father was critically ill. ''Giving employees this sort of flexibility will come back to us 100 times,'' she said.
Estimates vary on the number of employees who might take family leave under the new law. The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which has had a leave policy for years, reports that about 1 to 2 percent of its workers take maternity leave annually.
The telecommunications giant, which employs 50,000 people in New Jersey, recently expanded its family leave program to allow up to 12 months off for the birth of a child, with six to eight weeks of that time at full salary, depending on the type of delivery. Last year the company adopted a separate family leave policy similar to the new state law's provisions on caring for ailing relatives.
 
Paternity Leave Included
A spokeswoman for A.T. & T., Lynn Newman, said women make up 47 percent of the company's total work force and 36 percent of its managerial staff. ''Many are caring for young children and older relatives,'' she said. Even though men are entitled to take paternity leave at A.T. & T., Ms. Newman said, she was unable to find a single example of one doing so.
Merck & Company, the Rahway-based pharmaceutical concern, has also developed a leave policy. Women now account for 40 percent of its staff, up from 28 percent 10 years ago.
The company allows employees to choose either a leave of up to six months, at the end of which they are guaranteed their old jobs, or a leave of as long as 18 months, after which they are given an equivalent position in terms of pay and seniority. Art Strohmer, the director of executive staffing, said that Merck had not adopted a specific policy addressing leave to care for an ailing relative but that the company supported the idea.
''We feel this kind of response is necessary because of the changing work force,'' Mr. Strohmer said. It is not too difficult for a company like Merck, with 5,500 workers, to absorb the cost of family leave policies, he said.
 
Attrition Rate Reduced
Indeed, with the pool of workers shrinking, many employers find that better benefits often attract more talented workers and reduce their attrition rate. For example, Johnson & Johnson has created a broad program called ''Balancing Work and Family'' that goes beyond the standards set in the new law. The health-care products company now allows one year of family care leave, which had been limited to care for a newborn, and has expanded the policy to cover family illnesses.
The company also set up a training program to help managers deal with employees' family needs, and recently opened a day-care center at its New Brunswick headquarters.
While it is too early to measure the economic impact of the law, employers in four states with similar laws - Oregon, Minnesota, Wisconsin and Rhode Island - have adapted well, concluded a study performed by the Families and Work Institute.
''We found that the law has had a neutral effect,'' said Michele Lord, senior research associate at the institute.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
'Remembrance': Love And Politics in Ireland

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

LENGTH: 1353 words

HEADLINE: Queens and Nassau Vie For New F.A.A. Base

BYLINE: By ELLEN MITCHELL

 BODY:
But once Queens politicians and business leaders learned that the F.A.A., which has 600 employees and an annual payroll of $30 million, was planning to move to Nassau in this time of lagging economy, the turf battle began in earnest.
The Queens Borough President, Claire Shulman, let it be known that she would not sit by quietly and allow the agency to desert Queens.
''We have the airports and we feel we deserve their building if we are going to put up with the noise and pollution,'' she said.
Citing the proximity to Kennedy and La Guardia Airports and the availability of mass transit, the Borough President offered the agency free use of two city-owned parcels in Jamaica, Queens. Both sites - one at Parsons Boulevard and 160th Street, the other at Jamaica Avenue and 153d Street - are parking lots. 
Representatives Gary L. Ackerman, Democrat of Queens, and Susan Molinari, Republican of Staten Island, vowed to intercede in Washington to stop the exodus. Both are members of the Public Works Committee, which must decide on the relocation proposal.
 
'Roadblock' Has Been Set Up
''We've got the roadblock set up down the trail,'' said Representative Ackerman. ''I have an understanding with the chairman,'' [Douglas H. Boscoe, Democrat of California]. ''It will not pass. I suggest they redraw it now.
''This is no time to send a message that the Federal Government is abandoning the City of New York,'' Mr. Ackerman said. ''Losing 600 jobs doesn't mean the town is going to go bankrupt, but when you have the symbolism of flight, it picks up and then you're talking big numbers.
''We have 30,000 to 40,000 Federal employees in the New York area. If you're talking, let's move them to the suburbs, it becomes a real psychological game and a huge dollar drain.''
Michael A. LoGrande, former executive director of the Association for a Better Long Island, led the charge to move the agency's headquarters to Nassau. He called it ''an economic air strike into Queens.''
Supporting the builders' group are the Nassau County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, and the Hempstead Presiding Supervisor, Joseph N. Mondello.
Mr. Gulotta calls Nassau ''the place to be.'' He suggested that Mitchel Field might be ideal. ''We're talking of several million dollars a year of business in the area surrounding a new F.A.A. facility,'' he said.
Mr. Mondello urged commercial realtors in Nassau County to pepper the General Services Administration for applications. ''The G.S.A. should take advantage of the ruthlessly competitive real-estate market on the Island,'' he said.
 
Runway Approaches Cited
Mr. LoGrande reminded Borough President Shulman that ''the most active runway approaches are in Nassau.''
Those lobbying for a Nassau relocation suggest that it would be safer to put the administrative offices close to Tracon, which handles the complex routing of much of the Northeast's commercial air traffic.
They suggest that such proximity would ease stress and tension for the employees, and bolster the well-being of passengers, even though the administrative offices are involved in the more-mundane pursuits of communication, weather monitoring and paperwork.
Echoing the sentiments of the Nassau contingent, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, said that the move should be based on ''the greatest safety for the people in the skies - not on political muscle.''
That and similar statements from Mr. D'Amato, who earlier indicated to Mrs. Shulman's office that he was making the interests of his Queens constituents known to Federal officials, would seem to put the Senator squarely on the border between the two counties.
Representative Ackerman called the public-safety argument ''a bald-faced lie.''
''In this day of modern communications,'' he said, ''there is no reason for the administrative offices to sit near the radar.''
 
Commuting a Problem
Mr. Ackerman said the reason the F.A.A. wanted to move to Nassau County was because its employees live there. ''They want to move the mountain to Mohammed, and they're involved with Mr. D'Amato, who also lives in the neighborhood,'' the Congressman said.
Martin Happes, union representative for the Professional Airway Systems Specialists, who works at Kennedy, conceded that the commute to work was one of the reasons his members want to move.
''Traffic congestion is a real problem,'' Mr. Happes said. ''My people would like anything east of the Cross Island Parkway.''
About 40 percent of the workers at Kennedy live in Nassau and Suffolk, 50 percent in New York City, most of them in Queens and the rest in New Jersey, Connecticut and Westchester. The majority drive to work.
Mr. Happes called the worst stretch of the commute the Belt Parkway from the Cross Island Parkway to Kennedy, a four-mile stretch that can take a half-hour to drive.
Kathleen Bergen, regional manager of public affairs for the F.A.A., who also works at Kennedy, worries that adding a computer might overload the antiquated electrical system. ''We're already having blackouts,'' she said, adding: ''We've been in this building over 40 years. It's inadequate in terms of space and the power system. There's not enough heat or enough air-conditioning and it doesn't meet the city's fire and public-safety codes.''
 
Fair Bidding Process Urged
While the debate continues on the local front, the real decision is to be made in Washington. Representatives Ackerman and Molinari are ready for a showdown. Senator D'Amato said he would not stand for anything less than a fair and competitive bidding process to obtain the best site.
''Let the chips fall where they may,'' Mr. D'Amato said. ''Otherwise, it's dangerous.''
Mr. LoGrande's group is pushing for an open bidding process. He said Nassau County would win in that case.
''If we allow Congressman Ackerman to hold the F.A.A. hostage to back-room deals and good-old-boy agreements, we will have a lot to answer for if the F.A.A. system begins to fray,'' Mr. LoGrande said.
The General Services Administration is waiting for further direction. William Matthews, regional director for the agency's real-estate division, said the sensitivities of everyone involved are somewhat unusual.
''Ninety-nine percent of the time there's no controversy,'' Mr. Matthews said. ''That only happens when you cross somebody's political jurisdiction.''
Mr. Happes said that if the administrative offices were not moved east, there would have to be negotiations with the unions, and the employees would have to be accommodated in some other way.
''Right now, it's a matter of how the politicians play their politics to help one another out,'' he said. ''It's one of those 'I wash your back, you wash mine' kind of things.
''We're in limbo here. We ask for new furniture, but they say its been appropriated for the new building.
''I say, 'Should I save my empty cartons to pack my desk?' They tell me to put them on the side someplace. Eventually, I'm going to need them.''

HEADLINE: THE VIEW FROM: BRIDGEPORT'S FOREIGN TRADE ZONE;
'The Perfect Incubator For Smaller Companies'

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
''I'm giving it a shot,'' Mr. Megna said. ''I'm not 100 percent convinced yet, but I'm willing to come in based on the idea. It's definitely the right idea.''
Another tenant, E&S Imports of Westport, will soon move its headquarters into the zone, which is between Barnum Avenue and Arctic Street. E&S sells fireplace mantels from England, handcarved from mahogany, oak and other fine woods.
''The advantage for us is we don't have to pay the duty until it's sold,'' said Ellen Sloan, managing director and a partner in E&S. 
She said the company paid almost $1,700 in tariffs on its first shipment of 152 mantels, a cost the fledgling company could ill afford. ''I'm doing everything on a shoestring at the moment,'' Ms. Sloan said. The city received notice in late August that the trade zone will be approved, and it is waiting only for an activation order to begin international trade at the zone. The Bridgeport foreign trade zone could become the first in the state later this month or in early October, said Paul V. Joslin, vice president for operations and a partner in the Bridgeport Foreign Trade Zone Development Corporation, the company hired by the city to manage the zone.
Another foreign trade zone in New Haven should begin about the same time, or shortly afterward, and a third zone is planned in Windsor Locks, at Bradley International Airport.
''The situation we're creating will be particularly attractive to smaller companies that are just starting to get into the import-export business,'' Mr. Joslin said. ''The big guys all know how to handle foreign trade, and don't need the kind of services offered by a foreign trade zone, but this will be the perfect incubator for smaller companies.''
''We have more people interested in the zone than we have space,'' said Edward R. Lavernoich, Bridgeport's economic development planner. ''As soon as we have approval to start, we've going to have to apply for an immediate expansion.''
Paul S. Timpanelli, president of the Bridgeport Regional Business Council, said a survey of their 1,400 members revealed between 20 and 25 percent involved in international trade in some way, so the trade zone will be important to existing businesses.
''But it will also serve as an enticement for other businesses to move into Bridgeport,'' Mr. Timpanelli said. ''It gives us a new lure to bring businesses in.''
Mr. Timpanelli said Bridgeport's only hope of overcoming its budget woes, including a $60 million deficit last year that was covered with state bonds, is to build its tax base.
''The foreign trade zone is going to be an asset to the city, and an integral part of our efforts to put together an economic development plan,'' Mr. Timpanelli said.
Mr. Lavernoich said the city won authorization for a foreign trade zone in March 1982, and it was going to be in a new $750,000 building in the west end of Bridgeport.
But demand was too low to justify the expense, and the idea languished. The proposed site was instead developed as a marina that has been very successful.
Then in 1986 the city started to get inquiries about the zone from companies involved in international trade, and in late 1987 it began looking for a new site.
Mr. Lavernoich said Bridgeport settled on the former Remington Arms factory, about 1 million square feet of industrial space that is largely vacant. The new owner of the site, Remgrit Realty, uses some of the space to manufacture saw blades, and agreed to lease the rest for the foreign trade zone.
Since then, he said, the city has been satisfying the requirements of the Customs Service, mostly documenting demand for the zone, and demonstrating that security is adequate to make sure duty-free goods are not smuggled into the country.
''This is going to mean investment in the city, the creation of jobs here,'' Mr. Lavernoich said.
There are also several benefits for manufacturers and importers. For instance, a company importing something that has a quota could still buy when the price is low, store it in the warehouses in the trade zone and bring it in when the next quota period opens.
A company could also combine foreign and domestic parts, and if most of the value of the product was from the domestic parts, there would be no duty.
If a company was importing something with a high defect rate, the product could be screened in the warehouse and the defective pieces destroyed before the duty was paid.
Or, if a company was exporting a product that has some foreign parts, the parts could be shipped to the warehouse, assembled, then exported without paying duty. ''A lot of companies will get a competitive advantage in some way through the foreign trade zone,'' Mr. Lavernoich said.
''We didn't have the expertise to do this ourselves, though,'' Mr. Lavernoich said. ''You need people who understand sophisticated accounting methods, as they pertain to Customs.'' That's where Mr. Joslin's firm came in. The company is a partnership between Mr. Joslin, who has experience in international trade financing and business development, William Hooton, the president of the company, whose experience is in warehousing and distribution, and who is in Turkey on a trade mission, and Remgrit, the owners of the building.
Mr. Joslin said that at first 50,000 square feet would be authorized by Customs, but most of that space will be quickly committed.
''We'll need an immediate expansion, probably to 200,000 square feet,'' Mr. Joslin said. ''Eventually, we'd like to get the entire one-million-square-foot facility designated as a foreign trade zone.''
Mr. Joslin said a trade zone is particularly suited for an aging industrial center like Bridgeport.
''We're not the prettiest place in the world, so we don't get the best press. When we're on the 6 o'clock news it's usually negative,'' Mr. Joslin said. ''But we do have a strong industrial base, access to a good labor force, and access to the highways.''
''The message we have to get across is that Bridgeport is a place where you can get the job done,'' Mr. Joslin said.
Mr. Megna, the trade zone's earliest tenant, said that while none of the companies there are likely to make a significant difference in Bridgeport's economy individually, collectively they will have an impact.
''We're not a big company, we're not going to hire 50 or 60 employees, but even the 10 we will be hiring is going to help,'' Mr. Megna said.
Mr. Megna said an example of the type of product where savings would be greatest is the company's canvas toy box. The toy box has a wood frame made in the Orient, but the canvas is manufactured in North Carolina, where he can obtain it for about the same price as in Taiwan because the shipping costs are lower and there are no duties.
By assembling the toy box in Bridgeport, he would avoid a 7.2 percent tariff on the canvas (which he previously bought in Asia), buy American-made goods, and create local jobs.
Mr. Megna said in addition to the toy box and the Aqua Lab, marketed under the company's ''Dr. Frank's'' label, he is investigating whether other products might benefit from using the trade zone.
For instance, he markets a porch and patio chair made of canvas with a metal-rod frame. The frame is less costly when made in Korea, but is more expensive than the canvas.
If the frame and canvas were shipped to Bridgeport for packaging, the cost of the canvas, box, and handling, however, might exceed the price of the frame, so he would avoid duty.
Another advantage, Mr. Megna said, is that assembling the product here with mostly American parts would enable him to label it, ''Made in the U.S.A.,'' and some catalogue sales operations now carry almost exclusively items with that label.
The trade zone could also enhance local economic development efforts by giving importing companies a foothold.
Ms. Sloan said she sees a market for English mantelpieces after touring a few upscale houses in the area. ''I don't know how to say this diplomatically, but the mantels you've got over here are just terrible,'' she said.
But the oak, pine and other wood that is carved in England is largely grown in the United States and Canada, Ms. Sloan pointed out, ''and if this takes off, I'd like to even manufacture them over here.''

HEADLINE: Hospitals Defending Increases in Budgets

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
''They're asking for too much,'' said Joseph C. Mike, an analyst of health-care costs hired by the Connecticut Business and Industry Association. The group has been granted the right to participate in the budget process this year, because businesses typically pick up the bulk of health-care costs through employee benefit plans.
''It's imperative, if we're going to have an impact on the budgets, that we be involved in those hearings,'' Mr. Mike said. ''Otherwise, we're handcuffed when the budget request comes along, because you have to pay for the programs that have been approved.'' 
The volume of patients at the hospitals ''is not increasing that dramatically, and the complexity of cases is not changing that much,'' Mr. Mike said. ''We see no reason hospitals shouldn't be coming in with single-digit increases in their budget requests.''
The administrative officer for the cost commission, Marcia E. Schonberger, said hearings on the hospital budgets should be completed by Sept. 30. ''The applications are for the most part complete,'' she said.
 
Changes From Legislature
If the commission can stick to its schedule, this will be the first time in three years that a majority of hospitals in the state will begin their fiscal years with approved budgets. In previous years, legislative changes in the rate-setting formulas complicated and delayed the budget-review process, and some hospitals had to go halfway through the fiscal year operating on interim budgets, which were often inadequate.
But Ms. Schonberger said the commission has not begun any analysis of the budget requests to determine if the huge increases cited by the business association are accurate. Hospitals contend that some of the figures cited by the group are misleading.
At Lawrence and Memorial Hospital, in New London, the business association said, the requested gross-revenue increase from 1990 to 1991 is 23.4 percent. But the hospital's chief financial officer, Elwin Bresette, said the steep increase reflects a continuing rise in the number of patients. Also, he said, the hospital will complete its new outpatient-care building this year, and the project's costs will be phased into the budget next year.
''Our gross patient revenues are up, because our volume is up,'' Mr. Bresette said. ''But so are our expenses for caring for more patients.''
Mr. Mike said he foresees most of this year's conflict on hospital costs focusing on the hospitals' projections regarding Medicare and Medicaid.
Connecticut law allows hospital rates to make up the difference between the cost of serving Medicare and Medicaid patients and the reimbursement under the programs. Some hospitals have estimated the cost of providing service under the programs will rise by several million dollars, while their reimbursements will rise by less than $1 million.
''There is no justification for those kinds of projections,'' Mr. Mike said.
Hospitals and their critics agree that cost-containment pressures are likely to curb the number of services offered. Last month, for example, Danbury Hospital was denied permission to perform open-heart surgery. Such permission has been denied in the past by the commission because other hospitals in the state already offer the expensive surgery.
''The issue that's immediately on the horizon is not what new services will be offered but the possibility of having to discontinue existing services, and, a few steps down that road, the possibility of having to close a hospital,'' Mr. Pattis said. ''If the cost-containment pressures are screwed up to an unreasonable pitch, the time will come when hospitals will have to ask themselves whether they can afford to treat all classes of patients.''
Under a rate-setting process initiated last year, a hospital does not have to go through a full budget review if its requested increase is deemed reasonable, based on inflation. Last year, the increase determined to be reasonable for gross revenues was 13.5 percent; the ultimate increase granted the state's 35 hospitals was about 14 percent.
''Considering that the law deemed 13.5 percent to be reasonable, with 14 percent, we were very nearly on target,'' Mr. Pattis said. He said that this year, gross revenues will be negotiated individually, but the net revenue increase presumed reasonable by the cost commission is 7.5 percent, based on an inflation rate for the Northeast of 5.5 percent.
By the hospital group's reckoning, about half of the hospitals will meet that test and undergo a limited budget review, Mr. Pattis said. But Mr. Mike said most of the 35 hospitals will have to go through a time-consuming full budget review, so many could find themselves starting another fiscal year with an interim budget.
Mr. Mike said that if a 7.5 percent net revenue increase is considered reasonable, rises in gross revenues will probably be limited to about 11.5 percent, and only 10 hospitals meet that test. At least 23 hospitals have requested gross revenue increases larger than 11.5 percent, he said, including 8 that have sought increases larger than 20 percent. Two hospitals submitted their budgets too recently for analysis, he said.
James R. Rude, director of financial services at the Hospital of St. Raphael, in New Haven, said the statistics used by the business group are misleading. At his hospital, he said, while the requested increase in gross revenues for 1991 is 31.4 percent, the highest in the state, that figure includes increases in patient volume. The actual increase to the hospital's list of charges is only 24.3 percent, he said.
The figures also reflect a heavier Medicaid and Medicare case mix, Mr. Rude said. Those patients make up 49 percent of the volume in 1991's estimates, up from 45 percent this year, he said, and the case complexity is rising as well. The hospital's net revenue increase - after shortfalls in the Medicare and Medicaid programs are paid - amounts to 9.8 percent, Mr. Rude said.

HEADLINE: New South Has New Face for Black Tourists

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 5

 BODY:

 
'Timing Is Just Right'
''Ten years ago you could not have done this; now the timing is just right,'' said Francis Smiley, the black heritage coordinator for the Alabama Bureau of Tourism and Travel, whose 1983 brochure was Alabama's first statewide effort to market black history. ''It's an image builder, a recognition of the way the South has changed. And it reflects a new awareness that there's a black travel market that in the past has been totally overlooked. We're trying to say, 'Yes, we have Southern belles, but we're a lot more diverse than that.' ''
That brochure was aimed at luring back for visits the blacks who had left Alabama. It was such a hit that it is now in its third version with 180,000 copies in print and has grown into a slick 30-page booklet listing 163 attractions from the Freedom Quilting Bee organized by black women in Alberta to AfricaTown U.S.A. State Park northeast of Mobile.
Increasingly, other states and organizations in the South are trying to follow the same approach. John Horhn, a black man who is Mississippi's director of tourism, said the black travel market is worth $15 billion a year. Officials in his state are working to document the state's black history much as Alabama has done. Georgia and South Carolina already have put together listings of black historical sites, and Tennessee is planning one. 
 
'Blacks Are Half the History'
Civil rights memorials are being built and promoted by tourism officials in Birmingham, across the street from the Sixteenth Street Baptist Church, where four black children were killed in a 1963 church bombing, and in Memphis, at the Lorraine Motel, where Dr. King was killed in 1968.
And some private tourism groups are seeing the same opportunities. David A. Farrow, who runs a company that conducts walking tours of Charleston, S.C., said he is working to put together such a tour oriented toward black history.
''Blacks are half the history of the South,'' Mr. Farrow said, ''and often that part has not been recognized.''
The changes partly reflect the racial evolution in the South. ''Let's face it,'' said Lisa Shivers, director of the Alabama Bureau of Tourism and Travel. ''It's good for Alabama's image to promote its black history.''
But the changes also reflect the economic importance of blacks to the region, which is home to half the nation's black population and where most blacks have roots.
Mississippi has the sort of civil rights history and black heritage that make it singularly well equipped to tap the black travel market, said Mr. Horhn, the state tourism official.
Thirty-six percent of Mississippi's population is black, the nation's highest, which provides a lucrative pool for intrastate travel. Moreover, ''we are part of the cradle of African-American society in this country, and so many blacks have roots in Mississippi, the potential market is there to attract those so-called expatriates,'' Mr. Horhn said.
 
Coming Back in Style
The sheer numbers, combined with the increasing popularity of black family reunions has produced a particularly lucrative market, he said.
''Often it's important for those former Mississippians who have gone up north to show their relatives who are still here that, yes, they have made it,'' Mr. Horhn said. ''So they come back in style. They rent the biggest town car they can find. They stay in the finest hotel in town. There's tremendous economic potential there.''
The new awareness is benefiting historical sites that were part of the civil rights movement and those that predate it. Thus, in 1985, the Tuskegee Institute National Historic Site, with its landmarks and museum marking the contributions of Booker T. Washington and George Washington Carver, had 60,207 visitors by the end of August, its officials said. This year, it has had 275,724 for the same period.
''There's more awareness that we're here and a lot more interest in black history than there used to be,'' said Christine L. Biggers, a ranger with the National Park Service at the historic site.
Similarly, the black churches that were central to the civil rights movement are now actively promoted as tourist sites by state and local officials.
The Rev. Christopher Hamlin, pastor of the Sixteenth Street Baptist Church in Birmingham, said most of the tour groups that come to the church are referred by the local convention bureau. In addition, city officials or the Mayor have been available to speak to tour groups or conventions on the history of the church and its role in the civil rights turmoil, he said.
 
Momentum Is Growing
At the Dexter Avenue King Memorial Baptist Church in Montgomery, which became the focal point for blacks while Dr. King was helping organize the city bus boycott in 1955, the number of visitors has increased from 8,000 last year to what is likely to be more than 10,000 this year, said Addre Bryant Sr., presiding deacon.
''It looks like each year the momentum continues to grow,'' he said, ''especially because the state has sent this out on their stationary when they advertise sights in Alabama.''
At the Dexter Avenue church and most of the other black-oriented attractions, the majority of the visitors are black, many of them native Southerners who have left the region.
Ceaser Patterson lived in Montgomery in the civil rights era and has since moved to Seattle. But he said that for many blacks who have left the South there is enormous interest in seeing how much the region has changed and in showing family members what things were like in the days of segregation.
''If you forget history, then you will repeat it,'' said Mr. Patterson, who was showing the Dexter Avenue church to his wife, Vera, a native of the Pacific Northwest.
But many visitors are whites interested in seeing sites that are part of Southern history.
 
Commitment Is Incomplete
Still, much of that history is still painful to many people, and in some places the commitment to acknowledging it is incomplete.
For instance, the most popular stop for tourists here in Montgomery has become the civil rights memorial in front of the offices of the Southern Poverty Law Center. Yet officials with the center say they have been frustrated in getting the state to put up highway signs directing motorists to it.
State highway officials say Federal sign requirements make it impossible. But Morris Dees, director of the center, suggests that the problem is more political than bureaucratic, noting that there are signs for other attractions and that Gov. Guy Hunt, a conservative Republican, turned down an invitation to participate in the unveiling of the civil rights memorial.
''He doesn't want to do anything to alienate what he sees as his electorate,'' Mr. Dees said. ''Sometimes this sort of thing is easier to promote out of state than in state.''
Still, if there is ample evidence that the South, like the rest of the nation, has not solved all its racial problems, the degree to which states are acknowledging their black heritage is a potent sign of how far the region has come.
''People want to see history,'' Ms. Shivers said, ''and the civil rights movement is part of history, and it happened here. If you want to see the Edmund Pettus Bridge, you have to go to Selma, Ala., to see it.''

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf: Decoding the Signals;
The Superpowers Affirm Their Joint Aims But Iraq Could Focus on Their Differences

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 9

 BODY:
But at their joint news conference, when the two Presidents were left to speak spontaneously, it appeared that on many questions about how to deal with Iraq, including whether to link a settlement of the gulf crisis to a settlement of the Palestinian-Israeli dispute and whether Soviet military or naval units should also join the multinational forces in the gulf, there were significant differences.
Both leaders sought to play down those differences, insisting that they should not obscure the larger agreement. As Mr. Gorbachev remarked, there is now a ''solidarity'' for dealing with Iraqi aggression ''which has never been expressed before in the history of the world.''
But the long-term question is not how Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Bush put their agreements and differences into perspective, but rather how Mr. Hussein and the Arab world interpret them. 
Administration officials say the President wanted this meeting precisely in order to send the Iraqi leader an unambiguous message that Mr. Hussein cannot pose as the defender of the Arab nation against American ''imperialism.''
Rather, the message was to say, he faces a global coalition led by both his former patrons - the Soviets - and the Americans. This message, in turn, was meant both to embolden Arab nations like Egypt that have stood up to Iraq and to signal those who have wavered that they cannot count on an American-Soviet dispute to justify not choosing sides.
Will the Iraqi leader now be more impressed by the general agreement underlined by the communique, or will he find succor in the stated differences?
Will Arab leaders now fall more firmly in line against Baghdad, in light of today's message, or will they worry that the cracks apparent in the American-Soviet entente portend trouble, and so decide that they should be cautious in their commitments?
 
Unity on Isolating Baghdad
From the American and Soviet perspectives, the differences exhibited today between Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev were mostly hypothetical. They dealt with issues like whether military force should be used if sanctions fail, and whether a settlement in the gulf should be linked to an Arab-Israeli settlement.
None of these differences, though, diminishes Mr. Hussein's real and immediate problem: how to break out of the international boycott and isolation. The maintenance of those two pressures, on which there are no differences between Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev, is Mr. Hussein's biggest problem. In that sense, he cannot be wildly pleased with what he heard today.
This is especially true if one considers that Mr. Gorbachev, whatever his differences, has now committed his personal prestige to see that the United Nations sanctions produce an unconditional Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. Not only should this make future cooperation between himself and Mr. Bush easier, but it will also send a message to the Europeans to stand firm.
 
Revolutionary Agreement
Considering that Middle Eastern wars have historically been triggers for American-Soviet confrontation, and considering that a decade ago the Soviet Union would almost certainly have supported the invasion by its ally, Iraq, and scuttled international efforts to reverse it, the Bush-Gorbachev agreement on the core issues of how to deal with the Iraqi invasion marks nothing less than a revolution.
Mr. Bush said, ''Differences still remain, but the common ground, in my view, surges ahead of these differences.''
Still, theoretical or not, it would be dangerous to underestimate those differences.
Saddam Hussein is not a person who history would suggest is going to be impressed with words alone, or even sanctions. Therefore, it is significant that the most apparent difference between Presidents Bush and Gorbachev was over the question of using military force to drive the Iraqis out of Kuwait. The final communique states that ''we are determined to see this aggression end, and if the current steps fail to end it, we are prepared to consider additional ones consistent with the U.N. charter.''
President Bush and Mr. Baker indicated that they considered this language a signal that military force was still an option, although they would prefer a diplomatic solution. But when Mr. Gorbachev was asked if military force might be necessary if the Iraqis do not pull out, he responded: ''I did not state that. I do not state that. And moreover, in my view, that would draw us into consequences which we can't at this stage forecast.''
 
Little Leeway on Military
Those are not words that suggest that the Administration has much leeway in using a military option.
Another troubling difference was over the question of paid Soviet military advisers in Iraq. Mr. Bush said that he had asked Mr. Gorbachev to remove the advisers, and Mr. Gorbachev said that he had refused, although he said the number was being reduced as the contracts expire.
Mr. Bush said that he did not ask Mr. Gorbachev to send troops to Saudi Arabia or contribute to the naval blockade, and when the Soviet leader was asked whether he would do either he answered curtly: ''I don't see the point of doing that now.''
To be sure, because of the Afghanistan experience, Mr. Gorbachev faces more domestic resistance to sending forces than Mr. Bush does. But that does not explain why the Soviet leader cannot bring his military advisers home or contribute even a minesweeper to the United Nations blockade.
Not only will that refusal encourage the Iraqis to believe that they can break the blockade, it will send a bad signal to the Arab states still contemplating sending forces and, most seriously, it could portend American-Soviet problems.
If there is a common denominator behind these differences, it is the fact that for all the talk of cooperation today between Moscow and the United States - and it is both real and significant - it cannot mask the fact that the two are still engaged in a global competition for economic and political influence. It is no longer the ideologically driven crusade of the Cold War, but competition it is.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1510 words

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
BUSH AND GORBACHEV SAY IRAQIS MUST OBEY U.N. AND QUIT KUWAIT

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 9

 BODY:

 
Differences on Many Specifics
During an hourlong news conference, however, the two leaders often diverged on how to pursue the campaign against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. [The text of the joint statement and a transcript of the Bush-Gorbachev news conference are on pages A7 to A9.] Differences emerged over the possible use of military force, over Soviet participation in policing the embargo, over the linkage of Iraq's aggression with other Middle East conflicts, over the Arab role as possible brokers of a compromise, and over the presence of Soviet military experts in Iraq.
The meeting, the first the two leaders had held during a time of world crisis, seemed to underscore the new international situation created by the improved relations between Moscow and Washington.
 
Peril of 1967
Mr. Gorbachev alluded to this in an interview over Moscow television after the meeting had ended. He said that during the Middle East war in 1967, the United States and the Soviet Union ''were on the brink of war'' because they supported different sides in the conflict between Israel and the Arab nations of Egypt, Syria and Jordan. 
Mr. Bush, speaking to reporters on his flight back to Washington tonight, said he ''couldn't be more pleased'' by his talks with Mr. Gorbachev and the ''clear signal'' they sent to President Hussein.
Senior Administration officials insisted that Mr. Bush was satisfied that the meeting had served its main purpose - dispelling any doubts that Moscow and Washington are united in their resolve to force Mr. Hussein out of Kuwait.
They said this signal of active Soviet-American political cooperation, and not a list of concrete measures to be employed against Mr. Hussein, was the original purpose of the meeting.
In their joint statement, the two leaders agreed that the economic embargo against Iraq could be softened to allow the delivery of food under supervision of international aid organizations.
With several countries now proposing to ship such humanitarian aid to Iraq, Administration officials said they had sought the language to make sure that any food airlift was narrowly targeted and closely monitored.
 
No 'Wholesale Food Shipments'
''I hope that nobody around the world interprets this as our view that now there should be wholesale food shipments to Iraq,'' Mr. Bush said tonight.
Bantering with reporters after the news conference, Mr. Bush reported that he had accepted Mr. Gorbachev's invitation to visit Moscow, possibly before the end of this year.
The gulf crisis dominated the one-day working meeting, consuming almost all three hours of a private meeting between the two Presidents in the morning and most of an afternoon session with an expanded group of advisers.
Although White House officials had said in advance that Mr. Bush would seek some measure of Soviet military participation in the international stand against Iraq, the two leaders said they did not discuss military options or the introduction of Soviet land forces into the region.
''I did not ask him to send troops in,'' Mr. Bush said. ''If the Soviets decided to do that at the invitation of the Saudis, that would be fine with us. But I did not ask him to do that.''
 
Terseness on Soviet Forces
Mr. Gorbachev, who would face strong popular resistance at home to deploying forces in the Persian Gulf, said the Soviet Union was not considering even a lesser role like helping to police the economic embargo.
''I don't see the point of doing that now,'' Mr. Gorbachev said.
''I'm not disappointed in that answer,'' Mr. Bush added.
A senior Administration official said later that the Soviets had made clear that even a minor role, such as integrating Soviet warships into the armada now enforcing sanctions, would be ''very difficult for them'' unless the operation were put under United Nations command. The United States has resisted submitting its own armed forces to the control of the United Nations.
While Mr. Bush has always deliberately left military force open as an explicit threat, Mr. Gorbachev has never endorsed force in the crisis.
 
Gorbachev Is Explicit
When a reporter suggested tonight that the joint statement opened the way to the use of force, Mr. Gorbachev quickly distanced himself from that option, saying: ''I did not say that if Iraq does not withdraw peacefully, we are going to have recourse to military methods. I did not state that. I do not state that. And moreover, in my view, that would draw us into consequences which we cannot at this stage forecast.''
Mr. Bush conceded later, ''We may have a difference on that.''
Pressed repeatedly during the news conference to identify steps that might be taken against Iraq if the embargo fails, the two leaders declined to speculate.
''We didn't agree to specific and concrete steps,'' Mr. Bush said.
A senior Administration official said later that the Soviets are ''not on board yet with the use of force.''
''But the mere fact that we have a joint statement that doesn't rule it out as an option and that says additional measures will be considered, I think, moves the position even of the Soviet Union forward,'' the official said.
 
Assurance of U.S. Departure
Mr. Bush said he had assured the Soviets that the American troops in Saudi Arabia would leave after the crisis is over.
''They will be present in the area until we are satisfied that the security needs of the area have been met and that these resolutions have been complied with,'' the President said of the troops. ''And the sooner they are out of there, as far as I'm concerned, the better.''
Mr. Gorbachev called this ''a very iimportant statement.''
Although the Soviet President had said he understood and accepted the dispatch of American forces to Saudi Arabia, the grouping of tens of thousands of American troops a few hundred miles from the Soviet border had prompted complaints from the Soviet military and some members of Parliament.
The clearest disagreement between the two men came over the value of holding an international conference to discuss the gulf crisis and then move on to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and the civil war in Lebanon.
 
Division Over Mideast Linkage
The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, has promoted the idea in recent days as a way to make it easier for other Arab countries to remain united against Iraq, and as a possible cover for Mr. Hussein to withdraw his troops.
The United States argues that equating Iraq's invasion with the Palestinian issue would play into the hands of Mr. Hussein.
''The thing that I feel strongly about is that these issues are not linked,'' Mr. Bush said tonight. ''And any effort to link them is an effort to dilute the resolutions of the United Nations.''
But Mr. Gorbachev said later that he considered the gulf crisis and other disputes in the Middle East of ''equal concern.''
Mr. Gorbachev will apparently not take home any tangible commitment for American economic assistance. During their afternoon meeting, Mr. Gorbachev described his plans to move the Soviet Union toward a market-oriented economy, and Mr. Bush reiterated his willingness to give American technological help.
''I think this remarkable cooperation that has been demonstrated by the Soviet Union at the United Nations gets me inclined to recommend as close cooperation in ther economic field as possible,'' the American President said.
 
No Quid Pro Quo, Soviets Insist
Mr. Gorbachev, however, quickly interjected that Soviet cooperation in the gulf crisis was not tied to economic aid.
''It would be very oversimplified and very superficial to judge that the Soviet Union could be bought for dollars,'' the Soviet leader said.
An Administration official said the two men talked briefly about the lagging pace of arms negotiations aimed at cutting nuclear arsenals and reducing conventionial forces in Europe.
Although Mr. Bush said he was ''still hopeful'' that both agreements could be signed by the end of the year, Mr. Shevardnadze told reporters later that prospects for a nuclear weapons treaty this year were slim.
''This year it will probably not come off,'' Mr. Shevardnadze said.

PUB-DATE: September 10, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1185 words

HEADLINE: NEW YORK SCHOOLS OPEN, FACING TEST: DO MORE WITH LESS

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:

 
Full Test for Chancellor
The city's 120 high schools opened Thursday and Friday, but today is the first full day of school for the entire system. And with the new term, 82 of the city's 984 schools begin a dramatic experiment in power sharing among principals, teachers and parents. A new ''professional development'' program starts, with the aim of helping ineffective principals improve their leadership talents. Mr. Fernandez said three principals had enrolled voluntarily in the program and a dozen others were being scrutinized for enrollment.
The Board of Examiners, long criticized for impeding the recruitment of teachers, is being replaced in a few months by a new testing office directly under Mr. Fernandez's control. A new agency for investigating corruption among school officials independently of the Board of Education is about to be put in place. 
As a result of these seismic shifts, the year will present the first full test for Mr. Fernandez, who came to the city showered with praise for the job he had done leading the Miami area's school system and who is still grappling with gaining control over a far larger system, where power is divided between his office and 32 local boards.
The schools expect to welcome 945,000 students, about 6,500 more than last year. With little money to hire extra teachers, the fatter enrollment will likely mean more crowded classrooms.
And with New York City's economy at near-recession sluggishness, negotiators are far apart on a teachers' salary agreement. Both sides have expressed concern about what a low wage settlement would mean to the ability to attract qualified teachers.
Sandra Feldman, president of the United Federation of Teachers, goes so far as to argue that the problems of the city today stem from school cuts in the 1970's.
''Look at the kids who are assailants in the subways,'' she said. ''These are kids from every ethnic group who are out there without any values, who will kill a tourist to go to Roseland. They were in our early childhood classes in 1975 when there were horrendous cuts in the schools. We lost a whole generation of kids as a result of that and we've just begun to build back.''
There is also concern about the current pupils themselves. More than 60 percent come from homes where there is a single parent. While many of those children are outstanding pupils, educators also worry that many are coming from shaky homes, where discipline may be lacking and where parents may not be paying enough attention to whether a child is attending school and striving there.
The Board of Education has learned from the city's Human Resources Administration that in 1989 there were 322,615 New York children between the age of 5 and 17 whose families were receiving welfare payments under the Aid to Families with Dependent Children program. That is a sharp increase from the 1988 figure of 279,939, and it suggests that one of every three children in school is on welfare. Roughly 4,200 pupils live in hotels or shelters.
 
Results of Crack Feared
Five years after crack became widely available on the city streets, the first group of children born to mothers who used the drug during pregnancy is entering kindergarten. Mr. Fernandez estimates that 5 percent of the 60,000 children in kindergarten may have been exposed to crack.
Doctors and psychologists who have worked with such children say they may display short attention spans, violent outbursts of temper, poor speech and hyperactivity.
The small special-education classes that could work with these children are already bursting at the seams, and there are long waits for evaluation and placement. The cost of educating a child in special education is $15,000, compared with $6,500 for a child in a mainstream class, officials in the Chancellor's office say.
Figures completed just last week indicate that 110,246 pupils who attended school last year have limited proficiency in English. Most are immigrants or children of immigrants.
The welter of statistics that profile this year's student body suggest that teachers and administrators will have to work with children who in general will require more guidance, smaller classes, more programs like bilingual education.
In an interview days after the killing of a Utah tourist in the subways by a gang of muggers, Mr. Fernandez said the schools also bore the ''most important responsibility'' for solving society's problems of violence, drugs and racial tensions.
''While poverty is the underlying problem in a lot of this,'' he said, ''unless we're attacking the drug problem through education, the AIDS problem through education, the violence problem through education, it's not going to resolve itself.''
But money, officials say, is lacking. After taking sharp cuts forced by the city's fiscal problems, the Board of Education ended up with a $6.4 billion budget that officials regard as threadbare; it is roughly the same as last year's, even though wages and the cost of supplies have risen.
 
State Aid Helps
A recent infusion of $22 million in state aid, the result of a 2 to 3 percentage point improvement in attendance last year, will help avert layoffs and permit the hiring of more new teachers, Mr. Fernandez said.
Community School District 1 on the Lower East Side, for example, faced the loss of 13 assistant principals until last week; now it may lose three or fewer, said Donald Singer, president of the principals' union, the Council of Supervisors and Administrators.
Still, as late as Thursday, Ms. Feldman was saying that between 200 and 300 teachers had lost jobs at the schools they worked in last year and were looking for openings at other schools.
The city also expects to hire 3,000 new teachers to take jobs vacated by 1,700 teachers who retired last year and to handle the extra classes created by higher enrollments.
Even these new recruits are not an unmixed blessing. Two-thirds, Ms. Feldman said, lack education and other courses necessary to meet requirements for state certification. In the system as a whole, 15,000 of the 65,000 teachers do not meet those requirements.
City officials, Ms. Feldman noted, have said the new budget contains money for raises of only 1.5 percent for all its workers. Teachers in nearby suburban communities, she said, have been receiving raises of 8 to 9 percent a year.
