LENGTH: 967 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Mauritius Thrives as Textiles Boom

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRIOLET, Mauritius

 BODY:
The economic growth has been built on an export-processing zone established by the Government in the 1970's. Industrialists can set up enterprises in the zone at reduced tax and tariff rates.
The concept has been tried in a number of African countries, including Kenya, Zimbabwe and Togo, but so far without such results. Mauritius enjoyed an average annual growth rate of 7 percent for four years after the fledgling export zone was revitalized in 1983 with cuts in income taxes and corporate taxes. The per-capita income is now around $2,000 a year, catapulting the country from the low-income ranks into the middle-income category, as measured by the World Bank. 
The transformation was largely a result of textiles, which account for about 85 percent of the new industry. Fakhru Currimjee, the founder of Bonair, recalled that survival, and then success, did not come easily.
 
Expatriate Expertise
Bonair is one of the biggest companies in the zone, and copies of French Vogue in its waiting room set the tone of a fashion house rather than a textile mill. One of hundreds of factories opened after the establishment of the export zone, Bonair started out with expatriate expertise - Mr. Currimjee had been in the margarine business - and a dud of a first year.
''I came back without selling anything,'' Mr. Currimjee said of his first attempt to sell his products to European buyers in 1975.
Then he received an order from a French company to make an evening sweater according to a designated design. After some false starts in manufacturing - the necks were initially crocheted so tightly that women could not pull them over their heads - thousands were sold by the French company, and Mr. Currimjee had his first steady customer.
Now Bonair sells to the Galeries Layfayette and Au Printemps department stores in France, to the Cacharel label in France and to Next, a British chain of stores. The company also sells to Germany, Italy and Japan. Some Mauritian textile companies export to the United States, but American textile quotas have prevented large sales.
 
Distinct From Africa
Mauritius, whose population is largely Indian, Creole and Chinese, with a smattering of Mauritians of French descent, is usually counted as part of Africa because of its membership in the Organization of African Unity. But people like Mr. Currimjee, whose family came from India as traders more than 100 years ago, insist that the island has little in common with the African continent.
''This country is lumped into Africa, but it's not,'' said Mr. Currimjee, pointing to some of the reasons for Mauritius's economic growth that are missing on the continent.
The first is political stability in a multiparty democracy, a rare system in Africa. Indeed, a recent economic survey by the United States Agency for International Development assessed the political climate in Mauritius as better for business than those in some cheap-labor countries outside Africa, like Sri Lanka and the Philippines.
The second basic ingredient has been a reasonably well-educated work force. Since the country became independent from Britain in 1968, education through secondary school has been free. In contrast, many African nations, like Kenya and Uganda, require impoverished parents to pay school fees. More than half of Mauritius's Government officials have university degrees. Mr. Curimjee graduated from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology; his son, Arif, the managing director of the company, graduated from Williams College five years ago, and his daughter is currently studying Japanese at Brown University.
Mauritius's timing was also fortuitous. The Government of Prime Minister Aneerood Jugnauth rejuvenated the export zone in 1983 with some classic supply-side economic policies - cutting the corporate and income taxes by half, to 35 percent. At that time, Hong Kong investors, nervous because China will take control of their homeland in 1997, were starting to look for places to park their money. Hong Kong is now the largest foreign investor in Mauritius.
 
Connections With Europe
Another important factor for Mauritius was its membership in the Lome Convention, under which products from third world nations receive preferential treatment from the European Community.
The country's long connection with France has helped as well. The French were the first colonizers, even though the British took over in 1810. Many Mauritians are fluent in both English and French.
''French buyers were very happy I spoke French and came from Mauritius,'' Mr. Curimjee said. ''One buyer said to me, 'If you can match Hong Kong, I'll give the business to you, because you speak French.' ''

GRAPHIC: Photos: Once a third world country that struggled along on one cash crop and good will, Mauritius has become the envy of the underdeveloped world, particularly of Africa, because of an export-processing zone established by the Government. Asked if he was worried about domestic rates declining while those in Japan and possibly West Germany were headed higher, he said no policy was without risks. The dollar has weakened but its fall is not precipitous, he said.

HEADLINE: Ladies' Home Journal Takes Russian Tour

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
The issue, which is one of the largest in the magazine's 107-year history, carries interviews with what the magazine calls the 50 most powerful women in America.
 
Building Bridges
Myrna Blyth, the publishing director and editor in chief of The Ladies' Home Journal, said she will fly to Moscow in October for a party to introduce the magazine. The 50 most powerful women in the Soviet Union have been invited the party. 
''We are not doing this to start selling magazines in the Soviet Union as much as to demonstrate the power of women to do such a thing and the power of The Ladies' Home Journal to build bridges in this whole new world,'' Ms. Blyth said.
The venture is a partnership with Novosti, the Soviet press agency, which will distribute the magazines to kiosks throughout the Soviet Union. The magazine will be sold for rubles, which are not convertible to dollars.
Part of the proceeds will be donated to the Children of Crisis Foundation, a charity established by American and Soviet citizens to aid victims of the earthquake in Armenia, and to the Soviet Children's Fund.
 
No Profit for Journal's Owner
The Russian-language insert will be sponsored by Quintessence Inc., which makes Dare fragrance. Ms. Blyth said that the total cost of the Soviet venture had not been calculated but that The Journal, which is owned by the Meredith Corporation, would not make a profit.
Earlier this year, Business Week began publication of Business Week/ USSR, a Russian-language edition of the magazine, for distribution in the Soviet Union. Business Week/USSR is a joint venture between McGraw-Hill and Kniga Publishers of Moscow.
Among other American media ventures in the Soviet Union is a partnership between Rodale Press and an agricultural cooperative in the Soviet Union. One result of the partnership will be Novii Fermer, a magazine similar to Rodale's New Farmer. It is scheduled to begin publication early next year.
Omni, a magazine owned of General Media International, is published in the Soviet Union under an exchange program with the Soviet Academy of Sciences.
And International Data Group of Framingham, Mass., has been publishing PC World USSR in the Soviet Union since 1988.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Latest U.S. Import: a Japanese View of Japan's Economy

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
The 12-page newsletter is a synopsis of what has appeared in the various Asahi Shimbun publications the previous week, emphasizing in-depth analysis and commentary.
 
Explanation of Publication
In the first issue, Eiji Tominomori, managing director of Asahi Shimbun and publisher of Japan Access, wrote, ''Japan Access will explain accurately to its readers the Japanese point of view: how we do business, what we think and feel about our relationship with the United States and, perhaps most important, how we view the future of this relationship and our place in a fast-changing world in which we must compete.''
The newsletter is edited in Tokyo under the direction of Yasunori Asai, its executive editor, and transmitted by satellite to New York, where it is printed. 
Yasushi Hara, Asahi Shimbun's chief representative in New York, said that the initial press run was 10,000 copies but that it would be increased to meet the demand.
Asahi Shimbun already distributes 8,000 copies of the daily newspaper in the United States. Its circulation in Japan is nine million.
Japan Access, which will be published 50 weeks a year, will be sold by subscription only. A one-year subscription costs $250, or $5 a copy, and a half-year subscription is $175, or $7 a copy.
 
A Newsletter in Six Parts
The newsletter will consist of six parts: analysis of the most important news, focusing on politics, government and business; features on topics that especially concern the Japanese, with emphasis on prominent figures in business and government; a column of short items on people, places, trends and ideas; surveys and polls about the mood in Japan; columns on culture and opinion, and a question-and-answer column.
The first issue, for instance, has articles like ''Japan's Trade Surplus: Who Needs It?'' ''Broader Trade, Economic Relations Anticipated,'' ''Japan Demystified: Skyrocketing Land Prices'' and ''Technology: Bug-Free Pantyhose.''

SECTION: Section A; Page 23, Column 3; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 772 words

HEADLINE: Either Force Oil Prices Down . . .

BYLINE: By Joseph Stanislaw and Daniel Yergin; Joseph Stanislaw is managing director, and Daniel Yergin is president, of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, a consulting firm.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
While these are all sound reasons, they do not begin to match the case for tapping the reserves.
The oil market is currently walking a high wire, highly susceptible to the state of panic the Administration is trying to avoid. Traders are nervous not only about a possible gulf war but also about the approach of winter, when demand for oil rises and ability to switch to natural gas diminishes.
Markets - financial as well as oil - are indicating that they expect the consuming nations to fall off the oil trapeze in October or November. As soon as shooting looks imminent - or it appears that supply will not match demand - the price will really take off, to $40 a barrel and beyond. 
The idea of using the S.P.R. only to avert a physical shortage ignores economic reality. A ''shortage'' at $20 a barrel will disappear at $40 a barrel, as the world economy crashes and consumers cut back sharply on purchases. The fundamental rationale of the international energy emergency system established in the 1970's was to protect economic growth.
Moreover, a persistence of sharply-higher prices will threaten the Administration's geopolitcal objectives. Consumer complaints about gasoline and heating oil prices will send political shock waves that will erode the national consensus on the gulf intervention. Worse, severe inflationary and recessionary effects around the world eventually will raise questions, as Saddam Hussein is hoping, about the costs of the embargo. This could undermine the even more remarkable international consensus that has been forged.
If geopolitical reasoning isn't enough, simple arithmetic should convince us to open the reserves. On paper, we seem to have enough suppplies to replace the four million barrels a day lost in the embargo of Iraq (perhaps with an assist from reduced consumption). But to get that extra oil into the market requires a lot more than the flick of a switch.
Some of the facilities in the exporting countries have been idled for 10 years. Inevitably, there are going to be engineering problems, and, possibly, accidents. Thus, it will be months before the additional suppplies can be brought to the market.
In addition, there can always be further, unforseeable pressures in the market: everything from declining Soviet exports to hurricanes in the Gulf of Mexico. The system is very taut. There is no security margin, except for the emergency stocks.
Panic takes a very specific form in the oil market. It always involves the hasty and fevered building of inventories that drives up price. The slightest uncertainty can set the process in motion, sending prices through the roof.
But the process also works in reverse. The best antidote to an upward spiral is the fear among buyers that the oil they are contracting to buy at $40 a barrel will bring $30 a barrel when they sell it two months hence. That's how the S.P.R. can cleverly be used now.
The Administraion could simply announce that the S.P.R. has been activated, run modest demonstration sales and respond to needs as they emerge. Such steps - combined with increasing domestic production and conservation - would send a powerful, calming message to markets and governments around the world.
Of course, there are problems with the S.P.R. Much of the oil has a high-sulfur content, which makes it unsuitable for some domestic refineries. But the same is true of most of the additional oil from Venezuela and Saudi Arabia, which the Administration is counting on to calm the markets and assure supplies this winter.
The real value of the reserves would be to counteract the inherent tendency to panic. Using it for this purpose would establish a new credibility, showing the markets not only that the S.P.R. exists but that it is going to be part of the energy equation.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 5; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Bush & Gorbachev Inc.

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Conveying to Saddam Hussein the message that Moscow was standing with Washington and the rest of the world was meaningful in itself, of course; the chances of persuading him to pull out of Kuwait depend to a considerable degree on penetrating the Iraqi dictator's tough psychological carapace and making him feel increasingly shunned, cornered, friendless.
But Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev appear to have gone a good deal further than that enterprise in Helsinki. Their meeting may have also marked the beginning of a common search for peace in the turbulent Middle East - a goal that has eluded world statesmen even longer than an end to the cold war did.
The meeting's outcome underlined President Bush's determination to help his beleaguered Soviet friend to show himself a world statesman and his country a player on the world stage when everything is going so badly at home. 
 
A Change in Tone
Only two months ago - at the North Atlantic Treaty Organization conference and the seven-nation economic meeting in Houston - Administration officials compared sending economic aid to the Soviet Union in its present parlous state to ''pouring money down a rathole.''
The Germans and the French, Mr. Bush himself said, could do what they liked, but he wasn't going to provide much assistance until he saw evidence of thoroughgoing Soviet reform.
The gulf crisis has changed Mr. Bush's tone.
But Mr. Bush gave Mr. Gorbachev something more than financial assurances. The Soviet leader said at Malta that he wanted to build a world - not just a European continent - that would be free from the ''psychological and ideological struggles'' of the last decade, and now Mr. Bush is giving him a chance to get to work.
Just as the United States determined in the years after World War II to help rebuild its foes in that global struggle, Germany and Japan, and to make them allies for the decades ahead, President Bush appears to have committed himself to at least the early steps toward an alliance with the cold war enemy.
Mr. Gorbachev seems to have acquiesced in the strategy because, for the moment, he has little choice.
''Gorbachev is increasingly a general without any troops,'' said Prof. Peter Reddaway of George Washington University, a leading scholar of Soviet affairs. ''The republics are breaking away from central control, and he is even starting to lose his hold on the armed forces. So he can't commit his troops to help in Saudi Arabia.
''But the more he can strut on the world stage, the more he can strike a pose as a moral leader in search of world peace, the more he can cover up his huge domestic difficulties.''
 
Appearances Matter, Too
Dmitri Simes, a Soviet expert at the Carnegie Endowment, said, ''If you can't be a player, the next best thing is to look like a player.''
The Soviet Union has always sought a Middle Eastern role, long proposing a regional peace conference - a proposal the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevadnadze, has renewed since the invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. When Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d met last week with the Israeli Foreign Minister, David Levy, neither man ruled out the possibility of such a conference, as long as it was not linked to the crisis in the Persian Gulf. Mr. Hussein, the Iraqi leader, has also proposed an international peace confrence, but one that would deal specifically with the gulf question in a regional context.
Moscow has been quietly improving its once-distant relations with Israel, the major American strategic ally in the area. Two of the 11 members of the influential Soviet Presidential Council have recently been in Jerusalem, and Mr. Shevardnadze recently had a lengthy meeting in Moscow with Ezer Weizman, the Israeli Science Minister, who is a leading Labor Party dove.
 
Could Help Reduce Tensions
Though Israel could prove a major stumbling block to a Soviet role in the Middle East, Moscow could play a helpful part, from the American point of view, in resolving tensions there.
A former Washington official who asked not to be identified said that he suspected, though he had no firm evidence, that Mr. Bush had already asked Mr. Gorbachev to use his army's influence with Soviet-trained Iraqi officers to discover whether there was any chance of a coup against Mr. Hussein.
And Mr. Simes said that Moscow might be in a position, within the context of a future Middle East peace conference, ''to put the kind of pressure on the Israelis, especially on the Palestine question, that no American President could ever afford to do.''

 CORRECTION:
A front-page news analysis article yesterday about the Helsinki summit meeting referred incorrectly to the Israeli politician Ezer Weizman. He is a former Science Minister, not the current one.

PUB-DATE: September 11, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1670 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
BUSH, REVERSING U.S. POLICY, WON'T OPPOSE A SOVIET ROLE IN MIDDLE EAST PEACE TALKS

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
The first sign of this change was given at the Gorbachev-Bush news conference in Helsinki on Sunday when Mr. Gorbachev said he had a ''secret'' to reveal - that Mr. Bush had confessed that in the past the United States had tried to keep the Soviet Union out of the Middle East but that now he felt that it was important to cooperate. Was Israel Consulted? The officials today called this aspect of the meeting, which was reflected in comments by Mr. Gorbachev and in the two leaders' joint statement, a development that was overshadowed by the two leaders' vow to oppose Baghdad in the immediate crisis and by their apparent divisions over the use of military force.
But it was unclear whether this new American attitude toward Soviet participation in Middle East peacemaking would actually promote movement toward resolution of longstanding Arab-Israeli issues that through the years have resisted various efforts - sometimes including the Soviet Union - at solution. Administration officials freely discussed the latest development today, although they did not seek to call reporters' attention to it themselves. It was not clear whether the United States had discussed its new willingness to accommodate a Soviet diplomatic role in the Middle East with Israel, which has adamantly opposed the idea in the past. 
The Helsinki meeting also produced a clear willingness by Mr. Bush to expand American economic and technical assistance to the Soviet Union in light of Moscow's help in the gulf crisis. At the news conference, Mr. Gorbachev rather testily asserted that his country was not accepting payment for its actions in the crisis. Mr. Bush noted that direct financial aid, like credits and normal tariff treatment, must await the enactment of economic reforms and passage of a long-promised bill allowing unfettered emigration.
But Mr. Bush reiterated his support for perestroika, Mr. Gorbachev's program of economic restructuring, and said, ''This remarkable cooperation that has been demonstrated by the Soviet Union at the United Nations gets me inclined to recommend as close cooperation in the economic field as possible.''
Mr. Gorbachev badly needs Western help. But it was the apparent shift in American Middle East policy that lay behind his obvious delight when he spoke of changes in American attitudes toward his country. The new willingness to work with Moscow in the Middle East, he said, ''does really give me the hope that we'll get by.''
For decades, the United States has believed that the Soviet Union was seeking to foment, not resolve, regional conflicts, but at times in the past Washington was compelled to work with Moscow. More recently, the United States opposed Soviet involvement in Middle East peace efforts because Moscow had not restored diplomatic relations with Israel, which it broke in 1967, and because Washington believed that a foothold for Moscow would stack the deck against Israel because of the Kremlin's close ties to the Palestine Liberation Organization.
 
A New Attitude
But Administration officials said Soviet behavior in the gulf crisis suggested a new attitude. Assuming that new line continues, the United States is prepared not only to make room for the Soviet Union in Middle East diplomacy but perhaps even to work in tandem with the Kremlin, they said.
The United States believes that the Soviet Union could be helpful in resolving the dispute over the Israeli occupation of the West Bank, in bringing peace to Lebanon, in stemming the spread of missile technology in the Middle East and in creating a new security structure for the region once the immediate gulf crisis is over, an official said.
It is too soon to know how expanded Soviet-American cooperation will affect Israel, although Israel is not likely to welcome Soviet involvement in its dispute with the Palestinians and the United States is probably going to have to take pains to meet Israeli concerns.
''There is no blueprint here,'' an official said, ''but there is a recognition that Soviet foreign policy toward regional disputes is changing and that their new thinking deserves to be matched by new thinking here.''
 
Shift in Three Sentences
The apparent shift in policy was contained in three sentences at the end of the joint statement issued by Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev in Helsinki.
It said: ''As soon as the objectives mandated by the U.N. Security Council resolutions mentioned above have been achieved and we have demonstrated that aggression does not pay, the Presidents direct their foreign ministers to work with countries in the region and outside it to develop regional security structures and measures to promote peace and stability.
''It is essential to work actively to resolve all remaining conflicts in the Middle East and Persian Gulf. Both sides will continue to consult each other and initiate measures to pursue these broader objectives at the proper time.''
Behind these words, an Administration official said, is the prospect of the first serious American effort to engage the Soviet Union in the Middle East peace process in the 13 years since President Carter backed off a proposal for a multinational peace conference to be jointly sponsored with the Soviet Union in the face of powerful Israeli opposition, and the desire of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt to deal directly with the Israelis.
The official said that Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev had reached no specific agreements, but that the last three sentences of the statement were ''intended as a window on the future.''
''There is something potentially significant here,'' he said. ''Though we are not out of the woods on this crisis, people are impressed by and large by Soviet policy to date. People recognize the differences, and assuming this trend continues or even grows, it would be self-defeating not to take this into account when we approach other conflicts.''
 
Baker's Security Plan Cited
The official said the Soviet Union could play a part in American plans, outlined by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d last week, to create a new security umbrella for the gulf. ''Their efforts to participate in, or at least their willingness not to object to, some kind of new security arrangements, could be important,'' the official said.
In the Arab-Israeli conflict, the official said, the Soviet Union could help persuade allies including Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization to reach an accommodation with Israel.
The United States opposes an international peace conference that would link the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait to the Arab-Israeli dispute and other issues. But the official said that if the current crisis is resolved, ''one can imagine an international conference, or some type of gathering, in which the Soviet Union and the United States would participate.''
Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Bush both hinted at these prospects at their news conference. Mr. Bush said the common ground between the two countries outweighed their differences and added, ''We will continue to cooperate with President Gorbachev.''
Beaming, Mr. Gorbachev said: ''That last sentence does really give me hope that we'll get by. In our talks, the President said, 'You know, there was a long time when our view was that the Soviet Union had nothing to do in the Middle East.' This was something that we had to talk through during this meeting here in Helsinki, and what was said is that it's very important for us to cooperate in the Middle East, just as it is on other issues of world politics.''
This sort of talk is a powerful symbol for the Soviet Union, which has long been angered by American efforts to cut the Kremlin out of the Middle East peace process.
In December 1973, after the war between Egypt and Israel, the United States and Soviet Union convened a peace conference as co-chairmen in Geneva. But it lasted only a few days, and the United States then did the neogotiating between Israel and the Arabs.
After Mr. Carter's attempt to convene another conference collapsed in 1977, peace efforts shifted to the American-run Camp David process. Throughout the 1980's, the Soviet Union complained that the United States wanted to talk about cooperation in Afghanistan, Angola and Central America, but never the Middle East.
 
Senate Warning on Gulf Aid
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) - The Senate today approved a resolution threatening a deterioration in United States relations with nations deemed as failing to contribute enough to the effort against Iraq. Japan and West Germany were among countries singled out by irate senators.
The resolution, attached to a spending bill and passed by voice vote, directed President Bush to give Congress a detailed report on the Administration's cost-sharing efforts by Nov. 30.

LENGTH: 1395 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
As the Iraqis Search for Support, They Will Restore Full Iran Ties <10,813>

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 10

 BODY:

 
Continuing Process of Reconciliation
The announcement of diplomatic ties adds another layer of accord to the improvement of relations between the two nations, which has included the release of about 50,000 prisoners of war by both sides and the return to Iran of all territory occupied by Iraq during their eight-year war.
The resumption of ties came as United States officials in Washington said that truck convoys from Jordan and Iran had pierced the blockade of Iraq, although in numbers too small to prop up the economy. The worldwide embargo on Iraqi oil exports also continued, although President Saddam Hussein of Iraq offered today to give oil free to developing countries in a move aimed at ending his country's isolation [Page A17.] The Iranian decision to accede to Iraq's requests to resume ties comes as the Iraqis continue seeking to enlist help in the face of the international commercial and military embargo led by the United States. The embargo seeks to force Mr. Hussein to abandon his occupation of Kuwait, and, perhaps, bring about the collapse of his Government.
Iraq wants Iran to send food and medicine, more important, to help sell embargoed Iraqi oil in repayment for the Iranian assistance. 
 
Successful Mission to Teheran
A visit to Teheran by the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, came after Mr. Hussein moved last month to put a formal end to the war with Iran, which began in 1980 and halted with a United Nations-brokered cease-fire in 1988.
Although negotiations on a peace treaty had apparently been stalled, even before Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, there were increasing signals that the two countries were engaged in secret talks to move toward a final settlement at Iraq's urging.
While the degree of help that Iran is willing to give Iraq remains unknown, the Iranian press agency quoted Mr. Aziz tonight as describing his talks there as ''positive, serious, practical and friendly.'' The Aziz visit was the first in a decade to the Iranian capital by a senior Iraqi official.
The Iranian press agency went on to say that the Government's reaction to Iraq's formal request for the restoration of normal relations was ''a positive response.'' Iranian officials, it said, had given ''their consent in this connection.''
Iranian officials in Western Europe interviewed tonight by telephone, asked to characterize the future of the relationship with Iraq, said only that the normalization falls within the context of ending the Iran-Iraq war.
Arab and Iranian officials also noted that one official who accompanied Mr. Aziz to the talks was Issam al-Chalabi, the Iraqi Oil Minister. He has been leading an effort to break the embargo on the sale of Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude oil.
An Iranian oil-industry official underlined today in a conversation that Iran was one of three members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries that refused in August to endorse a decision by the cartel to increase oil output. Iraq and Libya also opposed the resolution, which was inspired by the Saudis and Venezuelans. Libya and Iran have expressed reservations about extending any embargo on Iraq to medicine and essential food.
 
Supplies Would Buoy Iraqis
''At this point, any effort to secure food and medicine would change the equation in Iraq's favor without any question,'' a Paris-based Arab diplomat said today. ''They can put up with the embargo for many months to come if this goes on.''
The resumption of diplomatic ties appears to be one of the final gestures before the signing of a formal peace treaty would put a formal end to hostilities between the two countries.
In return for Iran's cooperation, Iraq has virtually acceded to all of Teheran's conditions for ending the war, including the splitting of the Shatt al Arab, the waterway that is part of the two countries' long border.
Before Iraq invaded Kuwait, it had insisted on full control of the waterway, which was its only outlet to the Persian Gulf. Its annexation of Kuwait gave it a Persian Gulf coastline.
Palestinians and Arab diplomatic officials suggested tonight that the Iranian-Iraqi reconciliation could eventually result in an alliance between the two countries.
A Palestinian official who asked not to be further identified said it was ''not farfetched to see an Iraq-Iran-Syria-Libya axis emerging'' in the face of the growing American military buildup in the gulf aimed at Iraq. ''In that region, there are many people who feel the United States is not there to look after Arab interests, but after its own interests,'' the Palestinian said.
 
Little Help From West
Iranian officials would not go that far, but they did say that Teheran's repeated gestures of good will toward the West, including the release of several American hostages held by pro-Iranian terrorists in Lebanon and of other Western hostages, have not been met with reciprocal moves.
''Our oil is still embargoed in the United States,'' an Iranian official said.
It appears from these comments that Teheran officials are pondering the costs and benefits of cooperating with the international embargo, and weighing this against a growing reluctance in their country to appear to favor a big buildup of American forces in the gulf region, even a temporary one.
Iran continued today to reiterate its opposition to the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait, and the Teheran radio quoted President Hashemi Rafsanjani as saying that Iran saw no contradiction between its position on Kuwait and the resumption of relations with Iraq.
''The Islamic Republic of Iran, keeping to its position toward the region and Kuwait, insists on the need for a comprehensive peace and implementation of agreements between the two countries,'' the Iranian press agency quoted Mr. Rafsanjani as saying.
The talks today in Teheran pave the way for a meeting between President Rafsanjani and President Hussein of Iraq.
 
Question of War Reparations
Experts in Iranian affairs said the heavy losses suffered by Iran in the war would require further concessions and perhaps reparations from Iraq before the Iranian leadership can induce its people to support any acts of cooperation with Iraq.
Given Iraq's predicament, Arab diplomats said they did not at all dismiss the possibility that Baghdad will give Iran oil to pay for such reparations and may collect only partial payment in food and medical supplies.
The Iranian Government may now be pondering the consequences of international anger over breaking the boycott of Iraq, against what many Iranians say are the meager benefits of slowly normalizing ties to the West.
 
U.S. Response Is Mixed
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (Special to The New York Times) - The White House said today that Baghdad's attempts to improve relations with Teheran posed no threat to the situation in the Persian Gulf region.
''I don't know that there is anything special to fear about it,'' said the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater. ''There again, it shows Saddam Hussein is reaching out to a country where he murdered millions of their people. He's grasping at any straw he can find.''
''Iran says it will abide by the sanctions,'' Mr. Fitzwater added. ''We expect them to do that.''
Privately, United States officials expressed some concern over the decision. Some experts said the action could eventually lead Iran to move Iraqi oil through its pipelines for loading onto ships in Iranian ports.
Should that happen, an Administration official said, ''it would make things more difficult'' for supporters of the embargo, and the United States would probably be forced to stop Iranian tankers if the sanctions were to remain effective.

PUB-DATE: September 11, 1990
Correction Appended

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1877 words

HEADLINE: Its Cash and Tempers Short, Philadelphia Seeks Solvency

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10

 BODY:
In June, Moody's Investor Service responded to what it characterized as an unrealistic budget by lowering the city's bond rating to Ba, a rating for speculative investments, from Baa, the lowest rating for investment-grade bonds. It was the first time since Boston defaulted on bonds in 1980 that the credit agency had issued a speculative rating for a major city.
The chronic cash shortage, meanwhile, has prompted the officials to talk of such drastic steps as selling prime city property like Veterans Stadium and releasing several hundred prisoners from the crowded jails. Some outside observers have accused city officials of denying financial reality and resorting to accounting gimmicks.
No one can say exactly what would happen if Philadelphia becomes insolvent, but it would likely be forced to lay off employees, default on its debt and, under existing law, rely on the state to manage its finances. Will Other Cities Follow? Philadelphia's problems have no parallel in the nation now, but urban specialists say that if the national economy worsens other cities would follow Philadelphia's lead. ''Clearly, there would be financial emergencies in a number of municipalities across the country,'' said Douglas Peterson, the senior policy analyst for the National League of Cities. 
On Wall Street, investment bankers say that fiscal problems like Philadelphia's, which are occurring at the start of an economic downturn, will be much harder to resolve than those faced by New York, Boston and Cleveland just before the economy began expanding in the 1980's.
Felix Rohatyn, the investment banker who helped navigate New York through its fiscal crisis in the mid-to- late 1970's, said Philadelphia's problems are ''startlingly similar'' to New York's at the time, although the dollar amounts were far larger in New York.
Like Philadelphia, he said, New York had balanced its budget by repeatedly arranging short-term, high-interest loans based on optimistic estimates of tax receipts, and by enacting budgets that did not reflect expenditures that officials knew were looming.
As in many other cities in the Northeast, the underlying cause of Philadelphia's financial problems is the flight of its population to the suburbs. The preliminary 1990 census figures show an estimated 1,535,000 people living in the city, as against 2.1 million in 1950. Most of those leaving have had more money than those who remained, leaving the city with a shrinking tax base but an ever-growing need to provide social services.
 
Politics and Economics
But what sets Philadelphia apart from other cities, many experts say, are the enduring political standoff over the budget and the willingness to use unsound fiscal practices. William J. Stull, chairman of the Department of Economics at Temple University here, said Philadelphia is the first major city to have a fiscal crisis in the last decade because ''here it is substantially a political problem with an economic component.''
He said that unanticipated declines in tax revenues caused by the sluggish economy account for only about 20 percent of the city's deficit of $206 million in a budget of $2.1 billion for the current fiscal year. The rest of the deficit, he contended, represents ''fiscal irresponsibility'' on the part of local officials who supposedly balanced the budget in May.
Under Pennsylvania law, Philadelphia is supposed to balance its budget every year, but deficits have become a chronic problem for several years as the cost of social services, courts and corrections consistently outpaced city revenues. Mayor W. Wilson Goode has repeatedly tried to raise local taxes, already among the highest in the nation, but the City Council has refused, fearing that higher taxes would accelerate the exodus to the suburbs.
 
Services Are Cut Back
Unable to raise more money or reduce services that are mandated by law, the City Council balanced the budget for the fiscal year 1991, which began July 1, by reducing discretionary services, like aid to the homeless and street cleaning, by $65 million. The council's budget, which Mayor Goode permitted to take effect without his signature, also ignored many anticipated expenses, including tax refunds, court settlements and arbitrated wage or benefit increases for city employees.
In August, the city issued a preliminary offering of $400 million worth of short-term notes in anticipation of tax revenues to finance operations until it collected the bulk of its property and business taxes in the winter. The offering disclosed, contrary to the statements of most elected city officials up to this time, that the city anticipated a large budget deficit.
Institutional investors shied away, declining to offer any bids at all. ''The notes don't meet our investment standards,'' said Heidi Baxter, marketing manager for Fidelity Investments. ''We consider them too speculative.'' City officials say they still plan to market the notes this week, and they have been searching for a foreign bank to guarantee the notes. Local banks declined to participate, said Jonathan A. Saidel, the City Controller, who opposes the note sale. ''If we sell the notes, we're still going to have an emergency here, so we might as well come to grips with it first,'' he said. Help From Foreign Banks? Mr. Rohatyn said the plan to seek help from foreign banks reminded him of earlier events. ''Philadelphia's looking for Japanese banks is reminiscent of New York's looking for an Arab sheik to lend the city a billion dollars in 1975,'' he said. ''I wouldn't say the Japanese investors are as mythical as the Arab sheiks were in 1975, but you can't assume that Japanese banks will be any easier to deal with than American banks in gauging the city's credit and the safety of their investment.''
By 1975, Mr. Rohatyn said, New York piled up $5 billion in debt and a $1.5 billion deficit on a $13.5 billion budget. Faced with bankruptcy, the city agreed to let the state oversee its finances in exchange for permission to borrow on the state's credit. The Federal Government, after first balking, agreed to provide guarantees for $1.5 billion in bonds.
''It had no choice, because a bankruptcy of that size would have shaken the banking system,'' Mr. Rohatyn said. ''There is no chance Philadelphia will get Federal help, because there is no indication the city and state can't take care of it themselves.''
Until now, Philadelphia's officials have had irresolvable differences among themselves and with state officials over the budget problems. To make matters worse, this year and next are election years for nearly all state and city officials, with the big exception of Mayor Goode, a Democrat who cannot seek a third consecutive term next year.
 
Trading Charges of Blame
Most city officials contend that the state does not adequately finance the city's social service programs; most state legislators argue that the city spends too much on these services. Both seem to communicate with each other only through the news media.
On Aug. 20, for example, Mayor Goode gave a speech on television about the city's problems and said he would press the State Legislature to enact his plan for resolving the city's fiscal problems.
Three weeks later, Republican legislators, who control the State Senate, say they have heard nothing from the city. And Democratic legislators, who control the state House of Representatives, say that the Mayor has no plan or that they do not support his fundamental demand for more taing authority.
''It's not just a communication problem,'' said Robert W. O'Donnell, a Philadelphia Democrat and speaker of the House of Representatives. ''There has been a total collapse of a political infrastructure in Philadelphia, and there is no mechanism to carry a plan forward. In any kind of effective political process, there is an underlying set of durable, predictable relationships that people trade on. It does not exist in Philadelphia.''
 
A 1985 Disaster Was Pivotal
Race enters any discussion about Philadelphia politics and Mayor Goode, the city's first black mayor. Many people, including some of the Mayor's supporters, say he has lost credibility and date his problems back to 1985, when the Mayor approved the bombing of the home of the radical group Move. The resulting fire killed 11 people, destroyed 61 homes in the black neighborhood and left 250 people homeless.
Mayor Goode discussed his political problems in an interview this week, but he insisted that his remarks about the financial crisis be off the record because of the pending sale of city notes. ''It is unfortunate that my supporters and nonsupporters can't seem to understand that the people of this city have put the Move situation in perspective and no longer see that as a negative factor in regard to me,'' he said. ''But you cannot overlook the issue of race in politics, and a lot of what's happening now, in terms of not having support from other leaders, is because of my race as well as a pure political struggle over who should control the city.''
In the Mayor's television address, his last public comment on the issue, he said: ''The city is not bankrupt, but it will run low on readily available cash next spring if corrective measures are not taken - and even sooner if we do not obtain temporary loans.''
 
Planning Where to Trim
He said he would prepare a selective freeze on hiring, capital improvements and development projects and would identify all nonessential services that could be suspended.
The Goode Administration plans to send a lobbyist to Harrisburg Sept. 22. Among other things, the Mayor is seeking a tax dedicated to finance mass transit, a sales tax and additional power to withhold wage taxes. The Legislature, many of whose members harbor deep resentment toward Philadelphia and its leaders, has refused to act on these requests in previous sessions.
This package has almost no hope of passing, since the Democratic leadership and Gov. Robert P. Casey, a Democrat, say they are looking for a comprehensive plan that has wide local support, and they have begun meeting with city officials. Republican leaders say flatly that they do not trust the city with more money.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 12, 1990, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about Philadelphia's financial problems misstated Boston's fiscal record. The city of Boston did not default on its bonds in 1980; its bond rating was lowered in July 1981 by Moody's Investor Service to Ba, a rating reserved for speculative investments.

LENGTH: 829 words

HEADLINE: MAN IN THE NEWS;
A Foe to Be Feared: Prince Yormie Johnson

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:

 
Rebel Leaders Split
His involvement in the civil war that began last December stems from the bitter hatred between the Krahns, Mr. Doe's tribe, and the Mano and Gio tribes. Mr. Johnson, whose given name is a common one in Liberia and does not connote royalty, belongs to the Gio tribe.
Mr. Johnson is no stranger to coup attempts against the Doe regime. He was arrested in 1985 during an unsuccessful effort led by Gen. Thomas Quiwonkpa, but escaped to rejoin other exiles in the Ivory Coast. From there, four years later, the insurgents launched the attack against Mr. Doe. 
Once allied with another rebel leader, Charles Taylor, Mr. Johnson broke ranks this year to create a splinter group. The two men reportedly had a bitter split after Mr. Taylor accused Mr. Johnson of executing several rebels whom Mr. Johnson accused of looting.
Clearly Mr. Johnson has a flair for the dangerously dramatic. It was his threat to arrest foreigners in the Liberian capital, Monrovia, last month that spurred United States marines to evacuate scores of American Embassy officials and their dependents.
Mr. Johnson, who carried out his threat 24 hours after the evacuation and seized a dozen foreigners only to release them unharmed a few days later, said he wanted to provoke foreign intervention to help end the fighting that has claimed the lives of 5,000 people, mostly unarmed civilians.
 
'This Guy Is Dangerous'
While numerically smaller than Mr. Taylor's forces, Mr. Johnson's 600-member faction is considered by many Western diplomats to be more disciplined. Mr. Taylor's force controls most of the country, for example, but Mr. Johnson's guerrillas seized most of Monrovia, leaving Mr. Doe to defend his rule from his fortified seaside mansion.
''This guy is dangerous,'' said a Western official who is familiar with Mr. Johnson's tactics.
For the most part, his tactics have worked. Leaders of the 16-member Economic Community of West African States decided last month to send troops to halt the conflict. In contrast to Mr. Taylor, Mr. Johnson openly welcomed the troops, from Nigeria, Ghana, Guinea, Gambia and Sierra Leone.
But Western diplomats said that despite Mr. Johnson's pronouncements, it is unclear whether he will relinquish control once elections can be arranged or an interim government is set up by the peacekeeping force.
 
The Son of a Hunter
The son of a Gio hunter, Prince Yormie Johnson was born in Yorcomplay in Nimba County, an area in northeastern Liberia known for its rich iron deposits and industrious people.
Mr. Johnson grew up with an uncle in Monrovia, and was befriended there by an American family attached to the United States Agency for International Development. Friends and Liberian journalists said the family helped him complete St. Samuel High School, a private school in Monrovia.
He joined the Liberian Army in the early 1970's and quickly rose through the ranks as a military policeman and intelligence officer, ultimately attaining the rank of captain. Mr. Johnson is believed to have received some training from American military advisers, including instruction in guerrilla warfare tactics.
After the failed coup attempt in 1985, Mr. Johnson and other exiles regrouped and were frequently heard on British Broadcasting Corporation broadcasts condemning the Doe Government, said Joe S. Kappia, a former Liberian journalist who now lives in San Jose, Calif.
The rebels mounted their invasion last December, moving into Nimba County from neighboring Ivory Coast.
 
Fighting Could Drag On
Mr. Taylor is of mixed Americo-Liberian and African ancestry. Americo-Liberians are the descendants of American slaves who founded Liberia in 1847.
Western analysts and Liberian-American groups in the United States said that despite the presence of the multinational troops in Liberia, fighting between the two rebel groups could drag on for months.
And with Mr. Johnson's promise of free elections juxtaposed against his violent tendencies, Western officials are not sure which direction he will ultimately choose.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
NATO Members to Weigh Adding Troops to Gulf Force

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Sept. 10

 BODY:

 
Drawing West Europeans In
The move also appeared to be designed to draw the West Europeans more into the military alignment against Baghdad and to help defuse criticism in the United States that only Americans are risking their lives.
The Secretary of State also announced that in light of Moscow's agreement this summer to withdraw all Soviet troops from a united Germany by 1994 - effectively reducing Soviet troops in central Europe to zero - the understanding that the Soviets and Americans reached in Ottawa last February about their future troop levels in Europe was now null and void.
In the Ottawa agreement, the two said that they would reduce their troop levels in central Europe, as part of the conventional arms treaty now being negotiated in Vienna, to 195,000 soldiers each, from their present levels of more than 300,000 each.
''The understandings that were reached in Ottawa have been overtaken by events, and those understandings no longer pertain,'' Mr. Baker said. Mr. Baker said he and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, had agreed on this when they met in August in the Siberian city of Irkutsk. 
Mr. Shevardnadze said Sunday in an interview with Cable News Network that the Soviet Union does not expect the United States to reduce its troops in Europe to zero, after the Soviets do, but that Soviet officials do expect a cut in American forces to far below 195,000. He and Mr. Baker will begin negotiating a new understanding when the two meet in Moscow starting Tuesday.
 
Troops Not Available Soon
The troop accord could take weeks to negotiate and much longer to be completed and approved in treaty form, and thus it is not likely to make any more American forces available for the Persian Gulf crisis in the near future.
In the news conference after the NATO meeting today, Mr. Baker also announced that all of the pledges of financial support from Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, which he elicited last week, had been formally received by American embassies in the gulf region. The pledges amount to $12 billion dollars by the end of the year, he said. This will be split 50-50 between the United States and the poor Middle Eastern nations, like Syria, Egypt and Turkey, that have joined the coalition against Iraq but are suffering economically.
A substantial part of the $6 billion in aid to the United States will be in fuel, water, food and other essential materials, Mr. Baker said. Considering that Mr. Baker told Congress last week that the American military operation in the gulf would add $6 billion to the Pentagon budget by the end of 1990, it means that the Administration can say to the American people that there will be little cost to the United States Treasury from the gulf operation.
Mr. Baker said he had told his NATO colleagues that this financial assistance pointed ''to a central fact of the responsibility-sharing effort: Money is not enough.''
''The billions of dollars pledged are invaluable,'' he said. ''But all the money in the world cannot create the airlift and sealift capabilities required today to move heavy forces into place and to return refugees home. The industrialized democracies of Europe and Asia who have extensive airlift and sealift capabilities can help by making ships and planes available for this critical need.''
Mr. Baker said he had received the following new commitments today:
* West Germany, which says it is prohibited by its Constitution from dispatching troops abroad, will send additional airlift and sealift support.
* The Netherlands will contribute additional equipment for combating chemical and biological warfare.
* Belgium will send aircraft to Egypt to help evacuate refugees from Kuwait and will also provide 20,000 tons of food aid for Egypt.
* Norway will provide additional humanitarian aid to refugees and will respond to specific military requests after a debate by its Parliament.
* Greece's merchant marine committed three sealift vessels.
* Denmark pledged to supply garage ships for transporting vehicles and Egyptian troops.
Mr. Baker concluded by saying these were only the measures he felt comfortable listing in public, suggesting that others could not be disclosed.
Beside this appeal for transport assistance, though, Mr. Baker said he had told his NATO colleagues that Washington would ''welcome additional ground-based forces in the region should any of the countries around the table seek to send them.''
''We would welcome it, even if it were only symbolic,'' he said.
The NATO Secretary General, Manfred Worner, indicated that all the members agreed to consider the American request seriously, saying: ''There was a unanimous conviction that can and should still be done. The allies will consider and study favorably these requests.''

PUB-DATE: September 11, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 16, Column 5; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 870 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Baker Will Go to Syria For Help Against Iraqis

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Sept. 10

 BODY:
''Syria has been very supportive of the international effort that has been made to isolate Saddam Hussein,'' Mr. Baker said at a news conference at NATO headquarters. ''They have been supportive, obviously, of the U.N. resolutions, and they are supportive of the United States presence in Saudi Arabia.''
Syria has a great deal to offer the campaign against Saddam Hussein. To begin with, President Assad and President Hussein are bitter foes who have been plotting against one another for years. Syrian intelligence services are believed to have cultivated agents within Iraq and among Iraqi opposition movements, most of whom are now based in Damascus. They could prove very useful in any attempt to destabilize the Hussein regime. 
Equally important, Mr. Assad's Arab nationalist credentials are widely respected, and if he is joining the movement against Mr. Hussein, and even sending troops to fight alongside the Americans, it sends a powerful legitimizing signal in the Arab world for the effort. #3,200 Commandos in Saudi Arabia Syria has sent roughly 3,200 commandos to Saudi Arabia, and in return the Saudis have given Syria generous economic aid, the amount of which has not been disclosed.
''It is important,'' Mr. Baker said, ''that we have a face to face discussion of the situation in the gulf and how we might be able to cooperate to achieve what happen to be mutual goals. That does not mean that the formally strained relations are cured overnight, and it does not mean that we don't have some differences and won't continue to.''
In announcing his trip to Damascus, Mr. Baker also disclosed that Washington had appealed to Iran, which reopened diplomatic relations with Baghdad today, to engage in a similar dialogue with the United States. Thus far, he said, all that the Iranians have responded through third-party diplomatic channels was, ''Thank you for the message.''
''Would we welcome anything Iran could do to assist in the isolation of Saddam Hussein?'' Mr. Baker said. ''You bet we would. Has this been communicated to Iran? You bet it has. Would we go to Teheran today? No. We do not have relations at all with Iran, for reasons which are well known.''
By going to Damascus to court Mr. Assad, the Administration would seem to be inviting questions about whether in its zeal to roll back Mr. Hussein's invasion of Kuwait it is sacrificing human-rights principles. A similar desire to punish Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's Iran led the Reagan and Bush Administrations to provide aid and military intelligence and food aid to Mr. Hussein's Iraq for years.
 
On Department's Terrorism List
Syria has been on the State Department's annual list of governments supporting terrorism for several years, along with Iran, North Korea, Cuba, Libya and the former Government of South Yemen, which merged with Yemen this year. Iraq, by contrast, was added to that list only last week.
The State Department's handbook ''Patterns of Global Terrorism,'' published in April 1990, states, ''Both Syria and Syrian-occupied Lebanon remain sanctuaries for a wide variety of international groups that have engaged in terrorism,'' including the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, General Command - which is widely suspected of masterminding the Pan Am flight 103 bombing.
But for years, American Secretaries of State have been prepared to overlook some of the more violent characteristics of Mr. Assad's Government -which in February 1982 suppressed a Muslim revolt in the town of Hama by killing some 20,000 of its inhabitants -to enlist Damascus's support for Arab-Israeli peacemaking efforts, help in stabilizing Lebanon or assistance in securing the release of American hostages in Lebanon.
When Mr. Baker was asked if he had any qualms about warming relations with Syria, he responded categorically. ''We are not embracing Syria and everything that it has done,'' Mr. Baker said. ''We talk to a lot of people with whom we have disagreements. It is important to show the extent to which Iraq is isolated in its unprovoked aggression.''
The Secretary said he would not be visiting Israel on this trip, but pointed out that he met with Israel's Foreign Minister, David Levy, in Washington last week.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Trade Violations Are Called Too Small to Prop Up Iraq

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
''The first point is that we've shut off the ocean routes,'' said a Bush Administration official who is following the crisis. ''That's the key to the embargo's overall effectiveness. And one reason we've been so effective is that people know what will happen to their ships if they go into that area.'' 
 
Ships Intercepted
That official said the Administration regards the naval blockade as more important than the sealing of overland routes because it shuts off Iraq's ability to export oil, and therefore denies President Saddam Hussein the money Iraq needs to buy food and other goods.
France said today that its ships had stopped five vessels on the high seas since its navy began enforcing the trade embargo on Aug. 28. The United States has also intercepted ships and has briefly impounded one.
Jordan remains the prime route for goods entering Iraq, officials said, but what had been a steady flow of trucks across Jordan to the Iraq border slowed to a trickle by this week. The Jordanian port of Aqaba is ''pretty much shut down'' as an entry point for Iraq-bound goods, one official said.
Jordan's ruler, King Hussein, has moved more openly toward complying with the sanctions since he was assured of international assistance to offset the loss of trade with Iraq.
Iran, the only other neighboring nation that has voiced some support for Iraq in the gulf standoff, has permitted smugglers to conduct a flourishing trade across the two nations' border.
In addition, several convoys ''involving long-distance trucks which the Iranian Government probably knows about'' also have crossed into Iraq in the last two weeks, one Government official said. Iran has indicated that it would allow some food to reach Iraq, but it was not known what the truck convoys carried.
 
General Compliance by Iran
With the exception of those apparent violations, however, the Iranian Government has generally complied with the United Nations embargo, Administration officials said.
In Brussels today, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d was asked whether the United States would welcome Iran's help in enforcing the embargo and replied, ''You bet we would.''
While Administration experts profess to be delighted with the success of the sanctions, the most easily measurable impact, on Iraq's food supplies, has yet to be keenly felt, experts say.
Iraq's agricultural output has been anemic recently, said Patrick L. Clawson, an expert on the Iraqi economy at the Foreign Policy Research Institute in Philadelphia. But the Iraqi Government has increased incentives for farmers this summer, and the next harvest is likely to be large, he said.
According to a report from the agricultural attache at the American Embassy in Baghdad, Iraqi Government stockpiles held about 1.2 million tons of wheat, barley, corn and rice in July. Human and animal consumption of these staple grains is estimated to be about 500,000 tons a month.
 
Humanitarian Shipments
Western diplomats have said repeatedly that starving Iraq is not a goal, and the United Nations embargo allows shipments of food and medicine for humanitarian purposes.
There were tentative signs today that Iraq was beginning to feel the economic pinch. President Hussein sought to break the prohibition on exports of Iraqi oil, offering to supply the oil free to any third-world country that would run the blockade of Iraqi ports.
The Government also toughened its price controls, threatening 15-year prison sentences to merchants who try to profiteer from food shortages. The Government also gave permission for all Iraqis to plant wheat, corn and rice on Government-owned land.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Iraq Offers Free Oil to Nations That Run Embargo

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 10

 BODY:

 
Self-Service Delivery
He said that because of the embargo, Iraq would be unable to deliver the oil and that the other countries would have to send ships to pick it up.
Despite the pinch of rising oil prices, it seems doubtful that any developing country would take up Mr. Hussein's offer and run the risk of losing vessels to the armada of international warships that has quarantined Iraq. Insurance companies have stopped issuing coverage for ships destined for Iraq and almost all the sea traffic has halted.
In his brief television message, the latest of what has been a series of statements to the world, Mr. Hussein contended that his proposal would not violate the embargo because the oil was a gift and ''does not involve any buying or selling.'' 
The United Nations resolution imposing the embargo, however, makes no mention of the cost of goods, but merely prohibits their transport from or entry into Iraq.
In Baghdad today, thousands of Iraqis took part in protest demonstrations outside the United States and British embassies that were certainly approved if not fully inspired by the Government.
The protesters burned effigies of President Bush and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain and carried signs expressing defiance of the economic blockade.
''No surrender even if we starve to death,'' read one sign. ''The economic blockade will fail, and Iraq will triumph,'' read another.
In London, British diplomats announced that the United States and Britain planned to charter another Iraqi Airways jet to fly British and American women and children from Baghdad to London, as part of an exodus that began more than a week ago.
After holding thousands of Europeans and Asians hostage for nearly a month, Mr. Hussein decreed last week that women and children could leave Iraq but that most men would have to stay behind as human shields to deter an attack by the allied forces in Saudi Arabia and nearby waters.
After several delays, groups of mostly women and children have started to depart from Baghdad. The latest group of women and children, a total of 438 people, including 165 Americans and 186 Britons, landed in London on Sunday.
 
Boycott Beginning to Be Felt
Mr. Hussein has tried several maneuvers to circumvent the embargo, which has been in effect a little more than a month and is beginning to be felt in Bagdhad, according to reports from travelers and diplomats. Bread, rice, sugar and other basic foods are being rationed, and many restaurants have either closed or begun offering limited meals.
Last week, the Ambassadors of Pakistan, India, Sri Lanka and Bangladesh were summoned to the Foreign Ministry in Baghdad and told that the Government could no longer provide food for the tens of thousands of Asian citizens working in Iraq.
Instead, Mr. Hussein urged that the Asian countries confront the embargo by trying to ship food to Iraq for their own people.
 
Milk Can Be Found
Last week, he said in another television message, also read by an announcer, that children in Iraq were dying because of shortages of milk and medicines. The Iraqi leader has made prominent use of the fate of children, both Iraqi and foreign, in his public comments. Diplomats in Iraq said they had seen no evidence that Iraqi youngters were being deprived of milk.
A woman shopping in a neighborhood grocery store in Baghdad last week said that milk and some European-made baby foods were not available in all stores, but that with persistence they could be found.
 
The Broadcast Message
In his television message, Mr. Hussein said the developing countries need not pledge support for Iraq to get free oil.
''This decision,'' he said, ''was made irrespective of the stands you have taken toward the current crisis because we are understanding of your attitudes, and we do understand that there are differences of views and positions.''

SECTION: Section A; Page 18, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1002 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Junior Partner No More, Gorbachev Raises Role to Major Player in Crisis

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 10

 BODY:
By all indications, his desire was to tie the Soviets more tightly into the international consensus, to send to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq the picture of a solid front, not to open a new one.
In their joint communique on Sunday, the two Presidents remained in harmony on the ultimate objective: the application of international pressure until Iraq has carried out an unconditional retreat.
Mr. Bush could also feel satisfied that the statement included nothing to tie his hands if he decided to authorize military measures against Iraq. By not foreclosing the use of military force, the joint statement can be understood to mean that Moscow will not make a fuss if that is the option Mr. Bush chooses. 
But if Mr. Bush hoped for some more explicit closing of the ranks, he was disappointed.
On the contrary, Mr. Gorbachev was careful not to limit in any way his ability to maneuver as an intermediary.
First, he has made no commitment to involve the Soviet military in the gulf crisis. Indeed, in their news conference Sunday night, Mr. Gorbachev took pains to distance himself from any prospective military options.
 
Winning and Losing Points
Joining the military encirclement of Iraq would have won Mr. Gorbachev points with the White House, but it would have cost him at home - with his war-weary public and his Islamic minority - and narrowed his channels of communication with Iraq.
Second, he got a promise that the American troops massing in Saudi Arabia would not stay on after the crisis is resolved.
Mr. Gorbachev never showed much evidence of being personally worried on this score, but it has caused some anxiety among his military, and among some of the Arab nations that Mr. Gorbachev is cultivating.
The official Tass press agency, in its commentary today on the summit, singled out Mr. Bush's pledge: ''The Helsinki summit has answered the question that alarmed not only the Arabs but all the world - do certain Washington circles intend to exploit the present situation for perpetuating their military presence in the gulf area? President Bush replied unequivocally and with a sense of full responsibility that the Administration has no such plans.''
Third, Mr. Gorbachev underscored his insistence that the Iraq crisis is part of the broader Middle East problem, along with the Israeli-Palestian dispute and the civil war in Lebanon.
Mr. Bush sees this linkage as a recipe for delay, a sign of weakness in the face of Mr. Hussein. Mr. Gorbachev apparently feels that linkage could offer Iraq a face-saving excuse to retreat. Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union has already suggested that he may visit Iraq to pursue such a deal.
Fourth, Mr. Gorbachev resisted pressure from Mr. Bush to make a show of withdrawing his military trainers and technicians from Iraq, though he may do so gradually. The Soviets have argued that if these contract experts are pulled out, Iraq might retaliate by seizing Soviet hostages.
 
Bristling at Condescension
Finally, the Soviet leader went out of his way to dispel the impression that the Soviet Union was surrendering its freedom of action because of the lure of Western economic aid.
When President Bush condescendingly observed that Moscow's cooperation on Iraq ''gets me inclined to recommend as close cooperation in the economic field as possible,'' Mr. Gorbachev fairly bristled in replying that Soviet foreign policy would not be ''bought for dollars.''
How Mr. Gorbachev will choose to use his independence remains to be seen, but the political risks in taking on the role of intermediary are minimal.
His own compatriots are preoccupied with their economic woes, and do not much care whether he succeeds or fails in extricating the world from the gulf crisis, as long as he does not get Russians killed in the process of trying.
 
Potential Reward
Worldwide, the optimism about a diplomatic settlement brokered by the Soviet Union is not high. There are no great expectations to be let down.
And if Mr. Gorbachev succeeds in claiming credit for a resolution of the gulf crisis, the potential reward is substantial.
At his news conference on Sunday, Mr. Gorbachev almost crowed about an invitation from President Bush to participate more actively in the Middle East:
''In our talks, the President said, 'You know, there was a long time when our view was that the Soviet Union had nothing to do in the Middle East - had no business being there.'
''This was something that we had to talk through during this meeting here in Helsinki. And what was said here is that it's very important for us to cooperate in the Middle East, just as it is on other issues of world politics.''
Though Administration officials today professed to welcome a new Soviet partnership in the Middle East, Mr. Bush may merely have meant that the Soviets are welcome to play a supporting role in the region as long as they see things the American way and do not tilt the balance against Israel.
But if Gorbachev is perceived as helping resolve the current crisis, his claim to a substantial role in the region will not depend on an invitation from the White House.
