HEADLINE: Population Decline in Rural America: A Product of Advances in Technology

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SCRANTON, Iowa, Sept. 7

 BODY:
''It looks like a ghost town,'' said Bill Gibson, a 74-year-old farmer, whose grandfather broke ground on the family's land with a team of oxen in the middle of the 19th century. ''I sure miss the people.''
 
Census Tells the Story
The 1990 census has put into numbers what people in small towns around the country have been experiencing through so many sad farewells. The American small town, which has long occupied a revered place in the nation's history and mythology, is becoming something of a museum piece. 
''The image of the all-American small town is deeply implanted in our national psyche,'' said Calvin Beale, a demographer for the Agriculture Department. ''But small towns and the countryside are in grave trouble. In an economic sense, a lot of these little places just aren't needed anymore.''
The preliminary Census Bureau numbers show that rural regions saw sharper losses than expected in the last decade, fueled partly by the farm crisis. Between 1980 and 1990, the population of Iowa declined 5.1 percent, a deeper loss than in any other state and 1.5 percent sharper than demographers had predicted. In Wyoming, the decline was 3.9 percent more than had been projected.
But the agricultural recession in the 80's has simply accelerated a trend away from rural areas that has gone on since the turn of the century.
In 1950, about 44 percent of Americans lived on farms and in small towns. That number has declined to about 23 percent. Big cities have been losing ground, too. The most dramatic growth has come in the suburbs, which have essentially replaced the small town as the quintessential American hometown.
 
Main Streets Die Out
For the most part, small towns emerged as commercial centers for farmers. But technological advances, starting with the tractor, and other economic forces have increased the size of farms and cut the number of farmers. As a consequence, there are fewer customers for the cafes, bars and clothing stores that once filled the main streets of small towns.
Demographers say small towns within a reasonable distance of metropolitan areas, like ones in DeKalb County near Chicago and in Putnam County near New York City, will survive, even prosper, as people search for cheaper housing and smaller schools. But if these small towns become popular, they will essentially become suburbs themselves, the next ring in an ever-expanding metropolitan area.
Even as people move to suburbs and bigger towns, Americans are more likely to say that small towns are the best places to live.
A year ago, the Gallup Organization asked people if they would prefer to live in a city, suburb, small town or farm. Small towns were the choice favored by 34 percent; 24 percent chose a suburb; 22 percent picked a farm, and 19 percent favored a city. Four of the five respondents lived in a metropolitan area.
 
A Change in Society
''People in metropolitan areas tend to either romanticize or ridicule life in small towns,'' said Charles H. Hassebrook, a policy analyst for the Center for Rural Affairs, a private research and advocacy organization in Walthill, Neb. ''Neither of the stereotypes fit.''
But the decline in rural areas will diminish the larger society, he said. ''At a wedding in a small town, you can find the lawyer, the banker and the guy who changes tires at the gas station,'' he said. ''I don't think you find that in many metropolitan areas. And it would be a shame to lose that sense of egalitarianism.''
The losses have been deep in Iowa, a state that is heavily dependent on the farm economy. Here in Greene County, about 80 miles northwest of Des Moines, the population has dropped 17 percent since 1980, to about 10,000.
''$1,000 Reward!!'' reads the headline on a poster in a card shop in Jefferson, the county seat. Underneath, it promises the payment to anyone who can help attract an employer who would provide at least 15 jobs.
''You've got to be innovative,'' said Mike Coyne, the economic development chief for Jefferson. ''You can't just give in to the trends and wait for the demise.''
 
Success With Tofu
In this county, where the rich black earth yields millions of bushels of corn and soybeans, civic leaders have scored a victory with tofu.
A Japanese company has announced plans to build a soyflake plant near Jefferson, using a new process that will turn soybeans into flakes that can be converted instantly into tofu. The plant would employ about 25 workers.
Iowa officials say the state's economy has turned the corner. They cite an unemployment rate that has dipped below 4 percent, rebounding farm prices and an upturn in the meatpacking industry. ''It's not like people are packing up the cars like in the 'Grapes of Wrath' times,'' said Harvey Siegelman, the state's chief economist.
As in Iowa, many rural areas are hemorrhaging, as young people typically seek jobs far from home. The average age in Greene County is over 50. Enrollment at Scranton High School dipped so low that the school was closed in 1987, and students were sent to Jefferson, about 10 miles to the east. Even so, Jefferson's school enrollment has dropped by nearly half since 1980.
In trying to curtail the exodus, Mr. Seigelman said the state was considering the campaign slogan, ''Don't let your kids take your grandchildren elsewhere.''
 
Some Come Back Home
And some have returned home, for reasons from family ties to fear of earthquakes. Clara Beth Shockey, 66 years old, returned from San Francisco last year after the quake there.
After 17 years away from Greene County, Cheryl Nailor and her husband, Roger, returned to Scranton. Ms. Nailor found work as a librarian. Mr. Nailor works for the local bank.
''We're some of the lucky ones,'' said Mrs. Nailor, the only woman from the Scranton High School class of 1968 who lives here now. ''We wanted to raise our children in the small-town atmosphere.''
Mrs. Nailor's brother, Dennis Hoyt, was forced to leave farming in 1985, during the agricultural recession. He now lives in Quincy, Ill., where the population of 45,000 is nearly 100 times that of Scranton.
''It was tough to leave. said Mr. Hoyt, who works for a farm management company. ''My family, my history is there. But I've appreciated some of what our family has been exposed to. We take in cultural trips to St. Louis and Springfield. Our kids have greater opportunities in sports and other things at school. My wife works at the community college.
''Things have gone well. But I would never rule out returning.''

PUB-DATE: September 11, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 24, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 563 words

HEADLINE: What Congress Can't Ignore

 BODY:
The Government certainly needs a budget, and getting one won't be easy. The crisis in the Persian Gulf has created enormous uncertainties, particularly in spending for defense and foreign aid. Any overall agreement between the White House and Congressional leaders still faces fractious debate among members of both parties, compounded by everyone's growing nervousness over the state of the economy. 
After months of posturing on all sides, there are now just 20 days before the start of the new fiscal year on Oct 1. And if the necessary work isn't done by then, there will have to be big cutbacks in all manner of Federal programs under the arbitrary strictures of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget law. In any event, America's procrastinating politicians present a sorry spectacle of irresolute leadership.
But while the budget is bound to dominate what's left of the 101st Congress, there is more to be done. Much more. Except for the savings and loan bailout package, last year's opening session was woefully unproductive. This year's concluding session was going to make up for it.
At last, there would be child care legislation for the working poor. At last, there would be a fundamental rewriting of the Clean Air Act. A landmark civil rights bill would restore teeth to job bias laws weakened by Supreme Court decisions. And it even seemed possible that Congress might approve meaningful reform in campaign financing, not least because so many of its members had been profoundly embarrassed by their past pandering to savings and loan interests.
There's more: the pending investigations of the so-called ''Keating five'' Senators for their savings and loan meddling, and of Senator Alfonse D'Amato of New York for alleged meddling in housing contracts. And there's also the not-so-trivial matter of confirming or rejecting Judge David Souter's nomination to the Supreme Court.
Notwithstanding the importance of the budget and Iraq, all these pieces of business ought to be completed this year. If they're not, each one must start again through the 102d Congress. None of them, save perhaps child care, have a substantial bearing on the 1991 budget, and none relate to the gulf crisis. They could be handled in a lame duck session if necessary; skittish members always prefer to make tough choices after elections rather than before. It would be far better, however, and more responsible, if Congress completed its work in the regular session.
Finishing this agenda provides a truer test of the effectiveness of Congress's new Democratic leaders, House Speaker Thomas Foley and the Senate majority leader, George Mitchell, than all the muscle-flexing over spending and taxes. Given leadership, and the will to act, the members of the 101st Congress can get their work done in time for adjournment in early October. If they do, they'll have built a creditable record to campaign on. If they don't, they will have no one to blame but themselves if the voters elect someone else.

HEADLINE: New York Can Be Made to Work

BYLINE: By Felix Rohatyn; Felix Rohatyn, a partner with Lazard Freres & Co., is chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corp.

 BODY:
The workforce has grown by more than 50,000 people in the last 10 years. In the same period, labor contracts have grown generously, both in compensation and benefits. This is not the profile of a city without means, even though the needs to be met are also considerable.
Despite the growth in the workforce and its compensation, city services and the quality of life have declined. Thus, we need to question the city's overall wage and personnel policy. A test of the city's willingness to challenge past practices occurs in this year's labor negotiations. 
The 1991 budget deficit of $1.3 billion was closed with almost $900 million in new taxes, almost $300 million in surpluses from the Municipal Assistance Corporation and the balance in various types of savings. These actions cannot be repeated forever. Clearly, with the sharp deterioration in the city's economy, another budget gap of considerable proportions is looming. It could be well in excess of $1 billion, even $1.5 billion, without any increase in labor costs. Dealing with these deficits will be the Dinkins Administration's major challenge.
The city must develop an economic and management philosophy in setting wage and personnel policies. Failure to do so, in the highly uncertain economic environment, could result in a roller-coaster of layoffs and service cuts, damaging both the city and its employees.
To begin with, the city's 1.5 percent increase for labor costs, included in this year's budget, is more than the city can afford and probably less than the unions can settle for. The city could not find the $30-$50 million required to hire 1,000 additional policemen and had to finance these additions by piecemeal cutbacks in everything from education to libraries.
With today's lagging economy, the right approach is clear: a one-year freeze in total labor costs, while a clearer picture about the economic outlook is afforded, and while the city negotiates a different wage and personnel policy with its unions.
Nothing would be more destructive to the city's economy than an across-the-board labor settlement at rates the city cannot afford. Inevitably, this would be followed by widespread layoffs six months or a year from now or by further tax increases, which will drive more people out of town. Instead, the city needs to establish priorities among its working force and allocate its resources accordingly.
Thus, if crime control and public safety are the city's first priority, then, instead of hiring 1,000 policemen now and probably more later, the city should decide how many policemen are needed to do the job. If it's 5,000, then those 5,000 policemen should be hired and the funds taken away from lower priority functions, such as clerical. This can be accomplished by freezing the salaries of less essential workers, attrition and layoffs, or a combination of these. Reducing the size of the workforce need not mean fewer services; that is the challenge for city managers.
Public education deserves an equally high priority. If the city needs to increase teacher salaries, then the Schools Chancellor, Jospeh Fernandez, should be asked to reduce as drastically as possible the bureaucracy at 110 Livingston Street and the budgets of the local school boards.
It is always tempting to say, ''Increase taxes to pay for cops.'' Everyone wants cops. But then why not increase taxes to pay for teachers. Everyone wants teachers. But we have just had a $900 million tax increase and, in New York today, every form of human activity is taxed to the hilt. Before the city adds to the tax burden, New Yorkers will have to be given a credible, long-term plan for the city's economy and the structure of its services.

LENGTH: 1014 words

HEADLINE: $1 Billion a Year for New Jersey's Poorest Schools

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:

 
'Tough' Scrutiny Promised
After this analysis, the teams and school principals and teachers will draw up new programs tailored to each building's needs. Both these programs and the new money to finance them must be approved by Dr. Ellis before the programs start and the first increase in state aid arrives next September.
''I will approve no program unless I believe it has a reasonable chance of success,'' Dr. Ellis said in an interview. ''It is imperative the money be well-spent. I don't want it to go into administration. I don't want it to go into overhead. We intend to be quite tough on this point.'' 
In moving to send more money into the poorer school districts, New Jersey is entering an unsettled debate among education experts over whether spending more money by itself can insure better education and higher achievement by students.
In a ruling last June that ordered the state to make sure that spending in its 30 poorest districts was comparable to that in its wealthiest, the New Jersey Supreme Court suggested that broader socio-economic changes might be needed to insure true educational opportunity.
 
Performance to Be Checked
Dr. Ellis and other education aides express confidence, but make no guarantees, that pouring money into these districts will result in better student performance. Three areas in particular will be closely watched, he said: test scores, dropout rates and attendance.
A variety of new programs will be covered by the new aid. They include pre-kindergarten and other programs to help very young children; longer school days; broader summer school programs; the state's first tests to measure student grasp of history, English, science, geography, mathematics and other specific subjects; tutoring by peers; alternative education for high-risk students, and more extensive parental involvement in programs.
In addition Dr. Ellis stressed that his aides would challenge principals and teachers in all 435 schools to offer ''innovative ways'' to improve education.
''We have every expectation that we'll see substantial improvements,'' said Carl E. Van Horn, Governor Florio's director of policy and an author of the Quality Education Act, the new state law creating the urban education program.
 
Results 'by the Year 2000'
''I don't think it's fair to look for dramatic results in six months or a year,'' Dr. Ellis said. ''But by the year 2000, we should have world-class schools for every child in New Jersey, and that would mean very comparable scores for the urban, suburban and rural districts. We'll march toward that at a measured pace.''
The 30 poorer districts, which serve about 25 percent of New Jersey's 1.1 million students, include troubled large districts like Newark, Camden, Paterson and Jersey City; smaller cities like New Brunswick, Perth Amboy and Asbury Park, where students have performed relatively well despite a lack of broad course offerings and well-equipped laboratories available to students in wealthy districts; and urban hubs like Phillipsburg, Vineland, and Pleasantville in sparsely settled, outlying areas.
For this academic year, the 30 districts are receiving $1.3 billion of New Jersey's total education aid package of $3.5 billion, state figures show. Under the Quality Education Act, the 30 will receive $2.28 billion in the 1995-96 school year.
 
Multimillion Increases Due
Those getting the biggest increases over the five years will be Newark, up $189.4 million to nearly $500 million; Camden, up nearly $110 million to $216 million; Paterson, up $104.4 million to $223.3 million, and Jersey City, which the state now runs, up $99 million to $213.4 million.
In its June ruling on equalizing school financing, the state's high court found the gap between property values - and consequently spending for each pupil - was widest between the 30 districts and the state's 54 richest. The state was ordered to put the 30 on a spending par with the 54.
But the Quality Education Act, enacted about two weeks after the ruling, overhauled the state's entire financing formula in search of far broader equity. Besides the 30 poorest districts, Governor Florio's new law gives 316 other districts, most of them urban and rural, millions in new aid from a new $1.3 billion state income-tax increase.
The law also imposes a state aid cut of $284 million on 232 richer districts between mid-1992 and mid-1996, and it requires all districts to pay teachers' pensions and Social Security costs, now about $900 million, for the first time.
 
Rise of Tax Protests
The law has led to a widening tax protest by residents and deep resentment in the richer districts over looming cuts in state aid.
In its June ruling, the State Supreme said money alone had not cured all the ills of urban education and suggested the state address housing, employment, child care, welfare and other factors in the urban environment that shape students' lives and determine their educational needs.
Dr. Ellis said he had approached other departments in state government about creating ''parent academies.'' He defined them as coordinated, multi-service offices offering parents help on child-rearing, nutrition, school and social issues, job training and placement and health care. He said crime, drug abuse, poverty and rundown housing created an ''overwhelming oppressive environment'' in some cities.

HEADLINE: Cuomo's Crime Remedy: 'Produce the Police, Period'

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Sept. 10

 BODY:
But Mr. Cuomo did not address the question of how to pay for more police, a question that has occupied Mayor David N. Dinkins and the New York City Council for weeks. The Governor said he would discuss the issue further in a speech on Tuesday before the Citizens Crime Commission in Manhattan.
 
Criticism from Rinfret
In that speech, Mr. Cuomo is expected to call for 5,000 police officers to be added to the city's force, at a cost of about $250 million a year. He is also expected to announce that he will send 100 state troopers to the city to help fight crime. 
With his remarks today and his speech on Tuesday, the Governor appeared to be trying to quiet critics who have recently questioned his response to the city's latest wave of violence.
Mr. Cuomo, who has often responded to news events with a news conference of his own, has been uncharacteristically reserved on the city's crime problems. This prompted his Republican challenger for governor, Pierre A. Rinfret, to charge last week, ''This man refuses to speak out about any important issue facing New Yorkers, most especially the violence in our communities.''
The Governor's remarks today came one day after Mayor Dinkins, also stung by criticism, delivered an address on crime urging New Yorkers to participate in the fight against street violence. And in another indication that speaking out against crime has become a political imperative, both the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, and the City Council President, Andrew J. Stein, today held news conferences to call for tougher law enforcement.
 
Cuomo Defends Dinkins
But even while addressing the subject today, Mr. Cuomo seemed eager to maintain some distance from the crime problem, repeatedly saying that it was the responsibility of the Mayor and the City Council to come up with solutions - and ways to finance them.
''The judgments need to be made by the city,'' Mr. Cuomo said. ''You cannot pre-empt the City Council and the Mayor and say, 'Move over, pal, I think I can do this better.' We will be supportive, but they have to make the judgment as to what their fiscal, economic and safety situation requires.''
Mr. Dinkins has been criticized recently for what some consider a failure to express sufficient outrage over the latest rash of killings in the city. After a 22-year-old Utah man, Brian Watkins, was killed on a subway platform last week, Mr. Dinkins pledged to try to express his anger more effectively.
But Mr. Cuomo today defended the Mayor, saying that while Mr. Dinkins might express his outrage ''differently,'' he is ''constantly appearing, speaking after every tragedy, as I do.''
Dinkins administration officials said today that they were gratified by Mr. Cuomo's desire to help, but said his remarks did not seem to advance the debate very far.
''There's no doubt that the Mayor plans to increase the size of the police force,'' the First Deputy Mayor, Norman Steisel, said. ''But we have said all along that the question is, how do you pay for it?''
At today's news conference, the Governor refused to address that question directly. Last year, Mr. Cuomo said he would support an anticrime ''superfund'' to be financed through a surcharge on New York City income taxes. The Governor said today that he would still support such a plan, but noted that the Dinkins administration has already imposed an income-tax surcharge just to cover existing programs.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Attacks U.S. Priorities

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 10

 BODY:
Mr. Cuomo contended that the Bush and Reagan Administrations had forced state and local governments to raise taxes by slashing Federal aid to programs aimed at attacking national social problems, like drugs, education and homelessness.
''That creates a tension between the needs of states to raise revenues for unmet problems and the need to create congenial tax policies in order to attract and hold increasingly mobile business,'' he said. 
''States are pitted against each other in a kind of destructive competition, but that is precisely what we sought to move away from 200 years ago when we tore up the Articles of Confederation.''
Instead of the ''new federalism'' that has guided the Republicans, Mr. Cuomo proposed a ''progressive federalism'' that would recognize national responsibility for national problems.
As he has since early summer, when he introduced the theme in a speech at the New York State Democratic Convention, Mr. Cuomo used the Federal savings and loan bailout as evidence of misplaced Republican priorities.
''We know it is not the wallet that Washington lacks,'' he said. ''It's the will. It's the value judgment that is significant here.''
As of mid-July, when Mr. Cuomo last had to file a campaign financial report, the Governor had raised almost $8 million for his re-election war chest. His Republican opponent, Pierre A. Rinfret, a New York City economist, had raised $869,000.

HEADLINE: Though Views Differ on Progress, Budget Talks Are Called on Track

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
In comments today, the Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady, said he was ''not very optimistic'' about reaching an accord and expressed disappointment at the pace of the talks. ''I would say that the talks are going nowhere fast,'' he said in an interview on the ABC News program ''Good Morning America.''
 
'Can't Get Its Act Together'
But the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, who spent about an hour this morning at the base in consultations with his Democratic colleagues, took issue with Mr. Brady's assessment. ''The suggestion that Congress can't get its act together is inappropriate and wrong,'' Mr. Foley told reporters, adding that it was the ''beginning of blame assessment,'' which would not be helpful. 
Mr. Foley conceded that progress had not been as rapid as he had hoped, but he said he was confident that a deal would be reached before the end of the month and perhaps by the end of this week.
In initial bargaining, Democrats proposed a $14 billion cut in military spending and a cut of about half that amount in programs like Medicare and farm subsidies that involve automatic benefits. Republicans have been seeking deeper cuts in the benefits programs and a smaller cut in military spending.
 
Views on Capital Gains Issue
Democrats and Republicans have agreed in principle that $25 billion of the deficit reduction would come from increased revenue from higher taxes, but they remain at odds on the components of the tax package. Officials involved in the talks said the Bush Administration agreed over the weekend to accept estimates by Congressional tax and budget experts that the cut in the capital gains tax rate sought by President Bush would lose money over five years and that they would be willing to propose other revenue increases to offset the loss.
The Administration has argued that cutting the capital gains tax rate would generate revenue because investors would cash in their holdings to take advantage of the lower rate and because the reduction in the rate would stimulate economic activity.
Democrats argue that cutting the rate would benefit mainly the wealthiest taxpayers and that such a cut should be offset by increases in the income tax rate for upper-income Americans.

HEADLINE: In 10 State Primaries, Candidates Scurry Not to Look Like Politicians

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:

 
Primaries in 10 States
Ten states, in addition to Rhode Island, Minnesota and Arizona, will hold primary elections on Tuesday: Connecticut, Maryland, New Hampshire, New York, Utah, Vermont and Wisconsin. So does the District of Columbia, where Democrats will pick their nominees to succeed Marion S. Barry Jr., a three-term Mayor brought low by drug charges, as well as Representative Walter E. Fauntroy, a 19-year delegate to the House of Representatives, who is running for mayor.
In Minnesota, Mr. Perpich of the Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party, seemed headed for defeat early this year, but he has gone up in the polls as his opponent, Mike Hatch, the former commerce commissioner, called on negative political tactics, attacking him in television commercials. This is evidence, Mr. Strother said, that attacks, while still widespread, are backfiring more often than they did in the past. 
For his part, Mr. Perpich has not even tried to make promises to the voters, Mr. Strother said, for fear they would not be believed. Instead he has gone on television and read from out-of-state magazines that said Minnesota, where he has been Governor for 10 years, was a good place to live and work.
In the closing days, Mr. Hatch has focused on his support for legal abortion, which Mr. Perpich opposes. If Mr. Perpich survives the primary, he will be one of five opponents of abortion around the country running as the Democratic nominee for governor against a Republican who supports abortion rights, an illustration of how complex the issue's political impact has become.
In Rhode Island, a businessman, Bruce Sundlun, has been making progress in his campaign for the Democratic nomination for governor on the theme of ''I am not a politician.'' But newspapers reported today that he had been raising money in a very political way, with hints of favors to come after the election.
One opponent, Mayor Joseph Paolino of Providence, who was dropping in the polls as he attacked Mr. Sundlun, an old political ally, went on television to say he was eschewing any more negative campaigning.
''Together, we can take a stand against the old-style negative politics,'' Mr. Paolino said tonight in a television advertisement produced by his media consultants, Doak & Shrum, who have lost races in Texas, California, Florida and Alabama this year after their candidates engaged in heavily negative campaigns.
The third Democrat running for governor in Rhode Island, Mayor Frank Flaherty of Warwick, was the first to campaign against the tone of the campaign. ''It's getting embarrassing,'' he said last week.
Attacks can still be effective, and are surely still commonplace, politicians report. But they are more dangerous than they once were, if they make the attacker look like an old-fashioned politician, which is just about the worst attack than can be made on a candidate this year.
 
Governor Looks Vulnerable
The Democrats in Rhode Island are battling fiercely for the Democratic nomination because it would give them the right to face Governor Edward D. DiPrete, who has been badly wounded by ethics conflicts and the sagging New England economy. Campaigning in 1988 for another two-year term, Mr. DiPrete promised not to raise taxes but then was forced to raise the sales tax. Mr. DiPrete, first elected in 1984 after Democrats wounded each other in a divisive primary, is expected to win his primary against a former radio host, Steve White. Even with the damage they have inflicted on each other, all three of the Democrats are currently ahead of Mr. DiPrete in polls. But the Governor has said he is sure he can come back.
The public distaste for politics is also illustrated in both the governor's race in Connecticut and the House race in Vermont. Tuesday primaries in both states are largely overshadowed by the fact that independent candidates, Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the former Republican Senator, for governor in Connecticut, and Bernie Sanders, a Socialist, for Congress in Vermont, will be on the ballot in the fall and are given a serious chance of winning against party nominees chosen Tuesday.
In Arizona, former Gov. Evan Mecham, who was impeached and convicted in 1988, is attempting a comeback in Tuesday's Republican primary for governor, saying he is the only candidate who can stand up to ''the powerbrokers'' and ''the Phoenix 40,'' a business group.
The front-runner for the Republican nomination, J. Fife Symington, a millionaire developer, said he would support any of his four Republican opponents in the general election except Mr. Mecham, who he said needed, ''a poke in the nose.''
The Republican nominee will face Terry Goddard, who resigned as mayor of Pheonix, after saying he would not, to run for governor. Mr. Goddard's father, Samuel P. Goddard, is chairman of the Arizona Democratic Party and was once governor.
The incumbent, Rose Mofford, a Democrat who succeded Mr. Mecham, is retiring.
 
Trouble in Maryland
A number of House members have had close brushes with defeat in primaries this year as the mood against politicians dilutes their advantages in fund-raising and access to constituents.
Another is in trouble Tuesday in Maryland. Representative Roy Dyson, a Democrat whose district includes Southern Maryland and the Eastern Shore, faces a strong challenge from a state legislator, Barbara Kreamer.
Mr. Dyson has been in political trouble since an aide, Tom Pappas, committed suicide under mysterious circumstances in 1988. Mr. Dyson's situation further deteriorated when it was disclosed that he was a conscientious objector during the Vietnam War - a position his opponents say they cannot square with his pro-military stands on the Armed Services Committee and the substantial campaign contributions he has received from military contractors.
In New Hampshire there is a spirited Democratic primary to face Gov. Judd Gregg in the fall. Joe Grandmaison, a former state Democratic Party chairman, is the front-runner in that race but faces two opponents Tuesday.
In Utah there are two Republican races for Congressional nominations, one for the seat held by Representative Wayne Owens, a Democrat who is a two-term incumbent.
In Vermont, Gov. Madeleine M. Kunin, a Democrat, is not seeking re-election. Richard A. Snelling, a Republican who was Governor from 1977 to 1985, and Peter Welch, a former State Senator, face only token opposition in the primaries.
In Wisconsin, Gov. Tommy G. Thompson, a Republican, is expected to win renomination. and Congressional primaries have been quiet.

HEADLINE: Dukakis Antagonist Abandons Primary Race

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Mr. Dukakis's popular support has vanished since the state's economic condition became clear in the aftermath of his loss to George Bush in the 1988 Presidential election. Ms. Murphy, like Mr. Dukakis, is a liberal, and they share many supporters, the aide pointed out.
The aide said Ms. Murphy's challenge to the Governor, which forced him to delay his European trip, only further tarnished the image of the state's Democrats, who have already been badly hurt by the prolonged fiscal mess, and enhanced the chance that the small Republican Party here could win the governor's office for the first time since 1970.
Ms. Murphy said today that she would support Francis X. Bellotti, a former state Attorney General, who is leading in the polls for the Sept. 18 primary. Mr. Bellotti ''comes closest to the values that are important to me,'' Ms. Murphy said, particularly on the issue of women having a right to choose abortion. 
 
Silber Raises Anger
Ms. Murphy did not indicate whether she would campaign for Mr. Bellotti, a 67-year-old veteran politician. Many of Ms. Murphy's liberal backers have already been deserting her for Mr. Bellotti in hopes of stopping the third candidate, John R. Silber, the president of Boston University.
Ms. Murphy's action therefore appeared likely to deal a further blow to Mr. Silber, a political maverick whose public standing has been slipping in the past few weeks after he made barbed comments that have alienated many voters. In one debate, for instance, Mr. Silber seemed to suggest rationing health care for the elderly when he said, ''When you've had a long life and you're ripe, it's time to go.''
But Mr. Silber said he welcomed Ms. Murphy's withdrawal. ''It's a new race in which voters will have a clear choice between the politics of the past, as represented by Frank Bellotti, and the fundamental changes in government that I have proposed,'' he said.
 
Facing Up to Reality
In explaining Ms. Murphy's public rebellion last week, Mark Longabaugh, her campaign manager, said today: ''She knew that her candidacy was a long shot. And she knew it would have repercussions on her campaign.'' But he added, ''she had some ideas she needed to put on the table.''
Then over the weekend, when her own polls showed that Ms. Murphy was still trailing badly in the three-way race, she decided to drop out, said Michael Goldman, a consultant to her campaign. ''It was an effort to come to grips with reality,'' he said.
Mr. Dukakis, speaking from Paris, said: ''I know something about disappointment in politics. Evelyn Murphy ran a strong and progressive campaign, and she put her heart into it.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Probing School Success Of Asian-Americans

BYLINE: By DANIEL GOLEMAN

 BODY:
Part of that success, the new research suggests, is explained by the fact that Asian-American students, far more than members of other minorities, see earning advanced degrees as the only sure-fire way to overcome discrimination. That perception operates hand in hand with strong family bonds to make Asian-American students work harder at their studies, doing almost 50 percent more homework than their peers from grammar school on.
Beyond that intense effort, Asian-American students come from families and communities that have been less devastated by racism than those of other minority students, and so have more economic and emotional resources to draw on for their education. There is also a hidden advantage for some Asian-American students who have performed the best: in many cases their immigrant parents were professionals in their native countries and instill in their children a striving for the status they lost on leaving their homeland.
Of course, no single answer applies to every student. There are many Asian groups in America, ranging from impoverished Vietnamese boat people to prosperous fifth-generation Chinese-Americans. Even so, the overwhelming success of Asian-Americans has intrigued researchers who hope to find clues that can help other minorities do better in school. 
Although researchers differ on other points, there is a strong consensus that protecting themselves from discrimination is a compelling motive for many Asian-Americans in seeking academic success.
 
Prejudice as Motivation
While there have been no studies showing a causal link between fear of prejudice and academic success, reseachers report that in interviews Asian-Americans repeatedly cite the fear as a reason for increased academic effort. In some cases, researchers who are themselves Asian-American testify to the link from their own experience.
For example, Stanley Sue, a psychologist at the University of California at Los Angeles, recalls that his father was denied membership in the union at a shipyard where he worked because he was Chinese.
Dr. Sue said that experience led him to conclude that he would have to do well in school to overcome such discrimination. Although neither his mother nor his father had more than a high school education, he and his three brothers all went on to earn Ph.D.'s.
Dr. Sue argues that the impressive academic success of Asian-Americans is largely a result of their strong belief in education as an escape route from the social and economic limits imposed by prejudice - a belief they hold more strongly than do other minorities.
In a study of more than 10,000 high school students, Sanford Dornbusch, a sociologist at Stanford, found that Asian-American students far more than any other group believed that ''if you do not do well in school, you are doomed to a poor job.''
Many social scientists point to centuries of a mandarin tradition, in which Asian cultures, particularly China, had an intellectual elite that rose to power through passing stringent tests. They suggest that this model of a meritocracy of the intellect has left its mark in the high value Asians place on education.
One sign that Asian-American academic effort is propelled in large part by the need to overcome discrimination is that their academic achievement tends to drop over the generations, Dr. Sue said. Dr. Dornbusch, with Phillip Ritter, found that first-generation Asian-Americans had grade point averages of 3.2 on a scale of 4.0, while for the third generation it had slipped to 3.0. The more Americanized Asian-Americans have become, Dr. Sue said, the less they worry about being denied access to good jobs because of their ethnicity.
Several theories seek to explain why other minorities, unlike Asian-Americans, fail to gravitate to higher education. Leonard Gordon a sociologist at Arizona State University, looks to history to explain the difference he found between Asian-Americans and other minorities in studies of close to 600 students. While black and Hispanic students had the same life goals as did Asian-Americans, there was a great difference in their expectations. ''They didn't have the same hope of success as did Asian-American students,'' Dr. Gordon said. ''Their history leads them to be pessimistic about reaching their goals.''
That attitude marks one of the strongest differences in outlook between Asian-American students as compared with blacks, Hispanic Americans and native Americans, said John Ogbu, an anthropologist at the University of California at Berkeley, who is leading a study of school achievement by minority students in San Francisco.
Most Asian-Americans are voluntary immigrants, drawn here in part by the dream of success, he said in an article in the current issue of Daedalus. Such immigrants see cultural differences as something to overcome, while involuntary groups tend to cherish differences. That leaves many members of those groups unwilling to fit into patterns that undermine their group identity, he said.
Some education researchers see a secret of Asian-American academic success in how parents coax children to work harder at school.
For example, Shinying Lee, a psychologist at the University of Michigan who came to America as a graduate student, said she gave her 6-year-old extra work after school. ''I have him practice Chinese by writing two sentences every day, and then I have him do a few math problems,'' Dr. Lee said. ''Most other Chinese parents I know do the same.''
In studies of grammar school children in Chicago schools, Dr. Lee, working with a colleague, Harold Stevenson, found that there was virtually no difference between Asian-Americans and other students in intelligence or achievement.
''We studied first-graders in Chicago schools,'' Dr. Lee said. ''There is virtually no difference between Asian-Americans and other groups on achievement tests in first grade.''
 
Working Harder
''That rules out a difference in I.Q.,'' Dr. Lee said. ''But by fifth grade, Asian-Americans had much higher math achievement scores.'' The most obvious reason for that difference, which emerges in grade school and grows steadily, is that like Dr. Lee's 6-year-old, they work harder than other students.
In studies of 7,836 high school students in the San Francisco area, Asian-Americans spent about 40 percent more time doing homework than did other students - about seven hours a week versus five. ''That is the first and most important reason for the differences: Asian-Americans work harder,'' said Dr. Dornbusch, who did the studies.
There is also a fundamental difference between most Asian American parents and other parents in how they react to a child's poor performance. ''Most American parents are willing to accept a child's weak areas and emphasize the strengths,'' said Dr. Dornbusch, who has done dozens of studies on academic achievement among Asian and other minority groups. ''But for Asians, the attitude is that if you're not doing well, the answer is to study later at night, and if you still don't do well, to get up and study earlier in the morning. They believe that anyone can do well in school with the right effort.''
Behind the harder work, said Dr. Dornbusch, lies another basic difference between Asian-American and other students. ''They are oriented toward their families, not just their friends,'' he said. Interviews he conducted in his studies lead him to conclude, he said, that ''Asian kids tend to think of themselves as representing their family and see their task as doing well in school, not just for themselves, but for their families as a whole.''
A hidden factor in the academic success of Asian-American students is that a large number are themselves children of professionals, said Ronald Takaki, a professor of ethnic studies at the University of California at Berkeley. ''There is an important class difference between Asian and black or Hispanic students,'' he said. ''Those Asian-Americans who seem to be super whiz kids are mostly from professional families.''
While many black and Hispanic parents feel that education would help their children evade the pain of racism, they often do not have the same family resources available. ''Over 50 percent of black kids are from impoverished single-parent families,'' Dr. Takaki said. ''They don't have an intact family with highly educated parents, like many Asian-American students.'' Black students who come from such families perform above average academically, Dr. Gordon has found.
In many cases the parents of Asian-American students are immigrants who were not able to find jobs in America in the professions for which they trained in Asia. Such parents feel ''a tremendous psychological need to recover their lost class status,'' said Dr. Takaki. ''The way for them to do that is to be sure their children get high-status degrees.''

HEADLINE: Wrong Once, Expert Keep Quiet On Volcanic Activity in California

BYLINE: By SANDRA BLAKESLEE

DATELINE: MAMMOTH LAKES, Calif.

 BODY:
Local businessmen are still angry at geologists for issuing the earlier warning and say they would rather take their chances with a restless volcano than yield to fears that harm the economy.
This widespread attitude is now haunting state and local disaster officials who, working closely with Federal geologists, are trying to develop a new warning system for volcanic hazards in the area. The system that twice led to public warnings about volcanic activity in the early 1980's was dropped in 1983.
 
Fear of Crying Wolf
''We have not been able to decide when to alert the public,'' said Dr. Richard Andrews, chief deputy director in charge of the earthquake and volcano program at the California Office of Emergency Services. Frequent warnings about the sort volcanic activity that is happening now, he said, can scare away tourists. But if geologists felt that an eruption were imminent, he said, the public would have to be told of the danger and evacuated. 
''It's going to be a very hard call,'' said Dr. Andrews. ''We don't want to cry wolf.''
Mammoth Lakes is a four-square mile resort village with 5,500 year-round residents, well known for its nearby ski slopes, hiking and biking trails, ice-cold lakes, hot springs and extraordinary geologic features. Among them is the Long Valley caldera, the oval mouth of a collapsed volcano that is 19 miles long by 9 miles wide at the foot of the mountains rising behind the village.
Today the caldera is covered with fragrant grasses, grazing cows and a geothermal power plant. But 700,000 years ago, it was a young volcano that produced one of the largest volcanic eruptions in Earth's history.
Pieces of the volcano landed in Missouri, and its ash traveled to New York and beyond, said Dr. Hill. While the famous Indonesian volcano of Krakatoa ejected 48 cubic miles of molten material in 1883, the Long Valley volcano tossed up 360 cubic miles of material.
It is this caldera, or giant volcanic crater, that is now showing renewed signs of life. Volcanic activity has persisted in the area for hundreds of thousands of years, said Dr. Hill, but this is the first time modern geologists have been around to watch events unfold.
 
A Devastating Alert
Things began popping in 1980 with four earthquakes that measured 6 on the Richter scale, said Dr. Hill. Startled geologists discovered that the lava dome thought to underlie the caldera had risen by 10 inches between late 1979 and early 1980. Swarms of small earthquakes continued through 1982 as the dome rose several more inches.
On May 27, 1982, Federal geologists issued a notice of potential volcanic hazard, the lowest alert level in the system then used. The notice was issued on a Friday afternoon before a local weekend festival, said Dr. Andrews, and it had an immediate impact: tourists stayed home.
The local economy collapsed, said Glenn Thompson, Mammoth Lakes' town manager. Housing prices fell 40 percent overnight. In the next few years, dozens of businesses closed, new shopping centers stood empty and townspeople left to seek jobs elsewhere. Public anxiety was kept high in early 1983 by two magnitude 5 earthquakes, a continuing swarm of smaller earthquakes and new measurements showing the dome had risen another three inches. Federal geologists considered issuing a volcano watch, its second and more serious alert level telling people to prepare for disaster, but held off to see what would happen. The third level, a volcano warning, would have meant an eruption was thought to be imminent.
But after mid-1983, nothing happened. Tourists, home buyers and new businesses did not regain confidence in the town until 1986, said Mr. Thompson. The economy has been recovering steadily since then.
So when the caldera began showing new signs of life in spring of 1989, businessmen were shaken and geologists were circumspect. Scientists recorded thousands of small earthquakes throughout last summer and found that the dome had lifted another three inches. After a period of quiet, the small earthquakes - often hundreds a day - began again in December and have continued, off and on, through the present.
 
No Official Notice
The dome has probably lifted another two inches, said Dr. Hill. ''It means the magma is moving again,'' he said. Aside from a few articles in the local newspaper and one town meeting a year ago, said Dr. Hill, geologists have not said much to the public about the current activity. There has been no official notice of volcanic activity.
There are good reasons to stay quiet for now, said Dr. Hill. In 1983, geologists had few scientific instruments in the Long Valley region. Today they have at least 40 seismic stations and a network of other instruments that are providing a wealth of data on the caldera's behavior.
The emerging picture, said Dr. Hill, is potentially menacing but not in the near future. Under the caldera are several magma chambers capable of generating relatively serious volcanic eruptions, he said, but not on the scale of 700,000 years ago. Researchers estimate that the caldera would have to rise another one and a half to three feet before the overlying rock might give way to the pressures below.
Geologists say they are encouraged in their decision to not warn the public - at least not yet - because of the way two other active calderas have behaved in recent years. A caldera near Naples, Italy rose by nine feet in two bursts of activity over the last decade and did not erupt, said Dr. Hill. Similarly, a caldera in Papua New Guinea rose by more than six feet in the early 1980's, and nothing further happened.
The Long Valley caldera may be doing what it has normally been doing for thousands of years, said Verne McLean, a geologist with the National Forest Service in the nearby town of Bishop. It might roil around underground for some time, he said, ''or produce small volcanic eruptions that squeeze out magma like toothpaste.'' Or, he acknowledged, it could blow up, causing widespread damage and loss of life.
 
Signs of Violent Eruption
Fortunately, scientists think they will get strong warnings in the days or weeks before a violent eruption would occur. These include major earthquakes accompanied by ground tilting, changes in magnetic fields, earth tremors that exhibit harmonic frequencies and other signs indicating that the magma is headed for the surface.
In the meantime, geolgists and state and local offiicals have been working out a new warning system for the public. Instead of three levels, the proposed system has five alert levels, based on the intensity of geologic events and specific combinations of events. For example, swarms of small earthquakes might elicit a low level of alert. But the swarms accompanied by rapid tilting of the ground or venting of steam could elicit a higher alert level.
The first three or four levels would not be made public, Dr. Andrews said. The information would be used by geologists and disaster officials for ''internal readiness,'' he said. In to the chain of responsibility, geologists alert state officials who then decide when to alert local sheriffs.
Martin Strellnick, the Mono county sheriff whose district includes Long Valley, said he does not know when the public will be told about volcanic threats. ''If it gets to the hazard stage, the public has a right to know,'' he said. ''But who has the expertise to say a volcano will or will not do something? It's a scientific guessing game.''

HEADLINE: Cities Begin Taking Action on Environment

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF; Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 7

 BODY:
With a loan from the Interamerican Development Bank, Mayor Camacho reported, Mexico will be able to reduce its foreign debt by $150 million and use the money to plant trees on some 150,000 acres of now barren Federal lands around the city.
In an interview, Mayor Camacho said that not only would the project protect water quality, guard against soil erosion and provide recreation areas around Mexico City, the use of carbon dioxide by the trees would also help reduce the threat of global warming.
Carbon dioxide and other industrial gasses accumulating in the atmosphere are absorbing radiation from the sun and will cause the Earth's surface to warm by three to eight degrees Fahrenheit by the middle of the next century, many scientists now agree. 
Mayor Art Eggleton of Toronto described the measures his city was taking to reduce its carbon dioxide emissions by 20 percent by the year 2005. Its plan calls for expanding mass transportation, creating bicycle lanes for commuting, requiring more efficient lighting and new standards for energy conservation in houses, planting trees on a large scale and a variety of other measures. Toronto is believed to be the first large city in the world to initiate its own program for addressing the global warming threat.
Dr. James Hansen, the director of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Goddard Institute for Science, a pioneer in preparing projections of global warming and in calling the dangers to the attention of the public and policy makers, presented computer predictions of the effect of global warming on some cities around the world. In the past, such models had been available only for a sample of cities in the United States.
When carbon dioxide or its equivalent in other greenhouse gases reached a level double that of the pre-industrial era, Dr. Hansen projected greatly extended periods of very high temperatures. For example, Rio de Janeiro, which now averages five days a year of temperatures over 95 degrees Fahrenheit, would have 52 days a year of such high temperatures; Singapore would go from zero days over 95 to 124; Rome from six to 55, and Tokyo from five to 41.
Dr. Hansen emphasized that those projections were based on current trends but could be altered by lowering emissions of greenhouse gases.
The meeting was sponsored by the United Nations Environmental Program, the International Union of Local Authorities and the Center for Innovative Diplomacy.

HEADLINE: Another Toyota Plant in U.S.; Location Will Be Set Later

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 10

 BODY:
So far, no Japanese auto maker has built an assembly plant in a state that already has a Japanese plant, which has allowed those companies to build fairly broad political support where they have invested. Analysts have reported that Kansas might be Toyota's first choice, partly because no Japanese auto maker has built an assembly plant in that state.
Toyota's disclosure, first reported in The Wall Street Journal, was not surprising in light of Toyota's often-stated goal of selling 1.5 million cars and trucks in this country by the mid-1990's, half of which would be assembled here. If Toyota achieves that number, it will have captured approximately 10 percent of the nation's car market; for a number of years the company, Japan's No. 1 car maker, has had an internal corporate campaign, called ''Global 10,'' aimed at capturing 10 percent of the world market. 
While it was not announced which vehicles would be produced at the new plant, it is likely to be either the compact Camry or subcompact Corolla, two cars for which Toyota says it cannot meet customer demand.
In the last year Toyota has increased its overall United States vehicle sales by 17.1 percent, at a time when Detroit's Big Three have attributed their sales declines to a soft market. Toyota's share of the domestic market grew to 7.6 percent through the end of August, from 6.2 percent in the first eight months of 1989. Both the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation have lost market share, while the General Motors Corporation's share has risen slightly after years of decline.
Toyota now also operates an assembly plant in Canada and a joint venture with G.M. in Fremont, Calif., where it will begin producing compact pickup trucks next year.
 
'Transplants' Bolster Sales
Of the Japanese auto makers, Toyota has made the biggest inroads into the U.S. market, followed closely by the Honda Motor Company. As a group, the sales of Japanese auto makers have surged strongly in the last year, largely as a result of increased production by the ''transplant'' operations that build cars in the United States. Domestic auto makers and European importers are thus feeling tremendous pressure, particularly since the overall market is soft.
The transplants have an advantage over plants owned by American companies because their work forces are generally younger and healthier, which keeps health-care costs down. Pension expenses are also lower.
 
Gains Seen for Lexus
ATLANTA, Sept. 10 (Reuters) -The Toyota Motor Corporation expects higher sales for its Lexus luxury cars despite the uncertain outlook for the automotive market and the economy in general, the division's top official said today.
Davis Illingworth, Toyota's vice president in charge of the Lexus division, said more buyers than expected had switched to Lexus from Mercedes-Benz and BMW. After a meeting with dealers from the Southeast, he said the company was on track to meet its goal of shipping 60,000 of the imported cars this year.
Despite a ''difficult, uncertain'' American market, almost 40,000 Lexus cars had been sold through August, the executive said. The cars cost up to $40,000 each.
''If we do 60,000 this year, clearly we believe we'll do better than that next year,'' he added.

HEADLINE: Consumer Credit Rose 7.4% in July

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
The July advance was the largest since a 7.8 percent jump in November and approximated the $4.42 billion monthly average of 1988 and 1989.
 
'Two Explanations'
The Fed said consumer credit growth slowed to an average of $1.78 billion a month during the first seven months of 1990.
''There are two explanations'' for the sharp increase, said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist for the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. ''One is that it simply is a statistical aberration'' and that it will decline in coming months to $1 billion to $2 billion a month. 
''The other, more important possibility,'' he said, ''is that consumers are getting pinched right now. Prices were going up in general even before the oil crisis. Wages were not keeping up with prices, so consumers were relying more and more on revolving credit.''
The rise in credit in July came before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the sharp rise in oil prices that followed. In addition, since July the two major consumer confidence surveys have dropped sharply, showing that Amercans are more worried now about the possibility of a recession. Both these developments could mean that the next credit report will show the pattern moving back to the decline for the year that the annual numbers showed today.
In August, the University of Michigan index of consumer confidence dropped 11.8 points, to 76.4, its lowest level since the 1982 recession. The separate survey done by the Conference Board showed a decline to 83.8 in August, down from 101.7 in July. All the declines early this year had been much smaller.
Big declines in consumer confidence have helped push the economy into recession in the past, as people, even if they have the income, stop buying. Such a pullback by consumers would reduce the buying or revolving credit, which was the main reason for the July increase in consumer credit.
Nearly 75 percent of the July gain was in revolving, or credit card, debt. It was up 21.7 percent at a annual rate, or $3.77 billion, after rising 7 percent in June. Such debt had increased 18.8 percent in May.
The sluggish automobile sector, on the other hand, declined 2.2 percent, or $534 million, on top of a 7.3 percent drop a month earlier. It was unchanged in May.
Bank and credit union loans not secured by real estate rose 7 percent, or $1.20 billion, after gains of 4.4 percent in June and 2.1 percent in May.
Borrowing for mobile homes edged up 1.7 percent, or $33 million, after falling 4.3 percent in June. It had risen 6 percent in May.
The various changes left total consumer debt at the end of July at $729.1 billion.

LENGTH: 1331 words

HEADLINE: G.M. in New Moves To Halt Slide of Olds

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 10

 BODY:

 
Division Needs a 'Rationale'
G.M. executives say such a consolidation is not in the cards. They say that while there is some overlap between Oldsmobile and other G.M. brands, more cars can be sold with Oldsmobile than without it.
Ronald Glantz, automotive analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds in San Francisco, says he thinks Olds can be turned around and can survive on its own. ''I don't think it costs a lot to have separate divisions,'' he said, ''but each division has to have a rationale. Therefore, Mr. Losh must work to differentiate Oldsmobiles from other G.M. cars.'' 
G.M. executives hope that by emphasizing contemporary styling and new technology, Oldsmobile can be distinguished from the sporty racing image of Pontiac, the more traditional theme of Buick, the higher-priced exclusivity of Cadillac and the economy approach of Chevrolet.
Oldsmobile's 1991 line, which officially goes on sale this month, features some improvements but no new cars. In the absence of new cars, Mr. Losh is making at least three significant changes.
He is starting an unusual warranty program to cover used cars, which could help dealers sell more used cars and fetch higher prices. On another front, Olds last week introduced a sport-utility vehicle called the Bravada, a luxury version of the Chevy Blazer, to tap into the trend of using trucks as personal transportation.
Finally, Mr. Losh is renewing efforts to redefine a brand that in recent years has lost its identity. Shelving the ad campaign that boasted, ''This Is Not Your Father's Oldsmobile,'' Olds is introducing a campaign aimed at younger, better-educated and more affluent consumers, emphasizing advanced technology and contemporary styling.
Oldsmobile was once a hugely successful franchise, positioned midway between the budget-minded Chevrolet and the luxurious Cadillac. The strategy was developed in the 1920's by Alfred Sloan, who was then G.M. chairman.
Over the years, Olds became known as the technology leader of the G.M. divisions, and was the first to install front-wheel drive, in its first Toronado model in the late 1960's. For many years the division distinguished itself by applying the Rocket 88 name to its engines, with the attendant implication of power and space-age technology. By the early 1980's, however, consumers became aware that all G.M. engines had become basically the same.
The new Olds mission, Mr. Losh explained, is to attract customers interested in new technology and cleaner, modern styling. Mr. Losh declined to predict next year's results, citing economic uncertainty, but he vowed to increase the division's share of sales of domestically made cars to 6 percent, from 5.5 percent. In 1983, Olds's share was 10.9 percent.
G.M.'s other divisions have also attempted to sharpen their marketing focus, and with more success. Buick, once as sick as Oldsmobile, has increased its market share this year by concentrating on a more ''mature and traditional'' audience, emphasizing comfort. Buick's restyled Park Avenue, for example, borrows design flourishes from Jaguar.
Cadillac, too, has increased its share of the luxury-car segment. Pontiac, which had been G.M.'s biggest success story of the 1980's, has managed to hold, though not increase, its share. Chevrolet has attracted more younger, budget-conscious buyers through its Geo sub-franchise. All told, G.M. has increased its share of the American car market slightly in 1990 after losing 10 points in the 1980's.
Oldsmobile's main problem has been the defection of younger buyers, many of whom have moved to trucks, mini-vans and sport-utility vehicles. In 1984, the average age of all buyers was 44, while the average for Oldsmobile was 49; by 1989, the average at Oldsmobile had risen to 55 while the industry average remained the same.
Because Olds cars were selling so poorly, G.M. last year let the division sell a mini-van developed for Chevrolet. In the same vein, Olds last week introduced the Bravada. But because of production constraints, the Bravada and the Silhouette mini-van can theoretically restore less than 100,000 sales.
Beyond adding trucks to its lineup, Oldsmobile has restyled its once-popular full-size station wagon, the Custom Cruiser, for the first time in 13 years. The top-of-the-line 98 and Toronado models will get more powerful engines, and the Cutlass Supreme will receive a new multi-valve V-6 engine.
Olds has also been trying to curry favor with customers. The division agreed last year to replace any new car within 30 days with a comparable model if a customer was not satisfied. Mr. Losh said that about 1.2 percent of new cars were returned, but that dealers told him the offer led to about 20,000 additional sales.
 
Dealers Have Suffered
Oldsmobile's replacement offer bespeaks a recognition that poor quality had driven away many customers. ''We went through hell in 1987 and 1988,'' said Dick Smith, owner of Royal Oldsmobile in Charleston, W. Va. ''No one at G.M. would listen to us.'' Although G.M.'s warranty covers repairs of defective cars, the warranty's $100 deductible alienated many of his customers, Mr. Smith said.
Aside from hurting G.M., the sharply lower sales have been disastrous for the division's 3,150 franchised dealers. To compensate, some have added Japanese franchises; others have sold their businesses or closed. Mr. Losh said fewer than half of Olds dealers were profitable in 1989; that proportion increased to 70 percent this year, but he said he could not feel comfortable until at least 90 percent were profitable.
Analysts agree that the Olds managers grew complacent in the early 1980's, presuming that the venerable Cutlass nameplate would sell any vehicle they produced. In 1977, for example, about 555,000 Cutlass Supremes were sold - more than the entire division's sales this year. The Cutlass name is still used on the midsized Supreme, midsized Ciera and compact Calais, accounting for 67 percent of all Olds sales.
 
Acclaimed Ads Canceled
G.M. executives concede that the division's marketing image had grown blurry. One of Mr. Losh's first moves was to kill a series of advertisements by Leo Burnett, G.M.'s longtime agency, entitled ''This Is Not Your Father's Oldsmobile.'' The campaign had received much favorable comment within the ad industry and had scored highly in terms of consumer recall.
''It got a lot of attention, but those ads talked about what we weren't, not what we were,'' Mr. Losh said. The division's theme, he said, is ''smart, contemporary vehicles that are one step ahead in design, value and total satisfaction.''
The ads' main theme will remain ''The New Generation of Olds,'' and will emphasize technological improvements like a holographic display on one version of the Cutlass Supreme that allows drivers to see the gauges without looking away from the road, and, on the top-of-the-line 98, a computer-command ride that allows the driver to adjust the suspension between normal and firm settings. They also emphasize a smooth and rounded styling from which hood ornaments are absent.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Fall in Slow Day

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
''I don't think oil is the most germane issue at the moment,'' said James R. Capra, a senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Government Securities. ''The budget is the key to what the Fed will or won't do. And if we don't get a budget agreement in the next 24 hours, my feeling is they won't have one until the end of the month, when sequestration will push them into it.''
 
Some Expect an Accord
Although there appeared to be little reason for optimism, Mr. Capra and a few other market participants said that some sort of budget accord might emerge before tonight, when President Bush is scheduled to deliver a televised address on a number of topics, including the budget. 
If Congress is unable to come up with a budget compromise by Oct. 1, Gramm-Rudman legislation requires that some $100 billion in outlays be cut to meet the law's targets.
According to analysts, quick agreement on a deficit-reduction package might help to pursuade the Federal Reserve Board to move to ease short-term interest rates. Given the anemic state of the economy, a move by the Fed has been widely anticipated.
The central bank disappointed those who were looking for lower short-term rates again yesterday. Its open market operations did not provide any evidence that it had changed its stance on monetary policy, analysts said. Indeed, many said that time was growing short for the Fed to make a move, since the first of a series of bad reports on inflation is expected to be released at the end of the week.
''If the Fed is thinking of easing right now, their window of opportunity seems to be shrinking, because the market will get a very bad report on producer price inflation for August on Friday,'' said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides research and commentary on developments in the foreign exchange and credit markets.
''And if the Fed allows this window of opportunity to pass, I think it will bode ill for the economy,'' he added. ''There are no signs yet of a complete collapse, but if policy makers wait for those sorts of signals it will be too late.''
 
Oil Price Jump a Factor
Because of the big run-up in oil prices, economists are expecting that inflation moved sharply higher in August.
By late yesterday, the turnaround in oil prices had pushed the price of the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020, securities that are the most sensitive to changes in inflation expectations, down by 17/32, to an offered price of 97 26/32, to yield 8.96 percent. Late Friday the closely watched issue was offered at a price to yield 8.90 percent.
Among Treasury note issues, the 8 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 1/2, down 1/4 point, to yield 8.82 percent. Disappointment over the Fed's decision to leave monetary policy unchanged helped to push down the price of the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent two-year notes by 1/8 point, to 100 1/8, to yield 8.05 percent.
At the weekly Treasury bill auction, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.41 percent, up slightly from the average rate of 7.39 percent at last week's sale. Meanwhile, bids on six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 7.34 percent, down from an average rate of 7.36 percent a week ago.
Activity in the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate bonds and tax-exempt municipal securities was light, dealers said. Prices of most corporate bonds slipped by 3/8 point to 5/8 point, largely in sympathy with the decline in Treasury securities. Municipal bond traders said that prices of most widely quoted issues dipped by 1/4 point to 3/8 point.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Broad Gains But Eases Against the Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
A recovery on the Tokyo Stock Exchange has raised interest in Japanese investments, and traders who had put their money into currencies such as the British pound recently were now turning to the yen, said James T. McGroarty, a senior vice president with Greenwich Capital Markets Inc.
Investors also believed that interest rates in Britain, which have supported the pound, would begin to decline from their current high levels, Mr. McGroarty said. Such a development would make sterling a less attractive investment.
The dollar was higher against all major currencies except the yen yesterday, but ''it's more of an individual currency assessment rather than an overall dollar view,'' Mr. McGroarty said.
In New York, the dollar fell to 139.52 yen from late Friday's 140.10. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar fell to a closing 139.43 Japanese yen, from 140.25 Friday, and in London, it fell to 139.20 yen.
The pound fell sharply against the dollar, closing at $1.8580 in New York, compared with late Friday's $1.8930. In London earlier, sterling fell to $1.8565, from $1.8933 dollars late Friday.
Against the German currency, the dollar rose more than a pfennig, to 1.5820 marks, from 1.5680 on Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.3175 Swiss francs, up from 1.3055; 5.3005 French francs, up from 5.2530; 1,180.00 Italian lire, up from 1,170.50, and 1.16675 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16335.

LENGTH: 1027 words

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
Bush's Two Audiences

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
At times during his nationally televised speech to a joint session of Congress, the President seemed to be talking directly to the Iraqi leader, man to man, as when he declared bluntly, ''Saddam Hussein will fail.''
Mr. Bush appeared determined to demonstrate to the nation, the Iraqis and, indeed, the world that the passage of time would not erode American resolve.
 
Restating His Goals
He made it plain that he would not countenance the kind of process that the British weekly The Economist has described as the greatest danger to his strategy - a buildup of doubts and caveats at home through which ''slowly the turning-back of Iraq threatens to become a wobbling mirage that is redefined until it is unrecognizable before fading away.'' Fighting that tendency, he reiterated, without a shade of difference, the goals he set weeks ago. 
But there are other dangers, of course. The use of military force could strain the coalition with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev by which the President sets such great store. It could drive the moderate Arab states that now back the United States position into Saddam Hussein's arms. And it could extract a heavy political price at home if it did not have a clearly attainable goal and did not produce recognizable results in a reasonable time.
Another threat to solidarity on the home front is a rising feeling among average voters and among members of both parties on Capitol Hill that the United States is bearing much too great a share of the burden in the gulf.
 
Allies' Share of the Burden
In the House this afternoon, Representative Carroll Hubbard Jr., Democrat of Kentucky, and Representative Craig T. James, Republican of Florida, castigated Japan for what they described as Tokyo's inadequate financial contributions, and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany acknowledged publicly last weekend that he feared that the same sort of criticism would soon be directed at Bonn.
Responding to the President's speech on behalf of the Democrats, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, said Mr. Bush had the party's backing. But he called upon the Japanese and the Germans to ''respond to our potential sacrifice of lives with at least a financial sacrifice of their own.''
While attacking no one, Mr. Bush said pointedly that ''the response of most of our friends and allies'' to American appeals for burden-sharing ''has been good.'' He did not say ''all our friends and allies,'' and he added:
''We insist others do their share as well.''
Mr. Bush has done well in the past when he talked tough. His emulation of Clint Eastwood - ''Read my lips, no new taxes'' - was widely accounted one of the main factors in his sweeping electoral victory in November, 1988.
But he has backed off that pledge now, and some White House aides have expressed fears that in doing so, he has undercut the credibility of his future pledges. That may be another reason why he so doggedly went back tonight over all the promises he has made in his dozens of comments on the Middle East in recent weeks.
President Bush spoke on Capitol Hill, a setting for major speeches that he prefers to the Oval Office used so often and so effectively by Ronald Reagan, in a week marked by a confluence of events that he believes could go far toward defining his Presidency.
 
'New Partnership' With Moscow
He had just returned from a meeting in Helsinki with Mr. Gorbachev which, he said, may have laid the groundwork for ''a new partnership'' between Moscow and Washington, something stopping just short of an alliance and playing a key role in a new world order.
He had been told, just before traveling down Pennsylvania Avenue, that there suddenly seemed a better chance of agreement with the Democratic-controlled Congress in the protracted negotiations on the fiscal crisis.
His nominee for the Supreme Court, Judge David H. Souter of New Hampshire, is to begin testifying on Thursday before the Senate Judiciary Committee.
And the crisis in the gulf wears on, with Mr. Hussein wiggling and squirming to try to evade the trade boycott, offering free oil even to his ancient enemy Iran, manipulating the hostages and playing for time as tens of thousands of American troops sweat in the Saudi desert, wondering when their moment will come - the moment of battle or the moment to pack their gear and go home.
Only two months down the road loom the midterm elections, which could be heavily influenced by either the situation in the Middle East or by the budget negotiations. So Mr. Bush tried to sound statesmanlike, telling the legislators before him that ''Democrats, Republicans, liberals, conservatives can come together to fulfill our responsibilities here.'' But there was an obvious partisan edge to his demand for fast action on the budget.
''If the Congress cannot get me a budget,'' the President said, in what sounded a lot like attempted electoral point-scoring, ''then Americans will have to face a tough, mandated sequester'' - in other words, their fault, not mine, if you suffer.
