PUB-DATE: September 12, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1665 words

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
BUSH VOWS TO THWART IRAQ DESPITE FEAR FOR HOSTAGES; U.S. WON'T BE 'BLACKMAILED'

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
''Of course, our hearts go out to the hostages and their families,'' Mr. Bush said. His voice growing harder and his forefinger stabbing at the lectern, he added, ''But our policy cannot change. And it will not change. America and the world will not be blackmailed by this ruthless policy.''
President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, Mr. Bush said, ''is literally trying to wipe a country off the face of the earth.''
The speech seemed intended to leave no doubt in the mind of President Hussein that the United States would use force if necessary to push Iraqi forces out of Kuwait, and to prepare the American people for the possible loss of the lives of American soldiers and hostages if war broke out. 
 
Videotaped Talk to Iraqis
On Wednesday, Mr. Bush will try to take his message directly to the Iraqi people, videotaping a 10-minute address to offer to Iraq's national television network. But White House aides did not hold out great hope that the tape, which is to be hand-delivered to Iraqi representatives in the coming days, would be broadcast in Iraq in its entirety. The White House said it would not release the tape here or in other countries until Iraq had been given a chance to broadcast it.
The Democratic Party's response to Mr. Bush's speech, delivered by Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House Majority Leader, was strongly supportive at a time when public opinion appears to be solidly behind Mr. Bush and the gulf crisis seems to be going his way. Mr. Gephardt called opposition to Iraq ''a cause worth standing and fighting for.''
He called on other countries to provide more money for the effort. Mr. Gephardt said, ''When countries like Egypt can stand beside us, when young Americans stand on the front lines, only miles from the threat of poison gas, the least the Japanese and the Germans can do is support us - and not just with words.''
 
Iraqi Envoy in Chamber
The packed House chamber, which was filled with legislators, Cabinet members, the Joint Chiefs of Staff and foreign diplomats, gave Mr. Bush a 2 1/2-minute standing ovation as he entered the room. With the Iraqi Ambassador, Mohammed al-Mashat, virtually the only listener sitting impassively, the crowd punctuated the speech more than 30 times with applause.
But the loudest applause, and the few cheers that echoed in the chamber, were reserved for Mr. Bush's comments on the Federal budget deficit, particularly his call for a cut in the capital gains tax rate.
Addressing domestic concerns, Mr. Bush for the first time since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait offered a stern admonition that the United States had, through what he said was short-sighted policy, put itself in a vulnerable position by becoming overly dependent on Middle Eastern oil to fuel its economy.
 
Dependence on Imported Oil
Mr. Bush spoke of the country's ''failure'' to address its long-term energy needs. He said that by the time of the Iraqi invasion, the United States had increased its oil imports from 6 million barrels a day in the early 1970's to nearly 8 million barrels a day.
''We'd moved in the wrong direction,'' Mr. Bush said. ''And now we must act to correct that trend.''
To meet the challenge, Mr. Bush said, the United States must ''take advantage of our energy sources across the board: coal, natural gas, hydro and nuclear.''
Even as his comments seemed to embrace the energy policies of Jimmy Carter, they carried an implicit criticism of Ronald Reagan, as did a later passage in which Mr. Bush spoke of the Federal budget and said, ''America is tired of phony deficit reduction.'' Reaching for the all-encompassing principles behind his response to the immediate crisis in the Persian Gulf, Mr. Bush said the United States' leadership, its credibility as a superpower and its economic vitality are at stake.
 
'Test of Our Mettle'
He offered some hope, saying a ''new partnership of nations'' has been born in the midst of the threat of war on the Arabian Peninsula that could produce a world ''freer from the threat of terror, stronger in the pursuit of justice and more secure in the quest for peace.''
But the President warned, ''This is the first assault on the new world we seek, the first test of our mettle.''
''How we manage this crisis today,'' he said, ''could shape the future for generations to come.''
 
Iraq's Isolation Stressed
Throughout his speech, which the President and his aides refined virtually until the hour of his appearance in the House Chamber, Mr. Bush struck the central argument of his war of words with Mr. Hussein: that the United States is backed by the weight of world opinion and the support of even many of its former adversaries.
''This is not, as Saddam Hussein would have it, the United States against Iraq,'' he said. ''It is Iraq against the world.''
Mr. Bush's primary message was that while ''our brave servicemen and women stand watch in that distant desert and on distant seas,'' the United States is still counting on the worldwide economic embargo against Iraq as its primary weapon.
But the struggle, he said, will be a long one, and he made it clear that the United States is prepared to use its military muscle if there is no other choice.
 
'Review All Options'
''I cannot predict just how long it will take to convince Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait,'' Mr. Bush said. ''Sanctions will take time to have their full intended effect. We will continue to review all options with our allies, but let it be clear: We will not let this aggression stand.''
The President said the economic sanctions appear so far to be working. ''Together with our friends and allies, ships of the United States Navy are today patrolling Mideast waters,'' he said. ''They have already intercepted more than 700 ships to enforce the sanctions. Three regional leaders I spoke with just yesterday told me that these sanctions are working. Iraq is feeling the heat.''
Mr. Bush said he hopes ''that Iraq's leaders will recalculate just what their aggression has cost them. They are cut off from world trade, unable to sell their oil. And only a tiny fraction of goods gets through.''
 
Humanitarian Shipments
He tried to balance pressure to address humanitarian needs of civilians in Iraq with his efforts to hold together the disparate band of nations that are backing the embargo in the face of continued Iraq efforts.
He noted that he and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union had said in their meeting in Helsinki that they supported humanitarian shipments to Iraq, but he said that would occur only ''when the embargo is so effective that the children of Iraq literally need milk, or the sick truly need medicine.''
''Then,'' he said, ''under strict international supervision that guarantees the proper destination, then food will be permitted.''
Mr. Bush said the United States would have a ''lasting role'' in the Persian Gulf beyond the current crisis. Then, in what appeared to be a threat that whatever happens in Kuwait, Iraq will not be permitted to develop nuclear weapons, he said, ''Our role is to help our friends in their own self-defense. And something else: to curb the proliferation of chemical, biological, ballistic missile, and above all, nuclear technologies.''
Mr. Bush said that ''vital issues of principle'' were at stake in the Gulf crisis.
He said the economic stakes were high, arguing that if Mr. Hussein were allowed to remain in Kuwait, he could end up controlling much of the world's oil supply. ''We cannot permit a resource so vital to be dominated by one so ruthless,'' he said. ''And we won't.''
 
Test of U.S. Leadership
The President depicted the Persian Gulf crisis as a test of American leadership. He stressed the breadth of the alliance against Iraq, including United Nations Security Council resolutions condemning Iraq, imposing economic sanctions, demanding Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait and calling for the release of all foreign nationals held in Iraq and Kuwait.
''It is a mockery of human decency to call these people 'guests,' '' Mr. Bush said. ''They are hostages and the whole world knows it.''
Reflecting his struggle to fit the current threat of war into the larger context of a world in which East-West barriers have been falling and peace seemed more assured than ever in Europe, the President said, ''We stand today at a unique and extraordinary moment.''
 
New U.S.-Soviet Relationship
Because of the unparalleled Soviet- American cooperation so far in the Gulf crisis, Mr. Bush said, ''no longer can a dictator count on East-West confrontation to stymie concerted U.N. action against aggression.''
''The crisis in the Persian Gulf, as grave as it is also offers a rare opportunity to move toward an historic period of cooperation,'' Mr. Bush said.
He continued: ''A hundred generations have searched for his elusive path to peace, while a thousand wars raged across the span of human endeavor. Today that new world is struggling to be born: a world quite different from the one we've known, a world where the rule of law supplants the rule of the jungle. A world in which nations recognize the shared responsibility for freedom and justice. A world where the strong respect the rights of the weak.''

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1017 words

HEADLINE: White House and Congress Closer In Effort to Cut the Budget Deficit

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
''Most Americans are sick and tired of endless battles in the Congress and between the branches over budget matters,'' the President said. ''It is high time we pulled together and get the job done right. It is up to us to straighten this out.''
Mr. Bush reiterated his call for a cut in the capital gains tax and other measures he has pressed for all year. He gave no indication that the tax increases and spending reductions needed to reduce the deficit would by necessity cause pain. 
 
Leverage in Budget Talks
He also urged Congress for the first time to enact measures to encourage energy conservation, as well as more domestic oil production.
The President's handling of budgetary and economic matters has not been among his strongest political suits. But he may have gained leverage by presenting his case in a speech largely devoted to the military and diplomatic activity in the Middle East, couching the budget issue in patriotic terms.
The talk at the White House and in the Capitol today was more optimistic than it has been since the current budget talks began Friday. In part, that reflected the actual developments. But it also seemed to result from Republican efforts to smooth the way for the President's speech tonight and from the Democrats' desire to avert criticism from Mr. Bush.
''I'm on the positive side of the mood swing,'' said John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff.
Congressional leaders took a similar stance about the negotiators' work.
''Each day they get closer,'' said the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley of Washington. ''There is progress. There is movement.''
A crucial Republican in the talks, Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, agreed with that assessment, saying, ''We're at the place now wherethere is enough on the table on both sides that we can begin to pick and choose.''
 
Five Days of Talks
The negotiators began meeting at Andrews on Friday, away from reporters, camera crews and lobbyists. The meeting continued through the weekend and until 1:30 this morning. After a few hours' sleep the negotiators resumed talking until they adjourned to vote on other bills late this afternoon and for the President's address. They plan to return to the air base on Wednesday and to meet day and night until they reach an agreement.
Without a resolution soon there will not be enough time for Congress to pass the necessary legislation to avoid Draconian across-the-board cuts in most Government programs that would go into effect on Oct. 1, at the start of the next fiscal year, under the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law.
Some negotiators said Democrats had agreed to make much deeper cuts in programs like Social Security, Medicare and agriculture than they had accepted before.
The Republicans have demanded that these and other domestic programs be cut by at least $120 billion from what they would cost over the next five years if no changes are made in the laws, and by today Democrats had agreed to $100 billion in cuts.
But the Democrats have balked at a Republican proposal to sharply raise the premiums and deductibles that the elderly pay for Part B of Medicare. This is the part of the medical insurance program that pays doctors' bills.
 
Subsidy on Medical Insurance
A plan backed by Richard G. Darman, the President's budget director, which was said to save $40 billion over five years, would eliminate the Government subsidy for medical insurance altogether for people with annual incomes of more than $40,000 and for couples with incomes of more than $51,200.
Government officials could not say today how much such people would have to pay to purchase Government health insurance on their own.
For their part, the Republicans have agreed to a five-year reduction in military spending about $170 billion below what would be needed to keep pace with inflation, close to the figure the Democrats have insisted on. The cost for operations in the Persian Gulf are excluded from this accounting.
On taxes, both sides seem prepared to raise taxes on alcoholic beverages and luxury items like jewelry. But the Republicans continued to oppose raising the income tax on the wealthy, and the Democrats remained strongly against a cut in the capital gains tax.
 
Tax Breaks Proposed
In his address tonight Mr. Bush said the budget agreement should include not only a cut in the capital gains tax but also tax breaks for individual retirement accounts and saving accounts and new tax incentives for research and oil drilling.
He did not suggest what measures he might favor to encourage energy conservation, saying only that the ''trend'' toward importing more oil should be corrected.
''America is tired of phony deficit reduction or promise-now, save-later plans,'' Mr. Bush declared. ''Enough is enough. It is time for a program that is credible and real.''
In the Democratic response to the President, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, said the budget deal should emphasize ''fairness.''
''We must ask wealthy Americans to pay their fair share to prevent recession and reduce our debts,'' he said.

HEADLINE: African Force Is Protecting Doe's Tribe

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Sept. 11

 BODY:
Most of the killings in the eight-month-long civil war have involved four of Liberia's 16 main ethnic groups: the Krahn; the Mandingo, who are said to have aligned themselves with the Krahn, and the Gio and Mano tribes, from which the rebels are said to draw much of their support.
 
Gambian Cites Plea for Help
Gambia's President, Sir Dawda Jawara, who is also the head of the 16-member Economic Community of West African States, said that his group had received a request from the executive mansion for protection and that they were providing it as an ''humanitarian act.''
''If any other tribe or faction got into a corner like that and seemed to face massacre or extermination, I think it would only be humane for Ecowas to try and get them out,'' Sir Dawda said in an interview with the British Broadcasting Corporation. Ecowas is an acronym for the West African group. 
He added that President Doe's death appeared to complicate efforts to reach a settlement in the civil war.
''When you consider the relations between the tribes in Liberia,'' Sir Dawda said, President Doe's death ''could only worsen a very bad situation.'' The manner of his death, while he was visiting the peacekeeping force headquarters for reasons that have not been fully explained, has raised questions about the role that the West African group is playing in the conflict.
 
Already Faced Hurdles
Mohamed Ibn Chambas, Deputy Foreign Minister of Ghana, a major contributor to the force, said at a news conference today that President Doe's capture and death created ''an embarrassing situation which has exposed the difficult and complex posture'' of the West African force.
''Ecowas may eventually rue the day they got involved in this mess,'' a Western diplomat here said. ''The whole episode involving Doe was badly botched. And they are about to get themselves in even deeper by trying to protect the Krahns.''
The five-nation force was assembled last month after leaders of the West African group decided that the war was no longer solely an internal conflict because thousands of their citizens were trapped in Liberia, while an estimated 400,000 Liberians had fled to neighboring countries.
''Probably the only thing the rebels have in common is their hatred for the Krahns,'' said a Liberian businessman who recently fled the fighting there, ''There's going to be a lot of resentment if the peacekeeping force appears to be helping to keep them in power.''
 
U.S. Watching and Waiting
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (Special to The New York Times) - A State Department spokesman said today that the United States does not recognize any of the forces fighting to take power in Liberia, but is talking to all of them.
''The two rebel groups and elements of the remaining forces of Samuel Doe are all claiming to be the legally constituted Government of Liberia,'' the spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, said. ''We continue to be in touch with the various factions in the Liberian conflict.''
Asked if the United States recognized any of the groups, he replied: ''It's not for us to choose. At this point the situation as far as who's in charge, who's in control in Monrovia, is very confused.''

HEADLINE: Spanish-Cuban Asylum Battle Ends, Bitterly

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MADRID, Sept. 11

 BODY:
But in this case, with Havana asserting that Madrid had joined forces with the United States in trying to undermine the Cuban revolution, both the Spanish Government and public opinion were stunned when the Cuban leader himself resorted to fierce mud-slinging against Spain.
''I don't think the normalization of relations with Cuba, including the resumption of economic aid, can come tomorrow,'' Spain's Deputy Foreign Minister, Inocencio Arias, said last week. ''Unfortunately, these incidents, which in no case were provoked by us, leave a sediment.'' 
Mr. Castro told Spanish television that he was ready to patch things up, but added, ''We are not a country that can be humiliated or threatened because we have a high sense of honor and dignity that is part of our Spanish heritage.''
In reality, even before the first of the asylum-seekers entered Spain's mission in Havana on July 9, relations between the two countries were already being strained by suggestions from Madrid that Mr. Castro start liberalizing his Government in the wake of events in Eastern Europe.
Along with Mexico and Venezuela, Spain even discreetly asked Gabriel Garcia Marquez, the Nobel literature laureate, to convey a message to his friend, the Cuban leader, that Havana risked total isolation unless it made some democratic gestures. An Elected King? But last March, during a visit to Brazil, Mr. Castro sent a public message back to Madrid, scoffing at the idea of elections in Cuba by asking rhetorically whether voters had chosen King Juan Carlos to be Spain's head of state. His remarks brought a formal protest from Spain.
What appears to have awakened Mr. Castro's suspicions of a conspiracy in the case of the asylum-seekers was that 48 Cubans entered five European embassies in Havana in July almost immediately after Albania granted exit visas to 4,500 Albanians who took refuge in foreign embassies there.
In contrast to Albania, however, Cuba said none of its nationals could leave the country unless they sought permission through normal channels. Further, Spanish officials said, Cuba ordered nine police agents to force their way into the Spanish Embassy posing as asylum-seekers.
By the end of July, all the Cubans had left the Swiss, Czech, Italian and Belgian Embassies, but 18 remained in the Spanish mission. And after Cuba accused Spain of interfering in its internal affairs by encouraging asylum-seekers, Spain withdrew its Ambassador and suspended an aid program worth $2.5 million this year.
Verbal exchanges intensified. Cuba launched a personal attack on Spain's Foreign Minister, Francisco Fernandez Ordonez, while Spain's Secretary of International Cooperation, Luis Yanez said Cuba was ''a parched field in which any spark could set off a blaze.''
On July 26, Mr. Castro called Spain ''an accomplice of Yankee imperialism.'' Recalling Cuba's fight for independence in the 1890's, he also accused Madrid of ''colonialist arrogance.''
By late August, though, the asylum-seekers began leaving the Embassy. Spanish officials said that, when genuine asylum-seekers left, some police agents followed. The last five people left on Sept. 4. The officials said that while two wanted to be taken to their homes, three suspected agents asked to be dropped off in downtown Havana.

HEADLINE: Frustrated Chinese Look to U.S. as a Haven

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sept. 8

 BODY:
''There are two kinds of people in China these days,'' said a worker in his 20's, continuing with a cheerful exaggeration. ''First, there are those who simply want to go to the United States. And second, there are those who are already well along in their preparations to depart.'' 
Not everyone is afflicted by the ''emigration fever,'' as it is called here, but it is clear that the urge to leave has markedly increased since the army's crackdown on the democracy movement last year. That urge to relocate is motivated not only by political repression but by a far-deeper sense of frustration and discontent, as well as by rising economic expectations that China cannot meet.
''This place isn't stable, for all the official talk about stability,'' said a woman in her 40's, who agonized over lists of English words to prepare for moving to the United States. ''And everyone finds it stifling, with few opportunities to use your skills. What's more, Americans all have cars!'' Alarmed by the flood of students going abroad - compared with the trickle of people returning - the Chinese Government early this year imposed restrictions that on their face prevented college graduates from going abroad to study until they have worked for five years.
But ingenious young scholars are putting their minds to work evading the regulations. The most common method is to invent an aunt or uncle in Hong Kong or the United States, and take advantage of a clause allowing those with relatives abroad to pay fees instead of working for five years.
''We've had no significant change in the types of people who come in applying for student visas,'' an American diplomat here said. ''We're still seeing lots of recent college graduates who come in. The number of applicants and the number of issuances are both up.''
In August, for example, the United States Embassy in Beijing received 1,550 applications for student visas, compared with 1,371 applications in August 1989 and 949 applications in August 1988. The portion receiving visas has also risen, to 60 percent from 43 percent two years ago.
There is no doubt that the new regulations have had an effect - many recent graduates say that they have postponed their plans to go abroad - so one explanation for the increase in the number of applicants is that it would have soared without the restrictions.
''Five members of my senior class are applying to American universities,'' a high school student in Beijing said. ''I could do very well here, and join the Communist Party, and find a suitable husband, and get a good job. But there are lots of limits on what we can do here, and I think I'll be better off with training in America.''
A young business executive said that a few years ago, a Japanese executive offered to pay for her to study in Japan. She refused, and these days she thinks she made a terrible mistake.
''Now I can see that if you have talent here, you're suppressed and harassed,'' she said. She complained about her cramped dormitory room, which she shares with three roommates, and about her company's plans to send her to work in a factory to gain an appreciation for manual labor.
''I'm optimistic about my own future,'' she said, ''because I plan to go abroad, but I'm pessimistic about China. Anyone with talent is trying to leave. Absolutely everyone I know is looking for an exit.''

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
With Simple Arms and Derring-Do, Guerrillas in Kuwait Vex the Iraqis

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 5

 BODY:

 
In Small Bands
Western diplomats said that they did not know the strength of the resistance forces, but that they were apparently organized as guerrilla bands of a dozen members or less. Some of the fighters are former policemen or soldiers from Kuwait's armed forces, the diplomats said, but others are Kuwaiti civilians with no military background.
''The Kuwaitis had a quilt-work of neighborhood groups and alliances that were a part of their way of life, and these are the basis for the new guerrilla groups,'' one diplomat said. ''They are closely woven networks, and it is easy for the members to keep in touch with each other.'' 
Iraq swept into Kuwait on Aug. 2 with 150,000 soldiers, 1,200 tanks and 1,000 other armored vehicles. A diplomat said Iraq ''could vaporize'' the rebels with its superior force. But he and others said it appeared that the Iraqi Army was trying to avoid clashes.
''The Iraqis don't want to create a siege mentality,'' a diplomat said. ''For political purposes, Iraq would like the situation to seem normal.''
 
Weapons From Police Armories
The Kuwaiti rebel forces were originally equipped with weapons taken from the Kuwaiti police and military armories during the initial retreat. Some arms were captured from the Iraqis or purchased from Iraqi deserters, the diplomats said.
But the diplomats said the resistance now appears to be receiving support from inside Saudi Arabia. They cited unconfirmed reports that United States Army Special Forces teams are working with Kuwaitis there.
''I believe the Americans are in touch with the guys in Saudi Arabia,'' a diplomat said.
Before the invasion, Kuwait, a little smaller than Vermont, was one of the wealthiest countries in the world, with a per-capita income of nearly $15,000. Some of the guerrillas are communicating with expensive cellular telephones, a diplomat said.
Some people who have left the country in the last few days said they had seen Kuwaitis throw firebombs at Iraqi trucks and tanks and detontate remote-controlled explosives under military vehicles. In the early days of the Iraqi occupation, they said, some Kuwaitis used their cars to run down lone Iraqi soldiers.
 
Iraqis Travel in Groups
''Now you rarely see fewer than four Iraqi soldiers alone,'' a European who left the country said. ''They go out in groups for their own protection.''
Doctors in Kuwait have told diplomats that 20 to 25 Iraqi soldiers are arriving at hospitals nearly every night with gunshot wounds.
''The resistance is not strong enough to actually push the Iraqis out at this point,'' a diplomat said. ''But they are making life difficult for the Iraqis. They're making their presence known, and they are a force that can be built upon.''
A European woman recalled watching red tracer bullets sail through the night sky. On nights like these, she said, her family slept on the living room floor, well away from the windows.
Iraq has denied that a Kuwaiti resistance exists. None of the radio or television stations or newspapers, all run by the Government, have reported any guerrilla activity, and Government officials belittle the stories that have leaked out.
 
Wishful Thinking, Iraq Says
''It's very strong in your press,'' said Naji al-Hadithi, the chief spokesman for Iraq's Ministry of Information. ''It's very strong among wishful thinkers.''
But when the Rev. Jesse Jackson visited Kuwait with reporters on Aug. 31, the Iraqi security forces were clearly worried about being attacked. The Iraqi described as the chief local protocol officer carried a 9-millimeter automatic pistol jammed in his belt, and three carloads of men with rifles escorted Mr. Jackson everywhere.
Mr. Jackson asked why the Iraqis accompanying him were so heavily armed.
''We have to carry guns for safety and to make sure peace and security prevails,'' one of his escorts replied.
To guard against attacks from speeding cars, the Iraqis have set up a series of S-turns at approaches to their checkpoints throughout Kuwait City. Immediately after the invasion, diplomats said, sandbag bunkers were assembled along the waterfront to guard against raiders from the sea. Now, they said, the bunkers face inward, so Iraqi riflemen can scan the streets and buildings for guerrillas.
 
Protecting Foreigners
Diplomats and fleeing residents said the guerrillas have also been protecting foreigners hiding in Kuwait.
After initially moving to detain Westerners and Japanese in Iraq and Kuwait, President Saddam Hussein has been allowing some women and children to leave. He has said that most of the men will be detained as human shields against an American attack as long as the military standoff in the Persian Gulf continues.
After Mr. Hussein declared that any resident sheltering a foreigner would be executed, the rebels put out the word that they would shoot anyone who turned in a foreigner.
Two Dutch women said the Iraqis had marked the houses of foreigners in their neighborhood with red paint and the houses of Kuwaitis with black paint. Overnight, the women said, Kuwaitis opposing the occupation covered all of the red markings with black paint and obliterated street numbers on the houses.
To confuse the occupiers further, the two women said, resistance members also took down most street signs.
Before the invasion, Kuwait had a population of about two million, of which about a third were native Kuwaitis. More than 600,000 people have since fled to Jordan, and several hundred thousand others are believed to have taken refuge in Saudi Arabia. The declining population works to the disadvantage of the rebels, who try to blend in with other Kuwaitis and rely on them for support and information about the occupiers.
 
Hoping for a U.S. Attack
The guerrillas are yearning for a large-scale attack by the United States, but there has been no indication that their hopes will be met.
Kuwait's Crown Prince, Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, asserted at a news conference in London that the resistance would ''continue and escalate.''
Mr. Hadithi, the Iraqi spokesman, was asked whether his Government would consider holding a referendum in which Kuwaitis could decide whether their country should become part of Iraq. ''We don't hold referendums on matters of national sovereignty,'' he replied. ''This is a matter of national sovereignty.''
The Crown Prince said he also opposed a plebiscite in Kuwait.
''The Kuwaiti people have already expressed their opinion,'' he said. ''They are emphatic about what kind of Government they want.''
A European diplomat said the resistance could expect almost ''unlimited funding'' from Kuwait's royal family, which has vast holdings outside the country, and from Western nations committed to reversing Iraq's conquest.
''Money is going to be available from everyone,'' the diplomat said. ''The resistance is serious about what it's doing, and it's going to get plenty of help.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Photo released by a Kuwaiti resistance group is said to show Iraqi soldiers killed in a ambush recently in Kuwait City. Rebel forces were originally equipped with weapons taken from police and military armories. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
Attempts Have Been Made to Break Trade Embargo Against Iraq, U.S. Officials Say

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:

 
Disclosure Seen as Deterrent
None of the oil deliveries or the payments appear to violate the United Nations sanctions, which apply only to oil sales or other trade with Iraq conducted after Aug. 6.
The Bush Administration is citing the oil shipments and efforts to break the trade ban to United Nations diplomats in an effort to underscore American resolve and to deter potential violators by making it clear that illegal trade with Iraq will be detected and revealed.
United States intelligence agencies have uncovered efforts by private concerns in two dozen nations to smuggle goods to Iraq and have immediately notified the host governments and urged them to take legal action, Administration officials said today. 
One Government official said several of those concerns were ''professional sanctions-busters,'' experienced in breaking embargoes against such nations as Rhodesia, that are now seeking to sell their services to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.
That official said the companies were based in such locations as Brazil, Eastern Europe, Switzerland, Austria and Britain. They are described as ''fronts'' with no real corporate structure, none of them well known internationally.
None of those Governments were aware of the concerns' secret overtures to Iraq, the official said. He said Eastern European smugglers were proving a particular problem because the region's new democratic governments were ill-equipped to track or thwart illegal deals.
 
Some Deals Are Reported
The Associated Press, citing a State Department document, reported today that Cuba and Romania had struck oil deals with Iraq and that two unnamed companies in Western Europe had secretly offered to smuggle food into Iraq. The report also said unidentified companies in Eastern Europe, East Asia and Africa had offered to smuggle weapons and other goods as well.
Romania's Ambassador to the United States, Virgil Constantinescu, today denied the A.P. report and issued a list of his nation's oil purchases since Aug. 5, all from nations other than Iraq.
Mr. Constantinescu said in a written statement that Iraq had offered to give Romania about one million metric tons of oil to settle past debts but that the offer had been rejected. He also said Romania had canceled two contracts with an American oil company, Chevron Corporation, for 150,000 metric tons of Iraqi oil.
An Administration official, speaking on condition that he not be named, said that Iraq had discussed oil sales to Romania but that it was uncertain which nation had raised the prospect of a sale.
Romania, like many Eastern European nations, had conducted a busy trade with Iraq and is suffering economically from the trade embargo.
Officials said the Cuban oil shipment had been unloaded from the Iraqi-flag oil tanker Amuriyah, which docked in Cuba in the last week of August. Shipping officials said the Amuriyah left the Turkish city of Ceyhan on July 31, two days before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, after taking on a cargo of crude oil at an Iraqi pipeline that terminates on the Mediterranean Sea near Turkey's border with Syria.
Cuba has been hit by oil shortages stemming from a slowdown in deliveries by its major supplier, the Soviet Union, and President Fidel Castro recently imposed drastic energy conservation measures throughout the island.

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
Transcript of President's Address to Joint Session of Congress

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
They are some of the finest men and women of the United States of America. And they're doing one terrific job.
These valiant Americans were ready at a moment's notice to leave their spouses, and their children to serve on the front line halfway around the world. And they remind us who keeps America strong. They do.
In the trying circumstances of the gulf, the morale of our servicemen and women is excellent. In the face of danger, they are brave; they're well trained and dedicated. 
A soldier, Pfc. Wade Merritt of Knoxville, Tenn., now stationed in Saudi Arabia, wrote his parents of his worries, his love of family and his hope for peace. But Wade also wrote: ''I am proud of my country and its firm stance against inhumane aggression. I am proud of my army and its men. . . . I am proud to serve my country.''
Well, let me just say, Wade, America is proud of you, and is grateful to every soldier, sailor, marine and airman serving the cause of peace in the Persian Gulf.
I also want to thank the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, General Powell; the Chiefs here tonight; our commander in the Persian Gulf, General Schwarzkopf; and the men and women of the Department of Defense. What a magnificent job you all are doing, and thank you very, very much. I'm grateful to you.
I wish I could say that their work is done. But we all know it is not.
So if there ever was a time to put country before self and patriotism before party, time is now. Let me thank all Americans, especially those here in this chamber tonight, for your support for our armed forces and for their mission. That support will be even more important in the days to come.
 
Objectives in the Gulf
So tonight, I want to talk to you about what is at stake, what we must do together to defend civilized values around the world and maintain our economic strength at home.
Our objectives in the Persian Gulf are clear, our goals defined and familiar:
* Iraq must withdraw from Kuwait completely, immediately and without condition.
* Kuwait's legitimate Government must be restored.
* The security and stability of the Persian Gulf must be assured.
* And American citizens abroad must be protected.
These goals are not ours alone. They have been endorsed by the U.N. Security Council five times in as many weeks. Most countries share our concern for principle. And many have a stake in the stability of the Persian Gulf. This is not, as Saddam Hussein would have it, the United States against Iraq. It is Iraq against the world.
As you know, I've just returned from a very productive meeting with Soviet President Gorbachev. And I am pleased that we are working together to build a new relationship. In Helsinki, our joint statement affirmed to the world our shared resolve to counter Iraq's threat to peace. Let me quote: ''We are united in the belief that Iraq's aggression must not be tolerated. No peaceful international order is possible if larger states can devour their smaller neighbors.''
Clearly, no longer can a dictator count on East-West confrontation to stymie concerted United Nations action against aggression. A new partnership of nations has begun. And we stand today at a unique and extraordinary moment. The crisis in the Persian Gulf, as grave as it is, also offers a rare opportunity to move toward an historic period of cooperation. Out of these troubled times, our fifth objective - a new world order - can emerge: a new era, freer from the threat of terror, stronger in the pursuit of justice, and more secure in the quest for peace. An era in which the nations of the world, east and west, north and south, can prosper and live in harmony.
A hundred generations have searched for this elusive path to peace, while a thousand wars raged across the span of human endeavor. And today that new world is struggling to be born. A world quite different from the one we've known. A world where the rule of law supplants the rule of the jungle. A world in which nations recognize the shared responsibility for freedom and justice. A world where the strong respect the rights of the weak.
 
A Shared Vision
This is the vision that I shared with President Gorbachev in Helsinki. He, and other leaders from Europe, the gulf and around the world understand that how we manage this crisis today could shape the future for generations to come.
The test we face is great - and so are the stakes. This is the first assault on the new world that we seek, the first test of our mettle. Had we not responded to this first provocation with clarity of purpose, if we do not continue to demonstrate our determination, it would be a signal to actual and potential despots around the world.
America and the world must defend common vital interests. And we will. America and the world must support the rule of law. And we will. America and the world must stand up to aggression. And we will.
And one thing more: In the pursuit of these goals, America will not be intimidated.
Vital issues of principle are at stake. Saddam Hussein is literally trying to wipe a country off the face of the earth. We do not exaggerate. Nor do we exaggerate when we say: Saddam Hussein will fail.
Vital economic interests are at risk as well. Iraq itself controls some 10 percent of the world's proven oil reserves. Iraq plus Kuwait controls twice that. An Iraq permitted to swallow Kuwait would have the economic and military power, as well as the arrogance, to intimidate and coerce its neighbors, neighbors who control the lion's share of the world's remaining oil reserves. We cannot permit a resource so vital to be dominated by one so ruthless. And we won't.
Recent events have, have surely proven that there is no substitute for American leadership. In the face of tyranny, let no one doubt American credibility and reliability. Let no one doubt our staying power. We will stand by our friends. One way or another, the leader of Iraq must learn this fundamental truth.
 
Response to Aggression
From the outset, acting hand in hand with others, we've sought to fashion the broadest possible international response to Iraq's aggression. The level of world cooperation and condemnation of Iraq is unprecedented.
Armed forces from countries spanning four continents are there at the request of King Fahd of Saudi Arabia to deter and if need be to defend against attack. Muslims and non-Muslims, Arabs and non-Arabs, soldiers from many nations, stand shoulder to shoulder, resolute against Saddam Hussein's ambitions.
And we can now point to five United Nations Security Council resolutions that condemn Iraq's aggression. They call for Iraq's immediate and unconditional withdrawal, the restoration of Kuwait's legitimate Government, and categorically reject Iraq's cynical and self-serving attempt to annex Kuwait.
Finally, the United Nations has demanded the release of all foreign nationals held hostage against their will and in contravention of international law. It's a mockery of human decency to call these people ''guests.'' They are hostages, and the whole world knows it.
Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, a dependable ally, said it all: ''We do not bargain over hostages. We will not stoop to the level of using human beings as bargaining chips ever.''
Of course, of course, our hearts go out to the hostages and to their families. But our policy cannot change. And it will not change. America and the world will not be blackmailed by this ruthless policy.
We're now in sight of a United Nations that performs as envisioned by its founders. We owe much to the outstanding leadership of Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar. The United Nations is backing up its words with action. The Security Council has imposed mandatory economic sanctions on Iraq, designed to force Iraq to relinquish the spoils of its illegal conquest. The Security Council has also taken the decisive step of authorizing the use of all means necessary to ensure compliance with these sanctions.
Together with our friends and allies, ships of the United States Navy are today patrolling Mideast waters. And they've already intercepted more than 700 ships to enforce the sanctions. Three regional leaders I spoke with just yesterday told me that these sanctions are working. Iraq is feeling the heat.
We continue to hope that Iraq's leaders will recalculate just what their aggression has cost them. They are cut off from world trade, unable to sell their oil. And only a tiny fraction of goods gets through.
The communique with President Gorbachev made mention of what happens when the embargo is so effective that children of Iraq literally need milk, or the sick truly need medicine. Then, under strict international supervision that guarantees the proper destination, then food will be permitted.
 
Sharing the Burden
At home, the material cost of our leadership can be steep. And that's why Secretary of State Baker and Treasury Secretary Brady have met with many world leaders to underscore that the burden of this collective effort must be shared. We are prepared to do our share and more to help carry the load; we insist that others do their share as well.
The response of most of our friends and allies has been good. To help defray costs, the leaders of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the U.A.E., United Arab Emirates, have pledged to provide our deployed troops with all the food and fuel they need. And generous assistance will also be provided to stalwart front-line nations such as Turkey and Egypt.
And I am also heartened to report that this international response extends to the neediest victims of this conflict - those refugees. For our part, we have contributed $28 million for relief efforts. And this is but a portion of what is needed. I commend, in particular, Saudi Arabia, Japan and several European nations who have joined us in this purely humanitarian effort.
There is an energy-related cost to be borne as well. Oil-producting nations are already replacing lost Iraqi and Kuwaiti output. More than half of what was lost has been made up. And we're are getting superb cooperation. If producers, including the United States, continue steps to expand oil and gas production, we can stabilize prices and guarantee against hardship. Additionally, we and several of our allies always have the option to extract oil from our strategic petroleum reserves, if conditions warrant. As I have pointed out before, conservation efforts are essential to keep our energy needs as low as possible. And we must then take advantage of our energy sources across the board: coal, natural gas, hydro and nuclear. Our failure, our failure to do these things has made us more dependent on foreign oil than ever before. And finally, let no one even contemplate profiteering from this crisis. We will not have it.
 
Resolve on Kuwait
I cannot predict just how long it will take to convince Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. Sanctions will take time to have their full intended effect. We will continue to review all options with our allies, but let it be clear: We will not let this aggression stand.
Our interest, our involvement in the gulf, is not transitory. It predated Saddam Hussein's aggression and will survive it. Long after all our troops come home, and we all hope it's soon, very soon, there will be a lasting role for the United States in assisting the nations of the Persian Gulf. Our role, then, to deter future aggression. Our role is to help our friends in their own self-defense. And something else: to curb the proliferation of chemical, biological, ballistic missile and, above all, nuclear technologies.
And let me also make clear that the United States has no quarrel with the Iraqi people. Our quarrel is with Iraq's dictator, and with his aggression. Iraq will not be permitted to annex Kuwait. And that's not a threat, not a boast. It's just the way it's going to be.
Our ability to function effectively as a great power abroad depends on how we conduct ourselves at home. Our economy, our armed forces, our energy dependence, and our cohesion all determine whether we can help our friends and stand up to our foes.
For America to lead, America must remain strong and vital. Our world leadership and domestic strength are mutual and reinforcing; a woven piece, strongly bound as Old Glory.
To revitalize our leadership, our leadership capacity, we must address our budget deficit - not after Election Day, or next year, but now.
Higher oil prices slow our growth, and higher defense costs would only make our fiscal deficit problem worse. That deficit was already greater than it should have been: a projected $232 billion for the coming year. It must - it will - be reduced.
To my friends in Congress, together we must act this very month, before the next fiscal year begins on Oct. 1, to get America's economic house in order. The gulf situation helps us realize we are more economically vulnerable than we ever should be. Americans must never again enter any crisis, economic or military, with an excessive dependence on foreign oil and an excessive burden of Federal debt.
Most Americans are sick and tired of endless battles in the Congress and between the branches over budget matters. It is high time we pulled together, and get the job done right. And it's up to us to straighten this out.
 
Tax and Military Goals
And the job has four basic parts.
First, the Congress should, this month, within a budget agreement, enact growth-oriented tax measures to help avoid recession in the short term and to increase savings, investment, productivity and competitiveness for the longer term. These measures include extending incentives for research and experimentation; expanding the use of I.R.A.'s for new homeowners; establishing tax-deferred family savings accounts; creating incentives for the creation of enterprise zones and initiatives to encourage more domestic drilling, and, yes, reducing the tax rate on capital gains.
And second, the Congress should, this month, enact a prudent multiyear defense program, one that reflects not only the improvement in East-West relations, but our broader responsibilities to deal with the continuing risks of outlaw action and regional conflict. Even with our obligations in the gulf, a sound defense budget can have some reduction in real terms, and we are prepared to accept that. But to go beyond, but to go beyond such levels, where cutting defense would threaten our vital margin of safety, is something I will never accept.
The world is still dangerous. And surely that is now clear. Stability is not secure. American interests are far-reaching. Interdependence has increased. The consequences of regional instability can be global. This is no time to risk America's capacity to protect her vital interests.
And third, the Congress should, this month, enact measures to increase domestic energy production and energy conservation in order to reduce dependence on foreign oil. These measures should include my proposals to increase incentives for domestic oil and gas exploration, fuel switching and to accelerate the development of the Alaskan energy resources, without damage to wildlife.
As you know, when the oil embargo was imposed in the early 1970's, the United States imported almost six million barrels of oil a day. This year, before the Iraqi invasion, U.S. imports had risen to nearly eight million barrels per day. And we'd moved in the wrong direction. And now we must act to correct that trend. And fourth: The Congress should, this month, enact a five-year program to reduce the projected debt and deficits by $500 billion - that's by half a trillion dollars. And if, with the Congress, we can develop a satisfactory program by the end of the month, we can avoid the ax of ''sequester,'' deep across-the-board cuts that would threaten our military capacity and risk substantial domestic disruption.
 
Tests for a Budget Agreement
I want to be able to tell the American people that we have truly solved the deficit problem. And for me to do that, a budget agreement must meet these tests:
* It must include the measures I've recommended to increase economic growth and reduce dependence on foreign oil.
* It must be fair. All should contribute, but the burden should not be excessive for any one group or programs or people.
* It must address the growth of Government's hidden liabilities.
* It must reform the budget process, and further, it must be real.
I urge Congress to provide a comprehensive five-year deficit reduction program to me as a complete legislative package, with measures to assure that it can be fully enforced. America is tired of phony deficit reduction, or promise-now, save-later-plans. It is time for a program that is credible and real.
And finally, to the extent that the defict reduction program includes new revenue measures, it must avoid any measure that would threaten economic growth or turn us back towards the days of punishing income tax rates. That is one path we should not head down again.
I, I have been pleased with recent progress, although it's not always seemed so smooth.
 
But now it's time to produce
And I hope we can work out a responsible plan. But with or without agreement from the budget summit, I ask both houses of the Congress to allow a straight up-or-down vote on a complete $500 billion deficit reduction package, not later than Sept. 28th.
And if the Congress cannot get me a budget, then Americans will have to face a tough, mandated sequester.
I'm hopeful, in fact I'm confident, that the Congress will do what it should, and I can assure you that we in the executive branch will do our part.
In the final analysis, our ability to meet our responsibilities abroad depends upon political will and consensus at home. It's never easy in democracies, for we govern only with the consent of the governed. And although free people in a free society are bound to have their differences, Americans traditionally come together in times of adversity and challenge.
Once again, Americans have stepped forward to share a tearful goodbye with their families before leaving for a strange and distant shore. At this very moment, they serve together with Arabs, Europeans, Asians and Africans in defense of principle and the dream of a new world order. And that's why they sweat and toil in the sand and the heat and the sun.
And if they can come together under such adversity, if old adversaries like the Soviet Union and the United States can work in common cause, then surely we who are so fortunate to be in this great chamber - Democrats, Republicans, liberals, conservatives - can come together to fulfill our responsibilities here.
Thank you, good night and God bless the United States of America.

HEADLINE: Work With China, Without Illusions

 BODY:
The U.S. and other democracies should encourage these constructive moves now by easing the diplomatic ostracism imposed on Beijing after the June 1989 bloodbath in Tiananmen Square. President Bush was always right to insist that the world had nothing to gain from isolating China. But he then undermined support for his own arguments by downplaying Beijing's gross abuse of human rights. 
There's good reason for hard-headed diplomatic realism; there's no excuse for reviving soft-headed fantasies about the nature of Deng Xiaoping's China. Beijing's leadership has left no doubt about its determination to uphold Communist dictatorship by force, despite Communism's collapse elsewhere. Wise American policy would keep both American interests and values in clear sight.
Mr. Bush isn't the first President to let his diplomatic stance toward China color his reading of Chinese politics. For more than two decades after the Communists won control of the mainland, the U.S. insisted that Mao Zedong's regime was an extension of Soviet power, with the real China temporarily camped in Taiwan. This self-deception kept the U.S. from grasping the reality of Sino-Soviet rivalry, and contributed to disastrous misjudgments about the strategic significance of Vietnam.
Richard Nixon, while he prevented others from acting on the Sino-Soviet schism, made it a centerpiece of his own approach. Together with Henry Kissinger, he stood the old China policy on its head, courting Beijing as a strategic ally against Moscow.
The image of a heartless ''Red China'' yielded to something more worthy of American friendship: a land of Ping-Pong players, pandas and the Great Wall. That was all the more remarkable since the new U.S.-China amity began during the final years of the radical, murderous Cultural Revolution.
Mr. Deng's rise to power brought welcome economic reforms, but American leaders ignored continued political repression. To be sure, U.S. diplomats weren't the only ones surprised by the brutality of last year's massacre. But more than a year later the Bush Administration still won't reconcile its policies to Chinese realities.
Nations can make common cause in foreign policy even when they do not share common values. China's leaders understand that well enough. They wage fierce war against ''bourgeois liberalization'' and Soviet-style reforms at home even while they cooperate with Washington and Moscow. America's leaders would do well to learn that pragmatic alignment does not require wholesale endorsement.

HEADLINE: 'Motor-Voter' Bill: Good for Democracy

 BODY:
The House has already passed a bipartisan bill that would replace present state-by-state barriers to enrollment with reasonable standards for Federal elections. Similar legislation will soon reach the Senate floor. Democracy will surely be expanded if the Senate swiftly rebuffs ill-considered opposition from the Bush Administration and the Senate minority leader, Robert Dole.
The core provision of the so-called ''motor-voter'' bill, sponsored by Senator Wendell Ford, Democrat of Kentucky, would require states to enable eligible voters to register to vote when they apply for a driver's license or license renewal. That would be a tremendous boost for enrollment, since about 90 percent of voting-age Americans drive. The impact on actual turnout, while harder to forecast, would probably also be significant, since roughly 8 registered voters in 10 go to the polls.
Other provisions would permit registration by mail, and make registration forms available at public agencies like welfare and unemployment offices. The bill would also end the destructive practice of purging voters from the rolls simply for not voting.
These laudable efforts to boost participation have drawn fire from the Administration and Senator Dole, who has introduced a weaker bill in the hope of siphoning enough Republican votes to defeat mandatory reforms.
One complaint is that the bill could lead to voting fraud. The House version, however, contains strong anti-fraud provisions that could be incorporated into the final bill. Mr. Dole also says the new Federal requirement would usurp state authority. But that's precisely the point. If Congress won't act decisively to expand the franchise, who will?

HEADLINE: Sex Education Declines, Teen-Age Births Rise;
Plight in New York

 BODY:
The state tried to offset some of the loss with modest annual increases. But the funds were well below what was needed to keep up with the burgeoning needs of the quarter-million low-income women and adolescents who rely on the statewide network of 250 family-planning clinics for subsidized primary care.
Clinic visits for treatment of sexually transmissible diseases alone have increased by almost 80 percent since 1984. It is estimated that $2 million a year out of family-planning money goes toward these related services. Clinics also had to dig into pregnancy-prevention resources to start a department for human immunodeficiency virus in 1987 without any new appropriation. Doubling and tripling of Pap test costs has added some $1 million more to the squeeze, leaving fewer dollars earmarked specifically for contraceptive education and services. 
These funding constraints, plus major staffing difficulties, fueled by shrinking resources for nursing salaries, have severely reduced access. Forced to retrench vital services, clinics in some areas of the state have seen waiting time for appointments stretch to five weeks.
Our latest analysis shows that adolescents younger than 18 and women with family income less than 150 percent of the poverty level have become a steadily decreasing proportion of family-planning patients in the last three years.
The unmet need is tremendous. Upstate, less than 40 percent of adolescents 13 to 19 years old at risk of unintended pregnancy are receiving family-planning services. In New York City, the unmet need is significantly higher, with less than 25 percent served in discrete family-planning projects that provide subsidized care.
New funds are desperately needed in New York State to forestall further retrenchment in the family-planning program. Until we close the funding gap, we can expect to see more and more of the medical, social and economic consequences of unwed teen-age parents.
 
SHIRLEY GORDON
Executive Director, Family Planning
Advocates of New York State
Albany, Aug. 27, 1990

HEADLINE: We're on the Wrong Side in El Salvador

 BODY:
The suppression and exploitation of the Salvadoran people by less than 10 percent at the top of the economic structure, and by an army that fights only for that elite, is a serious matter for us, since our tax dollars, in large amounts, sustain that situation.
The Salvadoran Government, whether in league with the army or too weak to oppose it, in 1987 declared an amnesty, dropping charges against all army personnel accused of participating in massacres against, no doubt, ''leftist'' peasants, ''leftist'' members of the clergy, perhaps even ''rebels.'' The following year a judge threatened to prosecute army officers known to be connected with death squads; the case, or rather the judge, was disposed of by one more death-squad murder. 
As a stingy taxpayer, I'm always interested where our money goes. A little information comes from a House of Representatives resolution introduced two years ago by half a dozen representatives (at least one of them a Republican), which discloses that in the previous year the United States gave the Salvadoran Government $608 million. This is support for a government by and for the very small percentage of the Salvadoran people who own 90 percent of the land and everything else. The $608 million was 105 percent of what all Salvadorans contributed to their government's expenditures.
I don't think we can be proud of our support for this war against peasants, members of the clergy and ''rebels,'' the underdogs on whose side any normal American would be, if normal Americans received a little information about this situation.
That we have openly appropriated only $85 million this year is hardly encouraging. It is still going to the wrong side, and who knows how much more we're sending the oppressors through the Central Intelligence Agency.
 
ARNOLD SIMMEL
New York, Aug. 24, 1990

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Not the Only Crisis

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
Not at all. West Germany and the Soviet Union, for instance, now have agreed on how to share the costs of Soviet troop withdrawals from East Germany; so German reunification actually will take place on Oct. 3, barely three weeks from now. In the long run, this might be the most important event of 1990, or the coming decade; but it's taking place in a vacuum of public and perhaps official discussion, owing to the Middle East frenzy created by a dedicated Administration and a headline-happy press. 
Only five weeks ago the major topics of American political discussion were the nomination of David Souter to the Supreme Court, the $50 billion savings and loan scandal that made Neil Bush a household name, an economy that even an upbeat President called ''sluggish,'' his broken pledge to oppose new taxes, and efforts to deal with the budget deficit.
None of these matters have disappeared or been managed. Though Senate hearings on Mr. Souter are at hand, all have taken second place to the idea of the U.S. standing tall in the desert, in opposition to aggression and in defense of oil. It's not clear which comes first, and both are admittedly important; but so are other problems that existed before Saddam Hussein loosed his tanks - problems that will not be solved by more troops from Egypt or more Presidential backslapping in Helsinki.
In keeping to his August vacation schedule, Mr. Bush sought to show that he was not hostage to the Middle East crisis, as President Carter was thought to have been when Iran was holding U.S. hostages. Staying in Maine thus made some sense (though with oil supplies supposedly in danger the President at least could have beached his gas-guzzling speedboat). In fact, Mr. Bush's single-minded attention to the Iraqi problem, however successful his efforts, may have made him as much a hostage to a single issue as Mr. Carter was.
In particular, that sluggish U.S. economy, and the dubious determination of Democrats and Republicans alike to raise taxes anyway, demands Mr. Bush's attention as much as does the Middle East. An economic collapse at home would make a major military commitment abroad incongruous, if not impossible, even with Saudi money as a backup. And what would distinguish one supposed superpower from another if each tried to maintain a military front on top of an economy sliding into ruin?
It has largely escaped notice, moreover, in Americans' persistent innocence of even their own history, that Mr. Bush has reverted to the sort of imperial Presidential conduct that the Vietnam War should have taught the nation to question. It's true that he has kept Congress informed about his Middle East policy; but the strategy, decisions and announced goals all have been his, including one that could backfire - to expel Iraq from Kuwait and restore the emirate.
Few now dispute that goal; but suppose Iraq suddenly withdraws from Kuwait, contradicting Mr. Hussein but apparently bowing to overpowering opposition as well as to Mr. Bush's demands. That would bring about the end of the blockade, the embargo and the anti-Iraq coalition, force Mr. Bush to bring U.S. troops home and leave Iraq unscathed as a military power - perhaps, having defied the U.S. and the world without real loss, even enhanced as a dominant voice in the Middle East.
Mr. Bush's imperial crisis management might not then seem so impressive; both Congress and the public might ask some embarrassing questions, such as: Who was the real winner? And who took the U.S. out on a limb that could be cut off behind it?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1079 words

HEADLINE: In S.& L. Bailout, U.S. Is Moving to Evict 8 Rent-Regulated Tenants

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
The Resolution Trust foreclosed on the eight apartments as assets of a failed Long Island savings and loan association, and has said it intends to sell them.
Thousands of rent-regulated apartments in New York State are potentially at risk because they are owned either by thrift institutions, by investors who are in a tight financial squeeze because of the real-estate slump in New York and the rest of the Northeast, or by lenders who have foreclosed on the apartments.
Tenants of any of the apartments that are seized by the Resolution Trust Corporation could be evicted, Federal officials said yesterday.
State officials said they could not predict how widespread evictions would become if the Federal agency prevails on East 57th Street. Lawyers on Mr. Abrams's staff said yesterday that they knew of two other buildings in New York City and its suburbs where Federal regulators had already foreclosed on rent-regulated apartments, but they declined to specify the locations of the buildings or the number of apartments at risk. In a letter to the executive director of the Resolution Trust Corporation, David C. Cooke, Mr. Abrams called the Federal action illegal. The New York State Commissioner for Housing and Community Renewal, Richard L. Higgins, who oversees rent-stabilization laws, said lawyers for New York State were preparing to challenge the East 57th Street evictions in court. 
''They are trying to solve the savings and loan crisis on the back of our rent-regulated tenants,'' Mr. Higgins said, ''and we will not stand for it.''
A spokesman for the Resolution Trust Corporation in Washington, Stephen Katsanos, said the agency would not withdraw its eviction notices at the East 57th Street building.
If the Federal agency prevails, Mr. Katsanos said, it might evict rental tenants in any building it takes over from an insolvent lender.
Legal experts said the Resolution Trust Corporation might assert its right as an agent of the Federal Government to supersede state law.
The Resolution Trust Corporation said it was authorized to withdraw from any lease obligations through the same Federal legislation under which it was established, the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery and Enforcement Act of 1989. Mr. Katsanos said the Federal law allowed it to supersede state or local rental protection measures.
In the case of the East 57th Street condominium, the Federal agency sent letters to the eight rental tenants on Aug. 17 that gave them notice of eviction and offered them the opportunity to buy their apartments. The asking prices ranged from $330,000 to $920,000.
 
Protection Against Eviction
None of the tenants have accepted the offer. A lawyer for the tenants, Robert A. Machleder, said yesterday that some might consider lower offers but that all planned to defend themselves against eviction in court.
Some of the tenants' apartments are rent controlled and the others' are rent stablized. Rent control covers buildings construct before 1947. Rent stabilization generally covers apartments in buildings constructed between 1947 and 1974 and those built later with city tax abatements. Although the two sets of regulations apply different formulas to rent increases, they both offer the same protection against eviction.
Mr. Katsanos said the Federal agency decided to serve notice of eviction at the building because the tenants were paying rents far below the market rate and far less than the Government, as landlord of their units, would be required to pay in monthly common charges and other expenses. Collectively, the eight tenants pay rental bills of $9,000 a month, he said. In addition, carrying charges for the Government - which include common charges, taxes in arrears and payments to the condominium's reserve fund - are $37,000 a month.
 
Authority to Override
The eight tenants pay monthly rents ranging from $550 to $1,700.
The notices sent to them say that if they do not purchase their apartments, they must vacate when their current leases expire, some as early as Sept. 30.
Mr. Abrams said yesterday that the legal dispute with Resolution Trust would revolve around the Federal Government's authority to override state law. ''We assert that they do not have the power to override a law that protects peoples' homes,'' he said.
If Resolution Trust proceeds with its evictions, the action would not affect many tenants in the East 57th Street building. The eight apartments are among more than 20 in the building with rent-regulated tenants, officials said.
The other apartments were not used as collateral for bank financing by the sponsor in the building's 1982 conversion, Gerald Guterman, a New York developer. After converting the building, Mr. Guterman used some of his unsold, rent-regulated apartments as collateral for bank loans - a common practice among cooperative and condominium converters in the real-estate boom of the 1980's.
His loans were obtained from the Nassau Federal Savings and Loan Association of Long Island. In 1986, facing a financial downturn, Mr. Guterman defaulted on the loans, and the eight apartments were seized by the thrift institution.
But Nassau Federal was also a victim of the region's real-estate slump, and its assets were seized by the Resolution Trust Corporation in July.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

INDUSTRY: NAICS522120 SAVINGS INSTITUTIONS (93%); SIC6035 SAVINGS INSTITUTIONS, FEDERALLY CHARTERED (93%); 

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (94%); 

CITY: NEW YORK, NY, USA (92%);

HEADLINE: Morrison Is Democrats' Pick For Governor of Connecticut

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Sept. 11

 BODY:

 
Cibes Withholds Endorsement
The turnout in the primary was light, with about 20 percent of the state's 681,000 registered Democrats turning out to vote.
But it was not clear that the divisions within the party would be healed as quickly as Mr. Morrison hoped. Mr. Cibes, a professor of government at Connecticut College and a 12-year veteran of the General Assembly, conceded defeat just before 9:30, about 90 minutes after the polls closed, but he said he would withhold his endorsement of Mr. Morrison, pending further discussions with him.
Mr. Cibes, who entered the race in March with little money or name recognition, based his appeal to voters on what he said was the ''hard truth'' that Connecticut's tax system had reached a dead end and needed a complete overhaul, including the introduction of a personal income tax on wages. The state is one of only 10 without a tax on wages and salaries. 
''The issues that we raised in this campaign will not go away,'' Mr. Cibes said in his concession speech at the campaign headquarters here. He told his supporters that they should be proud of raising the issue of changing the tax system. He predicted tax change would ultimately be embraced by the party.
 
Landslide Proportions
Mr. Morrison, a former legal assistance lawyer for the poor in New Haven who has represented Connecticut's Third Congressional District since 1983, predicted last week that he would win by a 10 percentage-point margin, or by about 55 percent to 45 percent, the traditional measure, he said, of a landslide. But the victory was even greater than that.
Mr. Morrison won by major margins in his own Congressional district and also carried towns in the First Congressional District around Hartford, considered an important battleground. He carried East Hartford, for example, with 1,460 votes to 925 for Mr. Cibes. But many of the small towns like Columbia and Andover went to Mr. Cibes.
Mr. Morrison had maintained throughout the campaign that the real choice to be made was not the question of Mr. Cibes's tax plan but rather who would do best in November against Mr. Weicker and Mr. Rowland. Mr. Morrison said he opposed the income-tax plan and would never impose such a dramatic change on the state without first holding a referendum to seek majority approval.
In the only other major primary race today, for the Republican nomination for the Third Congressional District seat, the endorsed candidate, State Senator Thomas Scott, defeated former State Representative Gerard B. Patton, winning about 70 percent of the vote. Mr. Scott will face the Democratic nominee, Rosa L. DeLauro, in November.
While today's vote in the governor's race ended the formal competition for supremacy in the party, a number of unknowns still hang over the Democrats as they begin the race toward November.
 
O'Neill's Role at Issue
One is money. With three candidates in the running and the state's economy slumping, the competition for campaign contributions is intense. Mr. Cibes, for example, who had set a goal of $200,000 by Primary Day - a modest amount to start with compared with the other candidates - raised only $120,000 by last week. Mr. Morrison was forced to borrow more than $300,000 earlier this year to keep his campaign afloat and had only about $26,000 on hand.
Another question is the role of Gov. William A. O'Neill, a Democrat who will leave office after 10 years.
Mr. O'Neill, who intended to run for a third term, saw his popularity plummet beginning last year as residents blamed him for the state's souring economy and soaring tax rates. Although he withdrew from the race in March and stayed formally neutral, his presence hung over the primary and affected both candidates.
In comments to reporters, for example, Mr. O'Neill frequently displayed a distaste for Mr. Morrison in subtle and sometimes not-so-subtle terms and an open fondness for Mr. Cibes, a longtime colleague who helped organize Mr. O'Neill's campaign in 1986.
Mr. Morrison also appeared to cultivate his differences with Mr. O'Neill, identifying himself throughout the campaign as a governor who would be ''on your side for a change.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bruce A. Morrison, left, a Democratic candidate for governor of Connecticut, after voting yesterday at a polling place in Waterbury. (Stephen Castagneto for The New York Times)
