HEADLINE: New York City Acts to Protect Water

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 11

 BODY:
The overhaul is motivated by development pressure that has degraded, by varying degrees, water quality in the three systems. Tap water is still safe to drink, environmental officials say. But the existing regulations have failed to keep pace with changes in the reservoir watersheds, they add.
 
'Playing a Lot of Catch-Up'
New York City's authority to place restrictions on development in watershed areas stems from a state law passed 85 years ago. The law gave the city the right to take upstate lands and flood them for reservoirs. Today, the city owns 18 reservoirs, 12 of which are in the Croton system and 6 in the Catskill and Delaware systems. Besides New York City, they serve residents of Orange, Putnam, Ulster and Westchester counties. 
''This has not been gone through in 37 years and we're playing a lot of catch-up,'' Albert F. Appleton, the city's Commisioner of Environmental Protection, said today at a briefing here on the proposals to revise the 1953 regulations.
If the effort fails to halt the slippage in water quality, New York City may have to spend $2 1/2 billion - the state's estimate - or $4 billion - the city's -to filter water from the Catskill and Delaware systems that now receives minimal treatment. New York City is already building a $600 million filtration plant for the Croton system, which lies in Westchester and Putnam counties. The Croton system supplies 10 percent of the city's water. The Catskill and Delware systems supply the rest.
The tighter controls greatly concern upstate residents, who worry about their cost and impact on the economy.
 
Imperious Attitude Resented
''I'm worried that there is very little buildable land left'' and that the new regulations will put the remaining sites off limits, said Marian Umhey, supervisor of Shandaken, a town in Ulster County that relies on tourism.
Some residents are also resentful of New York City's imposing its will in empire-like fashion.
Herbert Hekler, planning director of Ulster County, said relations between the city and upstate residents had improved in recent years. ''But if New York comes in and says you can't do this and can't do that,'' Mr. Hekler said, ''there will be hostilities.''
New York officials are going to some lengths to blunt upstate suspicions. Today's proposal was an informal draft. After absorbing local views for several months, city officials plan to reissue the regulations, hold formal public hearings and then make them final, perhaps by March 1991.
 
City and State at Odds
Overhaul of watershed regulations is part of a broader effort by the Dinkins administration to preserve drinking water quality. The city has also sued upstate sewage treatment plants and a town planning board and intends to spend $44 million to upgrade nine upstate, city-owned sewage plants.
But the watershed regulations have not been revised since 1953. Pressure to do so has come from Federal and state governments. The Federal Environmental Protection Agency has stated that municipalities can avoid building filtration plants if they can demonstrate they have adequate watershed controls.
The State Health Department has proposed that filtration is the only way to assure a safe water supply. The city and state are at odds, and the issue may be decided by the state Health Commissioner by next January.
Mayor Dinkins and Mr. Appleton say the city can ill afford a filtration plant they estimate will cost $300 million in annual operating expenses and force a rise in water rates to pay for it. The less expensive and environmentally sounder approach is tougher watershed controls, Mr. Appleton said.
 
Widened Buffer Zones
The proposed regulations prohibit discharging hazardous substances. But the rules would widen the buffer zones between water and storage areas for hazardous materials or septic systems.
The rules would also limit the paving that could be done, in an effort to reduce runoff into streams or reservoirs. Disposal of snow removed from roads and parking lots into a waterway would be prohibited.
Some activities, like building new sewage treatment systems and designing stormwater runoff plans, would require approval by the City Department of Environmental Protection. Also, department notification would be required for catastrophic events like an oil spill.

HEADLINE: S.I. Naval Base Wins a Reprieve

 BODY:
Nonetheless, the fate of the port, on which Congress has already spent $230 million, is still unclear.
Ms. Molinari's amendment would prevent closing of the port until 30 days after Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney sends Congress an overall plan on the closing and realigning of naval installations. 
Ms. Molinari said last night she did not know when that might be.
 
Dinkins Wants Base Closed
''We had anticipated the Defense Secretary would have come in with the base closure recommendations already, but he hasn't because of the Persian Gulf crisis.''
But she said she was ''very optimistic that the Defense Deparment would recommend keeping the port.'' She called it ''vital for the New York City economy.''
Mayor David N. Dinkins, who supports closing the base on the grounds that some ships stationed there would be carrying nuclear weapons, called the action ''disturbing.''
''The home port neither serves our nation's strategic interests nor protects the safety of the millions of people who live along the shores of New York Harbor,'' Mr. Dinkins said.
The port was one of six planned under a Navy program begun in the mid-1980's when the Administration's goal was a 600-ship Navy.
Ms. Molinari, who succeeded her father, Guy, in Congress last March after he stepped down to run a successful campaign for the office of Staten Island Borough President, saw the 230-to-188 vote as a victory to keep the port open.

HEADLINE: Head of Census Defends Urban Tallies

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
Census officials and members of Congress said it was difficult to assess how big a problem the challenges would represent, or when the wave of formal objections to a census count would crest. The 39,000 local jurisdictions that were given their preliminary counts during the last weeks of August each have three weeks to respond and, if necessary, challenge the bureau's counts of housing units in their areas.
Bureau officials could not say today what percentage of local responses were represented by the 1,073 challenges. They also stopped short of any assurances that all the challenges would be rechecked before the bureau numbers could be made final.
 
Complaints From Texas
During the hearing, one witness, Representative Martin Frost, Democrat of Texas, argued that the preliminary counts released last month offered clear indications that Hispanic people in his state had been missed by the bureau's enumerators. 
Mr. Frost listed the population counts for eight predominantly white, suburban counties, whose preliminary 1990 population totals all exceeded the Census Bureau's own earlier estimates.
By contrast, in eight largely Hispanic counties, including two on the Mexican border, the preliminary counts fell consistently below the Census Bureau's earlier estimates.
''The pattern is not uniformly true for every single county in Texas,'' Mr. Frost said. But he added, ''It does occur often enough to raise very serious questions about the accuracy of the count in my state.''
 
Skepticism From Pennsylvania
Representative Tom Ridge, a Pennsylvania Republican whose district in and around the City of Erie showed a sharp decline in population, said he had ''a real strong feeling'' that the census bureau would be fielding many challenges.
''Do you have the time and resources to check all of them?'' he asked Dr. Bryant.
She responded that the bureau was ready to recheck housing units in as many as 500,000 local neighborhoods, which are designated as ''blocks'' on census maps. Other census officials said later that the bureau had set aside money to recheck up to 2.1 million individual housing units.
Others at the hearing questioned how much the housing counts could augment the 1990 census. Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who has been an outspoken critic of the census, said local jurisdictions might have little recourse if the possible shortage in the preliminary figures was caused by people, rather than homes, being missed.
The bureau has until mid-October to assess the challenges, which will come in on a staggered basis until Sept. 24, said John J. Connolly, an assistant to Dr. Bryant.
New York City's challenge, reflecting its review of more than 30,000 census ''blocks'' is due Sept. 19.
While those operations and other last-ditch efforts to augment the preliminary census count of 245.8 million are under way, a parallel process has begun. Bureau statisticians are now beginning their evaluations of a just-completed survey that is considered a crucial measure of how well the original census counted minorities, inner-city residents and the poor.
 
Questions From 1980
The success of this mini-census of 150,000 homes around the country is considered a critical element in the Commerce Department's eventual decision as to whether the flaws in the count are so severe that it should be statistically corrected.
New York City, Los Angeles, Chicago, Houston and Dade County, Fla., filed a lawsuit after the 1980 census seeking to force such a statistical correction of the 1990 count to insure that final figures accurately reflected minority and inner-city populations. That lawsuit is still pending, but in a 1989 agreement the Commerce Department agreed to conduct the mini-census to make an adjustment possible.
At today's hearing two witnesses, Robert S. Rifkind, a lawyer for New York City, and Eugene Ericksen, a statistican in favor of adjustment, questioned whether the bureau was deliberately complicating the completion of the analysis of the mini-census.
The subcommittee chairman, Representative Thomas C. Sawyer, an Ohio Democrat, joined Mr. Ridge in questioning Mark W. Plant, Commerce Department Deputy Under Secretary for economic affairs, as to whether the completion of the analysis was being jeopardized. They asked if the department was setting a higher standard of accuracy for the mini-census than for the 1990 count itself.
Mr. Plant, responding to the Congressmen, said '' We have to make sure that the Secretary has sufficient information to make a decision.'' Census Director Defends Her Agency Over Its Urban Tallies Why are so many moving vans going in the same direction? By FELICITY BARRINGER WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 - The director of the 1990 census responded heatedly today to officials of New York City and other towns and cities around the country who have widely criticized the preliminary census figures that they contend severely undercounted their populations.
Making her first public statements since the Census Bureau began releasing the preliminary figures last month, the Director, Barbara Everitt Bryant, challenged assertions by New York officials that the census failed to count 600,000 people, and that the count should show a large population increase over 1980.
Speaking at a Congressional hearing, she said in response to New York complaints: ''Why did the school enrollment drop by 54,000? Why do the moving vans show more people going out than coming in?''
''If local governments think there are more people out there, let them take out a were-you-counted form and find the people for us,'' she said, referring to the bureau's continuing program to find people missed when census counters did their work in the spring.
 
Challenges Come Early
After appearing before the House Post Office and Civil Service subcommittee on census and population, Dr. Bryant disclosed that 1,073 local jurisdictions had already filed challenges to the preliminary census figures only two days into the three-week period that localities have to respond to the figures.
Census officials and members of Congress said it was difficult to assess how big a problem the challenges would represent, or when the wave of formal objections to a census count would crest. The 39,000 local jurisdictions that were given their preliminary census counts during the last weeks of August each have three weeks to respond and, if necessary, challenge the bureau's counts of housing units in their areas.
Bureau officials could not say today what percentage of local responses were represented by the 1,073 challenges. They also stopped short of any assurances that all the challenges would be rechecked before the bureau numbers could be made final.
 
Complaints From Texas
During the hearing, one witness, Representative Martin Frost, Democrat of Texas, argued that the preliminary census counts released last month offered clear indications that Hispanic people in his state had been missed by the bureau's enumerators.

By contrast, in eight largely Hispanic counties, including two on the Mexican border, the preliminary 1990 counts fell consistently below the Census Bureau's earlier estimates.
''The pattern is not uniformly true for every single county in Texas,'' Mr. Frost said. But he added, ''It does occur often enough to raise very serious questions about the accuracy of the count in my state.''
 
Skepticism From Pennsylvania
Representative Tom Ridge, a Pennsylvania Republican whose district in and around the City of Erie showed a sharp decline in population, said he had ''a real strong feeling'' that the census bureau would be fielding many challenges.
''Do you have the time and resources to check all of them?'' he asked Dr. Bryant.

Others at the hearing questioned to what degree the housing counts could augment the 1990 census. Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who has been an outspoken critic of the census, said local jurisdictions might have little recourse if the possible shortage in the preliminary figures was caused by missed people rather than missed houses.
The bureau has until mid-October to assess the challenges, which will come in on a staggered basis until Sept. 24, said John J. Connolly, an assistant to Dr. Bryant.
New York City's challenge, reflecting its review of more than 30,000 census ''blocks'' is due Sept. 19.
While those operations and other last-ditch efforts to augment the preliminary census count of 245.8 million are under way, a parallel process has begun. Bureau statisticians are now beginning their evaluations of a just-completed survey that is considered a crucial measure of how well the original census counted minorities, inner-city residents and the poor.

The success of this mini-census of 150,000 homes around the country is considered a critical element in the Commerce Department's eventual decision as to whether the flaws in the census count are so severed that the count should be statistically corrected.
New York City, Los Angeles, Chicago, Houston and Dade County, Fla., filed a lawsuit after the 1980 census seeking to force such a statistical correction of the 1990 count to insure that final figures accurately reflected minority and inner-city populations. That lawsuit is still pending, but in a 1989 agreement the Commerce Department agreed to conduct the mini-census to make an adjustment possible.

The subcommittee chairman, Representative Thomas C. Sawyer, an Ohio Democrat, joined Mr. Ridge in questioning Mark W. Plant, Commerce Department deputy undersecretary for economic affairs, as to whether the completion of the analysis was being jeopardized. They asked if the department was setting a higher standard of accuracy for the mini-census than for the 1990 count itself.
Mr. Plant, responding to the Congressmen, said '' We have to make sure that the Secretary has sufficient information to make a decision.''

HEADLINE: GOVERNOR VICTOR IN MINNESOTA VOTE

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
Although Mr. Perpich opposes abortion, supporters of abortion rights did not mobilize the kind of national effort for Mr. Hatch that they have done in other states where opponents of abortion faced supporters of abortion rights.
The winner of the Republican nomination was Jon Grunseth, a businessman, who in the last days of the campaign bought thousands of dollars in television time to attack his opponent, State Auditor Arne Carlson, who had been favored to win the nomination. Mr. Grunseths, like Mr. Perpich, opposes abortion; Mr. Carlson supports legal access to abortion.
 
Questions About Integrity
Mr. Dyson survived a strong challenge in Maryland's First District from state Delegate Barbara Kreamer. He narrowly won re-election in 1988 after controversy over his financial support from military contractors ensnared in the Pentagon procurement scandal, and Ms. Kreamer attacked his integrity again in this campaign, She made an issue of the disclosure in the final days of the campaign that Mr. Dyson, a member of the House Armed Services Committee and a strong supporter of the military, had been a conscientious objector during the Vietnam War. 
But she was hamstrung in getting her message across in the sprawling district that stretches across the television markets of Baltimore, Washington and Salisbury in southeast Maryland and the Eastern Shore.
Ms. Kreamer's staff said she bought television time in Salisbury, on the Eastern Shore, and, in the final days, in Baltimore. But she could not afford spots on Washington television stations, which cover about 25 percent of the district.
With 70 percent of the precincts reporting at 11 P.M., Mr. Dyson won his party's nomination with 56 percent of the votes to Ms. Kreamer's 30 percent. The remaining votes were split by two minor candidates.
Wayne Gilchrest, who barely lost to Mr. Dyson two years ago, won an eight-way Republican primary for another opportunity to challenge Mr. Dyson.
 
Replay in Rhode Island
In Rhode Island, Bruce Sundlun, a millionaire businessman, won the Democratic nomination for governor. Gov. Edward D. DiPrete, a Republican who raised taxes after promising not to, is viewed as very vulnerable in his race for a fourth two-year term.
Mr. Sundlun defeated the Mayor of Providence, Joseph R. Paolino Jr., and the Mayor of Warwick, Francis Flaherty, in the Democratic primary today.
In Vermont, former Gov. Richard A, Snelling won the Republican nomination to seek his old job. He will face the winner of the Democratic primary, Peter Welch, former president pro tem of the State Senate. Gov. Madeleine M. Kunin, a Democrat, decided not to run again.
Representative Peter Smith won the Republican nomination to for re-election to Vermont's lone House seat for the second time. His main challenge will be from the independent candidacy of former Mayor Bernard Sanders of Burlington, a Socialist, who had no opposition in today's voting. Two Democrats sought their party's nomination but politicians said neither of them would be as strong a candidate as the well-known Mr. Sanders.
In another comeback effort, Evan Mecham, impeached as governor of Arizona in 1988, ran against four other Republicans, lead by Fife Symington, a Pheonix developer. The Republican nominee will face Terry Goodard, who resigned as Mayor of Phoenix to seek the governorship, once held by his father. He won the Democratic nomination over token opposition.
Three Republican Governors - Judd Gregg of New Hampshire, Edward D. DiPrete of Rhode Island and Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin - had token primary opposition.
But the weakened political position of Mr. DiPrete, who promised not to raise taxes but did so when Rhode Island's economy deteriorated, drew three Democrats into a fierce battle for their party's nomination to challenge the Republican incumbent.
Mr. Gregg easily defeated the operator of a nudist camp, Robert Bonser.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
ABOUT EDUCATION

BYLINE: By Fred M. Hechinger

 BODY:
Donald Stewart, president of the College Board, which administers the tests, cited a recent survey that found that more than half of the country's high school students read no more than 10 pages a day. ''Reading is in danger of becoming a lost art among too many American students, and that would be a national tragedy,'' he said.
Much of the debate in the last year has been on education's goals and ways to keep tabs on the schools' progress in reaching those goals. The Governors, largely in agreement with President Bush, have proclaimed their educational wish list: by the year 2000, all children would start school ready to learn; 90 percent of high school students would graduate, competent in basic subjects; American students would lead the world in math and science, and schools would be drug-free and safe. 
This week, at the starting gate of the race toward those goals, schools seem weighed down with a lot of ballast. Reflecting the downturn in the economy, many districts find their budgets cut.
Even though teachers' salaries have improved slightly, to an average of $33,300 a year, teachers are unhappy. A new report by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching finds that 96 percent of the teachers say they must spend their own money to pay for some necessary supplies.
Almost half of the 21,000 teachers questioned felt they lacked control over their professional lives. Ernest L. Boyer, the foundation's president, said, ''We've had much discussion about school-based management in recent years, yet our data reveal that when it comes to crucial decision-making, teachers often are left out.'' He expressed the ''uncomfortable feeling'' that the school reform movement ''has begun to stall.''
The endorsement of school-based management - letting each school be run the way its leaders think is best for the children - is a revolt against a dominating bureaucracy.
To succeed, the revolt needs well-educated and highly motivated teachers and principals. Yet the improvements in teacher training, licensing and certification have run into roadblocks.
Yesterday's promise too often becomes today's failure. For example, only a few years ago the policy of making failing students repeat a grade was thought to be beneficial. It turned out to be not necessarily so. In New York City, Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez reported that 40 percent of those who had once been held back would later drop out of high school. Perhaps one reason was that the extra year apparently gave them no help toward success.
Critics of the way the schools are run ask whether such matters should be subject to standardized policies. Or should the decision on whether a student is held back be made on an individual basis by teachers, principals and parents?
The answer to that question may also hold the answer to whether there is hope for the public schools.
There is hope if there are enough teachers like the one last week on a public-television program, ''Learning in America: Schools That Work'' (MacNeil/Lehrer Productions), who said: ''The kids are first. The teacher is there for them.'' Or principals like the one who said the central office should not be a power source but a help source: ''Problems have to be solved school by school.''
There is hope if reading, writing and numbers are taught to every child. Enough successful models exist to do this. Will they be replicated?
There is hope for drug- and violence-free schools - if the society cleans up its drug and violence problems.
There is even hope that by the year 2000 all American children will enter school ready to learn - but only if there is a quick shift to emphasizing prenatal care, child care and early-childhood education, available to all, but particularly to poor children. Without that, the experts and common sense tell us, the goal is out of sight, and there will be no hope for millions of children and, ultimately, for the schools and the country.

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL

 BODY:
A number of disparate factors came together to produce the modern Napa Valley. World War II forced Americans to come to terms with the rest of the world, on which they had turned their backs; travel in the postwar years made that world and its cultural riches more accessible, and an era of unparalleled prosperity gave many American discretionary income and the time to use it. Not a few of them discovered wine.
Simultaneously, other Americans were beginning to question the harsh competitiveness and materialistic excesses of the postwar years. A surprising number of them found the meaning they sought in nature, in the land. And a fortunate few found it in growing grapes and making wine.
And what better place to do those things than in the Napa Valley, a magnificent 25-mile-long stretch of farmland nestled against the eastern slope of the Mayacamas Mountains, and only an hour's drive north of San Francisco? 
Shaw once remarked that marriage was a successful institution because it had two ideal components: maximum temptation and maximum opportunity. Wine in the 1960's and 1970's was similar. It had a growing number of people eager to drink it and a growing number of people eager to make it for those eager to drink it.
As in the Gold Rush of the previous century, a colorful crowd descended on the valley. There were disillusioned business executives and starry-eyed academics, yearning to plunge their hands into the earth and give substance to their lives. There were foreign winemakers entranced by this new El Dorado. There were old-timers in the valley who decided grapes would make them richer than almonds, and there were hippies just wandering through. Finally, there was a host of the just plain rich, buying into what they saw as a chic new life style.
Mr. Conaway describes them all, some with indignation, some with fine irony, some with deadpan humor, a few with true pathos.
There are the lordly di Pins, of Beaulieu, like characters out of Offenbach; the enigmatic and ultimately tragic John Daniel of Inglenook, and the flamboyant Mondavis, right out of Verdi. And there are the hard-working, mostly anonymous Mexican laborers and a passel of sleazy corporate types from - where else? - the East.
Napa is Mr. Conaway's setting, but he can't resist slipping away to furnace-like Modesto for the melodramatic tale of the mighty Gallo brothers. He dashes off to Bordeaux to talk about Philippe de Rothschild, then jumps back in time to recall Carry Nation and her axe.
He dwells at length on a meeting of the Gastronomic Order of the Nonsensical and Dissipatory, a group of prominent Napa Valley winemen who meet occasionally to eat and drink to excess, dress foolishly, tell off-color jokes and - violating a club rule - talk business.
And there is a hilarious account of Robert Mondavi's trip from the Napa Valley to Woodbridge, in the Central Valley, for the blessing of the grapes. Woodbridge, near Lodi, is the site of the ''other'' Mondavi winery, a big plant that turns out the family's low-end wines.
Accompanying the famous wine maker in a limousine are his wife, Margrit, the priest who will pronounce the blessing and a woman identified only as Nina, whose sole function seems to be to fawn over Mr. Mondavi. ''You're a genius, Bob,'' she says, or something similar, whenever he pauses for breath.
Mr. Conaway is a reporter with a Saroyan-like sense of humor and, here and there, a Balzac-like eye for detail. If he had limited himself to these portraits and vignettes, he would have produced a delightful but ultimately slight book. But he has a larger agenda.
Only a few far-sighted people in the late 1950's and early 1960's understood the Napa Valley's potential as a world-class wine region. The tract developers were poised, ready to pounce, and the landowners, tired of scratching a living from prunes and cattle, were ready to accomodate them.
In a no-holds-barred battle that raged for years - and this is Mr. Conaway's real story - the people who wanted to save the land eventually won. The valley became an agricultural preserve with a minimum lot size of 20 acres. Subdividing was finished and the valley's future, at least for a time, was assured.
The valley had been saved, but for what? Two decades later it was well on its way to becoming something of a wine Disneyland. All summer long, the main road through Yountville and Oakville and Rutherford and St. Helena is jammed with tourist traffic. Wineries have become souvenir shops selling hats, T-shirts and corkscrews, and St. Helena, once an attractive little country town, has become a collection of banal tourist shops and trendy restaurants.
Worse, some of the biggest wineries have become giant wine factories, but not for Napa wines. They regularly truck in millions of gallons of cheap wine from other parts of the state to be bottled in the valley. The vines around their tasting-room doors are there to fool the tourists.
They did not fool the grape growers in the valley who depended on the wineries as customers for their grapes. ''What is a winery?'' the growers asked. ''A souvenir shop? A bottling plant?'' They demanded a moratorium on new wineries and a requirement that all wines bottled in Napa contain 75 percent Napa grapes. (They prevailed on the latter, but not the former.) Mr. Conaway throws himself into the fray reportorially (and sometimes at tedious length) but he sees the struggle as a metaphor for land-use battles everywhere. He comes down hardest on some greedy winery owners who cynically sided with the development faction to make sure their own development projects went forward.
The growers, he writes, ''considered the vintners a bunch of egomaniacs too selfish and too removed from reality to understand what they were doing to the valley by expanding and by importing grapes to be made into inferior wine.''
As for the vintners, they ''considered the growers little more than yahoos trying to create a monopoly and jack up the price of their product.''
Mr. Conaway reserves some of his deepest contempt for a particular group of vintners, who ''hungered after aristocracy, or the appearance of aristocracy.''
''Owning a winery,'' he writes, ''a California chateau, was often as close as they could get. Some vintners so yearned for nobility that they pursued barons, counts and princes, entering into deals with them and otherwise celebrating the association.
''It was good public relations, good marketing. But their one opportunity for truly noble behavior - to protect the land absolutely -they squandered in ego gratification and profits.''
 
TASTINGS
Gewurztraminer, Zind-Humbrecht, Herrenweg Turckheim, 1988; about $13.
 
First, let's get the terminology down. The wine is from Alsace, which is in France, in spite of all those Germanic jaw-breakers. Gewurztraminer is the grape, Zind-Humbrecht is the producer, and Herrenweg Turckheim is the vineyard. Zind-Humbrecht is in the little Alsatian town of Wintzenheim and Wintzenheim is just down the road from Turckheim. Why so much verbiage? To let you known that this wine is from a single vineyard. Most producers in Alsace buy grapes from many growers. Only a few own vineyards that are big enough to grow sufficient fruit to make single-vineyard wines. Leonard Humbrecht makes some of the finest wines in Alsace, and this one is especially rich. It tastes of nuts and fruit and spices, and while it can be drunk with food, it is really much better on its own, as an aperitif. Why does Mr. Humbrecht call his business Zind-Humbrecht? Because Zind is his wife's name and, so the story goes, her dowry included a very good vineyard.

HEADLINE: Kuwaiti Bank Serves An Economy in Exile

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
Today, most of the bank's top managers are in London, where the bank is trying to incorporate after managing to smuggle its records out of Kuwait. Some American and European banks have restored credit lines, and about half of the bank's $14 billion in assets is outside Kuwait. Of Kuwait's six largest banks, it is the only one up and running so far.
Oil and finance had been the twin engines of the Kuwaiti economy. So, not surprisingly, executives of the state-owned oil industry have also set up shop here, housed in the offices of Kuwait Petroleum International, which is in charge of Kuwait's extensive refining and marketing operations in Europe. 
Sheik Salem Abdul-Aziz al-Sabah, the governor of Kuwait's central bank, is working out of the London headquarters of the state-owned Kuwait Investment Office, which oversees a large portion of Kuwait's estimated $100 billion in foreign investments. Sheik Salem has been holding meetings almost daily with executives of the banks.
Before the invasion, the National Bank of Kuwait seemed to have everything going for it. While Kuwait's five other big banks, which were badly hurt by financial scandals and the collapse of the country's stock market in 1982, still had to depend on Government support, the National Bank of Kuwait was self-sufficient. With a market capitalization of $3.5 billion, it accounted for about 40 percent of the value of companies listed on Kuwait's stock exchange.
Besides being Kuwait's biggest bank, it had the reputation for being the best run and seemed well positioned to take advantage of an expected resurgence of the economies of the Persian Gulf region.
But after the invasion, its future looked anything but certain. Not only were half of its assets in Kuwait, but so were vital records. To make matters worse, the bank - like other financial institutions with Kuwaiti ownership - had to contend with severed lines of credit and a freeze on assets imposed by many governments.
 
'First Weeks Were a Nightmare'
Mr. Dabdoub, a Palestinian who has been with the bank 31 years, recalled the despair that prevailed at a board meeting on the afternoon of Aug. 2, in a room heavy with anxiety about the future of the bank and relatives in Kuwait.
''One of our board members actually cried,'' Mr. Dabdoub said, adding that while his wife and two children are out of Kuwait, other relatives and friends are still there. ''The first weeks were a nightmare.''
It was his round-the-clock struggle to save the bank, Mr. Dabdoub insists, that enabled him to cope emotionally. ''Work is the best therapy,'' he said. ''I really forgot everybody. My priority is the survival of the bank. It is my baby.''
The bank was lucky: six of the eight people on its board were not in the country when the Iraqis invaded. Of its five senior executives, only one is trapped inside Kuwait.
 
Branches Overseas
Unlike the other big Kuwaiti banks, it had branches in Singapore, New York, London, Bahrain and Paris, and two wholly owned subsidiaries in London and Geneva. And the vast majority of countries around the world, including the United States, have either lifted the asset freeze or given the bank enough leeway to function.
Of its foreign assets of about $7 billion, half was in loans and half in money-market securities. About 40 percent of those assets are in Britain and 20 percent in the United States.
After the invasion, the bank's first priority was to increase liquidity, to make sure it could meet its financial obligations and satisfy customer demands for funds, executives said. In the first two weeks, the bank sold about $1 billion of high-quality corporate loans and $400 million in securities. The bank also reduced by $1 billion its money-market positions.
Also making life easier, a handful of American, German and British banks - including Morgan Guaranty, Bankers Trust, Chemical Bank and Manufacturers Hanover - have restored lines of credit. But many, including Citicorp and Japanese institutions, are still refusing, and the total credit lines ''are nothing compared to before,'' said one National Bank of Kuwait executive, who declined to be more specific.
The Kuwait Investment Office is also helping. It has made $300 million available to the bank; about $100 million has been used.
Members of Kuwait's cabinet in exile have also been touring the capitals of world powers. They have been trying not only to make sure that international pressure on Iraq is maintained, but also to build confidence in the Kuwaiti businesses and financial institutions operating in exile.
The Kuwait Investment Office, which was secretive before the invasion, has not become any more forthcoming. But at news conferences in late August, Kuwait's Finance Minister, Sheik Ali al-Khalifa al-Sabah, hinted that Kuwait's state-owned companies, including the investment office, might increase their holdings of British stocks, whose prices he thought were low. The Kuwaiti Investment Office already has sizable stakes in British Petroleum and Midland Bank.
He also said that the state-owned companies, which hold big stakes in Daimler-Benz A.G., Hoechst A.G. and Metallgesellschaft A.G., planned to buy more German stocks. He said 36 to 38 percent of the Kuwait Investment Office's holdings were in Europe.
 
Pledges of Support
Besides helping Kuwaiti banks, the investment office has other demands on its resources: the Government in exile has pledged to provide $2.5 billion to support the multinational military forces in the Persian Gulf and $2.5 billion to help countries like Turkey and Egypt that are being hurt by the United Nations trade sanctions against Iraq.
In addition, the Government has promised to supply generous aid to exiled Kuwaitis. It plans to allocate about $55 million a month, according to The Financial Times. There may be as many as 250,000 of these exiles, with the vast majority in Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, Qatar and Oman.
The National Bank of Kuwait has also been trying to help exiles. For 10 days after the invasion, the bank offered to pay 500, or $930, to any Kuwaiti who had an account with it, no matter how small. And even though Kuwaiti dinars became worthless after the invasion, the bank still exchanges them at the rate that prevailed before the invasion: $3.46, or 1.80, to the dinar.
''The message we would like to give is, Kuwait is not really sand dunes and camels,'' Mr. Dabdoub said. ''It's a small, international country whose financial institutions are international and sophisticated enough to survive outside.''
 
Banker Criticizes Arafat
Although a Palestinian - one of the 300,000 to 400,000 who had been living in Kuwait - he makes it clear that his loyalties do not lie with Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, and the many Palestinians who support President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.
''I don't agree with Arafat at all,'' Mr. Dabdoub said. ''He has been attacking Israel on the premise of the illegality of its occupation.''
But now, he added, Mr. Arafat ''is approving an illegal occupation'' in the case of Kuwait.
Mr. Dabdoub added: ''It doesn't make sense. I think he has bet on the wrong horse.''

Dabdoub, chief executive of Kuwait's largest bank, the National Bank of Kuwait, oversaw the shift of the bank's headquarters to London after the Iraqi invasion. (National Bank of Kuwait, Reuters)

LENGTH: 774 words

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
See Who's Dying For Regulation

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
When airline safety rules were written in the 1940's and 50's, child seats were not an issue because practical restraints did not exist. Children too young to sit up in an ordinary airplane seat were safer in their parents' arms.
But since 1985, portable restraints have been widely available and all airlines now allow passengers to bring them on board. The only catch: children on laps ride free. To guarantee a seat to anchor a child restraint, parents must pay. According to airline estimates, four of five families would rather take a chance than come up with the extra cash. 
Child seats became a public issue after the United Airlines DC-10 crash in Sioux City, Iowa, in July 1989, in which a 23-month-old toddler was ripped from his mother's arms and suffered fatal injuries. Six months later, another baby died when an Avianca 707 ran out of fuel over Long Island. The National Transportation Safety Board, responsible for investigating both accidents, asked the F.A.A. to order mandatory restraints. Bills to the same end were served up in both the House and Senate. The airline industry, wishing to avoid the role of villain and perhaps scenting an opportunity to do well by doing good, decided to support the proposal.
With no organized opposition in sight it was widely assumed that the new rule would be quickly approved. But the regulators had other ideas. And, in the view of Richard MacKenzie and Dwight Lee, economists at the University of Mississippi and the University of Georgia, that is just as well.
Writing in a publication of the Cato Institute, a libertarian advocacy group in Washington, the two economists contend that the costs of restraints would far outweigh the likely benefits. Indeed, they argue, there might be no benefits at all.
A Department of Transportation study, they point out, concluded that restraints could have prevented just one infant death in the last 12 years. Another study by researchers at the Harvard Medical School estimated that the rule would save three lives every five years. On the other hand, they note, the F.A.A. has estimated that the airlines would sell an extra 3.3 million seats annually, at a cost to consumers of $205 million.
Much of that $205 million would represent a revenue windfall, as airlines charged for seats that would otherwise have flown empty. And in a competitive market, one would expect that a lot of this cash would be recycled in the form of lower fares for other passengers. But a portion represents a real cost, because airlines would undoubtedly add flights to meet some of the extra demand for reserved seats.
Worse yet, says the F.A.A., the parents of a fifth of the babies who now fly would be priced out of the air. And since car travel is at least 20 times as dangerous as commercial air travel, the net number of infants - and parents - dying en route would rise.
Airlines might be put under pressure to adopt a free-fare policy for babies, thereby assuring that the child restraint rule would, on balance, be a lifesaver even if parents were unwilling to pay for the extra security. But that still leaves the nagging question of social costs and benefits.
Suppose two of three infants would fill otherwise empty seats. The remaining one in three - 1.3 million children a year flying at a bottom-line cost of, say, $60 a flight - would add $78 million a year to the nation's air travel bill. If it is indeed worth $70 million-plus to avoid less than one death a year, why stop there? Why not, for example, make it a national policy to entice parents from their cars with Government subsidies for air travel?
One answer, of course, is that people contemplating the expenditure of $78 million to prevent an airline fatality might want to spend a few dollars saving babies from more cheaply avoided hazards. Come to think of it, they might even want to save a few adults.

GRAPHIC: Drawing

HEADLINE: 2 Companies Agree to Use Product From Rain Forest

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
The objective is to encourage the local population to preserve the rain forest and harvest a renewable crop instead of cutting down the trees for logs.
In addition to buying buttons from Ecuadorean harvesters, the companies will pay a licensing fee to Conservation International, a Washington-based organization,. The fee will be used to market buttons and other products made from the tagua.
Patagonia, based in Ventura, Calif., expects to buy $80,000 to $90,000 worth of buttons in the first year. Smith & Hawken, based in Mill Valley, Calif., plans to spend $50,000 to $60,000 on the tagua. The combined fee the companies will pay Conservation International is $50,000.
The development of a new industry based on a local product would help promote economic growth in the area, where the annual per capita income is less than $1,000 a year, according to an official of the Corporacion de Investigaciones para el Desarrollo Socio-Ambienta, an Ecuadorean conservation group that will coordinate the program.

HEADLINE: Nissan Adds New Model Of Infiniti Car

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 11

 BODY:

 
Emphasis on Handling
Along with the Toyota Motor Corporation's more successful line of Lexus luxury cars, the Infiniti lineup aims squarely at buyers of European luxury brands, including Jaguar, BMW and Mercedes-Benz. Like the European makers, Infiniti and Lexus have stressed handling and performance, sumptuous interior appointments and ample leg room.
William R. Bruce, a Nissan vice president and general manager of the Infiniti division, said that about 30 percent of Infiniti customers traded in a BMW, Jaguar or Mercedes. Another 30 percent traded in a Lincoln, made by the Ford Motor Company, or a Cadillac, manufactured by the General Motors Corporation. 
Mr. Bruce said today that Infiniti aimed to sell 40,000 cars in the 1991 model year, which begins in a few weeks, more than double the 17,000 Infinitis sold in the United States since the line's introduction in November. The G-20 is expected to account for a third of the line's sales in the next model year; about half of the total sales would be of the top-of-the-line Q-45 model, with the M-30 coupe and a new M-30 convertible accounting for about 15 percent.
 
Could Hurt Maxima Sales
But if Infiniti reaches its goal of selling 14,000 of the G-20 sedans, it could cut into sales of the Nissan Maxima, which is about the same size as the G-20 and is similarly priced.
''Our exercise is not intended to cannibalize Maxima sales,'' Mr. Bruce said, but he acknowledged that ''there will be some cross-shopping'' by prospective buyers.
Infiniti plans advertising that emphasizes the luxury appointments and long list of standard equipment, as well as Infiniti's 24-hour road service and more extensive warranties than Nissan currently offers.
One new extra from Infiniti is a computerized suspension system -the first of its type on a production car - which independently adjusts the height of each wheel, giving an improved ride over bumpy roads and around corners. The ''active suspension'' system, which Infiniti is offering as an option on the Q-45, costs $4,000.
It also adds 120 pounds to the car's weight and reduces mileage by about 2 miles a gallon. But Nissan executives say they do not expect prospective buyers of the Q-45 to be put off by that, since they already pay a Federal ''gas guzzler'' tax of $500, which is included in the car's $39,000 price.

HEADLINE: Small Rise In Trade Gap

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
The Commerce Department compares how much the nation spends on imports with what it earns from exporting goods and services, including banking, financial transactions, overseas earnings and tourism.
The first-quarter shortfall was the smallest in five years, and the combined deficit in the first half of 1990 was the smallest of any six-month period in more than six years, the department said. 
Last year, the current account deficit shrank to $110.03 billion, from $126.55 billion in 1988 and a peak of $153.96 billion in 1987.
Economists attributed much of the improvement in the deficit in the first half of this year to the slowing economy, which has dampened demand for foreign goods, rather than a dramatic improvement in the sale of United States goods.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Dire Forecast On Oil Supplies

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Because of the difference in quality, making up the resulting supply shortage will require far more than the 4.2 million barrels a day being lost from the two Middle East countries.
In all, the replacement oil, from such countries as Saudi Arabia, Nigeria and Venezuela, is likely to produce about 8.5 percent less gasoline and home heating oil per barrel, Mr. Leuffer said. That means that more than an additional 500,000 barrels a day are needed, he estimates.
That plays an important part in Mr. Leuffer's estimate that even with additional production from a variety of sources, the world will need to draw down inventories of crude oil and products by 1.4 million to 2.5 million barrels a day in the final three months of this year, assuming that the embargo against Kuwaiti and Iraqi oil remains in force. In the first quarter of next year, when winter weather is normally more severe, he estimated the needed inventory drawdown at 1.8 million to 2.9 million barrels a day. 
That is a direr forecast than the consensus, in part because Mr. Leuffer believes it will be difficult to get additional oil production from Alaska, where he thinks that no more than an extra 100,000 barrels a day will be produced, far below the 250,000-barrel figure mentioned in Congressional testimony by a Federal energy official.
He also puts less stock than many in conservation as a means of reducing demand for oil because governments from Washington to Tokyo have been putting pressure on oil companies to restrain gasoline price increases, thus delaying conservation responses that follow higher prices. He also estimates that an additional 500,000 barrels a day of oil products will be consumed by the military buildup in the Persian Gulf.
Mr. Leuffer calculates that if his estimates are correct, world inventories by the end of next March would be cut to their lowest levels since 1979. Companies, he predicts, are likely to run out of oil supplies needed for operations, which would force countries to tap official reserves, like the United States Strategic Petroleum Reserve.
Even with that, oil prices would probably rise, which is a major reason that Mr. Leuffer forecasts that $35 oil is likely, assuming no negotiated settlement. So far, the consensus of Wall Street on the current crisis - as shown by price movements - has been that it is unlikely to endure for long. While oil for October delivery closed yesterday at $30.76 a barrel, oil for delivery in January, the height of winter, was priced at only $28.05 a barrel in New York Mercantile Exchange trading. The gasoline spread is even larger, with wholesale gasoline for October delivery trading at 93.6 cents a gallon, 14.5 cents more than gasoline for January delivery. Mr. Leuffer estimates that current share prices for oil companies reflect an anticipated $25 oil price. ''Portfolio managers simply do not believe this will last very long,'' he said.
If the Middle East crisis was to end with a negotiated settlement that lifted the embargo, oil and gasoline prices would likely fall, as would oil company share prices. But Mr. Leuffer thinks that the other options - war or stalemate - are much more likely and is recommending oil stocks. He has buy recommendations on Exxon, Texaco, Kerr-McGee, Occidental, Pennzoil, Unocal and USX. He also likes Crown Central, a refiner.
Refiners could end up being major beneficiaries of any shortage. ''What we see is a shortage of oil, but an even greater shortage of products,'' Mr. Leuffer said, adding that refineries were already operating near capacity before the crisis began. ''That will ultimately boost refining margins.'' One thing that could go wrong with bullish forecasts for oil company shares is Government action. A windfall profits tax could slash profits for oil producers, although it is hard to imagine President Bush, a former oilman himself, making such a proposal.
But Mr. Bush did not shy away from putting pressure on oil companies not to increase gasoline prices, and Mr. Leuffer says that retail gasoline prices are still about 9 cents a gallon less than the price of crude would suggest they should be.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Modest Gains; Many Traders Focus on Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:

 
Nervous Mood
Ian Foakes, foreign exchange manager at Paine Webber International Inc. in New York, said a nervous mood prevailed in the market.
European currency dealers, meanwhile, said the dollar got a lift from speculation that the cost of German unification would undermine the mark.
The West German Government said Monday that it would pay 12 billion marks, or about $8 billion, to the Soviet Union to help repatriate that country's soldiers from East Germany. But the overall cost of unification is expected to run into the hundreds of billions of marks. 
The Japanese yen was the focus of activity on many foreign exchange markets, where dealers sold yen to pocket profits made during the currency's recent advance.
 
Renewed Interest in the Yen
The yen, which suffered when tensions first flared in the Middle East, has since regained strength. The Bank of Japan's decision to raise a key interest rate on Aug. 30 coupled with a recovery on the Tokyo Stock Exchange has renewed buying interest in the yen.
The dollar moved higher against the yen in New York, ending the day at 140.31 yen, up from 139.52 yen late Monday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 139.85 yen, up 0.42 yen from Monday's finish. In London, the dollar was quoted at 139.20 yen late in the session.
British sterling benefited from the selling of yen but still lost ground against the dollar. The pound finished at $1.8565 in New York, compared with $1.8580 late Monday. In late London activity, a pound was quoted at $1.8490, compared with $1.8565 late Monday.
Against the German currency, the dollar rose to 1.5865 marks, from 1.5820.
 
Gold Rises $1.90
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for September delivery rose $1.90 a troy ounce to settle at $380.50, after falling $10.90 on Monday. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $380.25 an ounce, or 35 cents higher than Monday's 4 P.M. bid.
Gold traded in London at a late price of $381.25 a troy ounce, down from $384.75 on Monday. In Zurich, gold was bid at $381.50 an ounce, down from $387 late Monday.
Gold in Hong Kong dropped $4.90 an ounce, to $379.6.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Chrysler Eases Attack On Japanese

BYLINE: By Kim Foltz

 BODY:
''Everything from Japan is perfect,'' he said. ''Everything from America is lousy.''
Japanese car makers were also mentioned in other ads in the series.
In the new campaign, the Japanese are never directly mentioned, although some of the ads make comparisons between Honda and Chrysler models. One spot begins by praising Honda: ''A good car the Honda Accord; no doubt about it,'' the announcer says as a beautiful shot of the car is shown. 
But the commercial quickly turns into the expected pitch for Chrysler as a Plymouth Acclaim pulls in front of the Honda. ''Compared to the Plymouth Acclaim, it has less interior room, a smaller engine, no air bag and costs $1,300 more,'' the announcer says. ''Now, we're not saying the Accord is second rate, merely second best.''
Some auto industry analysts were not surprised that Chrysler changed its anti-Japanese stance. After all, it has not significantly helped Chrysler's sales, which have been in a slump. ''The Japan-bashing obviously was not working well,'' said Tom Healy, an analyst with J. D. Power & Associates, an automobile marketing company. ''A 'Made in Japan' label is not necessarily a turnoff to many car buyers.''
Chrysler was also criticized for attacking Japanese car makers because it imports vehicles made by Mitsubishi in Japan and sells cars made in a joint venture with Mitsubishi in Illinois.
For its part, Chrysler, which spends about $700 million a year on advertising, said it had decided to modify its approach in part because research found that American consumers do not like to see other cultures criticized.
The company also decided to concentrate on ads that compared some Chrysler cars with Honda models, which it has done previously, because it found the tactic effective. Even though Chrysler's overall sales have been falling, Mr. Damoose said sales of Plymouth Acclaim have improved significantly since last spring, when ads comparing it with the Accord began to run.
The commercials are also more humorous than those in the past. ''It takes the edge off the criticism of Japanese cars,'' said David Bell, the president of Bozell, the agency that created both campaigns.
The agency also decided to give the ads a ''hip'' look to try to change some consumers' perception that Chrysler has not been moving with the times.
''We've found that a lot of people still associate Plymouth with an old-fashioned attitude,'' said Bert Gardner, an executive creative director at Bozell. ''We wanted to create a more contemporary image.''
To direct the commercials, Bozell hired Lol Creme, a former rock musician who now produces music videos. The sets on which the cars are photographed look like Broadway stage sets - they feature abstract representations of skyscrapers, mountain peaks and trees. The music sounds like a synthesized blend of Big Band tunes set to a rap music beat.
One spot features a group of dancers in clothes reminiscent of the 1960's, moving to a groovy beat as they cross the set to a 20-year-old Honda. The announcer tells viewers that Americans were once attracted to Honda because it was a well-made, less-expensive alternative to American cars.
The music and the clothes change to a 1990's version as the same group boogies back to a pack of new Chryslers and the announcer says that car buyers are now looking for well-made American alternatives to Honda.
Mr. Iacocca appears in only one commercial, for Chrysler's mini-van. Acting like a tour guide at a Chrysler factory, he explains how the mini-van has been redesigned.
In another spot about the design evolution of the mini-van, the agency used innovative computer-generated graphics that show the dashboard being reconfigured, the engine growing larger and the chassis changing shape.
It was an expensive and time-consuming commercial to create, but agency executives said it was necessary. ''The most convincing way to illustrate to consumers that the mini-van had drastically changed,'' Mr. Gardner said, ''was to show them the metamorphosis happening before their eyes.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dancers in 1960's clothes move to a groovy beat as they cross the set to a 20-year-old Honda, in this scene from a commercial created by the Bozell advertising agency to introduce Chrysler's 1991 models. (Jim Estrin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Bonn and Tokyo Are Criticized For Not Bearing More of Gulf Cost

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
On the floor, in television and newspaper interviews and in speeches to their constituents, the legislators are using startlingly abrasive language. To a considerable degree, that reflects the views of newspaper editorialists and of the general public, as reflected in recent opinion surveys.
''The most negative question you hear is why our allies aren't doing more,'' said Senator Trent Lott, a conservative Republican from Mississippi.
Representative Carroll Hubbard Jr., Democrat of Kentucky, said that ''the Japanese have been acting totally the way they usually do: if there's no profit in it for Japan, forget it.'' 
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, said the Japanese were motivated by ''greed and avarice,'' and Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, said West Germany, which plans to spend $7.5 billion to subsidize Soviet resettlement of troops now based in East Germany, ''is giving the money to the wrong people.''
In a speech on Tuesday night, Speaker Thomas S. Foley sought to quiet the rebellion, arguing that ''Japan has done more to respond to requests for assistance, arguably, than any other nation, yet finds itself more singled out'' for attack than others.
The Bush Administration is also trying to limit the damage; Mr. Bush treaded lightly on the issue in his speech Tuesday night, and Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, observed today that ''generally, we think that the response has been good,'' while conceding that ''in some cases, we think countries can do more.''
 
Potential to Damage Relations
But the potential for damage to relations with two important political and economic allies is great, and Senator Malcolm Wallop, Republican of Wyoming, warned today that ''these people who are talking this way run the risk of eroding the political support for the President's policy by focusing attention on arguments over money.''
Burden-sharing dominated the debate in the House today on the military spending bill. The amendment, proposed by Representative David E. Bonior, Democrat of Michigan, would require Japan to pay the full cost of stationing United States armed forces in that country, including their salaries, which Mr. Bonior estimated at more than $4.5 billion a year.
If the amendment became law and Japan refused to pay the costs, the United States would be obliged to begin withdrawing 5,000 of the 50,000 troops now based in Japan every year.
 
A Powerful Signal
Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, who heads the House Armed Services Committee, opposes the measure, as does his counterpart in the Senate, Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia. That makes it highly improbable that the amendment will ever reach the law books, but the vote nonetheless sent a powerful political signal, which might ultimately oblige Bonn and Tokyo to reassess their positions.
Mr. Aspin said that ''if you're picking on one country, it should be Germany, which is doing even less than Japan.'' Mr. Nunn said the Japanese response to any such legislation would be to say to the American troops, which defend United States regional interests as well as Japan, ''Adios, amigo.''
But both said they shared the general feeling that the two countries, which have the world's largest trade surpluses, two of the world's most productive economies and considerably more dependence on Middle East oil than the United States, have done too little.
 
Sending Equipment
Both countries are sending equipment to the international force, but Bonn has pledged no money yet and Japan has pledged only $1 billion.
The two nations have constitutional prohibitions against the use of their troops except in self-defense. But Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany has said he will seek to remove that prohibition from the constitution of the new, unified Germany, which is to come into being in three weeks.
Hideaki Ueda, the counselor for public affairs at the Japanese Embassy here, confirmed tonight that Japan would announce this weekend a grant of $2 billion to Turkey, Egypt and Jordan, the three countries other than Iraq that have been hardest hit by the United Nations trade sanctions. He said, ''This is not a small amount.''
''We find this criticism disturbing,'' Mr. Ueda said. ''We need to show unity. We are not fighting against each other, and we hope that reasonable men in the Senate and the House of Representatives will come to see that.''
A senior German official, who insisted on anonymity, said: ''We are astonished. We said we would bear our fair share, and we are ready to.''
Mr. Kohl is expected to present to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, who is scheduled to arrive in Bonn on Friday or Saturday, a plan for West German underwriting of American air-and sea-lift expenses in the Persian Gulf. But the official cautioned against any expectation that the Germans would make large cash grants.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
RESIST U.S. IN GULF, TOP IRANIAN CLERIC URGES ALL MUSLIMS

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 12

 BODY:
''We will never permit the United States to make a foothold or turn the region into its zone of influence wherever we are present and have influence and anywhere our words, as the voice of Islam, are heard by Muslims,'' Ayatollah Khamenei told a group that included leaders of Iranian veterans organizations.
The statement was quoted by the Iranian press agency and broadcast over Iranian radio and television.
Ayatollah Khamenei's comments were the clearest indication of Teheran's tilt toward Iraq in its confrontation with Saudi Arabia and its Western and Arab allies.
 
Linking the Pipelines
But some Iranian and Mideast experts said it was clearly in Iran's interests to see the gulf situation continue as it stands today, because it would weaken Iraq, increase Iran's oil revenue, keep the United States tied up with a regional conflict and conceivably prompt internal disturbances in Saudi Arabia, toward which Iran feels a deep antipathy. 
The Iraqi oil will be transported by idled trucks that once carried oil from Iraq to the Jordanian port of Aqaba for export before the embargo imposed by the United Nations on Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil.
Eventually, the oil industry officials said, larger quantities of Iraqi oil could be pumped directly to Iran if Iraqi and Iranian pipelines that run close to each other on both sides of the long Iranian-Iraqi border were to be linked.
In taking a position similar to that of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, who also called for a holy war to fight American troops in Saudi Arabia and for the liberation of the holy places of Islam, Ayatollah Khamenei is only supporting the position of those in the Government of Iran, like President Hashemi Rafsanjani, whose main concern is to draw the maximum benefit from the situation.
Ayatollah Khamenei bitterly criticized Saudi Arabia and other oil-producing Arab countries that invited American troops in after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2.
''Foreigners' defense of regional governments brings shame and disgrace to these governments,'' the press agency quoted him as saying. ''If these governments had relied on their nations they would have defended their national prestige, honor and dignity through resistance and devotion. Those governments defending themselves with the help of foreigners have humiliated their nations. The stain of such humiliation will not be effaced for years.''
The criticism, clearly aimed mainly at Saudi Arabia, indicates that Saudi-Iranian relations, already badly strained over the last three years, may be getting even worse.
More important, some experts on Middle East affairs argued, the development signals that an increasing number of Iranian leaders appear to believe that the American military presence in the gulf is a greater danger to Iran's vital interests than Iraq's takeover of Kuwait.
Ayatollah Khamenei's comments came after announcements about the reconciliation between the two nations, which fought a bitter war from 1980 until a cease-fire was brokered by the United Nations in 1988. With the resumption of diplomatic ties announced two days ago, the nations have exchanged prisoners of war and Iraq has withdrawn troops from Iranian territories occupied in the war, after Baghdad agreed to all terms Teheran had demanded for a peace treaty formally ending the war.
Ayatollah Khamenei raised the specter of a holy war in his speech when he said, ''Anyone who fights America's aggression, its greediness and its plans to encroach on the Persian Gulf region, has engaged in a holy war in the cause of Allah, and anyone who is killed on that path is a martyr.''
Gary Sick, an American expert on Iranian affairs, said Ayatollah Khamenei's remarks were probably motivated by Iran's desire to keep oil prices high, preserve its revolutionary credentials and keep President Hussein in a confrontation with the United States as long as possbile.
''As far as they are concerned it couldn't happen to nicer guys,'' Mr. Sick said in a telephone interview. ''They have absolutely no interest in getting militarily involved but would love for this to go on for quite some time.''
Indeed, The Teheran Times, which reflects the views of the administration of President Rafsanjani, said in an editorial today that Iraq was considering supplying food and medicine to Iraq.
''Iranian officials are convinced that the Muslim Iraqi people should not pay for the mistakes of their Government,'' the newspaper said. ''Iraqi children and women have had no role in the occupation of Kuwait by Baghdad troops.''
 
No U.S. Comment
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (Special to The New York Times) - The White House withheld comment today on Ayatollah Khamenei's statement, but senior Administration officials said they were closely watching to see if Iran moved to break the embargo against Iraq.
While officials said they expected continued Iranian adherence to the sanctions, and questioned whether Ayatollah Khamenei's statement reflected a firm decision by Iran to challenge the embargo, they acknowledged that Iran could produce a crucial break in the opposition to Iraq.
The officials said they believed Iran would not violate the embargo because it is seeking economic help from European countries, which all suppport the sanctions.
United States intelligence agencies are trying to monitor the 700-mile border between Iran and Iraq. The agencies have reported some truck movements into Iraq, but not a large flow. Washington's ability to track political developments in Iran is limited.
Officials said they had seen the reports of an Iraqi offer to give Iran oil in exchange for food and other help, but could not confirm that Iran had accepted the proposal.
The deputy State Department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, said: ''We'll have to look at more than what we've seen so far to know if there is such a deal. But we consider that Iran is firmly obligated under the U.N. sanctions to implement them, and, as I said, absent evidence that something is going on to the contrary, we would expect them to do so.''
 
15 Convicts Sent to Iran
 
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 12 (Special to The New York Times) - Fifteen escaped convicts whose fates are tied to those of Western hostages in Lebanon have been turned over to Iran by Iraqi occupation forces in Kuwait in another sign of improved relations between Baghdad and Teheran, Shiite Muslims here said today.
The 15, who were convicted of roles in bombings in Kuwait nearly seven years ago, broke out of their prison with other inmates on Aug. 2, the day Iraqi troops invaded, said Lebanese who fled Kuwait after the invasion.
A total of 17 men were convicted by Kuwait for their part in bomb attacks in December 1983 against the American and French Embassies and Kuwaiti public buildings and oil installations. Six Kuwaitis were killed and 80 wounded in the explosions. Two of the prisoners were released last year after serving their terms.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
A Historic Moment Slips By, Overtaken by Other Events

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 12

 BODY:
And yet the ''Treaty on the Final Settlement With Respect to Germany,'' to give it its full title, arguably had a significance akin to agreements familiar from every high school history text -the Versailles Treaty of 1871, from which a united Germany first emerged; and the Potsdam conference of 1945, from which the Germans emerged severed in two.
Now, after 45 years, the victorious allies were finally resolving the ''German Question'' and putting an end to the last formal remnants of occupation.
 
The Price of Full Sovereignty
They were restoring full sovereignty to a nation that had savaged Europe a half century earlier. In exchange, the Germans were renouncing all claims to ancestral lands east of the Oder and Neisse Rivers lost to Poland and the Soviet Union, restricting their military and pledging that hereafter only peace would emanate from German soil. 
More broadly, the European powers were laying the groundwork for a new European order, with a potent, wealthy Germany at its heart. Perhaps more clearly than any previous event, the treaty demonstrated the retreat of Communism from Europe. Not only the West German mark had gone East - the full Western package of liberal democracy, free-market economy and the North Atlantic alliance were being voluntarily accepted by the bankrupt rump of the ''first state of workers and peasants on German soil.''
Yet it was probably the first modern peace treaty that took pains to leave no winners or losers. The Germans, in fact, were insistent that it not be called a ''peace treaty'' at all, to underscore that it had been achieved in peace. In 1871, by contrast, a united Germany was proclaimed by Bismarck after a war against France, and in 1945 the victors had met in the midst of the smoldering ruins of the Third Reich.
 
'Without War, Pain or Strife'
But this, Chancellor Helmut Kohl declared, was ''the first unification of a country in modern history achieved without war, pain or strife.''
The statement invited a quick knock on wood, but it did reflect what the six signers - the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, France and the two Germanys - all agreed had been a harmonious and creative negotiation.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said the process had created a ''new lexicon of openness, cooperation and partnership,'' and he went out of his way to praise Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union.
The very harmony of the process was one reason why the signing of the final settlement could not attract as much attention as economic turmoil or military tension. Despite some 11th-hour haggling on technicalities and the price the Germans would pay the Soviets, the ''two plus four'' negotiations never really developed suspense.
The talks, moreover, were not really the locomotive or even the key to German unity. It was really the momentum to reunification touched off by the breach of the Berlin wall and the collapse of Communism in East Europe that had finally compelled the old Allies to resolve the nettlesome ''German Question.''
 
Forcing the Pace
In the end, the forces that brought Nazi Germany to its knees and partitioned it 45 years earlier often seemed to be pushed toward a settlement at a pace that they neither set, nor really liked.
The Soviet Union, which had, through its own internal reforms, directly empowered the East Germans to shed Communism, found itself especially uneasy at the prospect of losing its premier foothold in the West, and much of the real bargaining was over how to disentangle the Soviets from their enormous commitment to East Germany.
The solution was both bizarre and Solomonic. The Soviet Union was given four years to withdraw its army from Germany, and in the interim the Germans would help pay for the force and finance new housing for the troops when they return home. NATO forces would stay out of East German territory, though they would maintain garrisons in Berlin.
Mr. Gorbachev tried to put a positive twist on the situation, saying that the Soviet troops were now ''representatives of a friendly country.'' Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany was more blunt: the $7.5 billion deal, he said, was ''the price of unity.''
 
Credit for Gorbachev
It was not a cynical comment from Mr. Genscher. He had been among the first to recognize the promise for Germany held out by the soviet policy of ''perestroika,'' or openness, and the large majority of his countrymen shared his view that Mr. Gorbachev was the true midwife of German unity, and deserved a reward.
Military-political technicalities dominated the immediate discussion of the treaty. But if this served to obscure the historic dimensions of the accord, it also underscored its major virtue -that for once in their history, the Europeans were shaping a new order without bloodshed or trauma.
The negotiators seemed to tacitly agree from the outset that to humiliate the Russians or to frustrate the Germans would only undermine European security, and the main challenge of the negotiations became to find ways of avoiding either pitfall.
The initial breakthrough was the decision at NATO's summit meeting in July to forswear any aggressive intentions and to extend a hand of cooperation to the Soviets. That cleared the way for the next major step, the Soviet-West German summit talks at which Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Kohl agreed on a face-saving way for the Soviets to extricate themselves from East Germany while maintaining influence in European affairs.
The ''new European security order'' that both East and West have now declared as their goal, in which the two alliances would be replaced by a single conflict-resolving mechanism based on the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, is still a long way off. It will be four years before the last Soviet troops leave East Germany, and both Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union still face great upheavals.
But by making history as quietly as they did, by signing a treaty without undue debate and controversy, the authors of the Moscow treaty may have shown that shaping a new order does not necessarily require a major upheaval.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 14, 1990, Friday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the German unification treaty's place in history mistranslated the Russian word perestroika. It means restructuring; the word for openness is glasnost.
