HEADLINE: Politics of Police Strength;
New York City's Demands for More Officers Raise Questions About How to Use Them

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:

 
'Form of Political Stampede'
Police officers are among the costliest municipal employees, and New York already has a lot of them -26,000, a uniformed force twice as large as the nation's next largest - Chicago. What it does with them is only part of what is at stake in the growing clamor.
''My concern is that this whole thing is a form of political stampede because of some truly terrible crimes that have been committed,'' said Robert Gangi, executive director of the Correctional Association, a research and watchdog group that studies the justice system. ''More police, if they're part of a community policing strategy, can be an effective tool, but only if they're part of a larger plan to address the social and economic problems that drive crime.'' 
But Thomas A. Reppetto, president of the Citizens Crime Commission, another watchdog group, said of the 5,000 figure, ''An augmentation of that level is necessary, first to deal with the workload, and two, to install community policing and make it work to make a dramatic difference in the levels of crime and public order in this city.''
 
Many More Civilian Employees
The number 5,000 - cited by everyone from Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown to the Crime Commission to the City Council - is simply the difference between the current number of officers and the all-time high of about 31,000 in 1970. Restoring that total has been a formal goal of the city since at least 1984, when Mayor Edward I. Koch announced he would do so by 1988.
But the comparison is misleading because of the substantial increase in the number of civilian workers on the force, who do many tasks once performed by officers who were among the highest-paid clerk-typists in the world. In 1970, the department had 2,159 civilians; now it has 7,412, so adding 5,000 officers would put the department's actual uniformed strength well ahead of its all-time high.
City budget officials say that thanks to the civilians, when the force stood at 28,000 officers two years ago - before fiscal constraints led Mr. Koch to let it shrink - it had about as many uniformed officers available for duty as it did before the layoffs of the fiscal crisis of the mid-70's. If the separate transit and housing police forces were considered, it had even more.
 
Examining Every Unit
Crime has increased markedly since 1970, when there were 578,149 reported crimes and 1,117 murders, and last year, when there were 712,419 crimes and 1,905 murders. Serious assaults have more than doubled.
And even as the force grew, so did dozens of units and headquarters functions, which Mr. Dinkins said this week took thousands of officers from street duty. Mr. Brown has said that the department is too specialized, and he repeated in an interview yesterday that he was weighing every unit and ''its effectiveness, its goals and its mission'' for a report to Mr. Dinkins on personnel needs. The report is due Oct. 1.
However many officers are hired, Mr. Brown wants the extra power to fuel ''community policing,'' the most common image of which is officers who work on old-fashioned foot patrols in neighborhoods. It actually involves a mix of tactics - old and new - in which officers are urged to take time to emphasize solving community crime problems, rather than just cruising in patrol cars and reacting over and over again to the same kinds of crimes.
If that sounds a bit hard to define, it is. But Mr. Brown maintains it includes the aggressive hyphenated tactics of stop-and-frisk and buy-and-bust and is ''as tough as traditional policing, and tougher, because you do it smarter.'' Even hardened veterans like Mr. Reppetto of the Crime Commission, who spent years as a police commander in Chicago, say it is the wave of the future, and because it takes more time, it takes more people.
 
Other Government Approaches
''If your radio cars are now running 90 percent of the 911 calls, they can't do problem solving,'' Mr. Brown said.
Mr. Gangi complains that no one is talking about other government approaches to solving problems, like improving schools, housing and job opportunities, to keep communities stable enough to be susceptible to the effects of community policing.
''The kids who ripped off those people from Utah and killed the guy were out to rob somebody that night,'' he said. ''If there had been cops standing next to those folks, they would have robbed somebody else. You can't ever have enough cops on the street to prevent that kind of crime.''
But Mr. Reppetto said, ''What education is going to go on if all the kids are worried about is getting to school without getting shot?''
First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel said Mr. Brown's report would ''not simply be an analysis of the numbers, or how best to deploy them, but also a managerial agenda for the entire system.'' More officers will mean more arrests, which will require more prosecutors, Legal Aid lawyers, judges, courtrooms and jails - all of which take money.
 
Question of Money
But Mr. Steisel added: ''We feel it's not enough just to put money into the traditional criminal justice agencies. There are other places where we think other commitments need to be made. For example, we have to look very hard at supplementing programs for youth.''
No one yet knows how the city will pay for all this, but Mr. Dinkins now says he expects to, whether it takes $300 million, $400 million or $500 million a year, at a time when the city is facing a projected budget gap for the coming year of at least $1 billion and has not yet resolved how to bear the full cost of 1,058 new officers whom he promised last month to hire.
The Mayor warns that inevitably hiring more officers will lead to some combination of higher taxes and reduced services.
''If you're going to say that to a public, you've got to be able to explain why you need, what you need, where you're going to put it,'' he said on Tuesday. ''And so those who say 'Yeah, but you have got to say you need 5,000 cops now,' well, it seems to me that what I've been saying is eminently superior.''

HEADLINE: Cuban Defector Tells of Soviet Cuts

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Sept. 12

 BODY:
''The honeymoon has ended and now Cuba has no opportunity for re-exporting oil,'' Mr. Gonzalez said at a conference sponsored by the University of Miami's Research Institute of Cuban Studies. ''Even if they wanted to, the Soviets have no capability to maintain the kind of financial aid they have maintained during the last 30 years.''
 
Drastic Cuts Ahead
While Cuban officials have spoken in general terms about major changes in relations between the Soviet Union and Cuba, Mr. Gonzalez is the first Cuban involved in the negotiations with Moscow to reveal substantial details. 
In tense discussions in Moscow and Havana early this year, Mr. Gonzalez said, the Soviet Union informed Cuba of its intention to reduce its support drastically in almost every area of economic aid, from barter trade to subsidized prices for Cuban products and low-interest debt financing.
While Cuban officials reacted with surprise when the Soviet newspaper Izvestia published previously secret information on Cuba's debt to Moscow this year, Mr. Gonzalez said that he learned in a meeting with Carlos Rafael Rodriguez, the vice president of the Cuban Council of Ministers, that the Soviet debt figure of 15 billion rubles was, by Cuban calculations, at least 2 billion rubles too low.
The difference took on special importance, Mr. Gonzalez said, because of a warning by a Soviet Deputy Prime Minister, Leonid Abalkin, during a visit to Havana in April that Cuba's debt to the Soviet Union would be payable in dollars beginning in 1995, at an exchange rate to be determined this year.
 
'Special Period' Lies Ahead
Cuba has reacted to these and other changes in its ties with the Soviets by preparing people for what the Havana Government has called a ''special period in a time of peace,'' an era of draconian austerity that began recently when the Government announced steep reductions in supplies of electricity and gasoline.
After an initial period of hostility toward President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's restructuring program in the Soviet Union, Mr. Castro has reverted to a largely conciliatory tone.
But Mr. Gonzalez said that official Cuban disenchantment with the dwindling Soviet commitment manifests itself in complaints that many large Soviet industrial development projects are white elephants that have proven burdensome to the Cuban economy.
 
Nuclear Plant Cited
He cited an inoperative nuclear power plant that is $800 million over cost and is now encased in walls six yards thick because of concerns over safety after the Chernobyl nuclear power plant accident in the Soviet Union.
Another example, he said, was a new Soviet-built nickel plant that is at least twice as inefficient as plants dating from the 1950's.
Citing an energy shortage, the Cuban Government recently decided to close the nickel plant, Mr. Gonzalez said. But at least part of the motive for closing it, he added, was to send Moscow a message that ''if you reduce our oil supplies, we can reduce supplies to you too.''

LENGTH: 579 words

HEADLINE: FINAL DRIVE NEAR ON BUDGET ACCORD

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
''It's like buying a used car,'' said Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican whip. ''The buyer sort of thinks he likes the price of the car that he thinks he may be getting, and the seller sort of thinks he likes the price of the car he may be selling. But nobody has yet said, 'Here is the real car, and here is the real price.' '' 
 
'Everything Is Very Fluid'
Representative Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, the top Republican on the Budget Committee, cautioned that agreements that seemed solid could come unstuck.
''Everything is very fluid,'' he declared. ''Everything that seems to be dead could be revived very suddenly. Everything that is out of the packages could be in, and everything that is in both packages could be out.''
Thus, lawmakers said, general decisions made earlier this week to raise taxes on alcoholic beverages and luxury items and to reduce Medicare costs to the Government should not be considered final.
The two sides have basically agreed on the size of the deficit reduction they want to make, $50 billion in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1 and $500 billion cumulatively over the next five years. Moreover, they are not far apart on how they want to apportion the cuts in the military and domestic programs and for increases in taxes and fees.
 
Working on Tough Issues
But basic disagreements remain on which specific programs to cut and which particular taxes to raise.
''We're on the tough issues,'' said Representative Leon E. Panetta, the California Democrat who heads the Budget Committee. ''Nothing is agreed to unless everything is agreed to.''
Clearly wanting to avoid a battle of words with President Bush, Democrats refrained today from publicly criticizing him for calling in his televised address Tuesday night for a budget settlement without suggesting that politically it might be necessary to raise taxes or cut popular programs.
But lawmakers from both parties observed that they were unlikely to make friends with their budget decisions.
''We're going to lose votes on both sides,'' said Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the top Republican on the Ways and Means Committee.
Meanwhile, the General Accounting Office, the Government's chief auditor, issued a report today urging budget cuts of more than $1 trillion over the next six years. That is much more ambitious than what the negotiators are contemplating.
The deficit, the agency said, is ''out of control'' and threatens the nation's economic well-being for years to come.
No New Yorker is involved in the talks at Andrews. But all 34 of the state's Congressmen signed a letter today saying they would oppose limiting the amount of state and local tax payments that taxpayers could deduct on the Federal returns.
The White House has been advocating such a limit on deductions, but Democrats have resisted it.

HEADLINE: A Good Gulf Pep Rally

 BODY:
The President has thus earned the confidence to say that Iraqi aggression will be defeated. ''And that's not a threat, not a boast,'' he said. ''It's just the way it's going to be.'' 
Mr. Bush also has chosen the right strategy. He is tightening the world's embargo against Iraq, asking for patience and pressing ahead with his military buildup in the region. The clear-eyed purpose is to convince Mr. Hussein that he can neither outlast nor outduel the nations arrayed against him.
But in any situation this complicated, risky and volatile, there are bound to be unforeseen land mines and false steps. And several recent actions by the Bush Administration need to be explained more convincingly by the White House.
Relations with Syria. Secretary of State Baker is off to Damascus to strengthen ties with a nation that has sent troops to Saudi Arabia, and possibly to explore Syrian flexibility toward Israel. That's all well and good, but President Assad of Syria is a major supporter of anti-American terrorism. The Administration has to take the greatest care not to be fooled by him or to elevate his power, the very mistake the White House made in dealing with Saddam Hussein.
An international peace conference. Moscow has been pushing for such a meeting soon as a way of starting Israeli-Palestinian talks and encouraging moderate Arabs standing up to Iraq.
Mr. Bush seemed to back the proposal at the Helsinki summit meeting last week. But in Moscow on Tuesday, Mr. Baker gave the right response: no such conclave at any time soon, when it could be linked with the gulf crisis. At best such a gathering now would be diversionary; at worst it would reward Palestinians for their support of Iraq.
A regional security system. Administration officials continue to speculate about a peacekeeping force - U.S.-Arab, or multinational, or U.N.-sponsored - that would be created after the present crisis ends. That's a worthy idea, but the composition and purposes of such a force require much more thought.
America does not want to commit itself to the indefinite preservation of the Persian Gulf's autocratic regimes. For the long run, the U.S. should be trying to make itself less dependent on energy from this turbulent region.
All of these considerations aside, Mr. Bush did well in his address before the nation. He bought time for the noose to close around Iraq, and time to nurture support for further action if need be.

HEADLINE: Japan's One-Way Lobbying

 BODY:
These activities are entirely legal, Mr. Choate acknowledges, but also ''deeply corrosive of the U.S. political and economic system.'' One-third of the principal officials in the White House Trade Office since 1973 have left to become foreign agents, mostly for Japan. Japanese-led PAC's contribute heavily to political campaigns. Most university programs in Japanese studies rely on Japanese money, sapping academic independence, Mr. Choate says.
The money that slushes through the American political system is certainly occasion for unease. But in buying influence, Japanese companies are behaving just like Americans and other foreigners. On what basis, other than scale, is there reason to single out Japan?
The most serious reason is reciprocity. The Japanese political system is far less open than that of the United States, with intimate ties between Government ministries, industry and politicians. Foreigners are largely excluded from this tight triangle. This asymmetry could put American businesses at a considerable disadvantage.
The remedy is not to put specific restrictions on Japan's lobbying in the United States, although tighter rules for all lobbyists, domestic and foreign, may well be justified. The better course is to persuade Tokyo to make its political system more open. As with the United States, Japan's weight in economic matters gives foreigners many legitimate interests in its domestic affairs.
Japan's huge lobbying effort is fair subject for discussion, even if it buys less influence than Mr. Choate supposes. But the troubling asymmetry is better corrected with more openness in Tokyo than with more restrictions in Washington.

HEADLINE: Preventing Genocide in Liberia

 BODY:
Until the 1980's, Liberia's main divide was between indigenous people and the Americo-Liberians, descended from freed U.S. slaves. Mr. Doe's bloody coup ended the old elite's dominance. Power and patronage flowed instead to the Krahn. That favoritism, along with the regime's brutality and incompetence, sparked opposition from other ethnic groups, like the Gio and the Mano. One rebel leader, Prince Johnson, is from the Gio. His rival, Charles Taylor, is an Americo-Liberian.
The U.S. cannot be proud of its own early association with the Doe dictatorship. The Reagan Administration convinced itself that Mr. Doe could provide a strategic bulwark against Communist advance. It ignored abundant evidence of official misdeeds and popular discontent and made Liberia the largest per capita recipient of U.S. aid in sub-Saharan Africa. Congress finally cut back American support after 1985. When Mr. Doe's enemies began closing in on him earlier this year, the Bush Administration rightly resisted his pleas for help.
Instead, a peacekeeping force was raised from the 16-member Economic Community of West African States. With 5,000 Liberian civilians dead and 400,000 refugees streaming over the borders, neighboring states feared chaos. Yet the force's arrival last month touched off reprisals against foreigners and fears of a wider war.
Those concerns remain valid. President Doe's murder has not ended Liberia's ordeal. The prospect of ethnic genocide compels preventive action. From Sri Lanka to the Balkans, political opportunists have exploited ethnic rivalries in the quest for short-term advantage. Too often, their efforts have drowned their countries in blood. For taking risks to prevent the worst, West Africa's peacekeepers deserve the world's appreciation, and support.

HEADLINE: Clean Air Bills Are Likely to Cost More Than Anyone Expected

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The clean air bill being considered by Congress will pack a far greater economic wallop than anyone expected. Residents of New York State alone could pay as much as $5 billion a year for additional air-pollution controls, according to a study by Denny Technical Services. Nationwide costs of clean air proposals range between $51 billion and $91 billion a year, depending on decisions Congress will make this fall.
The Senate and House of Representatives are trying to reconcile their clean air bills in conference. If the most extreme proposals are enacted, citizens of New York would be required to pay $57 million more for controlling air toxics emissions, $160 million more for controlling acid rain and $4.8 billion more for controlling ozone - every year.
Our nation cannot ignore the enormous costs of clean air legislation, and these expenses will inevitably worsen America's economic problems. There are effective and affordable ways to clean our air. High-cost options will not necessarily mean improved environmental protection.
The business community, which my Clean Air Working Group represents, wants Congress to pass a clean air bill this year, and we believe Americans deserve a significant return on investment in improved environment. We need a law that allows us to meet our environmental goals without unduly burdening a sagging economy.
 
WILLIAM D. FAY
 Washington, Aug. 28, 1990

HEADLINE: Clean Air Bills Are Likely to Cost More Than Anyone Expected;
The Price of Breathing

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While Peter Passell's Economic Scene column on clean air (''What Price Cleaner Air,'' Aug. 15) contains valid points, one could wish he had applied himself to the question, What price polluted air? In reviewing an unpublished analysis by the economist Paul R. Portney, Mr. Passell seems to acknowledge that translating health into dollars is guesswork. Recent polls suggest, however, that most Americans place a higher value on clean air than most economists do. 
Both houses of Congress are considering amendments to the Clean Air Act that would exempt automakers from the stringent pollution controls needed to reach the Environmental Protection Agency's air-quality objectives. Critics say that not enough Americans are suffering to justify the expense. Yet E.P.A. studies indicate that approximately 40 percent of air pollution is attributable to motor vehicles. The new controls would substantially reduce auto emissions for only $130 a vehicle. Where industry sees billions of dollars in ''unjustified'' expenses, advocates, such as the American Lung Association, see a relatively small sacrifice that most Americans would accept for cleaner air.
We aren't willing to accept a new status quo in which poor air quality continues to prevent children and adults with lung diseases from enjoying the outdoors fully. We don't think economics alone should dictate solutions that ignore the needs of millions of Americans.
 
JOHN R. GARRISON
Managing Director
American Lung Association
 New York, Aug. 24, 1990

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Free The Baltics II

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A little over a year ago, an incendiary headline appeared in this space: ''Free the Baltics.'' A dispatch from a Baltic capital appeared here later with a provocative dateline: ''RIGA, Soviet-occupied Latvia.''
This went beyond the usual Op-Ed thumbsucking to the borders of naked political agitation. In neglected causes - Kurdistan for the Kurds, independence for the Balts, freedom from the polygraph - pundits are allowed to engage in such open agitprop. 
Campaigning for an end to the Soviet occupation of the three nations illegally handed to Stalin by Mr. Hitler, I confess to an ulterior motive. A return to independence by these captive nations would not only redress a great moral wrong done to Estonians, Latvians and Lithuanians. I hoped it would also be the beginning of the end of the Russian empire that went by the name of ''Soviet Union.''
The reasoning: The world would benefit from the breakup of the superpower that has supported much of the mischief in the world. The disparate peoples now in the grip of Moscow's dead hand would do better, and be less of a threat to peace, if permitted to go their own nationalist, non-Communist way.
Today, Soviet disunion is coming right along. The Balts have been leading the way, issuing proclamations of sovereignty, protesting the presence of Russian troops, publicizing the crackdowns and cutoffs intended to intimidate them.
The Bush Administration, in the beginning, treated the Baltic aspirations only ''correctly,'' protecting Mikhail Gorbachev; recently it has begun to go with freedom's flow. This includes a belated recognition of the popular support behind Boris Yeltsin, who embodies the dissatisfaction with Mr. Gorbachev's timidity in overturning the Communist apparat and economic system.
But Mr. Bush, along with most of the U.S. foreign policy establishment, is of two minds about the breakup of the internal empire.
In one mind, he likes the end to a superpower-polarized world, because now nations can act collectively to repel aggression. In his other mind, Mr. Bush hates to lose his coordinated interlocutor - the Soviet Union, now nicely weakened but still answering as an entity - in exchange for a loosely confederated group of nations, headed by a bunch of strangers, that might fall to squabbling.
We should resolve the ambiguity on the side of disunion. We should be rooting for the orderly devolution of power - independence for the Baltics, autonomy for the dozen Soviet republics, with central control limited to nuclear and space defenses.
We should be rooting against the seat-of-the-pants improvisation of Mr. Gorbachev, because drift invites anarchy; bread lines and panic could bring on a military-K.G.B. coup. Better an amicable separation, with agreed-upon custody of the nukes, than an explosive divorce.
''To be, or not to be, a united government,'' said Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov this week, arguing against a free market, ''that is the question.'' This is no time for Hamlet, lest he usher in a Caesar; this is the time for the Shatalin 500-day crash diet to organized disunion.
I am indebted to Elizabeth Teague, the brilliant Kremlinologist at Radio Free Europe in Munich, for fingering Stanislav Shatalin as the fulcrum of controversy last week. He is the Yeltsin economist advocating a free-market economy, private property and devolution of sovereignty - including the power to tax - to the republics.
With all its attendant ills - ethnic hatred, class resentment, the opportunity for personal failure - this cold-turkey Shatalin approach is a way out of Communism's addiction to false security.
It embraces a truth that Mr. Gorbachev has for five years refused to face: Political and economic freedom cannot be separated. Mr. Shatalin even dared to leave the word perestroika out of his devolutionary plan, because he knows the Gorbachev rhetoric is a smokescreen for continued central control.
How can we help this along? Not by inviting the Russians into the Middle East, or by sending trade missions to salvage their old system - but by pressing for disarmament down to our level of 6 percent of gross national product from their current 24 percent, by sending a Capitalism Corps to prepare the way for investment and by predicating our cooperation on freedom within the republics.
One final way: by urging the crumbling center in Moscow to recognize that its lust for control has been overtaken by events, and to proclaim its new realism by freeing the Baltics.

HEADLINE: New York City Will Prevail

BYLINE: By David N. Dinkins; David N. Dinkins is Mayor of New York City.

 BODY:
New York City is at war with its criminals, and the city needs help from every quarter.
 
When I arrived at
City Hall in January, I found a police force severely restricted in its size and effectiveness by the policies of the last 12 years. Over the past five months, we have deployed our troops and squeezed our budget to place the equivalent of nearly 3,000 more cops in the trenches to battle street crime.
These are not imaginary police officers, created by politicians or statisticians to placate an enraged public. These officers, skilled and dedicated, have been shifted from desk jobs and paid to work a second shift. Hundreds more will move in a few weeks from the Police Academy straight onto the streets, rather than to interim programs in borough headquarters. 
We have already placed more cops on foot patrol and have dedicated the force to the principle of community policing to choke off criminal activity before it can grow. The Police Department dispatched these officers to high-crime areas to attack the thieves, muggers and pushers on their home turf. Preliminary figures suggest that the strategy is paying off: as arrests rise, the number of criminals on the street falls, and so does the number of victims.
We did not set out to wage war by degree. We have a strategy. We have had it since April and we are implementing it. And we will prevail.
We will prevail because so many have heeded our cry to join the battle, as the City Council Speaker, Peter Vallone and Gov. Mario Cuomo have now done.
Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown will complete an analysis of the staffing needs in his department this month - the first manpower review of the department in nearly 30 years. We will then know exactly how many more cops it will take during the next several years to win this war. Whatever his number - 3,216, or the 5,000 often mentioned, or 6,481 - the city must find a way, as the Governor has made plain, to pay the bill even in this fragile economic environment.
The commitment of the Speaker and the Governor to our plan offers substantial hope that these thousands of new officers will not vanish with the next budget modification.
And we need more help. We need the Congress and the State Legislature to stand up against the gun lobbyists to give us effective laws against automatic weapons. We need business and civic leaders to come forward to fight the battle here in America's greatest and most complex urban center.
But most of all, we need the good people of New York - the great majority of the men and women of our communities - to keep the faith and stand together. We can and must roll back the wave of crime that began to afflict our neighborhoods more than 25 years ago.
In August, in neighborhoods throughout the city, residents who had hidden behind their window grates and steel doors came out to organize their communities to drive away the fear. We helped them form block patrols and have provided $1 million for communications equipment and training.
We must stop the drug runners, the child killers and the muggers, but we must also refuse to tolerate the subway fare-beaters and the car thieves. We need the calm assistance of every citizen of New York to win this war.
The plea for more personnel immediately issues from our contempt for criminals and our human need to do something, anything, in the face of inhuman behavior. Yet, more personnel is not the only solution. Paradoxically, it isn't even the best solution. Random violence cannot be cured with random solutions, sketched on the back of an envelope, then fired off into the nearest microphone.
We must not forget the irrefutable truth that if we abandon our schools, abolish drug treatment or close our libraries to pay for an ill-conceived plan to hire an arbitrary number of cops, we will soon find ourselves with more criminals wreaking more violence requiring even more cops.
Merely more officers would not eliminate group violence, the kind that introduced us to Bernhard Goetz, the Central Park jogger, Yusuf Hawkins and Brian Watkins.
Indeed, crime in the subways, particularly group violence, has risen even though the number of Transit Police officers will next month reach the highest level in the system's history. Nor would more personnel ease the torrent of automatic weapons flooding our streets. These afflictions yield only to a perceptive and determined strategy that does more than throw soldiers into the line of fire.
We have yet to deploy fully this city's greatest resource: our pride and collective will. As the Watkins family reminded us last week with such dignity and courage, we can face down the thugs if we but join hands -with our police officers and other law enforcement officials, with our business, religious and civic leaders and with each other. This is our town, and we intend to fight for it.

HEADLINE: Post at the Brink Again as Owner Seeks Wage Cuts

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
The New York Post, which has lost money for decades, is at death's door for the second time in two and a half years, and union leaders met all day yesterday with representatives of the paper's owner in an effort to hammer out an agreement that would keep it alive.
On Tuesday, Peter S. Kalikow, who owns The Post, said he would close the paper unless unions agree to $18.5 million in wage and benefit concessions by 8 P.M. Friday. Last week he set a deadline of midnight Saturday, but revised it so that The Post could announce its own salvation - or demise -on Saturday.
''I desperately want to keep it open,'' Mr. Kalikow said in an interview yesterday. But he added that he was not willing to put more money into a paper that has cost him more than $100 million since he acquired it in 1988. 
Mr. Kalikow said he wants to preserve The Post in part because it is the city's only politically conservative paper. And on most days, he said, he does not regret buying it.
But his weariness is apparent. He said the prospective buyers that courted him last year ''have evaporated'' more recently, and added that he negotiated to sell the paper this spring to a buyer he declined to identify, but the deal fell through.
Union leaders say that they do not think that Mr. Kalikow is bluffing. In general, they subscribe to the popular wisdom that New York City cannot support more than two daily newspapers, and have long regarded The Post's continued existence as a gift made possible by a rich person's whim.
The death of the city's oldest daily - it was founded in 1801 by Alexander Hamilton - would silence New York City's most unrepentantly sensational newspaper voice. In typical Post style, its headline yesterday shrieked ''Salaam Baloney!'' in reference to a poem read by Yusef Salaam at his sentencing for his part in the rape and beating of a jogger in Central Park.
 
Painful Proposals
George E. McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council, the umbrella organization for the paper's nine unions, said there was little progress in yesterday's talks, although he remains ''optimistic'' that a deal can be struck. Though the Allied includes 10 unions, the small Photoengravers Union has no members at The Post.
Mr. McDonald said that moving up the deadline is unlikely to make a difference. ''If we're going to do it, we can do it by Friday,'' he said.
But the cost cutting would be painful. For instance, Barry F. Lipton, president of the Newspaper Guild, said late yesterday that The Post had effectively demanded a 46 percent cut in wages and benefits from the Guild's 352 members, who include newsroom, advertising and circulation employees. The Post has essentially ruled out layoffs as a means of achieving the $5 million or so in savings it has demanded of the Guild, because current staffing levels are already lean.
Mr. Lipton said he has been unwilling to accept such huge salary cuts, adding ruefully, ''We're going to keep at it.''
 
A Word From The News
The negotiations were further complicated Tuesday when The Daily News notified the Guild that it would seek for itself any cost reductions granted The Post. Mr. Lipton, the Guild's president, described The News's action as an attempt to scuttle The Post negotiations and put a competitor out of business. He said The News has no legal right to concessions the union might give Mr. Kalikow.
A News spokesman, John T. Sloan, said his paper hopes The Post survives, but has an obligation to the shareholders of The Tribune Company, The News's parent company, to pursue the savings because The News is also facing severe economic hardship.
William Adler, a spokesman for The New York Times, said yesterday that The Times ''would seek to gain concessions as well,'' to the extent that they were related to the same adverse economic conditions that have affected The Post and The Daily News.
But Mr. McDonald said that under the language of The Times's contract, which expires in March 1993, it would not be entitled to concessions given to The Post.
 
Seat on the Board
Mr. Kalikow said that his plan is to reduce The Post's overall annual costs to the break-even point, and that he is willing to operate indefinitely without a profit. He said he would give unions a stake in the paper's ownership and a seat on the board.
But he said he would no longer subsidize the operation.
In documents presented to the paper's unions, he has estimated 1990's costs to be $108 million, which would mean a $27.5 million loss if revenues are the expected $80.5 million.
In addition to slashing union expenses, he has cut management staff, negotiated lower newsprint prices and plans to reduce the number of pages in the paper.
Yesterday, the city announced that The Post would be given reduced electrical rates that could save the paper $8.3 million over 20 years, under an economic development program used since 1985 to keep businesses in the city and preserve jobs. A spokesman for Mayor David N. Dinkins said the rate reduction would be available even if The Post's work force is reduced.
The Post has operated in the red virtually without interruption for almost two decades and newspaper analysts are skeptical that the hemorrhage could be stopped for long, even with a 25 percent cost reduction.
 
Advertising Slump
''I think it would be just temporary relief,'' said Kevin R. Gruneich, a newspaper analyst for First Boston Company, an investment banking firm in New York City.
All of the city's dailies, including The News, The Times and New York Newsday, have suffered advertising declines as the region's economy has slumped during the last 18 months, and no end to the trough is in sight.
In a tight advertising market, with fierce competition for every available dollar, The Post is at a particular disadvantage. It has no Sunday paper, which is the other papers's principal advertising vehicle, and also has a smaller circulation than the others, if Long Island Newsday's readers are included with New York Newsday's.
Many of The Post's traditional advertisers, like Korvette's, have closed, and there is also a reluctance by many retailers to advertise in a publication that Mr. Kalikow, with some pride, describes as ''a little bit crazy.''
 
History of Decline
In 1988, the year Mr. Kalikow acquired The Post from Rupert Murdoch, the paper's advertising dropped 20 percent, and then declined another 13.5 percent in 1989, according to Media Records, which tracks newspaper advertising lineage. Through July, this year's lineage had declined a further 12.5 percent, compared with the same period a year before.
Documents provided to unions by Mr. Kalikow estimated that 1990's ad revenues would be $35 million. Mr. Kalikow said that 1988's ad revenues were almost $48 million.
The Post's history of steady economic decline was known to Mr. Kalikow when he agreed to buy the paper from Mr. Murdoch for $37.5 million, a figure he said grew to $48 million after closing costs, inventory and receiveables were calculated.
 
Change of Editors
Mr. Kalikow, whose main business is real-estate development, had emerged as a white knight to save the paper after Mr. Murdoch established his own deadline and threatened to close it unless unions agreed to $24 million in savings.
Mr. Murdoch, who had owned the paper for 11 years, estimated his cumulative losses at $150 million.
Mr. Kalikow hired Jane Amsterdam, a repected editor who moved the paper away from the focus on sex and mayhem that had marked it under Mr. Murdoch. Mr. Kalikow also began a Sunday paper in an effort to attract more advertising.
But the Sunday paper failed, with Mr. Kalikow losing about $25 million. And Mr. Kalikow dismissed Ms. Amsterdam after concluding that The Post had become a bit too sedate and needed to shift emphasis toward local political coverage, as well as such staples as scandal and crime.
Under Jerry Nachman, a streetwise political columnist and former broadcaster whom Mr. Kalikow made editor, The Post prompted controversy by its sensational headlines, but was also first to report some important news.
Some union leaders note that Mr. Kalikow only threatened to close The Post after the Board of Estimate in late August removed a hurdle to Mr. Kalikow's plan to build an apartment tower on a site now occupied by a tenement complex that had been designated as a landmark.
Mr. Kalikow said that in June he began telling union leaders he needed relief, and that owning The Post had probably worked against him with the board because it attracted so much attention.

HEADLINE: THE 1990 ELECTIONS;
Primary Results Across U.S. Reflect Wide Outcry Against Politics as Usual

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
A public outcry against business-as-usual politics welled up among voters in primary voting around the country on Tuesday, illustrating a mood of anxiety about growth, the economy, the quality of life and the quality of politics.
In the suburbs just north of here voters dumped the chief executive of Maryland's largest county, a jurisdiction more populous than either Baltimore or Washington.
Voters in the Democratic primary in Montgomery County, a booming suburb typical of the places where much of American politics is now shaped, moved to replace the County Executive with a candidate who had railed against special interest groups and said that he wanted to impose a tax on development. The vote reflected the public mood as voters in 10 states and the District of Columbia voted in primary balloting with less than two months to go before the general election. 
 
'A Mood of Change'
In the Rhode Island governor's race, Democrats turned their backs on two veteran politicians, the Mayors of Providence and Warwick, and instead nominated as their candidate a businessman, Bruce Sundlun, who insisted that he was not a politician at all, his two previous races against the Republican Governor, Edward D. DiPrete, notwithstanding.
''There is definitely a mood of change in this country,'' said Mark Gearan, executive director of the Democratic Governors Conference. ''Candidates who were able to capitalize on that were successful.''
Nonetheless, it remained difficult to oust incumbents. A Maryland Representative, Roy Dyson, was renominated by Democratic voters, perhaps because his opponent could not afford enough television time to reach voters.
An important element of the voter mood of frustration this year, particularly in suburban jurisdictions, is an anger at crowding, traffic congestion, noise and dirt.
''It is one of those unexpressed, inchoate grievances among the electorate here,'' Bill Bradley, who publishes a newsletter on California Politics, said in Sacramento. ''Growth is a huge issue here. Both candidates for governor are trying to incorporate what they describe as their support of growth management into their campaigns.''
 
Issue of Growth
The issue of growth has become a way in which many voters express the belief that government is on the side of powerful interests, instead of ordinary people, politicians said.
''The people of this county can control their own interests,'' Neal Potter said after capturing the nomination for Montgomery County Executuve against the incumbent, Sidney Kramer. Mr. Potter, a 75-year-old Council member, ran on a platform to curb growth.
The defeat of Mr. Kramer, who has served four years as the County Executive, was the most dramatic illustration. Steady growth in recent years has pushed Montgomery County's population to 750,000 people, making it the largest jurisdiction in Maryland.
In a county that tends to vote Democratic, Mr. Potter has become the the favorite in November to defeat the Republican nominee, Albert Ceccone.
 
Crowding in California
Candidates in other areas are trying to show their concern about growth and the quality of voters' lives. Dianne Feinstein, the Democratic candidate for governor of California, has called for a growth management commission, while her Republican opponent, Senator Pete Wilson, has been citing his experience in managing growth as Mayor of San Diego.
In June, Californians approved a gasoline tax increase on the promise that the money would be used to alleviate freeway crowding.
Concern about growth and suspicion toward government came through clearly in the voting across the country on Tuesday as the primary season neared an end. Other themes were less certain.
Supporters of legal abortion won a victory in Maryland, but lost in Minnesota. In Maryland, four state legislators who had been part of a filbuster against legislation to protect legal abortion, were defeated in primary voting. But in Minnesota, often thought of as an early part of the anti-abortion movement, supporters of legal abortion were defeated in both the Democratic and Republican gubernatorial primaries by opponents of abortion.
The incumbent Governor, Rudy Perpich, a Democrat, will now face a conservative businessman, Jon Grunseth. Mr. Perpich said he was glad the Republicans had nominated a conservative because now he could occupy the middle ground.
But Mr. Grunseth, making it clear he planned a sharp attack on what some Minnesotans contend has been Mr. Perpich's odd behavior in office, replied, ''I'd rather be a little conservative than a little goofy.''
Mr. Grunseth won the Republican nomination by launching a wave of negative campaign commercials against his principal opponent, Arne Carlson, in the final weeks of the campaign. Mr. Grunseth's attack was described as the largest buy of television time for a political campaign in the state's history.
While public restiveness overturned one incumbent in Maryland, it was not enough to defeat another. Representative Dyson survived a challenge from State Delegate Barbara Kreamer and two other candidates. Mr. Dyson, a hawk on military issues, was embarrassed by the disclosure that he had been a conscientious objector in the Vietnam War.
Politicians said Ms. Kreamer had been unable to buy enough television time to reach all of the district, which sprawls through three television markets from Baltimore to Washington.
Mr. Dyson's victory set up a rematch with Wayne Gilchrest, a Republican who nearly defeated Mr. Dyson, a member of the House Armed Services Committee, in 1988 after the disclosure that some of his campaign contributions came from military contractors linked to the Pentagon procurement scandal.
In Arizona, voters rejected a return bid by Evan Mecham, who was impeached and ousted as Governor in 1988. He was defeated for the Republican nomination for governor by J. Fife Symington, a Phoenix developer. Mr. Symington will face the Democratic nominee, Terry Goddard, whose father, a former Governor, is now the state Democratic chairman.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Chase Faces Many Doubts on Wall Street

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Just how bad off are the large New York banks? Investors are acting as if many of them are in very poor shape.
With the common stocks of some banks already trading at their lowest levels in eight years or more, banks received another jolt on Tuesday with the news of an extremely poor auction for bonds issued by the Chase Manhattan Corporation. As a result, Chase will pay a little more than 13 percent interest on $200 million in borrowing for the next two years.
''It was the clearest manifestation of the fact that investors are very leery of bank holding company paper,'' George Salem, the banking analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said yesterday. 
At Chase, Michael Esposito, the chief financial officer, said the auction result ''was a function of the marketplace at that time.''
He added that ''there has been a general deterioration'' in the perception of banks in general.
Nowhere is the deterioration more evident than at Chase, whose common stock price has fallen 57 percent since it sold 16.1 million shares to investors at $40.125 each last fall.
Yesterday, as investors reacted to the auction results, the shares fell 50 cents, to $17.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. The shares are now trading at their lowest levels since 1982, when the Mexican debt problem burst into investor consciousness.
While worries over third-world loans remain, they have been joined by concerns over the fate of loans made for leveraged corporate buyouts in the 1980's and, especially, over possible real estate losses.
''The biggest risk to the bankers now is a significant recession,'' said Ronald Mandle, an analyst for Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. ''That would cause higher loan losses and would put earnings under even greater pressure.''
Chase's common stock now pays a quarterly dividend of 62 cents, for an annual yield on yesterday's stock price of 14.5 percent, the highest of any large bank. There has been widespread speculation that the payout could be cut, but Mr. Esposito said yesterday that the bank expected to maintain it.
In the most recent quarter, ending June 30, Chase reported profits of just 24 cents a share, or $52 million, after setting aside a $225 million provision for loan losses as nonperforming real estate loans soared. According to Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, a Wall Street firm, about 17 percent of Chase's commercial real estate loans were nonperforming as of June 30.
''We certainly recognize that our profitability was below acceptable levels,'' Mr. Esposito said yesterday, adding that he expected it to improve as a result of Chase's restructuring program. Under that program, the company hopes to cut about $300 million a year from annual expenses, which have been running at around $4 billion.
Mr. Mandle said he expected the restructuring to be successful and to enable Chase to maintain its dividend. He is recommending the stock.
He noted that Chase has 4.6 percent in ''tier one'' capital, in excess of the the Federal requirement for 1992 of at least 4 percent of assets. Mr. Esposito said there were no plans to raise additional tier-one capital by selling common stock. But he said the company might sell subordinated debt from time to time. Such debt counts as tier-two capital.
But some other analysts say the dividends of many banks, including Chase, could be in jeopardy. ''I think a year from now we will have seen several dividend reductions from major banks,'' he said. ''Morgan's dividend will go up, and the dividends of some of the ailing banks will go down in the next year.''
Among the seven largest New York commercial bank holding companies, J. P. Morgan & Company, the parent of Morgan Guaranty Trust, has seen its stock suffer the least over the last year. Its dividend yield, at 5.6 percent, is also the lowest of any of the companies, indicating higher investor confidence. Morgan is widely perceived to be the best capitalized of all major banks.
The recent auction by Chase was for an existing bond issue of $200 million in subordinated debt, which matures nine years from now. Issued in 1987, it yielded 9.66 percent in the first three years. Through Tuesday's auction, the rate was reset for two years, after which a new auction will be held.
Chase determined the date of the auction three years ago, and it had the misfortune to choose the day on which the General Accounting Office issued a report warning that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation fund that insures bank deposits may be depleted. That report may have made the psychology even worse for the auction.
At the auction, those holders who wanted to sell their bonds at face value could do so, as long as there were sufficient bidders for the bonds. The maximum rate those bidders could seek was 5 percentage points above two-year Treasury securities. The eventual result was 4.92 percentage points above that rate, for a yield of 13.017 percent.
Mr. Mandle estimated that the added interest payments would reduce Chase's annual earnings by about 4 cents a share.
At the auction, the largest buyer of the bonds was Salomon Brothers, one of the original underwriters of the bonds, said Jay Weintraub, a bank bond analyst for the firm. He said yesterday that Salomon had later found buyers for all those bonds, and said they were trading in the secondary market at slightly above face value.
The most recent similar auction for a similar bank issue was in May, when an auction by the BankAmerica Corporation produced a yield of 9.37 percent. In part, the higher yield of the Chase bonds reflects the fact that BankAmerica is considered a somewhat better credit risk, but most of the increase would seem to indicate rising investor concern over the entire banking system.
It is such concern that can create opportunities for investors. ''The whole banking group is exceptionally undervalued relative to the market,' Mr. Mandle said. He is recommending several bank stocks besides Chase, among them Chemical and Manufacturers Hanover.
But Mr. Salem, who has been negative on bank stocks for more than a year, said it was still not time to buy. ''Bottom fishing in bank stocks is a sport much like spear catching,'' he said yesterday.

HEADLINE: Lawmakers Rushing to Lift Caps on F.D.I.C. Premiums

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
As dire predictions about the future of the Federal fund that insures deposits at banks continued to mount, lawmakers moved quickly today to propose regulatory reforms in an apparent effort to escape the political taint of another taxpayer bailout.
The proposals come amid reports by the General Accounting Office yesterday and the Congressional Budget Office today that one large bank failure or a further downturn in the economy could wipe out the remaining $13.2 billion in the fund and force taxpayers to rescue it.
The depletion of a separate fund insuring deposits at savings and loan institutions has forced a bailout that is expected to cost taxpayers hundreds of billions of dollars over 30 years.
Democrats and Republicans on Capitol Hill today joined the Bush Administration in proposing the lifting of limitations that prevent the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation from increasing the premiums banks pay to the insurance fund. 
Urging Congress to act before it begins a recess next month, the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, Donald W. Riegle Jr., said he would introduce a measure eliminating caps on these premiums. Last month, the F.D.I.C. said it would increase the premium to 19.5 cents for every $100 of deposits; an increase of 30 percent, the maximum permitted under legislation adopted last year.
A similar proposal eliminating the caps on premiums was also introduced today in the House with the support of the chairman of the House Banking Committee, Henry B. Gonzalez. Last week, Mr. Gonzalez introduced a package of measures he said would save the fund money by substantially reducing the amount of insurance available to depositors.
Late this afternoon, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said it would endorse eliminating the ceiling on premiums to give the F.D.I.C. greater flexibility in setting rates.
In moving to abandon the statutory caps on premium increases without actually suggesting a new rate, Congress and the Bush Administration are clearly seeking to shift the political pressure to the F.D.I.C., which oversees the fund.
But there is no indication that the F.D.I.C. will take the bait. In a letter last week to Representative Gonzalez, L. William Seidman, chairman of the F.D.I.C., said that while he would like the discretion to make further increases, he did not foresee the need for them now. Alan J. Whitney, a spokesman for the F.D.I.C., said there had been no change in the agency's view since the letter was sent.
 
Passing New Costs to Consumers
Bankers have raised the prospect that a further increase in premiums could lead more banks to post losses at a time when the industry is suffering from poor loans and declining real estate markets in many parts of the nation. They have also suggested that a further increase in premiums would force banks to pass much of the new costs on to their customers by making fewer loans, charging higher rates for them, and generally increasing their fees.
''The increase that has already been announced will bring in $5 billion to the fund plus an additional $1 billion in interest income, and we expect that even under the G.A.O. projections, that should be enough,'' said Kenneth Guenther of the Independent Bankers Association, a trade group for small banks.
Senator Jake Garn, the ranking Republican on the banking committee, cautioned that an increase in the premium could be more harmful than helpful by further weakening the industry.
''We just can't willy-nilly raise premiums because it's the perception that we should and place in jeopardy a lot of these smaller institutions,'' he said. ''It's a dilemma and I don't know exactly where we should go.''
 
Fund at its Lowest Level
Still, both the G.A.O. and the budget office predict that even under the most optimistic of economic forecasts, the fund will be unable to reach its required level of $1.25 for each $100 of deposits by 1995 - a prospect that has raised concern among the lawmakers.
Now, at 70 cents per $100 worth of deposits, the fund is at its lowest level since it was created during the Great Depression. It is at half the level mandated by last year's bailout legislation of the savings and loan industry. Bank regulators predict the fund will likely lose as much as $2 billion this year.
Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, said today that over the next three years, the insurance fund would probably lose at least $20.8 billion from the failure of 631 insured institutions.
 
'On Thin Ice'
''We're on thin ice, but our skates are still dry,'' Mr. Reischauer told the Senate Banking Committee. ''The fact that the failure of one of the very large banks could, by itself, deplete the fund, underscores the fund's vulnerability.''
He added that the budget office projections for the next few years did not consider a sharp downturn in the economy.
''The uncertain economic outlook, exacerbated by declines in real estate values and sharp increases in oil prices, raises concerns that spending from the fund could be greater during the next few years than we have estimated,'' he said.
The committee also heard fom Michael DeStefano, a vice president at the Standard & Poor's Corporation, which rates the soundness of securities issued by corporations and municipalities. As a further sign of the decline in the banking industry, Mr. DeStefano said that within the last six months Standard & Poor's had lowered ratings of 36 bank holding companies, some more than once, and upgraded only four.

HEADLINE: Black Business Ownership Up

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
The number of businesses owned by black Americans rose modestly from 1982 to 1987, but revenues for the same period more than doubled, according to a new Census Bureau survey released on Tuesday. 
In 1987, there were 424,000 black-owned businesses in the United States, up 38 percent from 308,000 in 1982, while receipts swelled to $19.8 billion, from $9.6 billion.
The total number of concerns in the United States grew 14 percent, to 13.7 million. Revenues leaped to $1.99 trillion, from $967.5 billion. Large corporations are not included in the survey.
On average, revenues per black-owned businesses were $47,000, compared with $146,000 for all American concerns, the study showed.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Yields Mixed Amid Worry

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday.
Donoghue's analysts noted that the employment figures for August showed the economy in a perilous state. ''It is close to a recession,'' said Walter S. Frank, Donoghue's chief economist. ''The markets are waiting for the Federal Reserve Bank to move toward easing interest rates if we are to avoid a serious decline.'' 
So far, the Fed, concerned about fueling inflation, has held off cutting interest rates, which is why yields have remained flat all these weeks, Mr. Frank said.
 
Need for Easing of Rates Seen
Any budget agreement negotiated in Washington would likely include tax increases and budget cuts, he added, which would need to be offset by an easing of rates.
Managers of tax-exempt funds shortened the number of days that securities were held in portfolios by one, to 58. But many analysts maintain that the average is still unusually long.
Assets increased by $1.3 billion, to a total of $81.2 billion, as the average seven-day tax-exempt compounded yield rose 11 basis points, to 5.54 percent for the week. The 30-day average yield rose by 10 basis points, to 5.39 percent.
For investors in a 28 percent tax bracket, the equivalent taxable seven-day compounded yield is 7.69 percent, and it is 8.26 percent for investors in the 33 percent bracket.
Among tax-exempt funds with assets of better than $100 million that are monitored by IBC/Donoghue's, the Strong Municipal Money Market fund gave the best return. The compounded average yield is 6.30 percent, or about 36 basis points better than the average. The fund is distributed by Strong/Corneliuson Capital Management Inc., Milwaukee.
 
Taxable Fund Assets Up
Meanwhile assets of taxable funds rose by $1.1 billion, to $399.9 billion. Most of the activity was in consumer funds, where assets increased $1.1 billion, to $315.7 billion, with virtually no activity in institutional funds, up only $14 million, to $84.2 billion. Some of the money going into the consumer funds may be coming from banks, where yields continue to erode.
The average days to maturity of securities held in managers' portfolios increased by one, to 47, the highest in three years.
Donoghue's said the seven-day compounded average yield for a taxable money market fund was unchanged at 7.75 percent, while the 30-day average yield fell a basis point, to 7.76 percent, underlining the flatness in yields.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Mixed in a Quiet Day

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in lackluster trading yesterday, and interest rates on the longer maturities rose slightly.
In the wake of President Bush's address to Congress on Tuesday night, dealers said that market participants were taking a wait-and-see attitude on a number of fronts.
''Everything is on hold,'' said Joe Liro, a vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg Securities Inc. ''There are expectations about a budget package, but the market can't react to that until it sees a deal. The Middle East is stalemated, and likely to remain that way for a while, and oil prices are fairly stable. For the first time in several sessions, the market spent the day marking time.'' 
Market participants said the only breath of real activity occurred at midmorning, when the World Bank priced a $2 billion offering of five-year global bonds.
 
'Something Good' Expected
''The market still has expectations that something good is going to happen,'' one government bond trader said. ''But we will be in a narrow trading range until we get some news that addresses those expectations. Still, the market held and $2 billion worth of securities were sold. Under the circumstances, that's not a bad performance.''
In addition to the World Bank offering, the City of New York offered $850 million worth of general obligation bonds to investors in the tax-exempt municipal bond market.
With the city's economy still under pressure and its image tarnished further by the recent spate of violent killings, investors demanded higher interest rates on the new securities than at the last offering of general obligation bonds in late June.
The negotiated issue consisted of serial bonds with maturities from 1992 to 2004, two sets of term bonds insured by the Financial Guaranty Insurance Corporation and an additional set of uninsured term bonds.
The serial bonds were priced to yield 6.50 percent in 1992, 7.20 percent in 1995, 7.70 percent in 2000 and 7.85 percent in 2004.
The 7.30 percent insured bonds, which mature in 2005 and 2006, were both priced to yield 7.35 percent.
At the city's last sale of new general obligation debt in February, interest rates on serial bonds sold ranged from 6 percent on securities maturing in 1991 to 7.71 percent on issues that matured in 2013. Insured bonds, which carried maturities from 2014 to 2019, were priced to yield 7.15 percent.
Bear, Stearns & Company acted as lead manager for the underwriting, which is rated A by Moody's Investors Service and A-minus by Standard & Poor's.
 
Shortfalls Seen
In assigning its A-minus rating, Maury Cooper, an analyst who covers New York City for S.& P., did not sound a sanguine note about the future.
''Present economic and revenue trends indicate that the current $27.9 billion budget will likely show revenue shortfalls,'' Ms. Cooper wrote in assigning the rating. ''Due to the fiscal and economic risks and uncertainties, S.& P.'s long-term rating outlook remains negative.''
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 98 2/32 late yesterday, down 1/8 point, to yield 8.93 percent, compared with 8.92 percent late Tuesday.
Among note issues, the 8 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 22/ 32, down 2/32, to yield 8.68 percent. And the 8 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 7/32, up 1/32, to yield 7.99 percent.
While a substantive budget accord would meet with approval in the fixed-income markets, analysts said an agreement would be viewed especially favorably by foreign investors.
''The budget is much more of a focus for our foreign clients than either inflation or a possible recession,'' said Roger A. Portnoy, director of international production in the London office of Technical Data, a bond market advisory service.
 
Bill Rates Drop
As bonds and notes were turning in a mixed performance, short-term Treasury bill rates moved slightly lower.
By late yesterday, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.35 percent, down three basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bill rates dipped by four basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.28 percent. And one-year bills fell by two basis points, to 7.21 percent.
Aside from the New York City bond offering, a $100 million competitive offering of bonds from the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power was priced in the municipal bond market. The issue consists of serial bonds with maturities from 1996 to 2010 and a term bond that matures in 2030. Yields on the serial bonds range from 6.40 percent in 1996 to 7.20 percent in 2010. The 7.25 percent term bonds were priced to yield 7.37 percent.
A bid from a group led by the investment banking subsidiary of Bankers Trust won the issue, which is rated AA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said that prices of most issues were little changed in light trading.
Meanwhile, most actively quoted issues in the secondary municipal bond market rose by 1/8 point to 1/4 point, dealers said.Bear Stearnsd (Bear, Stearns)

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
World Bank's 5-Year Bonds Are Priced to Yield 8.74%

 BODY:
The World Bank yesterday priced $2 billion in five-year global bonds through a group of 15 international dealers jointly managed by Deutsche Bank Capital Markets and Salomon Brothers Inc.
The issue was priced simultaneously in the United States, Europe and Japanese markets, with the 8 5/8 percent bonds offered at 99.54 to yield 8.74 percent, or about 31 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Yesterday's offering was the third global bond issue by the World Bank in nearly a year.
The last offering was in February, when $1.5 billion in 10-year bonds were priced to yield 8.75 percent. Those bonds were the first such issue to be sold directly on the Japanese market.
Investment bankers familiar with yesterday's transaction said demand for the new issue was spread fairly equally among New York, Tokyo and London.
The bankers said participation by American investors was better than for previous global bond offerings. World Bank officials had made a special marketing effort to attract American buyers.
The World Bank, owned by 151 Governments, including the United States and Japan, is the largest source of loans to third world countries. Proceeds from the sale will be used for these loans.
Bond traders said the bank's outstanding debt was rated triple-A by both Moody's Investors Service and by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mostly Up in U.S. But Tumbles Against Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mostly higher in New York yesterday after falling in overseas trading and reaching a 13-month low against the Japanese yen in Tokyo. Gold prices advanced. Analysts said a variety of factors, including German reunification, helped move the dollar higher in domestic dealings. 
''There is some skepticism in the market about whether or not the reunification process can be completed without any disruptions,'' said Bill Janson, an analyst with the Discount Corporation.
That uncertainty weakened the German mark against the dollar. The United States currency closed at 1.5915 marks in New York, up from 1.5865 late Tuesday.
The possibility of interest rate changes accounted for other gains by the dollar in New York - but also attributed to its decline overseas. Indications that French and Swiss rates will decline bolstered the dollar in United States trading, Mr. Janson said. Yet dealers in London said earlier that expectations of lower United States rates depressed the dollar there.
Lower interest rates are a negative for any currency, as they reduce the yield on investments in that currency.
The Japanese yen, meanwhile, continued to recover from its own recent losses. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at a 13-month low of 138.30 Japanese yen from 139.85 yen at Tuesday's close. It was the dollar's lowest closing there since Aug. 4, 1989, when it finished trading at 138.05 yen.
Later, in London, the dollar fell to 137.60 yen and in New York, it fell more than two yen to close at 138.075 yen, down from 140.305.
The yen had been depressed recently by the tensions in the Persian Gulf. The Japanese import almost all of their crude oil, and there were concerns the country's businesses would be hurt by energy prices that rose sharply after Iraq invaded Kuwait last month.
The British pound rose slightly against the dollar in New York and closed at $1.8590, up from $1.8565. In London earlier, the British pound rose to $1.8650 from $1.8490 late Tuesday.
Other late rates for the dollar in New York, compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 1.3290 Swiss francs, up from 1.3245; 5.3303 French francs, up from 5.3125; 1,187.75 Italian lire, up from 1,183.00, and 1.16355 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16095.
Gold rose in New York, picking up $1.60 and closing at $382.10 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange.

LENGTH: 591 words

HEADLINE: 'NATO' in the Gulf: A Certain Disaster

BYLINE: By Caleb Carr and James Chace; Caleb Carr and James Chace are co-authors of ''America Invulnerable: The Quest for Absolute Security From 1812 to Star Wars.''

 BODY:
An entangling alliance in the Persian Gulf, as outlined by Secretary of State James Baker in testimony before the House Foreign Affairs Committee on Sept. 5, is not in the national interest of the United States.
In speaking of ''a new regional security structure,'' designed first to contain Iraqi aggression and later to help create a ''stable gulf'' in which ''legitimate security concerns can be preserved'' and ''energy supplies flow freely,'' Mr. Baker seeks to apply the lessons of NATO's successful 50-year defense of Western Europe to the Middle East. But the parallel is fatally flawed. The free flow of oil out of the Persian Gulf is vital to Western Europe and Japan, which meet more than half their energy needs with gulf oil. Any crisis that threatens a cutoff of that oil therefore merits a forceful American response, even though we receive only 5 to 10 percent of our oil from the region. 
Secretary Baker's remarks, however, reveal that the American military umbrella opening over the Persian Gulf is more than a pragmatic, decisive response to a single threat to Western security. It's the opening move in the formation of a nominally multilateral but effectively American and, more alarmingly, open-ended commitment to defend the integrity of the oil-producing states of the Arabian Peninsula.
Such a commitment is disturbing for several reasons. Because the Bush Administration is determined not to relinquish effective control of the peacekeeping force, we will continue to bear the greater part of the economic burden for the operation. As in the case of NATO, our allies will be allowed to spend less than their fair share because we wish to retain authority.
But the United States of 1990 is not the United States of 1949, the year NATO was formed. As the world's greatest debtor nation, we can today ill afford even the $15 to $18 billion (almost certainly a conservative estimate) that Operation Desert Shield alone will cost in fiscal 1991, much less the additional burden of a semi-permanent regional security arrangement. Even should the Arab states underwrite the alliance, America could end up beholden to them. Secretary Baker's plan will only heighten the insolvency of our foreign policy and intensify our domestic economic debate.
Perhaps more dangerous than the purely economic cost of Mr. Baker's proposed security system is the fact that it will cast us in the role of status quo power in the Persian Gulf. Besides Saudi Arabia, the United States now has military units stationed in Oman, Bahrain, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates - nations that, like Kuwait, have exhibited little attachment to the principles of liberal democracy.
Agitation for a greater popular voice in governmental affairs is today characteristic of most of the Arab world. By interposing to protect the sheiks and emirs of the gulf, we run the very great risk of eventually making enemies not only of those unpredictable leaders but of the peoples they rule, the peoples whose right to ''live free of the fear of coercion'' Secretary Baker says we are in the gulf to protect.
It is one thing to mobilize a temporary alliance for definable ends, such as the withdrawal of Saddam Hussein from Kuwait. It is a far more dangerous thing to erect an alliance structure in which we play the commanding role in countless skirmishes, expending our blood and treasure in a region that is of greater importance to our allies than to ourselves. The Middle East may be an inescapable entanglement, but it need not be a permanent one.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
