HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
JAPAN DEFENDS AID IN MIDEAST EFFORT

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 14

 BODY:
Jolted by mounting criticism of Japan in Washington, Government officials asserted today that Japan had done more than any other country outside the gulf region to aid the American buildup in the Middle East and pledged another $3 billion in assistance to the region.
The officials said that $2 billion, for economic aid to Jordan, Egypt and Turkey, includes a fast infusion of $600 million to make up for revenues those countries lost because of the sanctions against Iraq.
In addition, the officials said, another $1 billion will be used to assist the multinational military effort in the gulf beyond the $1 billion announced two weeks ago.
The new money will bring to $4 billion the total amount Japan has committed to the Persian Gulf since the beginning of the crisis caused by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. [In West Germany, Chancellor Helmut Kohl also pledged more help, apparently trying to soften the anger expressed in Congress that Bonn is not pulling its weight in the gulf. He offered few details. 
 
Page A11.]
Since Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu announced the previous pledge of $1 billion, only one shipment of goods, consisting of 800 vehicles, has gone to the Middle East.
Shipments of goods by Japan have been delayed for several reasons, partly because of the reluctance of Japan Airlines and independent shippers to send material into a combat zone.
Japanese officials also said Tokyo had to wait for the creation of a legal entity before it could in effect write a check to help pay for the American military effort.
Japanese officials said a direct transfer of money to another country, like the United States, is forbidden by law unless it is for purposes like economic assistance or disaster relief. ''As soon as we finish working out a scheme in cooperation with the United States Government, the money can be processed,'' a Japanese official said.
A larger obstacle to Japanese assistance has been the interpretation long applied to the Constitution written by the United States after the end of World War II. The Constitution rules out use of force by Japan in pursuit of its interests. Tokyo has cited the clause in rejecting an American appeal to send minesweepers, refueling tankers and other equipment.
 
Vehicles, Housing, Money
Japanese officials said that while other countries outside the gulf had sent troops and ships to the Middle East, no country outside the region had come up with a sum anywhere near even the $1 billion Japan had previously committed.
Kuwait's exiled Emir has said he will contribute about $5 billion to the effort before the end of the year, and the Saudis have promised to contribute about $500 million a month. The United Arab Emirates has also pledged a sizable contribution.
The Japanese assistance is to come largely in vehicles, housing, air-conditioning equipment and other goods, as well as direct financial support for the multinational military effort.
In addition, officials said the $2 billion for Jordan, Egypt and Turkey will help their economic development in the years ahead.
But it has not been clear whether the $2 billion in economic aid is in addition to or part of the roughly $10 billion a year Japan has committed in recent years for economic development in poor countries.
 
Dismayed by Admendment
On Thursday night officials said they were especially dismayed by the passage on Wednesday of an anti-Japanese amendment to a military spending bill in the United States House of Representatives by a vote of 370 to 53.
''Some of those 370 Congressmen may not be aware that Japan is the biggest supporter of United States forces overseas,'' Taizo Watanabe, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, said in an interview Thursday night. ''We hope that once they know the full magnitude of what we are doing, their appreciation will increase.''
Other officials warned that the part of the resolution calling for a reduction in American forces in Japan was potentially dangerous. The resolution called for a cut of 5,000 troops each year if Tokyo does not increase its support for the 50,000 American troops on Japanese soil.
''These resolutions are coming out of pure ignorance,'' said a Foreign Ministry official, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified. ''To withdraw 5,000 troops a year for Japan is sheer nonsense. It would destroy not only the national interest of Japan, but of the United States as well.''
 
Protecting American Interests
He added that American troops are in Japan ''not for the narrow purpose of defending Japan alone,'' but to protect American interests in the Pacific and Indian Oceans.
 
Prime Minister Kaifu telephoned
President Bush about the announcement of additional aid, the Japanese Embassy in Washington said, adding that the President said he appreciated the efforts.
A White House spokesman, Sean T. Walsh, said, ''The President and Secretary Baker have been asking all the allies to contribute and we would welcome the additional contribution.''
The tone of statements from Japan earlier this week had been one of alarm, apparently mixed with a feeling that criticism in the United States seemed to be inevitable because of what some have acknowledged to be the delays in Japanese assistance.
The 800 vehicles finally shipped, for instance, were delayed because union seamen did not want to take such cargo to a combat zone.
In addition, some 38 Japanese company representatives in Iraq made an unusual appeal two weeks ago to the Tokyo Government to rescind the $1 billion effort for the United States and instead spend the money for food and medicine in Baghdad. The appeal was disavowed by some of the companies' headquarters in Japan.
Mr. Kaifu was also said to be ready to submit legislation to create a United Nations Peacekeeping Amendment to Japanese statutes. As envisioned by some officials, the measure would permit Tokyo to pay for United Nations efforts now barred by current law.
A change in the law might enable Japan to send vehicles, medical aid and other items to the military peacekeeping missions of the United Nations, Japanese officials say.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
U.N. Council Votes Strict Limits On Food Aid to Iraq and Kuwait

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 13

 BODY:
The Security Council voted overwhelmingly tonight to adopt a plan setting tight limits on humanitarian food supplies sent to Iraq and occupied Kuwait.
The Council voted 13 to 2 in favor of the plan, with Cuba and Yemen in opposition. The resolution, drafted by the United States and the other four permanent members - Britain, France, the Soviet Union and China - says the Council alone will determine when such deliveries are justified in light of the United Nations embargo against Iraqi commerce.
The measure also requires that any food supplies be distributed ''through the United Nations in cooperation with the International Committee of the Red Cross or other appropriate humanitarian agencies'' to insure that they reach ''the intended beneficiaries'' and are not seized by the Iraqi Government for its supporters. 
The Council plans to monitor Iraq's supplies to determine whether a threat of famine exists that would justify emergency food deliveries.
It pledged to pay particular attention to the plight of the more vulnerable groups, including children under the age of 15, pregnant women, the sick and the elderly.
 
Cuba and Yemen Vote No
In voting against the limits, Cuba and Yemen, the Council's sole Arab member, argued that the 15-member Council had no right to place any restrictions on access to food.
But the United States Representative, Thomas R. Pickering, described the plan as ''a fair procedure'' that would enable the Security Council to meet genuine humanitarian needs without undermining the trade sanctions.
The plan seeks to insure that the embargo, which has been in effect since early August, can legally be relaxed only in extreme cases. Iraq has said it will not permit international supervision of the distribution of food, raising doubts about whether even the limited shipments allowed in principle by the resolution will ever take place.
Because the Security Council resolution adopted last month on trade sanctions included provisions for humanitarian relief, questions quickly arose on whether Iraq would be able to evade the embargo by having friendly countries send in ''humanitarian'' aid.
The United States made it clear last week that it intended to press for United Nations approval of exceptions to the embargo on a case-by-case basis, with each shipment monitored by an international agency, like the Red Cross.
At the meeting on Sunday in Helsinki between Presidents Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the two men agreed on such monitored food shipments.
An Iranian newspaper that reflects the views of the Government of President Hashemi Rafsanjani said on Wednesday that Iran was considering sending food and medicine across the border to Iraq. ''Muslim Iraqi people shouldn't pay for the mistakes of their Government,'' the editorial in The Teheran Times said.
The Council is expected to allow India to send a shipload of food to Kuwait for the hundreds of thousands of its citizens living there and in Iraq who, along with tens of thousands of other expatriate workers, are having trouble finding food.
There have been reports of severe food shortages in Kuwait, with Iraqi troops reportedly seizing supplies and sending them home. There have been no reports of severe food shortages in Iraq itself.
Western diplomats see the witholding of food from Asians in Kuwait and Iraq as a calculated attempt by Baghdad to weaken third world support for sanctions.
The final votes on the guidelines for humanitarian aid and on India's request to dispatch its food ship were held up by Cuba and Yemen, which have consistently sought to weaken and delay sanctions against Iraq in the past.
Today Cuba introduced an alternative resolution that would have exempted all food supplies from the United Nations trade embargo, but the measure won no support from other members. Western diplomats accused both countries of trying to postpone a final decision through a variety of procedural maneuvers but expressed confidence throughout the day that their version would eventually be approved.
Cuba and Yemen sought to link approval of the Indian relief shipment to Kuwait with acceptance by the Council of the general guidelines for emergency supplies proposed by the five permanent members. They argued that the United States might block the Indian shipment once the Council approved the restrictive guidelines. Will the Needy Get the Food? The potential effect on world opinion of the sight of starving women and children has long been recognized by the Security Council as one of the most vulnerable aspects of its effort to use a comprehensive trade embargo to force Baghdad to retreat from Kuwait.
But whether needy people in Iraq and Kuwait will ever receive food supplies was thrown into doubt on Tuesday by Iraq's United Nations representative, Abdul Amir al-Anbari.
After meeting with the Secretary General, he told reporters that Iraq would never allow foreign organizations to control the distribution of food suppplies, saying that this would be an affront to its sovereignty. But Western diplomats said they doubted that local Iraqi humanitarian organizations like the Iraqi Red Crescent could be relied on to insure that the food goes to the people for whom it is intended.
Finland's deputy representative, Marjatta Rasi, who heads the Security Council committee monitoring compliance with the embargo, said today that Iraq's food stocks are still relatively plentiful, enough to last anywhere from two months to more than six months.
 
Using 'the Food Weapon'
But Mrs. Rasi said that Iraq was already using ''the food weapon'' against tens of thousands of poor Asian workers still in the country by denying them ration cards. Withholding food in this way, she said at a news conference, constitutes a ''gross violation'' of Iraq's duty to protect foreign nationals under international law.
Asian diplomats confirmed that Iraqi authorities had told India, Sri Lanka and the Philippines that their nationals would be given no food and would have to rely on suppplies from home. An estimated 150,000 Indians, some 93,000 Sri Lankans and about 60,000 Flipinos are in Iraq and Kuwait.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The United Nations Security Council voted overwhelmingly yesterday to set tight limits on food relief sent to Iraq and Kuwait. Kuwait's chief delegate, Mohammad A. Abulhasan, right, conferred during the session with Javed Zarif, deputy chief delegate from Iran. (Reuters) (pg. A10)

HEADLINE: Split, Catholic Bishops Defer Proposals on Women's Issues

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS

 BODY:
A final decision on a seven-year effort by the nation's Roman Catholic bishops to set church policy on issues of concern to women, from abortion to sexual discrimination to ordination, was postponed indefinitely yesterday under the weight of criticism from both liberals and conservatives in the church.
The National Conference of Catholic Bishops had been scheduled to vote in November on a final draft of the policy-setting pastoral letter on women's concerns, but the conference's administrative committee postponed the vote after the Vatican requested that the bishops preparing the document consult with fellow bishops in other nations on the matter.
 
A Division Over Tradition
The pastoral letter has sharply divided Catholics who want more change in church practices regarding women and those who uphold traditional restrictions. Representatives of both positions have demanded that the whole project be dropped. 
Yesterday's postponement provoked sharply different interpretations of the likelihood that a statement on women's concerns would ever emerge from the bishops' deliberations.
''I certainly do not think that this is the first step toward abandoning the project, nor a hint from Rome that this is a way to close down the pastoral letter,'' said Bishop Joseph L. Imesch of Joliet, Ill., who heads the panel of six bishops that has been working on the letter since November 1983. ''I look upon the consultation and extra time as a great opportunity.''
The international consultation ''means another year of work,'' Bishop Imesch said. ''This is Rome's recognition of the importance of the topic,'' he said. ''This is not just a national issue. The concerns of women are worldwide.''
Other Catholics, many of whom had already expressed unhappiness about the all-male hierarchy writing a document on women, took the opposite view about the life of the project. ''I could be wrong, but I think this means the end of the pastoral letter,'' said Sister Maria Riley, a feminist writer and staff member at the Center of Concern, a Catholic research organization dealing with economic and political questions.
In recent weeks the Vatican has been urging the international consultation, which probably will take place in Rome sometime next year, Bishop Imesch said yesterday. Pastoral letters are not necessarily binding on Catholics, but they sometimes include authoritative teaching and always set guidelines for preaching, educational efforts and national programs by the bishops' conference.
 
'Sin of Sexism' Condemned
There have been two drafts of the pastoral letter on women, and the committee had been receiving further amendments from the bishops. Both drafts condemn the ''sin of sexism,'' expressed in violence against women, sexual exploitation and economic discrimination, and both said sexist attitudes had colored church teachings.
The first draft, however, was considered to be too liberal by many lay people, bishops and Vatican officials. They criticized the draft for appearing merely to restate without clearly endorsing the church's prohibitions of contraception and the ordination of women and for recommending further discussion of these teachings.
The second draft, issued in April, endorsed the prohibitions in detail and took a position closer to that of Pope John Paul II, who has said that debate is closed on the matters. Also, while not eliminating the earlier version's criticism of sexual discrimination in the church, the April draft toned it down.
As a result, a number of liberals and conservatives alike have rejected the second draft as an unacceptable compromise between upholding traditional church teachings on the one hand and affirming the equality of women in nearly feminist terms on the other.
Sister Riley, of the Center of Concern, said that although the April draft probably included the ''strongest statement of any Catholic Church document on the radical equality'' between men and women, her organization had called for the letter to be dropped.
In June, the center had issued a statement concluding that the draft ''clearly illustrates the current untenable position the institutional church finds itself in as it tries to respond to the historical shift in human consciousness about women and simultaneously maintain its traditional patriarchal structures and processes.''
Only two weeks ago, Women for Faith and Family, a St. Louis-based traditionalist organization, also asked the bishops to reject the draft and abandon their effort. The pastoral letter, the group said, threatened to compromise traditional church teaching, encourage dissent and increase polarization among Catholics.
 
Amendment Was Proposed
Earlier a group of seven bishops sent Bishop Imesch an amendment for the November meeting that would have transformed the letter into a simple report from the drafting committee and called for further discussion with women.
Last May, Archbishop Rembert G. Weakland of Milwaukee wrote in his diocesan paper that the letter should be dropped, saying that it evaded the question of women's leadership in the church and that ''the section in the new draft on the ordination of women comes as an even more chilling cold shower.''
The Leadership Conference of Women Religious, which brings together many of the leaders of religious orders of women, also said last month that the project should be dropped. The church was ''not ready'' for the kind of self-criticism implied in ''its insistence on the fundamental equality of all persons,'' the group said, although it applauded the drafting commitee's ''effort to take the unique experience and insights of women seriously.''
Groups of Catholic women voiced similar opposition when consultations on the letter began in the mid-1980's, but that criticism was somewhat muted after the first draft in 1988 cited both liberal and conservative testimony from Catholic women and seemed to create openings for further discussion of the most controversial issues.
 
'Voices Heard Are Negative'
Bishop Imesch rejected the conclusion that the church was too divided to reach a consensus. ''The only voices being heard are the negative ones,'' he said. So far the committee has received responses to the April draft from only 40 of the church's 185 dioceses, he said.
In one precedent for international consultation on pastoral letters, the Vatican summoned American bishops to Rome to consult with bishops from NATO nations before the Americans issued their 1983 statement on war and peace.
Unofficial accounts of that meeting have portrayed it as subjecting the American bishops to harsh criticism, but Bishop Imesch said he did not foresee anything of that nature if the consultation included strong representation from other Western nations where discussions of issues of sexual equality are similar to those in the United States.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Urges Cautious Moves To Shore Up the Banking System

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
Warning Congress to move cautiously in trying to cure the ailing banking system, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that increasing the premiums that institutions pay to the declining fund that insures bank deposits could be more harmful than helpful, threatening some banks with insolvency.
Instead, Mr. Greenspan proposed increasing the amount of money that banks must hold as a cushion against losses and called for more extensive reviews of banks by regulators.
Testifying before the House Banking Committee, Mr. Greenspan also said that the Federal Reserve had detected in recent months that banks were ''pulling back'' on extending credit, and he reiterated his longstanding position that adoption of a ''credible'' Federal budget that reduced the deficit would lead to an easing of interest rates.
Lower American interest rates would make dollar-denominated investments less attractive to foreigners, and the dollar had a steep slide against all major currencies yesterday after Mr. Greenspan's testimony. 
Mr. Greenspan acknowledged that raising banks' capital requirements would probably force many of them to reduce credit further even when they have already shown signs of restricting loans. Such a move would also lead to greater consolidation in the banking industry and slower growth, he said.
Still, he said, increasing the capital requirement is necessary to protect the banks and the Federal insurance fund, which is expected to post its third consecutive loss this year. Some analysts have even said the fund could be wiped out by either an economic downturn or the failure of one or several large institutions.
 
Concern About Risky Lending
Mr. Greenspan stopped short of proposing precise figures for increasing the standards, but said that the current level of capital was not adequate to protect institutions, particularly those interested in making riskier types of loans and investments.
After estimates this week by the General Accounting Office and the Congressional Budget Office that the insurance fund might soon be exhausted, legislators and the Bush Administration have moved to eliminate the restrictions on the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's ability to raise the premiums that banks pay to the fund.
The accounting office said a significant number of failed banks had not appeared on the F.D.I.C.'s list of ''problem banks'' before their collapse, or had been listed only shortly before failing. Both the accounting office and the budget office have said the present standards of financial reporting make it difficult for regulators to detect troubled banks early enough to intervene and reduce the costs to the deposit insurance fund.
The two agencies' estimates, while generally in line with earlier forecasts by the F.D.I.C., look at the fund from a broader perspective. The accounting office's auditors said they knew of 35 banks that had failed or would probably fail, at a total cost to the fund of $4.4 billion to $6.3 billion. They also said that the fund's balance sheet had failed to take account of $8 billion that might have to be spent in connection with Southwestern banks.
 
Worries on Capitol Hill
Declining real estate markets in many parts of the nation and the growing number of troubled loans held by banks have increased concern on Capitol Hill that the number of bank failures could increase to the point of depleting the insurance fund. Lawmakers, stung by the costly rescue of failed savings and loan associations, are now worried that they will be blamed if taxpayers are forced to bail out the banking industry.
Yesterday the stocks of several leading banks, which were already trading at or near their lowest levels in many years, continued to drop. Shares of Chase Manhattan dropped 37.5 cents, to $16.75; Chemical Banking fell 50 cents, to $20.875; Manufacturers Hanover was off $1.25, to $25.625, and BankAmerica lost 62.5 cents, to $21.75.
Last month, the F.D.I.C., which oversees the bank fund, said it would raise premiums by 30 percent, to 19.5 cents for every $100 in deposits, by the beginning of the year. The increase was the maximum permitted in the savings bailout legislation adopted last year. Lawmakers are now proposing to amend that provision of the legislation.
Mr. Greenspan, in his Congressional testimony today, joined the chorus of Government officials who are worried about the deposit insurance fund.
 
'The Fund Is Under Stress'
''There is no question that the fund is under stress, and it should be audited closely by the regulators and Congress in order to avoid the problems that have occurred with thrifts,'' he said. ''That the ratio of insured funds to deposits is a low number and heading lower is of concern.''
He said that while he supported the move to give the F.D.I.C. greater discretion in setting insurance premiums, any move to raise them further could ultimately cost the fund more than it brings in because it might squeeze the industry too hard.
''Let's remember that we can create problems for the American taxpayer by having premiums that are too low, or too high,'' he said. ''If we set the premiums too high, we can induce more bankruptcies. The banks would then fall back on the F.D.I.C., and taxpayers would be worse off.''

LENGTH: 469 words

HEADLINE: Moscow and Bonn in a 'Good Neighbor' Pact

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 13

 BODY:
The Soviet Union and West Germany today initialed a broad ''treaty on good-neighborliness, partnership and cooperation'' setting a framework for relations between Moscow and a united Germany.
Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union, who initialed the document, hailed it as something of a historic breakthrough.
In fact, the treaty included few concrete agreements, and consisted largely of pledges of peace and cooperation. 
Western diplomats said the document had been part of the package sought by the Soviet Union in exchange for its agreement to German unity. In effect, it replaced the treaties Moscow had concluded with the separate German nations with one broad statement on the shape of future relations.
 
For Domestic Consumption
The diplomats said part of Moscow's reason for seeking the pact was for domestic consumption, to demonstrate to a nation reared on the accounts of Soviet sacrifices in World War II that a united Germany was prepared to put its peaceful intentions on paper.
The treaty was initialed the day after foreign ministers of the Germanys, the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France signed the ''two plus four'' treaty settling all Allied claims on Germany stemming from World War II and clearing the way for the Germans to reunite.
The Soviet-German treaty was only initialed because it is to be signed later by Chancellor Helmut Kohl for a united Germany and by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev for the Soviet Union. But both sides evidently wanted to publicize the treaty in conjunction with the ''two plus four'' document, as well as on the 35th anniversary of the restoration of relations between the Soviet Union and West Germany on Sept. 13, 1955.
The preamble declared that both sides were ''resolved to continue the good traditions of their centuries-old history,'' and spoke of ''historic challenges on the threshold to the third millennium.''
 
'This Is a Great Thing'
The document included statements banning aggression against each other and calling for annual summit meetings, consultation in times of crisis and expanded trade, travel and scientific cooperation. Though it had no detailed projects, officials said separate treaties detailing economic relations, including German financial aid for the Soviet Union and incentives for trade and investment, were under negotiation.
''The treaty leads both our countries into the 21st century marked by responsibility, trust and cooperation,'' Mr. Genscher said. Mr. Shevardnadze called the treaty a ''historic document in spirit and content,'' adding: ''Now we can rightly say that the postwar era has ended. We are satisfied that the Federal Republic and we again appear as partners. This is a great thing.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Foreign Ministers Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany, left, and Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union toasted each other at ceremony in Moscow yesterday after they initialed a pact setting a framework for future relations between Moscow and a united Germany. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: TAXES APPROVED BY ISRAELI CABINET

BYLINE: By SABRA CHARTRAND, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Sept. 13

 BODY:
The Israeli Cabinet unanimously approved an economic package today that includes harsh new taxes to help pay for the absorption of Soviet Jewish immigrants.
The plan now goes to Israel's Parliament, where members of the Government, which is led by the rightist Likud party, expect a tough battle for approval.
The proposal to raise $450 million more in taxes from an already heavily taxed nation marks the Government's first real effort to extend the burden of paying for the massive influx of Soviet Jews to the Israeli public. Until now Israel has sought funds mainly from Washington and from Jews across the world, particularly in the United States. 
The plan proposes to raise the money through several new taxes, including a 16 percent value-added tax on fruits and vegetables; taxes of 20 percent on nearly all types of savings accounts, pension plans, and life insurance; a 20 percent tax on corporate stock-market profits, and a 16 percent tax on the tourism industry.
 
A Heavily Taxed Nation
Sales taxes on beer and cigarettes will be increased.
Even if all of the provisions were adopted, the new revenue would only provide a fraction of the money needed to build houses, create jobs, educate and otherwise absorb the hundreds of thousands of Soviet Jewish immigrants expected here in the next year or so. The Government has estimated the cost of absorbing what some predict could be as many as 500,000 immigrants at $30 billion.
Israel is already one of the most heavily taxed nations in the world. Israelis like electronic goods and cars are subject to staggering taxes of up to 250 percent.
The average income for a family of four is $16,800 a year, but income taxes can range up to 45 percent. There is even a ''travel tax,'' a $120 tariff that Israelis must pay to leave the country.
The economic package also proposes to liberalize Israel's restrictive capital and foreign-currency markets to stimulate private investment and create more jobs. A key measure calls for lowering the minimum wage from its present level of $490 a month by an as yet unspecified amount.
 
Opening Markets
Another provision would eliminate some import restrictions and open the country's markets to nations that do not have trade agreements with Israel.
Finance Minister Yitzhak Modai, the author of the economic plan, hopes the changes will inject $40 billion into the economy by 1995 and create thousands of jobs, primarily for Soviet immigrants.
Israel's unemployment rate is 10 percent, and inflation is currently rising by an annual rate of 20 percent.
The proposals do not envisage any cuts in Israel's defense budget. Nor does the plan reduce Government subsidies on basic foodstuffs, or impose taxes on Government stipends for children or add fees for health care or education.
Mr. Modai had barely finished announcing that the economic plan was approved before a Likud colleague, Tourism Minister Gideon Patt, began what may ultimately become a bitter fight in Parliament over the taxes.
''I don't know what will come out of this subcommittee but I can assure you of one thing, it won't be a 16 percent tax on tourism,'' Mr. Patt said.
Labor Party officials also criticized the plan. The party leader, Shimon Peres, accused the Cabinet of speaking in two voices on the tax on fruit and vegetables. He said that agreement on the economic package should be sought from the trade union federation and from industrialists.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Oil Deal With Iraq Denied in Iran, But Private Executives Confirm It

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 13

 BODY:
An Iranian daily newspaper known to reflect the views of the Iranian Foreign Ministry today denied reports that Iran had agreed to take oil from Iraq to use in its own refineries.
But American, Arab and Iranian oil executives, confirming reports Wednesday, asserted that an agreement had been negotiated between the two countries in which Iran would help break the United Nations embargo of Iraq by taking about 200,000 barrels a day of Iraqi crude oil and some refined products like fuel oil and naphtha, which Iran used to import.
The Teheran Times, an English-language daily, today quoted what it described as an ''informed source'' who said the Wednesday reports of the Iran-Iraq oil deal were ''totally baseless.'' 
 
'Kept Its Options Open'
The newspaper said the Iranian Government had not decided whether to supply its blockaded neighbor with essential food and medicine, even though Iranian officials were quoted earlier by other Iranian dailies as saying they would do so.
''The Government has kept its options open on that,'' the paper, which is close to aides of President Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, asserted today.
But American, Arab and Iranian oil executives who live in Western Europe and the gulf region said in interviews today that Iran and Iraq had discussed details of a plan that would lead to the delivery of some 200,000 barrels of oil a day from Iraq to Iran. They said the oil would be moved by barges to Abadan in Iran across the Shatt al Arab, the narrow estuary that divides Iran and Iraq, and to Ahwaz by road.
 
'It's a Done Deal'
The oil executives said Iraq made the offer in talks in Teheran that included Foreign Ministry and Oil Ministry officials on Sunday and Monday.
''It's a done deal,'' said a chief executive of an American oil company that handles substantial Middle East oil sales. ''They will provide the oil by barges and trucks to be fed into Iranian refineries.''
The executive said that he was not sure when the shipments would begin. He said the deal meant that although Iraq would sell some of its oil, all the Iraqi oil would be used internally in Iran and no Iraqi crude oil would surface on world oil markets, Arab oil executives in the gulf region said the plan presumed that the oil going to Ababan would be fed into the Abadan refinery, which can process some 130,000 barrels a day.
 
Trucks From Recent War
One Iranian oil executive in Western Europe confirmed that Iranian officials had consulted him on these arrangements with Iraq.
He said some Iraqi oil would be trucked to Ahwaz overland. From 1980 to 1988, when Iraq and Iran were at war, Baghdad developed a large fleet of trucks to carry some 200,000 barrels daily to be shipped from the port of Aqaba in Jordan. The fleet, the oil executives say, can easily be reactivated and expanded.
The Iranian executive said the deal was seen in Iran as a ''small and symbolic'' gesture primarily aimed at ''encouraging'' Iraqi dependence on Iran. He said there were discussions of expanding the deal eventually, but that this would require the linking of Iraqi and Iranian pipelines near Ahwaz.
The American chief executive said Iraqi officials had told him they hoped to raise exports to Iran to as much as 600,000 barrels a day, however.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Jordan Port Falls Still And Its Leaders Seethe

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AQABA, Jordan, Sept. 13

 BODY:
The streets seem virtually deserted, the hotels are empty, most of the port structures lie still and more than 80 percent of the 11,000-strong tractor-trailor fleet sits parked and silent.
Aqaba, Jordan's only port, seems almost a ghost town today, a victim, depending on whom you ask, of Saddam Hussein's aggression against Kuwait or of American gunboat diplomacy.
''Aqaba is the lifeline for Jordan, and now we are almost at a standstill,'' said Bassam E. Kakish, a retired general who is chairman of the Aqaba Regional Authority. ''For God's sake, before we strangle here, tell your people to take your armies back. Go home and leave us alone!'' 
Aqaba, a somnolent little port town for decades, doubled in size as it grew wealthy on all the money earned from shipping mountains of arms to Iraq starting in 1981, after Iraq's only port was blocked in the war with Iran.
 
Town Is Transformed
At the height of that war, 60 or 70 ships sat in the harbor every day, and the ripple effect through the economy brought on by all that shipping transformed the town.
The port more than doubled its installations and work force so that 5,000 people worked there, until last month. Business blossomed for gas station owners, mechanics and tire salesmen serving the fleets of trucks shipping goods to Iraq.
Aqaba's population boomed too, from 22,000 10 years ago to 45,000 just before the gulf crisis began. Next to the ancient Arab village, a new town sprouted up - dozens of clean white apartment buildings that housed thousands of Egyptian workers and others.
But most of those itinerant workers have now gone home. The town seems a hollow shell of its former self, and it leaders seethe with resentment.
The director of the Aqaba Customs Authority, Ahmed Haayari, raised no eyebrows among six other local leaders in the room this afternoon when he said, ''This is the jihad,'' the holy war. He added, ''I hope I will be given the honor of fighting Americans in the desert and be killed there. That would be my honor.''
 
Only 3 Ships in Port
Three ships were in the harbor today, when before, Mr. Kakish said, the daily average was 20. The American naval blockade in the Red Sea, put in place when it became clear that Jordan was not enforcing the United Nations sanctions against Iraq, has cut off most of the shipments bound not just for Iraq but for Jordan, too, he asserted.
''Jordan is a small country, 85 percent desert,'' he said. ''We don't have many ships just for Jordan. We can't fill them up. So some of our goods are put on other ships with goods for other countries, including Iraq. And now those goods are being turned away.''
A local woman said: ''We can't get chicken here anymore. All of it was imported, frozen, from Europe.''
Still, even with the shipping business almost at a standstill, local diplomats report that a trickle of trucking freight still trundles up the road, though it is not clear how how much cargo is bound for elsewhere in Jordan and how much is to be slipped through the blockade.
While the shipping business has been sharply curtailed, the town's tourism business is in suspension. Because of the fear of war, the tourists who came here at the rate of 20,000 a month during the season last year have gone to other destinations.
''They don't come mostly because they are scared, scared there will be a war between America and Iraq, and Israel is so close by, too,'' said Habab al-Wahhab, manager of the largest restaurant in town, Ali Baba.
 
Tourism Dries Up
Most tourists came from Europe, and they choose Aqaba or the neighboring Israeli town of Eilat for the beaches, sunshine and warm weather. The season here runs from about Sept. 1 until the end of April.
Last September, Mr. Wahab said, ''you had to wait two hours to get a table here for lunch.'' Today, he had to turn on the lights in the restaurant's largest dining room when visitors requested a table.
''Last month, we had 14 waiters,'' he said. ''Now we've laid off all but 3.''
Six large resort hotels line the beach, Jordan's only waterfront. Two have already closed and laid off their staffs.
At one of those still open, the 152-room Alcazar, the owner, William Sawalha, sat by the empty swimming pool this afternoon. Asked how many rooms were filled during this week,the second of the tourist season, Mr. Sawalha's wife, Jill, thought for a moment and said, ''We have three guests.''
Her husband shook his head as he corrected her. ''No,'' he said. ''They checked out. We're empty.''

HEADLINE: Capital Gains Issue Blocks Budget Talks

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept 13

 BODY:
Under mounting pressure to conclude an agreement on cutting $50 billion from next year's Federal deficit, White House and Congressional budget negotiators remained at loggerheads today over the issue that has dogged them for the past four months: reducing the tax rate for capital gains.
Documents made available to reporters late today showed that the latest Republican proposal on taxes includes tax breaks for business, including oil and gas producers, as well as the capital gains tax reduction. These tax cuts would be offset by limits on the deductibility of state and local income taxes. Lawmakers assert such limits would disproportionately hurt states like New York and California, which rely heavily on their income taxes to finance a variety of programs. 
The Republican proposal also calls for increases in taxes on beer, wine, gasoline and other petroleum products, among other measures.
According to the Congress's bipartisan Joint Committee on Tax, the net effect of the Republican tax proposal would be tax increases for Americans with incomes under $50,000 while those with incomes above $50,000 would receive tax cuts. The committee said Americans with incomes over $200,000 a year would receive a tax cut totaling $7.4 billion in the first year.
The latest proposal by Democrats included a 20 percent surtax on the income taxes paid by people with incomes of more than $500,000 a year, The Associated Press reported. It would also double the taxes on beer and wine, as well as increasing the levy on distilled spirits. Also citing estimates by the Joint Committee on Tax, The Associated Press said the Democratic offer would lower by $4 billion the taxes paid by people with incomes below $20,000, while boosting them by $26.8 billion for everyone else.
But a senior Republican Congressional aide monitoring the talks said last night that news accounts appeared to be describing a Republican plan offered several days ago and complained that ''its release and distortion'' was a serious breach of ''the good will that had been developed in the sessions.''
With some elements of the deficit package at least tentatively agreed to, participants in the talks said the central issue dividing the negotiators was the demand by Republicans for reducing the gains rate and insistence from Democrats that such a cut be accompanied by an increase in taxes for the wealthy.
 
'Republicans Didn't Bite'
Democrats have said they would drop their demand for a tax increase on upper income Americans if Republicans would forgo the capital gains cut, but as one participant put it, ''the Republicans didn't bite.''
During today's session, John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, argued that all the deficit reduction measures contemplated by negotiators would be a drag an already weak economy and that cutting the capital gains tax rate would provide a stimulus by generating new jobs and investment.
Democrats countered that measures like higher excise taxes on gasoline and cuts in Federal benefit programs would strike hardest at low- and middle-income Americans and that the wealthy should bear their fair share with an increase in income taxes.
Congressional tax experts have said that 90 percent of the direct benefits from reducing the capital gains tax would go to the wealthiest 10 percent of taxpayers.
The negotiators, who have been meeting at Andrews Air Force Base just outside Washington, are now in their seventh day of bargaining. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington told reporters that it was quite possible that the talks could go through the weekend.
Delays in reaching an agreement have already taken a toll at the Capitol, where Congressional leaders have been forced to postpone votes on major legislation to accommodate the negotiators' schedules. As word of some spending cuts under consideration, particularly those involving the Medicare program, filtered back to Capitol Hill, lawmakers in both parties began to protest.
Mr. Foley got a taste of the backlash this morning in a stormy meeting with leading members who told him they would not accept some premium increases and benefit reductions being contemplated for the health program for the elderly.
With Republicans arguing equally vehemently that the elderly should not bear what Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, called ''an unconscionable burden,'' there were signs that the budget negotiators were considering a change.
 
Backing Off on Medicare
Officials involved with the talks said the negotiators had scaled back their proposals for cuts in Medicare and were rapidly backing away from a suggestion to link benefits to income levels.
Democrats who are not participating in the talks said they had been assured by their colleagues on the negotiating team that no proposals for a link between benefits and income had been accepted. But officials said Democrats have agreed to support a lifting of the wage cap for payroll taxes that finance a portion of the program.
A payroll tax of 1.45 percent on the first $51,300 of workers' income pays for Medicare coverage of the cost of hospital stays. The other part of Medicare, which covers doctors' fees, is financed partly by premiums paid by beneficiaries, but the bulk of the costs are paid by the Federal Government.
Some 33 million elderly and disabled Americans are covered by the Mediare program, which is expected to cost the Federal Government an estimated $105 billion this year.
The negotiators are aiming for a package that would cut $500 billion from the Federal deficit over five years, but they have yet to agree on a new and tougher rules for enforcing the future year spending cuts. Republicans have insisted that even if a compromise was reached on all spending cuts and tax increases in the package, no deal would be final without stiff enforcement rules.

HEADLINE: Iran's Dangerous Game

 BODY:
Beneath its spiritual leader's call for a holy war against a permanent American presence in the Persian Gulf, Iran is playing power politics, crude and simple. Eyeing the conflict between Iraq and the United States, Teheran's two bitterest enemies, Iranian leaders may be wishing for it to last as long as possible. To give the beleaguered Saddam Hussein more breathing space, Iranians have signaled they will provide food and medicine to Iraq. There are also reports, as yet unacknowledged, that Teheran has agreed to accept Iraqi oil. What should the United States do? 
The best response now is to keep cool, especially since Western influence is quite limited anyway. A minor breach of the sanctions, as Iran seems to have in mind, will be undesirable but not decisive. If Teheran's hope is to auction off its favors between Washington and Baghdad, Washington should not bid, since to do so will only increase Iran's leverage. Better to stand aside and let the ayatollahs risk the opprobrium and other inconveniences their opportunism may invite both at home and abroad.
So far Iran has taken only one overt step, the restoration of diplomatic ties with Iraq. However, oil company executives maintain that Teheran has agreed to exchange 200,000 barrels of Iraqi oil a day for food and medicine. Both acts would violate U.N. sanctions. But provided they stay at the reported scale, not much harm to the embargo is likely.
If Iran and Iraq were to link their pipelines and expand the oil flow, that would open a very serious breach in the sanctions. But the danger is not immediate. Building pipeline connections takes time, and in any case Iran has not indicated an intent to wreck the embargo altogether.
Iran's goals are probably more limited. It still seeks Iraq's ouster from Kuwait. The Ayatollah Khamenei's call for a holy war seems directed against a permanent American presence in the gulf, not the present deployment.
A violation of the embargo on a larger scale would put at risk Iran's hope of European help in its reconstruction. Even though Iran is now less dependent on Western favor, with the doubling in the price of oil and its victorious peace with Iraq, the ayatollahs might still hesitate to burn their bridges by giving all-out support to Saddam Hussein. Such a policy also might be hard to explain at home, since 500,000 Iranians perished in Ayatollah Khomeini's drive to overthrow the Iraqi leader.
Iran has considerable ability to prolong the crisis with small, covert breaches of the embargo. But its leaders must recognize they are playing with fire. The longer the crisis lasts, the more room for miscalculation and catastrophe.
The ayatollahs certainly savor the thought of Saddam Hussein being crushed by American troops and the United States embroiled with the Arab world. But surely they must realize that any short-term gains in helping Iraq will destroy what seemed to be their long-term policy of re-establishing ties with the West.

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
The Damascus Road

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis; Anthony Lewis's column will now appear on Mondays and Fridays.

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
Secretary of State Baker's visit to Damascus points to an important political byproduct of the Persian Gulf crisis. Syria is emerging from isolation to become a key diplomatic player in the region.
President Hafez al-Assad may even be ready to play a central role in a new effort to settle the Arab-Israeli conflict. Top Israeli officials think that is a real possibility. 
Given recent history, all that may seem eye-rubbing stuff. Syria has stayed aloof from the various initiatives for Arab-Israeli peace, for years taking a rejectionist line. It excoriated President Sadat for making peace with Israel and dismissed as useless the Bush Administration's effort to get talks going between Israel and Palestinians.
Moreover, President Assad has been ruthless in putting down dissent at home, and the United States has linked his Government to terrorism. A recent State Department report said that Syria's record had improved but that it still gave ''support and safe haven to a number of groups'' engaging in terrorist acts.
For those reasons, no one can operate on the assumption that Mr. Assad is a nice chap. But he is a realist. That is the point that Israelis make in discussing him. Ambitious though he is, for his country and himself, he is not a megalomaniac like Saddam Hussein. He has an acute sense of limits.
Events have been pressing in on Syria over the last two years. The end of the Iran-Iraq war gave new freedom of action to Syria's principal enemy, Saddam Hussein. The end of the cold war brought sharp cuts in Soviet military aid to Syria. The economy deteriorated.
Even before Iraq gobbled up Kuwait, President Assad had begun adjusting to those realities. Concluding that he could not look to the Soviet Union for help in the event of war and that isolation was dangerous, he made overtures to the United States and Europe. And he repaired relations with Egypt.
When Iraq attacked Kuwait, Mr. Assad supported American diplomacy and joined the military effort against Iraq. Syria now has 4,000 soldiers in Saudi Arabia and is sending an armored division with up to 10,000 more. Its contingent will be the largest after the American force.
If the world forces Iraq out of Kuwait, Syria could emerge with Egypt and Saudi Arabia as leading powers in Arab diplomacy. The U.S. Ambassador in Damascus, Edward P. Djerijian, told The Boston Globe this week that such a combination ''is potentially very promising for regional conflict resolution, and especially for the Arab-Israeli peace process.''
Prime Minister Shamir of Israel actually invited President Assad to talk peace this spring. The move got nowhere, dismissed as a gesture to distract attention from Mr. Shamir's sabotaging of the American plan for Israeli-Palestinian talks. But if the Persian Gulf crisis is resolved satisfactorily, the idea of finding a road to peace through Damascus will be taken seriously.
One thing that commends that possibility to Israel is the belief that President Assad keeps his bargains. He has meticulously carried out the 1974 disengagement agreement with Israel. There have been no incidents on the Golan Heights.
Would Syria really agree to talk with Israel after all these years of refusing? The answer, as best we can tell, is that President Assad would go with Jordanians and Palestinians to an ''international conference'' or to something under U.S.-Soviet sponsorship - and under such an umbrella would negotiate bilateral issues with Israel. He wants the umbrella to avoid the unilateralism charge that he made against Sadat.
Israel has been negative about an international conference. But the collaboration between Moscow and Washington on the Persian Gulf has made the idea of jointly sponsored peace talks acceptable to the Bush Administration and very possibly to Israel.
The premise of any talks would have to be United Nations Resolution 242: territory for peace. President Sadat went to Jerusalem only after getting a fair assurance that Israel would withdraw from Sinai in exchange for real peace. For President Assad, the issue is the Golan Heights.
Israel has said that security requires retaining the Golan Heights. But in the new world of Soviet-American entente, it is possible to imagine other security arrangements.
These are all visions. With a reasonable outcome in the gulf, they could become the real challenges of diplomacy.

HEADLINE: Housing Lag In Newark: After a Year, One House

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, Sept. 13

 BODY:
In the year since Newark agreed to stop tearing down its dilapidated public housing projects until new housing could be found, none of the city's battered high-rise projects have been razed, but only one new subsidized town house has been built.
Under a court settlement signed Sept. 14, 1989, the Newark Housing Authority was also supposed to renovate some 1,600 apartments in the high-rise projects for families. The authority has renovated more than 1,300, but tenants say the work is shoddy, amounting to little more than cosmetics that cover but do not correct serious defects like broken windows, rusted bathtubs and barely functioning heating systems.
''They have been doing some things, but we need windows and we need heat before the winter'' said Pearl Cole, president of the tenants coaltion at Building 1 of Hayes Homes, a pockmarked complex of 10 high-rise buildings and barren grounds in the Central Ward, not far from Newark's downtown business district. 
 
Unforeseen Problems Cited
Housing Authority officials said they had tried to comply with the letter and the spirit of the court agreement. But they said unforseen problems, like finding that some building sites were contaminated, had hindered their efforts.
So far the authority has built a single modular town house in the Central Ward, but it is considered only a demonstration model of the type of low-rise housing that will go up to replace the high-rises.
Until the settlement was reached last year, Newark pursued one of the largest public housing demolition programs in the country. The city planned to tear down 39 of 46 high-rise buildings that, without exception, had deteriorated so badly they were considered unlivable. More than 30,000 people lived in Newark's public housing projects.
In 1987 the Housing Authority dynamited four buildings containing 800 apartments and was prepared to take down others when a coalition of housing advocates and public housing tenants challenged the plans in court.
With the assistance of a state mediator, the Housing Authority and the housing groups reached a settlement under which the demolition plans were scaled back to 1,506 apartments in 11 buildings, including all eight high-rises at the Christopher Columbus Homes alongside Route 280 in the North Ward.
The authority is bound to replace each of the 1,506 lost apartments with new ones, and it can proceed in stages only after construction of the replacements has begun.
The acting general counsel to the Housing Authority, Frank L. Armour, said a contract for the first 100 new town houses could be signed next month, with construction starting early next year. The authority is soliciting bids for 512 more.
Mr. Armour said that the construction could have begun sooner but that there were problems getting clear title to the land involved. In at least one instance, he said, the land was found to be contaminated with hazardous wastes that must be removed before work on the new houses can begin.
Mr. Armour said demolition of the Columbus projects could start before the end of this year.
 
Minimum Requirements Met
At a news conference Wednesday at the site where the four buildings were torn down in 1987, Victor DeLuca, a leader of the Newark Coalition for Low-Income Housing, faulted the Housing Authority for the construction delays. He said that by continuing to seek demolition contracts, the authority was not showing good faith.
But he said also that the renovation work seemed to have gone as promised and that an independent monitor had been hired to oversee the authority's work.
''So far they have met the minimum requirements of the settlement,'' Mr. DeLuca said.
But several tenants of Hayes Homes called the renovations slipshod. Laura Foster, a tenant for 15 years, said that her renovated apartment had new kitchen cabinets and new linoleum tile floors but that her stove barely worked, her bathtub was rusted and her toilet flushed only if she put her hand in the tank and pulled the flapper.
 
Expectations Not Met
''It wasn't nowhere near what they said it was going to be,'' she said.
In Geraldine Smith's apartment, also at Hayes Homes, the tub had a splotch of rust the size of a dinner plate, one of the old casement windows was broken, the bathroom door was missing its knob, and one side of the new kitchen cabinets was splashed with paint.
''I know they can't make the apartments like new, unless they tear them down and start over,'' Miss Smith said, ''but we expected better than this.''
Housing Authority officials said any problems would be corrected.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Geraldine Smith, who lives at the Hayes Homes project in Newark, pointing out a rust spot in her bathtub (Frank C. Dougherty for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Cuomo Says 'No New Taxes' Is Not an 'Absolute' Promise

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BROCTON, N.Y., Sept. 13

 BODY:
Issuing one of the more elastic versions of a ''no new taxes'' pledge, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today that he planned to hold the line on tax increases next year but could not make an ''absolute'' promise because of uncertainty over the state's economy and the Federal budget.
Mr. Cuomo, who is running for re-election on a record that includes two successive years of some of the largest tax increases in the state's history, said that the increase in next year's budget would be well below the inflation rate because neither he nor the Legislature could find the revenues necessary to keep pace with inflation.
''We know that we can't do taxes, nor would we want to,'' Mr. Cuomo told reporters who traveled with him on a state airplane to Chautauqua County in the southwest corner of New York, where the Governor spoke to graduating inmates at a shock-incarceration prison. But asked if this was a formal pledge, Mr. Cuomo said, ''No,'' explaining that certain factors that went into the budget were beyond his control. 
His comments were immediately ridiculed by the Republicans who control the State Senate and by his Republican opponent, Pierre A. Rinfret, who described Mr. Cuomo as ''the biggest con artist in the state.''
 
Rinfret Sees Ploy
Mr. Rinfret, who has already promised both a spending freeze and no new taxes if he wins in November, suggested that Mr. Cuomo's comments were simply a ploy to distract attention from the tax increases over which he has already presided.
Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders, struggling against projected budget gaps that widened as the year wore on, agreed to about $1.8 billion in new tax revenues this spring, including deferral of a planned $400 million cut in personal-income taxes. That came on top of $1 billion in new taxes they adopted to close similar gaps in 1989.
With no political gain evident in dwelling on those accomplishments, Mr. Cuomo appeared intent today on trying to shift the focus to the upcoming budget struggle, which will not actually play out until well after the November election. He has already gone on the attack against the Republican leader of the Senate, Ralph J. Marino, whom he has berated for declining to guarantee that he will approve a budget no larger than whatever Mr. Cuomo proposes.
In a shouting match that ultimately proved wearying to even the most enthusiastic observers of the Capitol, Mr. Cuomo and Senate Republicans spent weeks this spring arguing over who was a bigger spender.
The Republicans noted that the $49.8 billion budget they finally approved was $1.5 billion less than what Mr. Cuomo had proposed in January, while Mr. Cuomo countered by saying that he wound up pushing to spend hundreds of millions of dollars less than the final budget once the state's worsening budget problems became clear.
Mr. Marino's spokesman, John McArdle, put little stock in Mr. Cuomo's comments today, saying that the Governor's ''actions will speak louder than his words.''
''We'll believe it when we see it,'' Mr. McArdle added.
The Governor's demi-pledge of no new taxes was echoed by the Speaker of the Democratic-controlled Assembly, Mel Miller, who said that he could not envision his house approving yet another package of new taxes.
 
Tough Approach to Budget
''I think we've run out of the bag of tricks,'' Mr. Miller, a Brooklyn Democrat, said. ''The whole approach to the budget is going to have to be a very tough one, and I think we're going to be in the unenviable position of saying we can't deal with all of the priorities out there.''
Mr. Cuomo declined to identify areas where he planned to cut spending, but he did rule put proposing any reductions in money for criminal justice or for drug or AIDS treatment.
Here in Brocton, near the shore of Lake Erie, Mr. Cuomo attended a graduation ceremony at the Lakeview Shock Incarceration Center for 43 inmates who chose a six-month paramilitary course as an alternative to a longer sentence in a traditional prison. Most inmates were originally sentenced on drug-related charges.
Strolling along prison pathways with names like Shock Street and Discipline Drive, and stopping in classrooms and a cafeteria, the Governor asked several prisoners about the program and whether it had been effective. These drew repeated answers of ''Sir, Yes Sir,'' and occasionally, elaboration, though much of Mr. Cuomo's direct dialogue with inmates was held out of earshot of reporters.
Later, as wives, parents and children of the graduating inmates looked on, Mr. Cuomo praised them for putting themselves through the boot camp-like rigors of the program and told them that with their graduation they would ''regain the freedom to make your own choices.''
Now, he added, ''you're good enough and tough enough to go all the way -the right way.''

HEADLINE: Ideas Compete On Paying For Officers

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Now that Mayor David N. Dinkins has pledged to hire unspecified thousands of additional police officers, he is besieged with conflicting advice from his own aides, the New York City Council, state officials, citizens groups and business leaders on how to pay for them.
The one point of agreement is that it will not be easy to find the $300 million to $500 million each year that the Mayor has said such an undertaking could cost, particularly when the city is facing a projected budget gap of at least $1 billion next year and must reach new labor settlements with its unionized workers, probably within weeks.
Those giving the Mayor advice have used the demand for new officers as a lever to lift their own pet causes, whether freezing labor costs for other workers, protecting homeowners from property-tax increases or saving the regional economy from anticompetitive, counterproductive taxes that would drive people and business profits away.
 
Tax Surcharges to Telethons
''There's no easy option,'' said Ronald K. Shelp, president of the New York City Partnership and the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry, which has called a special meeting in about 10 days to discuss the issue. ''You're trying to balance the fact that you've already had some substantial tax increases in the city and state this year and the impact that has on economic development, with the clear need to address public safety.'' 
''The bottom line,'' Mr. Shelp said in a phone interview yesterday, ''is going to have to be some combination of revenue increases, but also cost-cutting and reallocation of priorities.''
There is no shortage of proposals. The City Council has suggested a package that would rely heavily on a 25-cent surcharge on state lottery tickets sold in New York City. Others have proposed surcharges on property taxes, income taxes or the cigarette tax to pay for law enforcement.
One leading law-enforcement figure, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said yesterday that some business executives had even approached him about having private corporations contribute enough money to the city to finance the hiring of 100 officers.
Others, including the comedian Jackie Mason, have suggested sponsoring telethons to raise money for the police.
But Allen J. Proctor, executive director of the State Financial Control Board, which monitors the city's finances, said that with city tax revenues falling below projections and costs rising, hiring more officers would mean hard choices on ''what we're not going to do.''
''We should begin the dialogue about what to cut now,'' Mr. Proctor said. ''Otherwise we could be in the undesirable position of adding cops now, and a year from now, without agreement on priorities, we'll be canceling the cop classes we added.''
If hiring thousands of new officers led to layoffs or wage deferrals for other city workers, Mr. Dinkins would be in the position of rewarding a union that did not support him politically while hurting unions that did. He won office with heavy support from most municipal unions but lost the endorsement of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association to Edward I. Koch in the Democratic primary. The police union was neutral in the general election.
Spending hundreds of millions of dollars for the police could also tie the Mayor's hands on other initiatives.
 
An Investment Strategy
The current city budget includes only enough money for an average 1.5 percent annual wage increase for city workers, a number the unions have said is unacceptable. Senior city officials have suggested financing wage increases of something like 5 percent by diversifying union pension fund investments to earn higher rates of return. That could allow the city to reduce its annual contributions to the funds and use the difference for raises.
But now, one senior city official said, some business executives have suggested using such money to hire officers instead. That might be difficult, since changing the investment policy requires support from the union representatives on the pension boards, and they might not support the idea if their workers did not benefit.
On the surface, it may seem hard to understand how a city with a budget of $28 billion and a work force of a quarter million people cannot easily afford to hire police officers. Each new officer would cost about $60,000 a year, including benefits. But additional money would be needed to hire more prosecutors, Legal Aid lawyers, jail guards and probation officers to handle the additional arrests the officers would make.
Further, about 70 cents of each dollar in city revenues is effectively spoken for by the time it arrives. That money handles the existing workload and pay for employees either mandated by law or considered essential, like social service caseworkers and jail guards. And with the city economy stagnant, achieving growth in one city program is difficult without trims in another.
''We're essentially in the position of a very large business that has its revenues dropping and is unable to raise prices,'' said Felix G. Rohatyn, the investment banker and chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation. He argues that significant increases in the size of the municipal workforce and in its salaries in recent years did not lead to marked improvements in services. But better management, he suggests, might wring out improvements, even if new police hiring forced cuts in the workforce elsewhere.
Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a group financed by businesses, said the city should not hire more officers until it deploys the ones it has more efficiently, in more one-officer patrol cars, for example. But if more officers are to be hired, he said, ''I personally think the best way to do it is an across-the-board increase in the property tax.''
''It's a very straightforward approach that says if it works, then homeowners have an opportunity to praise the politicians who wanted to add the cops,'' Mr. Horton said. ''And if it doesn't work, then homeowners have an opportunity to vote them out of office.''

HEADLINE: Labor Talks Are Stalled As Post Deadline Nears

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
The New York Post's negotiations with its three principal unions were stalled yesterday, and only hours remain before the deadline set by the paper's owner for closing it.
The Post has been losing money for years and its owner, Peter S. Kalikow, has said tomorrow's issue will be the last unless the paper's nine unions agree to $18.5 million in wage and benefit concessions by 8 P.M. today.
Union leaders say the paper's smaller unions are prepared to make the concessions demanded by Mr. Kalikow. Late yesterday Mr. Kalikow's representatives reached a settlement with New York Mailers Union Local 6, whose president is George E. McDonald, who is president of the Allied Printing Trades Council, the newspaper unions' umbrella organization. 
But representatives of the drivers, pressmen and the Newspaper Guild, which includes news and advertising employees, have been unable to reach an agreement with Mr. Kalikow's representatives.
 
Cuomo Is Asked for Help
''I think it's touch and go,'' said Theodore W. Kheel, a lawyer who acts as an unpaid adviser to the unions.
Mr. Kalikow said he had asked Gov. Mario M. Cuomo for help in resolving the crisis, and the Governor has dispatched his Labor Commissioner, Thomas F. Hartnett, to participate in the negotiations today.
But Mr. Kalikow has declined union proposals that would result in savings smaller than he has demanded and has remained firm in his insistence that he must have concessions that will allow The Post to break even. ''It's not a victory to go from losing $20 million to losing $5 million,'' Mr. Kalikow said.
Union leaders and Mr. Kalikow were united yesterday in strongly criticizing The New York Times and The Daily News for what both described as damaging interference in the negotiations.
On Tuesday, The News asserted that its contract with the Guild would entitle the paper to any concessions given The Post under what is known in labor parlance as a ''me too'' clause.
On Wednesday, The Times said it ''would seek to gain concessions as well'' to the extent that they were related to the same adverse economic conditions affecting The Post and The News. The Times has declined to say whether it considers its contracts to have a me-too provision but has made a point not to cite such a provision as the basis for seeking concessions.
Union leaders have said that neither paper would be legally entitled to concessions granted The Post. They note that The News terminated its contract with the Guild earlier this year as a negotiating tactic and that The Times has contracts with no me-too provision that do not expire until 1993.
Mr. McDonald and Mr. Kheel said yesterday that even raising the question has made union leaders far more reluctant to grant the Post concessions.
Mr. Kheel said that the papers appeared to have acted in concert to scuttle the negotiations and that there might be criminal and civil liabilities if they were found to have violated the Sherman Antitrust Act.
Mr. Kalikow issued a statement saying The Times and The News were trying to ''ride on the back'' of The Post's negotiations and may have broken the law by interfering in them.
A spokesman for The News, John T. Sloan, said such ''false and irresponsible charges'' were the result of the ''stress of current labor negotiations.''
A Times spokesman, William Adler, said The Times would not respond to the assertions.
Even without such complications, The Post's negotiations are proving difficult for the three principal unions, each of which has a somewhat different problem.
 
A Stumbling Block
For the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union of New York, which represents The Post's drivers, the fundamental stumbling block is the magnitude of Mr. Kalikow's demands. The Post has asked for $8.5 million in concessions from the drivers' union, or almost half of the total.
The Guild, which has been asked for $5 million, has objected to The Post's insistence that almost all the concessions take the form of lower wages and longer hours rather than layoffs, which would be based on seniority. The Post has said that to operate effectively, it must retain the younger and lower-paid employees whom a layoff would remove, but Guild leaders have said the deep wage cut for everyone is unacceptable. The Guild broke off talks yesterday, but, at Mr. McDonald's behest, agreed to resume negotiations today.
The New York Newspaper Printing Pressmen's Union Local 2, representing the pressmen at The Post, has been asked for $2.7 million in concessions and is concerned particularly that cuts in manning for the paper's presses might damage the union's future negotiating posture with The Times and The News, which have similar presses.
