HEADLINE: U.S. Says It May Tap Oil Reserve

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
The Bush Administration, confronting what it believes will be the maximum risk of an oil shortage over the next several weeks, seemed less confident today that it could avoid drawing on the nation's strategic reserve, a move that would almost certainly push prices down as the additional oil is auctioned into the market.
''We view the current market as relatively stable, but uncertain about future supply,'' Energy Secretary James D. Watkins told a Senate panel today. ''Should the situation warrant it, we are prepared to implement a coordinated drawdown of the more than one billion barrels in strategic stocks'' held by the United States and other members of the International Energy Agency, a Paris-based group whose member countries have agreed to build stocks and to share oil in a crisis.
 
Calculating the Shortage
Secretary Watkins insisted that the United States would not move unilaterally without the agreement of the agency, which is scheduled to meet in two weeks. The world will have an average of 3.5 million barrels of oil a day less this month than it had before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August, which could produce a shortage. 
But as more and more countries increase their production, this shortfall is expected to contract to less than two million barrels a day in October and to a million or less by March.
Secretary Watkins cut short his appearance before the Senate Energy Committee to fly to Boston to announce the introduction of a public service campaign before a convention of the National Association of Broadcasters, which is being enlisted to promote it. [Page D6.] Setting the Conditions The Administration has repeatedly contended that the reserve should be tapped only in the case of shortages, resisting the pleas of those including Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, who believe it should be tapped immediately to counter price increases. The reserve, the filling of which stopped shortly after the invasion of Kuwait to keep as much supply as possible in the markets, cannot be turned on and off, officials said.
At the same time, the Administration reaffirmed its opposition to a bill that would force auto makers to raise fuel economy in their fleets by an additional 40 percent over the decade to 40.2 miles a gallon by 2001.
Supporters of that measure, promoted by Senator Richard H. Bryan, a Nevada Democrat, complained that this showed that the Bush Administration had yet to get serious about energy conservation despite the urgency implicit in the President's address on the Persian Gulf situation Tuesday night.
''I am clearly disappointed,'' said William A. Nitze, president of the Alliance to Save Energy, a coalition of business, government, environmental and consumer leaders seeking improved energy efficiency. He referred both to the continued opposition to the Bryan bill and to a package of conservation and supply-enhancing measures disclosed by the Administration today.
The new measures, supplementing a list put forward in mid-August, consist mainly of hortatory items to reduce demand and raise supplies.
The initiatives are aimed at saving an estimated 530,000 barrels a day by the end of 1991. They include saving an estimated 120,000 barrels from ''better driving techniques;'' 90,000 from car-pooling, 75,000 from more efficient utility and industrial use and 50,000 each from proper tire inflation, use of lower octane gasoline and compliance with speed limits. Previously, the Administration had projected savings of 100,000 if tires were inflated to manufacturer's specification.
The supply-enhancing measures, totaling a hoped-for 607,000 barrels a day by the end of this year include 200,000 barrels a day of additional production from Alaska and various other efforts involving the extraction of heavy oil, state authorizations for faster pumping of wells, fuel switching, gasohol use and tax incentives.
Another critic, Edwin S. Rothschild, director of energy policy for Citizen Action, complained that the Administration is giving ''lip service to conservation but policy initiatives to production.''
In testimony today, Deputy Energy Secretary W. Henson Moore said he was not sure what Mr. Bush meant Tuesday night in asking Congress to pass conservation measures since those announced by the Administration today required no such approval from Congress.
After the Administration abandoned its longstanding opposition to expanding the reserve, House and Senate conferees agreed late Wednesday - and the House passed overwhelmingly today - a bill to expand the reserve to a billion barrels. The reserve, currently authorized to rise to 750 million barrels, now holds 590 million barrels at a half-dozen sites along the Gulf Coast in Louisiana and Texas.
Mr. Moore said the Administration's opposition to expansion had become politically futile but that it had not changed its view that a larger reserve would not provide enough additional security to be worth its cost.
 
Refined Products Added
The bill increasing the reserve also requires that 10 percent of the reserve, now confined to crude oil, consist of refined products like gasoline.
This reflected doubts, shared by the Administration, about the industry's ability to process crude that might be drawn from the existing reserve, much of which is high-sulfur ''sour'' Mexican oil, which few refineries can handle. Moreover, much of the new crude coming on line to replace Iraqi and Kuwait oil is of relatively low quality. ''We are very concerned about the ability of refiners to continue operating at near maximum capacity for an extended period,'' Mr. Watkins said today.
Yet another provision of the bill authorizes the Administration to conduct a major test of the existing reserve, drawing up to five million barrels to make sure the reserve can be tapped smoothly at high rates for sustained periods.
The Administration called today's list of initiatives, most of which have been informally discussed before, ''medium-term'' measures that can be put in place pending its much-heralded 18-month effort to fashion a long-term national energy strategy to be completed this winter.
 
Use of Ethanol Ordered
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -All Agriculture Department employees have been ordered to use ethanol blends of gasoline in Government vehicles, Agriculture Secretary Clayton K. Yeutter said today, if the fuels are available at prices competitive with those of regular unleaded gasoline. In many locations, including Washington, they are scarce.
''Ethanol is produced from American corn and other agricultural products, and that's good for American farmers,'' Mr. Yeutter said, adding that it also helps reduce dependence on foreign oil.

HEADLINE: The Mileage Debate;
Some Say a Tax Increase Is Cheaper Than Putting Cars on a Stricter Diet

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
With the Middle East conflict pushing gasoline prices higher, the Senate is debating today a bill that would require a 40 percent improvement during the next decade in the fuel efficiency of cars sold in America. To its supporters, the issue is simple: if oil from the Persian Gulf is worth the risk of American lives, auto makers can surely be asked to produce cars that consume as little oil as possible.
But to many economists, the bill by Senator Richard H. Bryan, a Nevada Democrat, is dismaying evidence of Washington's predilection for regulation over market-based incentives. The energy-security benefits of higher mileage standards might be worth the price, they concede. But they insist there is an easier, cheaper and safer alternative - taxing fuel at the pump. 
This is not the first time Congress has wrestled with the issue of squeezing more mileage out of America's auto fleet. Fuel economy standards, imposed in 1975 after the Arab oil embargo, required auto makers to double the average fuel efficiency of their cars to 27.5 miles a gallon by 1985.
 
Fulfilling a Demand
In the early years, said Robert W. Crandall, an economist at the Brookings Institution, Congress was pushing on an open door: higher gasoline prices led consumers to demand the fuel-efficient cars called for by the corporate average fuel efficiency, or CAFE, standards.
But by the mid-1980's, Mr. Crandall notes, the real cost of gasoline had fallen to pre-embargo levels and the efficiency standard began to bind. A variety of measures were used to improve mileage, ranging from increasing the use of smaller turbocharged engines to decreasing aerodynamic drag. But much of the improvement, which saved billions of gallons of gasoline in the last few years, came from downsizing - selling smaller, lighter cars. By the 1989 model year, he estimates, manufacturers were meeting the requirements by paring the average weight of their cars by about 500 pounds.
Today, proponents of the Bryan bill argue that improved mileage would not burden drivers. Marc Ledbetter, an analyst for the nonprofit American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy, said the higher sticker prices of comfortable, peppy cars that attain 40 miles a gallon would be more than offset by the savings on $1.30-a-gallon gasoline.
But that judgment, based on estimates of how much mileage could be improved with off-the-shelf technology, and at what cost, is vehemently disputed by every auto maker.
Carmine Defiglio, an expert at the Energy Department, ends up somewhere in the middle. At current gasoline prices, he says, a technological fix would pay for itself in savings on gasoline up to the 34-miles-a-gallon level.
Charles Lave, an economist at the University of California at Irvine, suggests that the auto makers might do better. ''CAFE standards,'' he said, ''increase the incentive to look for new cost-effective technologies.''
 
Paying Extra
But the prospect for such ''technology-forcing'' is a matter of speculation. It is likely that consumers would have to pay extra for fuel efficiency or accept smaller, less powerful cars.
Economists try to finesse judgments about how auto makers would meet fuel-efficiency requirements by extrapolating from the companies' past performance. Probably the most sophisticated such effort was made by Robert Leone of Boston University and Thomas Parkinson of the consulting firm of Putnam, Hayes & Bartlett. Their work was done with financing from auto importers, but it uses the same data and closely follows the reasoning of respected independent economists - notably Andrew Kleit of the Federal Trade Commission.
The Leone-Parkinson study concluded that a 40-mile-a-gallon standard would cost drivers about 15 cents for every gallon, even after accounting for the savings from using less fuel. The combined benefits of reduced dependence on imported energy and reduced pollution might indeed be worth 15 cents a gallon, Mr. Parkinson concedes. But the same savings in fuel, he argues, could be achieved at just one-fifth the cost by taxing gasoline.
 
Weighing the Factors
A gasoline tax would give all drivers an incentive to conserve fuel, he points out, while changes in the mileage standard would only change the fuel consumption of new cars. What is more, savings from higher mileage standards are partially self-canceling. For one thing, owners of more efficient cars tend to drive more because their cost per mile is less. For another, older cars that are less fuel efficient would remain in use longer because replacements are more expensive.
Yet another disadvantage of mileage standards, argue Mr. Crandall and John Graham, a researcher at the Harvard School of Public Health, is the probable deterioration in safety. Car makers, he points out, would, in part, adjust to higher standards by further downsizing. And smaller, lighter cars, even with comparable safety equipment, would inevitably be more dangerous. They estimate that CAFE-induced downsizing in the 1989 model cars will lead to an extra 2,220 to 3,900 highway fatalities and an extra 11,000 to 19,000 serious injuries.
Gasoline taxes would also tend to increase fatalities to the degree that consumers responded by driving smaller cars. But the impact on safety would certainly be far less because much of the fuel savings would come from changes in the use of older cars. ''If people drove less,'' points out John Meyer, an economist at Harvard's Kennedy School, ''they would probably die less.''
By the same token, a gasoline tax would reduce pollution more than a mileage standard that reduced gasoline consumption by the same amount. Tougher mileage standards would keep older, dirtier cars in use longer. And because the price of gasoline would be lower, the total miles driven by cars of every vintage would be greater.
But for all their apparent superiority in saving gasoline, conservation taxes are far harder to sell politically than tougher mileage standards. And to Mr. Crandall, the reasons seem obvious: politicans - and perhaps voters - prefer the ''hidden tax'' imposed by expensive regulation.
Is it better to take a wasteful route to gasoline savings than not to save gasoline at all? Some economists, including Mr. Crandall, would take a hard line. But Charles Lave believes that the best cannot be allowed to be an enemy of the good: ''For what it is worth,'' he said, ''I'm for CAFE.''

HEADLINE: Mexican Free Trade Pact Pushed

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
President Bush, acting more swiftly than expected, will ask Congress next week for authority to negotiate a comprehensive free trade agreement with Mexico, Administration officials said today. Though not the only reason, the Persian Gulf crisis was a factor in the decision, they said.
They also said Canada, already a free trade partner of the United States, was likely to participate, giving an accord hemispheric scope and clearing the way for common standards and trading rules in all three countries by the end of the century.
The integration of economies in North America would follow similar moves in Europe, as the European Community inches toward economic union. 
''Acting at this time is a way of telling Mexico that we're really serious,'' a senior Administration official said. In late August, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari asked the United States to open the talks.
 
Mexico's Oil Reserves
The Middle East crisis has focused the world's attention on global oil supplies. Mexico, with the eighth-largest reserves in the world, would be likely to attract more outside capital with a trade pact to help tap those reserves.
While the United States wants to work with Mexico on increasing oil production, another factor behind the speed-up, officials said, is a desire to accommodate President Salinas, who has seized on free trade to modernize the Mexican economy.
Mexico, which has already cut tariffs from 100 percent or more to less than 10 percent, sees an agreement with the United States attracting foreign capital that would spur modernization.
An economic basket case early in the last decade, Mexico, through deregulation and tax cuts as well as freer trade, has already reduced inflation and interest rates sharply and all but eliminated capital flight.
 
Cooperation in Energy
Bush Administration officials expect a trade agreement to intensify cooperation in the energy sector, for example, by increasing already robust sales of American oil equipment to Mexico.
One recent sign of cooperation was Mexico's pledge to lift overall oil exports by 100,000 barrels daily to help ease the current pressure on global supplies. Mexico exports about half of its 2.5 million barrels daily. The United States takes about 60 percent of the exports, Japan 15 percent and Europe most of the rest.
Far more controversial is the issue of American participation in Mexican oil and gas exploration, for 50 years the exclusive preserve of the state-owned Petroleos Mexicanos, or Pemex.
Because of political sensitivity about oil, many analysts consider it unlikely that international oil companies would be permitted to operate in Mexico.
''The political cost associated with accepting foreign investment in the upstream sector of the petroleum industry would be substantial,'' said Rafael G. Quijano, director of the Petroleum Finance Corporation, a Washington energy consulting group.
Still Mr. Quijano, a former Pemex executive, suggested that ways might be found to get around the issue.
 
Foreign Investment Fund
One possible solution, he said, is a financial mechanism, like a trust fund established by foreign investors in a Mexican bank with which Mexican operators would carry out drilling activities.
Decisions on such issues are not likely to be taken before the Salinas Government tests its strength at the polls in 1991 midterm elections.
The Presidents of the United States and Mexico agreed in June to go forward with the pact, but the expectation then was that little progress would be made before yearend.
George W. Grayson, a Mexican oil expert at William and Mary College in Williamsburg, Va., said that Mexico was producing about at capacity and that because of rising domestic use from its rapid industrialization, it badly needed to find new oil.
Immigration is another sensitive issue. Mexico had wanted to take up freer movement of workers as well as goods. Washington had warned that this could doom the talks and won its point. Immigration will not be negotiated, American officials said.
 
Immigration Issues
But immigration could be affected indirectly. If a free trade pact leads to a more prosperous Mexico, there will be less pressure on workers to come north.
Organized labor in the United States has already signaled its strong opposition to a free trade pact with Mexico. But most industry groups, seeing a large potential for exports, have come out in favor.
''Mexico is a wonderful potential market,'' said Colleen S. Morton, director of the United States Council of the Mexico-United States Business Committee. The council represents key American business groups.
If, as expected, Canada joins the talks, in return for greater access to Mexico, Canada would have to be willing to offer Mexico the same tariff cuts and privileged access to Canada as the United States offers.
The Administration's request to Congress starts a clock in which Congress has 60 legislative days, or at least four months, to determine whether such an agreement would be in the United States' interest.
If Congress gives its assent, which is considered likely, negotiations will probably continue until 1993, officials said. It took about 18 months for Canada and the United States to negotiate a free trade pact in the late 1980's. Though still controversial in Canada, that pact has been so successful that the two nations agreed recently to accelerate scheduled tariff cuts.
Mexico is the third-largest American trading partner after Canada and Japan. In 1989 two-way trade exceeded $51 billion. The United States is Mexico's primary export market.

HEADLINE: Early-Month Vehicle Sales Up by 2.5%

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 13

 BODY:
Large rebates on many models drew buyers and lifted car sales above the trend for the year, as sales of domestically produced cars and light trucks increased 2.5 percent in early September over relatively weak sales a year ago. But sales of light trucks fell, a sign to some analysts that higher gasoline prices were beginning to take their toll.
Car sales increased 6.7 percent over last year's levels, a larger gain than many analysts had forecast. 
On a seasonally adjusted basis, cars sold at an annual rate of 7.1 million, compared with 6.8 million in the period last year. Since January, cars have been selling at about a 6.6 million rate.
 
Not a 'Frothy Market'
''People are just buying up the remaining 1990 models, knowing that the manufacturers are offering big rebates on them and expecting higher prices on new 1991 models,'' said Maryann N. Keller, an analyst with Furman Selz in New York. ''We're not talking about a frothy market.''
Dealers said rebates had lifted showroom traffic. ''The sales comparisons are against a weak year-ago period,'' observed Tom Webb, chief economist of the National Automobile Dealers Association, ''but even so, I would say they look mighty good.''
Light-truck sales declined 4.4 percent in early September. Some analysts suggested that a sales slide that began in August indicates that consumers are beginning to shift away from less fuel-efficient pickups, mini-vans and four-wheel-drive vehicles.
''Trucks are this generation's gas guzzlers,'' Ms. Keller said, ''and I think we are seeing the effects now of higher gasoline prices and a weaker economy.''
The sales gains in early September were not shared by all 10 makers of vehicles in the United States. The General Motors Corporation reported an increase of 6.4 in car sales, to 70,697 units. But its light-truck sales fell 13.8 percent, to 33,655. The Chrysler Corporation continued to struggle, posting sales declines of 15.9 percent in cars, to 15,984, and 17 percent in light trucks, to 12,755, including Jeeps and mini-vans.
The Ford Motor Company sold 36,817 cars, unchanged from a year ago, despite a 13.9 percent increase in sales of its Escort subcompact, which has sold poorly since its introduction in April. The No. 2 auto maker posted strong sales of its light trucks, which increased 10.2 percent, led by the Explorer, a four-wheel-drive vehicle that has caught on quickly.
Among the Japanese auto makers, the Honda Motor Company reported its car sales increased 89.1 percent, to 10,234 units, while the Toyota Motor Corporation's car sales rose 70.9 percent, to 3,277 units. Honda manufactures cars in Marysville, Ohio, and Toyota operates plants in Fremont, Calif. and Georgetown, Ky.
Over all, the Big Three lost ground in early September, as their share of the United States car market fell to 87.7 percent, from 92.8 percent a year ago. The Japanese transplants picked up more than 5 points of market share, growing to 12.3 percent of the domestic market for cars, compared with 7.2 percent in the period last year.
With labor contracts between the auto makers and their American and Canadian workers due to expire at midnight Friday, many dealers have taken precautions against a possible strike by building their inventories. Dealers who sell vehicles made by G.M., the strike target of the United Automobile Workers, increased their inventories to an average 73-day supply at the end of August, compared with a 58-day supply a year ago. Dealers of vehicles made by Ford, the strike target of the Canadian Automobile Workers, have raised their inventories to a 68-day supply, compared with a 63-day supply a year ago.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Turkey's Stake In Mideast Crisis

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

DATELINE: ANTALYA, Turkey

 BODY:
IN the midst of the Middle Eastern crisis, Turkey is struggling to maintain its strong support for the United States and the United Nations in their opposition to Iraq's aggression against Kuwait. But the Turkish President, Turgut Ozal, is under heavy pressure from other politicians and Turkish military commanders not to send troops to the Persian Gulf. The Turks are building up their forces along their border with Iraq.
Mr. Ozal has staked his presidency on his country's rapid economic development - which is threatened by the crisis. This year, Turkey's real rate of economic growth is expected to reach a record high of 10.04 percent, according to the forecasts of the State Institute of Statistics. 
Addressing the United Nations Development Conference here, President Ozal said the key element in sustained economic growth is the ''free interplay of market forces.'' He described the drastic measures Turkey had taken to ''transform an inward-looking economy into one which was to integrate with international markets.''
Historically, Mr. Ozal said, the main obstacle to Turkey's economic growth had been a shortage of foreign exchange. To overcome that, his Government took measures to stimulate private savings and adopted a liberal system to encourage foreign capital, aiming at ''export-led'' growth. Turkey has applied for membership in the European Community, but is being kept waiting by Germany and other countries that are loath to open their doors more widely to Turkish immigration.
The crisis in the gulf and the United Nations embargo against Iraqi oil, which Turkey has helped to enforce by shutting down the pipeline that carries Iraqi oil to its Mediterranean port of Yumurtalik, are putting renewed pressure on Turkey's inflation and balance of payments, which had moved into surplus and given Turkey $11 billion in foreign exchange reserves, its highest level ever.
So Turkey is seeking sizable financial assistance from the United States, Saudi Arabia and other countries to help it sustain the embargo against Iraq. Mesuf Yilmaz, a member of President Ozal's Motherland Party, who is expected to be Turkey's next Prime Minister, said in an interview that so far the cost of Turkey's ''quick and courageous decision to back the United States' stand'' had cost about $4 billion. He broke this figure down into four elements: $300 million in lost income from closing the pipeline; $1 billion for lost exports to Iraq; $500 million in lost transit trade through Turkey, and $2 billion from higher oil prices.
In addition, he said, payments had been suspended by Iraq on nearly $1 billion due on Turkish exports to Iraq, which were to be paid for by oil, together with $2 billion to Turkish construction companies on contracts for building the Vecma Dam near the Turkish border with Iraq.
Turkey is torn between its desire to improve its economic relations with the West as well as with the Arab countries. Mr. Yilmaz said Turkey's foreign policy was guided by the principle enunciated in the 1920's by Kemal Ataturk, the founder of modern Turkey: ''Peace at home, peace abroad.'' That doctrine has led, he added, to Turkey's pursuit of ''a rather cautious foreign policy.''
Until 1965, Mr. Yilmaz said, ''our historical ties with the Arab countries were largely ignored, and became very distant.'' He added, ''But after the clash between Turks and Greeks over Cyprus, Turkey felt the obligation to improve its relations with the Arab countries; we became a member of the Islamic Conference.''
However, he said, in recent years, in its conflict with Bulgaria over the Turkish minority in that country, and its disputes with Greece, ''we did not get the support of the Arabs we expected and found this disappointing, and very recently we have faced conflict with Iraq and Syria over river water claims affected by the Ataturk Dam.''
Yet there is no consensus in Turkey about sending troops to the gulf. Far from it. Although Parliament has recently voted certain war powers to the President, Turkish politicians insist these are intended to be a deterrent to Iraqi aggression, not measures for war.
Mr. Yilmaz said: ''I have shared the opinion of President Ozal that Turkey should follow a more active policy to secure peace in its region, but have also considered it as my duty to warn the Government about the risks Turkey may be dealt. I don't think sending troops to the region will be meaningful.'' Turkish military leaders have also sought to restrain the President from sending troops to the gulf.
The present Minister of Foreign Affairs, Ali Bozer, said in an interview that he saw no big differences over Turkey's role. He named the main principles on which Turkey's policy is based: ''Be together with the West; Iraqi aggression has to be canceled; territorial integrity has to be restored in the region of Kuwait; territorial aggression has to be restored; apply United Nations resolutions without any exceptions, and avoid war.'' All these principles, he said, should be applied, but the main one is to maintain solidarity with the West.
That is the message President Ozal will be taking to President Bush when he visits Washington later this month. Political goals are reinforced by economic interests.

HEADLINE: Price of Oil Rises Amid Nervousness

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Persistent nervousness over the Middle East crisis and its effect on energy supplies pushed oil prices slightly higher yesterday.
Many investors hovered at the sidelines, unsure how long the standoff could last and unwilling to take on big positions amid such uncertainty, analysts said.
''It's really a market that people are afraid of,'' said Tom Bentz, director of trading for United Energy Inc. 
Crude oil for October delivery on the New York Mercantile Exchange rose 10 cents, to $31.07 a barrel, after swinging in a 60-cent range. That contract is now just 86 cents below its highest level since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.
 
A High for London Contract
In London, October futures for the world benchmark Brent blend reached a record contract high of $31.25 a barrel on the International Petroleum Exchange. The exchange said it was the highest price since the contract began selling in 1988.
The nervous tone of the world's crude oil markets was underpinned by a steady stream of ominous statements about the Middle East crisis.
Iraq accused the United States of seeking an excuse to attack it and said it would hold President Bush responsible for any strike. And Washington has informed Baghdad that it knows pro-Iraqi terrorist groups are preparing to attack United States and allied targets, the Iraqi press agency reported.
''As time goes on, it seems more and more people think the only solution is some type of military action,'' said Craig Whitley, futures analyst at Booner & Moore in Houston. A crude oil price of ''$32 or $33 is not out of the question,'' he said.
Traders said they disbelieved Teheran's pledge that it would not break an economic embargo against Baghdad by swapping food and medicine for Iraqi oil.
Washington said there was no evidence that Iran or Romania had broken the embargo, but oil traders remained skeptical.
 
'I Wouldn't Count on Iran'
''I wouldn't count on Iran to abide by any United Nations embargo at all,'' one oil broker said.
Contracts for petroleum products were mixed as market players unraveled spreads, selling gasoline and buying heating oil, traders said.
The unleaded gasoline contract for October delivery fell 0.48 cent, to 93.36 cents a gallon.
Traders said gasoline prices were also under pressure from Wednesday's Energy Department inventory data, which showed stocks rose by 1.8 million barrels in the week to Sept. 7. The American Petroleum Institute said Tuesday that gasoline inventories rose by 650,000 barrels.
Heating oil for delivery next month rose 0.89 cent, to 83.48 cents a gallon, on supply concerns ahead of winter, traders said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Narrowly Mixed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in generally sluggish trading yesterday, despite a big drop in the value of the dollar, and interest rates for longer maturities rose slightly.
Dealers reported that a spurt of trading took place late in the morning, when reports of testimony before Congress by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, began to flash across news tickers and trading screens.
Mr. Greenspan's remarks, which included the suggestion that the Fed would react to a credible budget agreement by easing monetary policy, were seen as a mild positive for the credit markets. But the weakness in the dollar, a move spurred in large part by the Fed chairman's comments, prevented note and bond prices from moving much. 
''The big trade of the day was the dollar,'' one bond trader said. ''Treasuries have pretty much been back and forth.''
 
Foreign Accounts Unload
Prices moved higher immediately after Mr. Greenspan's comments. But market participants said that foreign accounts soon began to unload some positions, wiping out the earlier gains.
In addition to the dollar's weakness, analysts said auto sales for the first 10 days of September, which were reported yesterday, were disconcertingly strong. The Big Three manufacturers reported sales of around 7.1 million units at a seasonally adjusted annual rate, a pace that does not suggest economic weakness.
''With the uncertainty in the Middle East and the rise in gasoline prices, a lot of people would have expected to see consumers move to the sidelines, yet you are not seeing that,'' said William V. Sullivan, Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds.
Although the potential for a surprise always exists, analysts do not expect August reports due to be released this morning on the Producer Price Index and retail sales to shake interest rates out of the narrow trading range they have occupied since late August.
 
Braced for a Big Jump
Because of the sharp rise in oil prices, market participants are already braced for a big jump in the producer price figures. But a big rise in the index excluding food and energy prices, the so-called core inflation rate, would not be welcomed. Retail sales figures for last month are likely to be quite soft.
Bond traders said they did not expect anything conclusive from these reports. The market is focused on the Middle East and Federal budget negotiations, they said.
By late yesterday, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent bonds were offered at a price of 97 30/32, down 2/32, to yield 8.94 percent, compared with 8.93 percent late Wednesday. Since late August yields on the benchmark issue have oscillated in a tight range of 9 percent and 8.90 percent.
Among Treasury note issues, the 8 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 5/8 in late trading, down 2/ 32, to yield 8.80 percent. Meanwhile, the 8 1/2 percent seven-year notes were offered at 99 2/32, unchanged on the day, to yield 8.68 percent. And the 8 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 7/32, up 1/32, to yield 7.99 percent.
 
Short-Term Rates
Short-term Treasury bill rates eased slightly.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.34 percent, down one basis point, or one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bills fell by two basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.26 percent.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, the financially battered City of Philadelphia said yesterday that it had postponed a planned $375 million short-term note offering.
The offering, which will be used to help avert the city's looming insolvency, had to be pulled when a bank in Switzerland abruptly withdrew its plan late Wednesday to guarantee $50 million worth of the issue.
Investment bankers said it would take about a week before a reconstituted offering would be priced.
The largest offering in the municipal bond market yesterday was a competitive offering of $198 million worth of serial bonds from the State of Louisiana.
A bid from a group led by Lehman Brothers won the issue.
The securities, which carry maturities from 1991 to 2010, were reoffered to investors at yields from 6.10 percent in 1991 to 7.60 percent in 2010.
The Federal Reserve Board also reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose strongly during the week ended Aug. 27, but the report had no impact on prices in the credit markets.
